reviews.review: Interesting attraction "behind the Iron Curtain". This was an interesting attraction just as a hospital inside the Castle Hill. But for an American, the 1956 Revolution information against the Soviet Union, and the atomic bomb information later, was captivating. The courage and determination of first, doctors and nurses, and later wounded soldiers, medical personnel, with 600 patients in a place meant for 40--beyond belief. Told from those who were on the other side of the "Iron Curtain." The guides were outstanding, available in English. Highly recommend.

Incredible. A fascinating insight to the history of Budapest. The suffering and ingenuity of its people is certainly highlighted here. Tour was reasonably priced and reduced with a Budapest Card. Guide was very informative but could've done with headsets as if your were at the back of the group it was a little hard to hear.

Great and a little unusual. Good hour long tour that can be a bit unsettling sometimes when you see the conditions they would have had to put up with. One of my favourite attractions when I was in Budapest.

Unique and Impressive. We enjoyed the tour of this WW2 air raid hospital and later nuclear bunker built in the caves under Buda Hill. Budapest is a beautiful place but it's good to remember it's extremely difficult history during the world wars and cold war. This is a moving exhibition, very well done. It's fascinating that a functioning hospital could be built here, and we had to admire the doctors and nurses who understood how critical they were, and lived full time inside the facility to serve the wounded.

Thought provoking & insightful. This is a great look into Hungary's past, I would recommend on a rainy or cold day. They do tours in English. It's certainly eye opening to the experiences of war time & the treatment of soldiers, what they went through, how they coped in such small spaces etc. I'm claustrophobic & managed ok!

Unique and Unusual. This is a unique and unusual attraction that describes the history of a WW2 air raid hospital and Soviet-era air raid bunker. I also found it interesting because there is an accurate mock up of my company's radio equipment in one of the dioramas describing more recent events. This is recommended for history buffs, but not for the squeamish.
very interesting. after a short introductory film we were shown around this 1km complex and its importance up to being a museum the exhibits are good and the guide was excellent well worth a trip

Great rainy day activity to do in Prague when all museums closed (Mondays!). This was nicely organised and we had a well-spoken guide who negotiated a large group of us in tandem with another group and did this very well. It's a very interesting place with lots of WW1 & 2 plus Cold War history. Starts with a subtitled film (note to self: sit in back row or against wall so can stand to see subtitles). Film starts dead on time so don't be late :)

Don't miss this attraction. We didn't really know what to expect but were really leased we visited. The tour was led by an English speaking guide who was excellent and explained everything very well. It was a part of Hungarian/Budapest history which was important and although a little difficult to find well worth the effort. DON'T MISS IT!

A Hidden Hospital. The Hospital in the Rocks is a must-visit for anybody in Budapest. Although it is difficult to locate (considering you have to find an elevator near to the Funicular and then walk up the road to find it), it is still worth locating this hidden gem. There are tours offered in various languages. Our tour guide was very enthusiastic about informing tourists about the role that the hospital played, not only in the war, but also how it has shaped treatment now. The Hospital also shows how parts of the Buda Castle area still have parts of the hospital built into the architecture, such as the vents in the street. Learn about the machine that played a part in Evita and the (largely unmentioned) story of how Hungarian soldiers saved an American soldier's life.

Very interesting visit!. My boyfriend and I visited in October and both really enjoyed the tour. It was so interesting and not what I was expecting! Our tour guide was excellent (I think his name was Fernandez - forgive me if I'm wrong) and he was clearly very knowledgeable on the history of Budapest. I would highly recommend visiting the Hospital in The Rock. Also a tip for potential visitors - if you visit the Our Lady Of Buda Church first, you will receive a 10% discount voucher for the Hospital in The Rock.

Fascinating. We arrived with minutes to spare before a tour in English set off. The tour took about an hour, and was fascinating. Well worth the visit, but not for the claustrophobic, as it is all underground.

Interesting Tour, if your looking for something different. This is a tour of a hospital that is actually tunnels built into the rock under Buda Castle in the 1930's. Both soldiers and civilians were treated in this hospital. In the 1950's the hospital was turned into a shelter in case of nuclear attack. Interest and inexpensive tour.

Definitely worth a visit. This was not a cheap tour by Hungarian Standards but we felt it was definitely worth the money. There was 4 of us with 2 on their early 20s and 2 in our late 40s and we enjoyed it equally. I would not recommend it to very young children but anyone with teenagers I am sure they would like it. The tours about an hour and Milan our tour guide was fabulous. He makes it interesting,thought provoking and he was clearly passionate about his job. You tour round the tunnels of what was the hospital and it's brought to life with the equipment and lifelike waxworks and the history behind it and Hungary during and after the war is emotional but Interesting. Don't do this tour if you are claustrophobic as the whole tour is underground in the tunnels.The only minus is they show you a film for 10 minutes before the tour and the subtitles in English are too low in the screen to read unless you are in the front row so you don't know what the film is about Just put the subtitles at the top of the screen and the whole experience would have been an excellent but apart from that it is certainly worth doing. It's in the beautiful castle district which if you don't want to pay the price to get up there by the funicular or walk the rather steep steps then the number 16 bus goes and the stop is just opposite the funicular

Very interesting. We had a tour of the Hospital in the Rock and were not disappointed. Our guide was informative and spoke very good English. Before you go round the attraction there is a short film giving you the history of the hospital. The tour itself takes around 50 minutes and the exhibits and tour itself is great. Well worth a visit if you are at the Castle area follow the signs and take the lift.

Very interesting and informative, really great place to visit. This is so much better than the Labyrinth complex (which isn't worth going to)! Our tour guide was excellent, exhibitions are eye-opening and it really gives an idea of what it was like to be there during the second world war.
Unique place. The hospital is a unique place to visit, you really get to understand the history and the tragedy of the war in a surreal place.

Hospital in the Rock. Our tour of the Hospital in the Rock was quite informative and interesting. From its inception prior to WWII until it became a nuclear bunker when Hungary was under Soviet control. Exhibits in the actual hospital were very graphic and showed the actual equipment and crowded conditions experienced during WWII and Hungarian uprising against Soviet rule. The guide was very informed and stressed the conditions during both conflicts, citing people who had worked there that he was able to talk with when they came back to see the place after it was opened to the public.

Very interesting history. We found this site very interesting and the story behind it's creation, the tour was about an hour, we took the English tour, our guide spoke very good english and certaily had answers for all the question, I recommend this tour

Overpriced creepy mannequins. We had high expectations, so we ended up dissapointed. The ticket is expensive (around 14 Euros) for what it really is: tunnels with veeery heavy air leading to small rooms full of creepy mannequins.

If There Is Only One Thing You Do. We absolutely loved Budapest, it is a great city, but if there is absolutely one thing you have to do it is the Hospital in the Rock. It is a surreal experience. You really get to understand the pain that the city went through under the Nazis and Communists. It is an amazing experience. And added bonus our 11 year old son loved it.

Very Unusual and Interesting. This is a good side experience beyond all the hustle of Budapest. It is good value and interesting content. Recommend if you are looking for a bit of 'filler' in your day.
Brilliant museum. well worth the money. Such a good museum, so interesting & our tour guide Petra spoke great English & was very knowledgeable. Lots to see. We loved it
most interesting place. the guide was interesting knew what he was on about and made the tour that much more plesurable also taught me a few things i didnt know about the war
Worth a visit. If you are a health care professional you will love this place! Just wish the tour was longer but definitly worth it!

Very interesting tour and excellent guide. This was a wonderful insight into Buda's history during world war 2. We went on the 5 O'clock tour and the air was getting stale and my friends and I found it quite difficult to keep alert. However the tour lasted an hour and this was really long enough. It is an unusual place, very graphic, some of the displays are not for the faint hearted. I don't think it is suitable for young children or any one who is squeamish. However very well done on the whole and really educational.

interesting museum of WWII hospital and Soviet era nuclear bunker. A friend recommended this museum, and since our daughter is a physician, we thought it would be interesting for all of us to see under what conditions doctors worked during WWII. Originally built to take in 60 patients, the hospital often had over 200, so that the beds were pushed together, and patients placed virtually on top of each other. And although the hospital had running water, occasionally the water supply was cut when bombs destroyed the municipal supply. We could only imagine how rapidly sanitation deteriorated. After WWII, the hospital was converted to a civil defense shelter in case of nuclear attack, with washing stations and special ventilation. The radiation symbols and gas masks were grim reminders of the nuclear threat during the 1950's and 1960's. On the way out of the bunker, there is a long hallway with drawings by survivors of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki bombs. Our guide spoke very good English, and as a result of the popularity of this museum, there is an English tour every hour.

Amazing museum. Although I am claustrophobic I went into the hill to see this museum. It starts with a short video outlining the history and building and then you are off through the corridors with a guide. They have tours in several languages. Call ahead to check what time for each language. She explained each room and section from xray, treatment, operating room, dormitories, power,and water. Very interesting from all aspects. Worth an hour.
Amazing. This relic of the wars and Hungary's past is both interesting and disturbing. A fascinating way to spend an hour . If you are over 70 you get in free.

Amazing History. This one of those places you know nothing about and after the visit you shake your head in amazement. This hospital was set up in the limestone caves under the Buda castle hill by the Red Cross during World War II where the injured from Hungary, Germany and Russia were treated. It later became a nuclear bunker. Highly recommend a tour of this place.
Interesting museum. Definitely worth a visit. Our guide was knowledgeable and obviously enjoyed her job. The tour was approx 1 hour duration. The wax work models were incredible

Highly unusual and well worth visiting!. I would have given the hospital an 'excellent' except for the fact that the tour was very rushed and visitors have no time to stop and look or even read the signs on the walls. This is not only a fascinating piece of Budapest's history but, for anyone interested in the war time practise of medicine, these caves, transformed into a working hospital with operation theatres and wards, acted as a safe haven for soldiers and civilians, both Hungary's enemies and friends. However, the guides are trained to say politically correct things, acceptable to everyone, which will not cause offence to eventual losers of the war. For more accurate information, buy Gàbor Tatai's 'Short History of the Hospital in the Rocks', on sale in the shop, which will give you a truer account of what actually happened inside and outside the hospital, not only during WWII but through the Hungarian Revolution of 1956. A sobering read!

Fascinating insight into WW2/Cold War Budapest. I visited in 2015 and returned this October, with my 19 yr-old son (EU citizens under 26 or over 62 get 50% reduction). The entrance and gift shop have been renovated/decorated and some displays updated, with more emphasis now on the post-Hiroshima/Cold War era, and further extensions ongoing. Admission is via guided tour only (in Hungarian, English or German: other languages on request), which takes about an hour, including an introductory film (in Hungarian with English subtitles, which could be improved). Our guide, Anna, spoke very good English, as did all the staff, and was very well briefed. There is much walking through tunnels, with some steps at one point. The environment - 20 metres underground - is not for claustrophobics and some displays may not suit young children. Photography is prohibited, as it makes groups difficult to manage (I can see the argument), but this does help focus visitors' attention on what is a fascinating insight into the events of World War 2 and the subsequent Communist era. If you want an idea of what the citizens of Budapest experienced during the war, this is a very good starting point.

Good but limited. The visit is conducted by guided tour but tô be honest I would rather have made my own way. Relatively small site, possibly charging above its weight but open Mondays when little else is.

interesting piece of history. Don't be fooled by the simple facade. It's quite interesting how this hospital was built, and hats off to the architects, engineers and builders. Had an interesting display of medical items that were used in the 40's-50's. A great place to visit if you are a history buff, especially if you work in the medical sciences.
100% reccomend. Definately worth paying for, it is eye opening, educational and interesting. Brilliant tour guides as well.

Very informative! . My husband and I visited the hospital in the rock on a recent visit to Budapest. The tour lasts just an hour, no photos allowed which was disappointing, but is very informative not only about the hospital itself but about the history of Hungary in general. Our guide (originally from Sardinia) was very helpful. Would definitely recommend!

Fascinating and unusual . A unusual place to visit.The hospital is will preserved and has been configured with manikins to show how the hospital was operating before and during WWII. A real insight into what happens in a besieged city.The nuclear bunker is so well preserved that the air filtration system is still in use today.I would recommend a visit

Mind Blowing. I loved this museum. Very interesting and informative. Excellent guide (in English). Group size was perfect. Bless the medical staff that worked here during the war and revolution. A real eye opener. A tour is mandatory for safety reasons so make sure you know what time they run tours. I'm not sure what languages are available.I would definitely avoid this if you have claustrophobia. The tour lasts an hour, the ceilings are low and the air is a little heavy. You can't take pictures but frankly that is a breath of fresh air!! I expect there are various pics on the website.

Unique and Interesting. This is a very unique museum and full of great things to learn. Although the wax figures are a bit creepy, the displays are generally very interesting. It is also a great way to cool off on a hot day while also experiencing Budapest.
Fascinating. My husband is a scientist and loved this. Unfortunately, could not take photos, but he thought the the history here was really fascinating.

Unusual place to visit.. I don't regret visiting this place. The english speaking guide carried out his duties in an excellent manner. I have a feeling that the armband worn by one of the officials in a ward was worn upside down since the first stripe was green not red.

Very Good Experience. We really loved this museum. The staff was great and our tour guide, Fernindad, was knowledgeable and passionate without being obnoxious. It is a very worthwhile experience and one of the better glimpses we had while here of some aspects of life under communist rule. It was really interesting to hear their responses to the nuclear threat from the West.

Great to see WWII and Communist history site. I will admit since being in healthcare that I was intrigued to go see this to begin with. It far and away exceeded my expectations. The hospital looks largely like it did when it was being used. I particularly enjoyed all the displays of medical equipment and mock ups of the rooms. The mechanicals are all still present. There is also a great history display chronicaling the hospitals use and why it got started. Overall awesome place to visit!
Great History Under the Beaten Path. The tour of the Hospital is well organized and informative. Guides are young and enthusiastic. Some folks may find the displays and history disturbing.

Completely Fascinating!. While on the Buda side of Pest, I would highly recommend including the Hospital in the Rock in your itinerary. It was fascinating and highly informative. The tour guide was excellent - so knowledgable and passionate. This was one of the more eye-opening and interesting museums we visited during our 8 day stay in Budapest. Must see!

This vivid, haunting walk back into history likely will be among your strongest Budapest memories. We've never experienced a museum as realistic and impressionable as this must-see attraction.History comes alive where it was made in the 1940s-60s, enhanced by original beds, surgical tables, stretchers, medical instruments and -- especially -- lifelike wax figures of patients, physicians, nurses and soldiers at full size and in original clothes.More than once, we turned a corner and though a unifromed wax figure mannequin was a person.World War II and the era of superpower nuclear threats is far from, abstract in the former medieval caves under Castle Hill. It's a bit like being in a "Twilight Zone" episode or sci-fi film, without the fiction.Don't hesitate to go/ It stays with you long after returning home.

Excellent hospital museum from the 2nd World War to the nuclear agewith an informative guide. We toured the complex in a small group with an English speaking guide. The tour started with a visit the Hospital which was first used during the siege of Budapest in the 2nd World War then in the 1956 uprising and was ready to be used again if there was a nuclear attack during the Cold War. All the original equipment is still in place including medical instruments/equipment with wax figures representing patients/doctors/nurses etc. The tour continued into the communictions area and the extension created during the Cold War all the service equipment is still in place. The Guide was very informative and we were certainly pleased we took the tour which took about an hour

Interesting but smelly. The hospital is interesting, especially for those in the medical field or interested in history. The air is close underground and I found the experience to be a bit smelly and stuffy to the point that I wish I had not made the visit.

Interesting and Eerie. The hospital in the rock was brilliant. The guided tour was informative and gave you time to look at all the rooms and equipment that was left in them. Walking around this place and learning about its history is a strange experience, you can imagine how horrendous it could have been. I would recommend this to anyone visiting Budapest.

Great mystery spot. Very interesting with great props from the era. The only complaint was that they rushed thru all of the rooms. Many of us in medicine would have liked to stay a bit and look at the equipment and techniques of a bygone era. Also they forbid pictures...no idea why.Otherwise is a great tour. Highly recommended. Also ate at Miros (just above) while we waited and had a really. Ice meal

Brilliant. Stumbled across this and so glad we did.we went on the tour which lasted an hour, very interesting and the girl who was the guide was lovely and very informative.well worth a visit.I could honestly say one, if not the best highlight of my visit to Budapest

Moving and thought provoking . This was an excellent museum. There is a compulsory one hour tour included in the entrance fee. The tour guide was extremely knowledgeable and led us through the different areas of the museum, explaining the fascinating history of this hidden hospital which later became a nuclear bunker. I found the whole experience very moving and would thoroughly recommend it.
Worth going to.. This is an amazing place to visit. It surpassed my expectations and worth the entry fee and guide. A must see experience and a real one.

Highlight of the trip. I had wanted to see the Hospital in the Rock since previously hearing about it on a previous visit to Budapest. Thankfully I was not disappointed.The place is a great historical reference to a very traumatic time in the history of the city and also helps to demonstrate the resilience of the population of the city over the years.Both the hospital and Nuclear Bunker parts of the tour were fascinating and well worth the time.I would definitely make this a one to do for anyone interested in the history of Budapest.
Only did a drive-by. Only did a drive-by while on a tike with our guide giving us the history of hospital. Had injured my leg and didn't want to do much walking

Interesting, but hurried.. We both enjoyed this visit, probably for different reasons. I'm a nurse working in an operating theatre and my husband is very interested in communications and 'army type' stuff. Our guide spoke excellent English and we could hear him clearly, but it was very rushed. There was no time to look at the exhibits or posters etc. after he had finished speaking, he just moved on to the next room. This was a shame as there was so much to see. At one point we did get left behind, but there was at least two other tours going on and their guides could point us in the right direction.Perhaps a room or two with some of the exhibits on display where you can look at your leisure after your tour?I think it's worth a visit, but you do need more time. It feels a bit like going through a museum on a timer.

HIDDEN HISTORY. This is a faithful preservation of wartime history with excellent commentary. The entrance can be accessed from the street above by lift, stairs or taxi. There is little publicity so we were grateful for word-of-mouth recommendation. There are so many places of interest in the Buda Castle District that a full day should be reserved to explore, on foot.

Very interesting. The hospital can only be visited with a tour guide in a group. The tours start every 30 minutes, and cost was around 4000 forint or 15 euros. There were discounts at least for people under 26. The tour starts with a short back and white film about the history of the hospital during WWII and the Hungarian revolution in 1956. After that the tour guide takes you and the group around the tunnels, telling about each room, some of the equipment and people that used to work there. The wax figurines made the place feel alive, and some of the rooms were quite shoking when combined with the descriptions told by the guide. Some rooms that used to be full of hospital beads were transformed into small museums showing WWII and modern Hungarian army gear etc. I would have liked to see those rooms in their original use instead, but I guess the reason behind this was to avoid too much repetition with showing too many rooms with the same purpose and layout. There is also a nuclear bunker built on the side of the hospital, and the tour takes you through both. I usually don't like being forced to walk with a group and to listen to a guide, but in this case it was much more interesting to listen to the guide than it would have been just to read the same info. Very interesting tour, and I would definitely recommend this to any people interested in history of modern medicine, WWII era and the Cold War's nuclear threat.

unusual piece of ww2/cold war history. A very interesting guide tour (you can only visit with a guided tour). the guide was very easy to understand, this hospital/ fall out bunker is very well preserved and the use of manaquins in the hospital only and to the experience, we went on a hot day so the temperature of 17 degrees inside was welcome (is about this temp all year round)
Nice Tour. Our son was really excited about this tour, but we all ended up liking it. Interesting way to immerse yourself in history by seeing it almost life-like.

Our favorite attraction in Budapest!. My husband and I added the Hospital in the Rock Nuclear Bunker Museum to our itinerary later in the trip because we happened to have time. It ended up being our favorite attraction. While a little difficult to find, it's definitely worth the visit. Our tour guide was very friendly and knowledgeable and did a great job telling the story and helping us to really relive the history. This site is well preserved and beautifully done. Don't miss this highlight in Budapest.

Fascinating piece of history. I had cut out an article about the Hospital in the Rock prior to leaving on our trip. We were walking around in the Castle area when we came across the sign advertising it and so immediately went there. A really fascinating insight into the terrible toll of WW2 with hospital equipment and lifelike wax figures depicting patients, nurses and doctors. These narrow caves were turned into a hospital for 60 people but more than 200 found safety here. We also found the nuclear bunker part very interesting with its reminder of the Cold War.

Great look at history. We enjoyed the education of this facility from the world war to current day. It spoke of the ingenuity and advancement of patient treatment from triage to healing. There were no details spared in the value of the facility and its greatness to its lack of essentials and how the staff and patients overcame in spite of deficit. It was a horrible time and the tour guide showed the humanity of the effort. I have been impressed with the advancement of modern conveniences since being here. The knowledge of the use of electricity since the 1800's and how this was a necessity to use of this hospital is truly impressive. A very well worth tour.

WW2 and Cold War Experience. Brilliant attraction. Historically very interesting and great for visiting when raining as we did. Guide gave an excellent presentation of the history of the hospital which was also used as a nuclear bunker in the Cold War.
This was surprising good. An unusual place with interesting history and use from WW2 thru the Cold War. It served well as a hospital, then a nuclear bunker.

Educational. You start your tour with a short educational film. Then you split up into your groups and the tour guide explains the rules. They lead you through the maze of the hospital explaining the significance and history of each room.
Best guide in Budapest . A very interesting museum and our guide Timea was so enthusiastic it really made the whole experience great. Not for tall people!
So interesting!. Loved that they had the wax figures it made it seem so real. The tour guide was excellent and it was such a great story to hear.

Interesting museum. Please check the timing when the tours start because the visit are in groups. You watch a video at the beginning and then you can start the tour in the rock hospital. It is authentic and very believable while they tell you a lot of history. I have learned a lot from this visit and I recommend it to people who are interested in history.

Worth the visit.. Husband and I both went here while visiting Buda Castle. Overall the whole presentation was engaging and very interesting. Many of the props were the original ones used way back when it was an active hospital/bunker. Our presenter was fantastic and knowledgeable. The tour lasts an hour long and you learn how the hospital operated during the war and Seige of Budapest. Also we thought it was pretty cool you could buy a real gas mask at the gift shop for a steal compared to local army surplus stores in North America so we bought one as a cool souvenir and possible halloween costume prop.

Worth it!. We nearly didn't stay when we learned you could only visit as part of a group and that the tour lasted an hour. So glad that we stayed. It was so interesting that the hour just sped by. We had a great guide who spoke beautiful Englsih. There is so much to see, it was informative and fascinating.

Rip off. I think this was about $17/per person and I still have no idea what happened. We signed up for the English tour, but it starts with a 10 minute video in Hungarian. There are English subtitles at the bottom, but we were sitting in the 3rd row and couldn't read the through the people that were sitting in front of us. Maybe this would have given us the background information we desperately needed, but we never really had any idea what was going on in the tour. It was just a bunch of wax figures in rooms to us. But even if we had gotten something out of that video, I don't see how any of this would have been worth more that $5.....???

Mildly interesting. I've no complaints to the very helpful staff and our tour guide who was very informative and helpful- It's just that I didn't find any of the exhibits to be particularly interesting. It might just be me, though.

Good Time Capsule. The Hospital in the Rock Museum provides two good snapshots in time - the siege of Budapest and the Cold War period. To address some of the comments of other reviewers: the mannequins are not that bad at all, they provided scale and interest; the nuclear war discussion is a reasonable effort to address what was a primary threat to life on Earth and is still a lingering - though not discussed - issue; the guide had some good context to the helicopter and current battlefield MEDEVAC diorama; and a good explanation was given for why the raw cave network is not accessible. Our guide was very good and engaged. Another good feature of this site is its lengthy opening hours. The only thing holding me back from a higher rating was a sense, shared by some other reviewers, that the charge is a bit too high. I've toured huge Maginot Line Fortifications for less that the entry charge to this museum.

Historic hospital in the rock. We decided to visit the hospital instantaneously, we did not have to prebook tickets. Everything is kept I its original state including medicines, bandages cabinitery and wards. The tour was fascinating.

A different experience. Visit the inside of an underground bunker. There's mannequins set up and recreations of hospital wards and offices, all designed to give you an idea of how this place was once used. A few people on here have complained about things like the full size helicopter but I don't think the idea is to accurately recreate very aspect of this bunker. It's also designed to show you aspects of war and show how the casualties ended up down here. Some notes:- teachers get in free, just take some proof of ID and give them the name of the institute where you work. - they sell gas masks here and they are cheap (around £6 each - 2000ft)- no photos or videos are allowed. I'm not sure why, perhaps they think people might not visit if they can watch a tour online.

If you do not see this in Budapest where else you find anythig close on the World?. It as amazing experience from kids(my dougther at the age of 4!) up to 100+. A touch of geology, history back to Middle Ages through the Budapest battle till the crazy, paranoid communist regime -you will understand me during the visit! It was kept secret till 2001.

Interesting. Offers a student & senior discount. We found this hidden treasure in the Budapest Guide w/Budapest Card Catalogue. It is a hospital/underground nuclear bunker. The one hour tour takes you thru the whole facility. Excellent props and artifacts. Hard to believe this was still in operation in the fifties & sixties.
Excellent site. An interesting and unique piece of Budapest history and an informative tour. A cool refuge on a hot day. Well worth it

Very atmospheric. Great tour guide, with lots of interesting info. Tours are available in different languages. Its cool underground, so you might want to take a jacket although they do have some coats that you can borrow.

Cool, in both senses of the word. We did a group tour for kids/parents as part of our multi-day river cruise. Not only was HitR a pleasant place to be temperature-wise on a boiling hot summer day, but it was also very interesting and different from all the churches/castles/etc. (which were also terrific, but did tend to blend together in our minds after several days' worth!). Our guide was knowledgeable and spoke English well. Because it was a tour for families, she incorporated activities such as a trivia competition, letting the kids dress up in hospital garb and put bandages on each other, letting them turn the air raid crank, etc. As other reviewers have noted, we were told not to take photos in the facility itself. However, we were allowed to take photos of the kids still dressed up in hospital garb, in the gift shop just inside the entrance.Altogether memorable and also well located in the Castle District not too far from other stuff worth seeing, such as the Fisherman's Bastion overlook.

One from my bucket list !!. A must visit in Budapest ! Being a doctor I related to it and enjoyed it even more. Our English speaking guide was great with all the elaborate descriptions and stories about the place and all the history. With several human like figures and actual, well maintained instruments , it looks like a functional hospital. Authentic pieces from the wartime can be bought as souvenirs too ! No photography allowed unfortunately..
Practically Unique! . Yes, a little bit expensive at 4000 forints, but a very interesting, unique and informative tour of a relatively recent history.

History on a time capsule . No pictures are allowed. We were able to take the English tour.They have successfully captured the horror of war using mannequins & artifacts. A grim reminder of war. Worth going to though. Small facality designed for 60. But up to 200 at a time. A short taxi ride from downtown area.
Worth the visit. So fascinating! No pictures allowed, but it's really fascinating and one of the best tours we took. Really puts you in the right mindset of that era.

Very good tour!. You can't visit the place without a tour, what is a good thing. The story helps you so much more to understand the place.The price is a little bit high for a museum at Budapest (4000 HUF/person), but after the tour we thought that this was worth it.Some of the exhibitions were a little odd - why you would reassemble whole helicopter to bunker just to show how CPR has evolved?It is not allowed to take any pictures or video inside.

Interesting but Rushed. Visited on a Saturday and booked for an English guided tour. The guide was very knowledgable and her English was very good. However, the museum was very busy the group was probably too big which meant at times we were rushed past an exhibition with merely a glance. Fascinating Hungarian history and worth a visit.

Neat but not Amazing Tour. The tour was pretty neat to more or less see a time capsule from World War II and the Cold War era about a emergency triage hospital (and later nuclear bunker) within the hill of Budapest. Tour guide was great but tour material and dioramas lack some focus. The information was very cursory and by the end I was wondering why some things were included at all (why reassemble a helicopter within the bunker, have a modern-day combat triage scene or branch off quite a bit onto the nuclear bombs dropped on Japan? The tour definitely lost focus towards the end and I would have appreciated more detail on the primary subject at hand instead of going down all these tangents.

Worthwhile visit to a grim location. This popular underground museum, an emergency hospital before and during WWII, and later during the Cold War, is a grim reminder of the siege of Budapest in 1944 and of preparations for a nuclear war considered almost inevitable in the '50s. We had an excellent English-speaking tour guide, who led us through operating rooms, wards, ventilation and water treatment rooms, etc. that had their original equipment and a "staff" and "patients" of lifelike mannequins. The tunnels and displays made us think of what people had gone through in Budapest. The Hospital sends a strong message about the importance of peace.

Morbidly fascinating. Well worth it. Fascinating history and a horrifying glimpse into what happened during the siege of Budapest. Combine this with an elevator going up to the top of the hill with the Fisherman's Bastion, art galleries, nice restaurants, etc.

Loved the tour. Did a tour here. It was very interesting to learn about the situations that led to the opening of this hospital and how it functioned in the old days. The old medical instruments were pretty cool. Mannequins and layout of rooms really helped to tell the story. At the end, we also got to try sounding the alarm. Tour was short but informative. Loved it.

There are better programs for sure. Expensive, probably more interesting for foreigners with advanced health care. Unfortunatly, the place highly reminds me for an average clinic at the SU in 2016. It was good to have the tour finished.

Amazing, could imagine how it was. We had a lovely tour by Vera who was amazing and really good at keeping our interest. The wax figures and displays really give you a feel for what it was like! Must see
Very interesting. You can visit the museum with all the original objects from the hospital and the nuclear bunker, the ticket includes a guide who explains everything. The best museum in Budapest.

Interesting hidden place. To discover something about Budapests war history and to do something special, I can recommend this tour through the bunker. They rebuilt and were modelling the time when the hospital was running with life-big dolls with authentic material and clothes from that time. Price is ok, around 7€ and you have to do a tour, which is good but also a bummer because all the information in the museum is not readable in the time you "rush through" with your guide. For the introduction video, sit in the front, otherwise you can't read the subtitles:) Also I didn't know that you couldn't take pictures...All in all a good memory for myself and noone else I could share it with
Interesting . The guided tour was informative. They build a authentic museum. You can feel and hear the past ( not smell).

A Must See Piece of History. We are very glad to have visited the Hospital in the Rock, a very well preserved piece of Budapest's history. To experience a fully guided tour through its many labyrinths with its many restored displays of how it was a secret hospital during WWII, and a nuclear bunker during the 1956 uprising was truly amazing and well worth it.

Don't miss this excellent tour. We saw many sights during our Budapest visit but this was one of the best. There are no photos allowed so I'll have to just describe the experience. First there's a historical video to provide the context of what was going on in 1945 and 1958 when this hospital was used. Then we're offered coats since we're 8 meters deep in solid rock and it can be chilly without the body heat of patients and staff to warm it. They are 40s era coats; mine was a nurse's cape. I really didn't need it. All the equipment,surgical tools and furniture are original. They say the mannequins are wax but I saw them as eerily realistic. As we walked through the emergency treatment/triage area to the wards (populated with patients in the beds and nurses/doctors attending) it was possible to forget that it was just a tour. Our guide's English was excellent. His knowledge was broad, including the hospital and the subsequent Soviet use of the space as a nuclear bunker. It wasn't just a speech he's memorized and he asked for questions at each stop.We were silent as we left, reflecting how very lucky our country is to have never suffered an external attack on our city and homes.

Hidden gem. As I have been to Budapest before I was looking for something different. I found this advertised in a magazine in my hotel room. I thoroughly enjoyed it as I work on the health profession and I am also an avid historian. Especially war time and post war. This was right up my street and it did not disappoint. Very good guide with excellent language skills. A real treat. Glad i found it!

A definite must do when in Budapest. My husband visited this wonderful museum on our first day in Budapest and we are so glad we did it at the beginning of our long weekend as it opened our eyes to exactly what Budapest went through during the war. The tour guides are very informative and open to all questions. We did not realise just how much of Budapest was destroyed during the war and it really made us appreciate just how much had gone into rebuilding this city into the amazing place it is now.

Good way to escape the heat. Like catacombs in some towns, this bunker complex provides a good way to shelter from the mid-day heat. There is a wax figure exhibit inside which makes it easier to imagine what the place was like in earlier times. Entrance is only as part of groups, which seem to start frequently enough.

A jewel not to be missed. The other place that is a must visit in my books and just as interesting and not as crowded at the House of Terror is the Sziklas Korhas (Hospital in the Rock) which is located on the other side of the Danube , at the bottom of the Castle. It was a fully functioning hospital during the Nazi uprising and then turned into a Nuclear bunker after 1956 and the Cold War period.There are tours in English during the day that last an hour. Well worth the visit !

A must-see if you're in the Castle rock area. The tour into the old hospital was really fascinating, and definitely worth the 4000HUF price. But be aware that this tour is very popular and you might have to buy the ticket even 2 hours in advance.

Really unique site. Highlight of our trip to Budapest. Fascinating history of this underground hospital; excellent tour that starts with a video. When you're burnt-out on the churches and endless monuments in Budapest, this is THE place to visit!

Interesting . Realistic representation of the second world war and cold war in Budapest.No available tours in Italian and I suggest a high knowledge of English in order to fully understand and enjoy the visit ( the guide we met had a strong accent)

Secret Hospital. The Hospital in the rock is nowadays a museum. Inside you can find a old historical atomic bunker/shelter, which was build inside natural caves (Castle Hill) Only a small part of the Shelter is visible. The Hospital belongs to the Janos Korhaz which is not far away from the shelter. If necessary, within some hours the Shelter could be aktivated and some nurses and doctors were able to operate. Even the whole building is huge, it provided help only for a few patients. A guided tour needs about 45 minutes - and you can see how a hospital was operating during war or crisis. Most of the Rooms contain original stuff from 2nd WW. If you never saw a shelter maybe you should invest also the - from my point of view - high Entry price

Don't miss it!. We went there recommended by a friend and it was totally worth it. The visit lasts for an hour and it felt very short! It is very interesting and quite surprising, you have to see it for yourself! The guide was very nice and answered all our questions.
Walking tour. Excellent overview tour of the hospital used during the WW II and the sacrifices that people made during its use, very authentic displays. English speaking guide was excellent.
Very interesting and moving. I found it quite harrowing thinking about what the conditions must have been like in the hospital during times of conflict. Very good guide.
Fascinating. A one our tour with an excellent guide. This was a highlight of our visit to Budapest--a must see! Don't miss it!

History that touches your heart. Natural caves were connected to make an underground system that was used as a hospital in the 2nd world war and later as a secret nuclear bunker in the cold war.You have to book in for a tour at a given time. I've found the commentary very interesting and informative, a stark reminder of the past, but at the same time inspiring to see that human spirit can raise above all sorts of difficulties.Original furniture and equipment are arranged together with wax figures to help you imagine what it would have been like at the time.The only thing was a bit of a shame that we had to stick to the group and there wasn't always enough time to read all the captions and explanations,since each group had a given time.
DO NOT MISS. very impressive to see what they were able to preserve. this hospital is frozen in time. our guide was great

Absolutely worth the tour!. This is something that might not sound like a lot of fun but it's truly remarkable and frankly a lot of fun to see. While deep in the mountain frankly, a fully functional hospital was created to care for wounded civilians and military. Inside are rooms showing operating rooms, dental care, patient wards and so forth. You get a sense of what it must have been like during that time.

Hmmmm. Interesting place to visit. Good reminder of the horrors oh WW2. But turns out once more that the Hungarians have their own particular knowledge of geography, and not in the good way. On a map displayed in the transmission center there was a map that was supposed to show Hungary during the Cold War era. That map strangely included all Transilvania, a Romanian region clearly established as Romanian teritory long before Cold War.....and Romanian teritory ever since. So a little bit disapointing on this hystoric level......

Surprise I really enjoyed this visit. One of our travelling companions wanted to do this tour and I have to admit I was less than excited about going, but everyone gets their pick so off we went. Well she picked great, I found this tour fascinating and our guide was well informed, friendly and answered all of our questions. Sometimes it’s good to let someone else pick otherwise I would have missed this and it would have been my loss.

Medicine in the mountain. It was a chapter in history of which I was unaware. It was quite an engineering feat to knock out the barriers between caves, sufficient to create a 10 km. tunnel system which served as a hospital during 1944-45, then later during the 1956 Hungarian Revolution. Manikin personnel, vintage equipment, materials etc. lend an aura of authenticity. The tour was informative; a great opportunity to learn about a unique hospital.

Very good. The tour was really great, guide spoke english fluently and we saw many interesting exhibits and learned about the history of Budapest and this hospital. Really worth the price. Taking photos is not allowed inside so that is why you don't see many of them here. The downside is that the groups that are allowed in are a bit too big, if you fall behind a bit you cannot hear much because the rooms and corridors are small. You get to see a short film too, but only subtitles are in english so sit in front otherwise you will not see them. 50% discount if under 26 years!

A must see!. The inside of the bunker can only be seen by guided tours. Tours leave often and guides do speak English very well. The tour last about a hour. Once inside the bunker there are too many things to see! The place is filled with wax models and most of the things are kept in the original setting.The hospital in the rock survived 2 major wars and could hold 200 patients after the first renovation. But it did hold 700 patients in the midst of the war! The hospital is built inside an old cave system and is later on upgraded to nuclear bunker.The tour leads you through the wards, emergency room, operation rooms and eventually through the generator, ventilation and water/gasoline supply rooms.No photography is allowed inside the bunker. Price/Quality ratio for us was good, we were under 26 and could go in for half price. Which made our ticket 2000HUF each.

an excellent place to know the recent history of the country. a great place full of memories of the 20th century, they show a film about the beginning of the hospital and then how it was working during the WWII, the soviet occupation and after the 1956 revolution.It's a good place to know how to manage an hospital during wars

Really interesting visit - especially for nurses and history buffs. Really interesting visit - learned lots about the history of the hospital, but also the huge impact that War had on Budapest and the doctors and nurses who worked at the hospital. Seeing the conditions in which they had to work was humbling and awe inspiring in equal measures, and seeing the Nuclear bunker part of the hospital was very interesting - my husband and I both really enjoyed it

Unique and very interesting. The entrance was a little hard to find but it was within walking distance from the Budapest Hilton. Lots of steps down to it and then back up. A guided tour with lots of ww2 and later artifacts. It was so interesting that I did it twice. It was about a 4 block walk from the Hilton and then a long set of steps down to the entrance.

Excellent tour and museum . Our tour guide was Timi, who was amazing - she was informative and answered all our questions regarding the history of the hospital. If you get a chance, you should do your tour with her! Tours run about once every half an hour. The hospital museum itself has a great presentation and the reconstruction with mannequins effectively relayed the stories of the difficulties patients and doctors both faced.
Has to be seen. We went and saw this museum. It is a reminder of the horrors of war. Excellent presentation but be prepared to be shocked and amazed at the resilience of the human spirit

For WW II History Buffs. A rare glimpse into an unseen world. This hospital was built in a natural underground cave and provided refuge for hundreds of people during the midst of terrible bombing in WW2. To see the conditions where these brave medical people and volunteers survived and saved lives is an experience I'll never forget.

Eerily amazing. This is one tour/site to visit. Once inside you realize what is was like to live and be treated in an underground nature made cavern. You also realize that during war everyone is treated equally regardless of race, German soldier or Soviet soldier

Worth an hour...come for the Cold War history, stay for the revisionist Hungarian history. The tour is the only way you can get into this intriguing Cold War-era facility, and fortunately it's a pretty good tour. The rooms have been stocked with life-size wax figurines, some of them pretty gruesome, but the whole package does give you a decent sense of what it might have been like as a patient in this hospital.Added bonus is the revisionist history on display: Budapest as a perpetual victim of invasion and siege, equating the shelling of the city during the Communist period (particularly during the 1956 Hungarian Revolution) with the shelling of the city at the end of the Second World War...and conveniently downplaying the fact that Hungary was an Axis power during the war. The hospital makes a big deal of saying that it was open as a public facility during both sieges (it was a secret military facility the rest of the time), furthering that symbolic equation. So all of that is an additional, if unintentional, piece of the attraction.

Pretty Strange but interesting for those who lived the Cold War. Walking down the street from the Hilton in Buda we were interested by the signs pointing to a hospital and nuclear bunker. They are one in the same. Small museum that shows how the Hungarians prepared for a nuclear war in the 50's and 60's.

Terribly interresting. This hospital is reminder of past and the harsh reality of wartimes. The project started around the '30s and the aim was to build a hospital which was out of reach for the enemy, during the second World War it was improved so it also served as an atom bunker. There are no individuals tours, you must join a group with a guide. There are tours in English and in Hungarian, and they are quite frequent. Be aware that it can be cold down there, bring a sweater. There was maybe one downside, the tour was a bit too fast, we couldn't spend as much time looking at the artifacts as we have wished. And pictures are not allowed.

Really interesting visit.. It was my wife who decided she'd like to visit here and despite my initial misgivings it was a really interesting and informative place to visit. Sadly they don't allow photographs inside the bunker.
Very interesting. Fascinating bit of history and an excellent tour. Very well described and a lot of work has been put into the display. Well worth going to.

Must see cultural and historial jewel. This was recommended by a tour guide, she really insisted on it so we went, and we took the best history and cultural lesson of the trip. It is a very interesting passage in time to see the actual rooms and halls of the war hospital which later became a nuclear bunker. There is an introductory video which summarizes the 20th century history of Budapest and of the Hospital in the Rock. Very interesting for history, medicine, culture, geology lovers.
Amazing visit. A must see in Budapest, it is moving and totally worth it, SO much our only complaint is wish we could have spent longer than the guided 50 min!! Be sure to visit!

Surprisingly Good. This was included as an option on our recent European River Tour. It starts of with a 10 minute movie which was in Hungarian but has English subtitles. The documentary gives you a really good basis of why & how the Hospital/Nuclear Bunker came into being. Then the local guide (young, great English and really interesting) takes you through the Museum which has amazing waxwork recreations of hospital treatments and day-to-day scenarios during the siege. It was really interesting. Aside from the local stories they also have information on other world-wide stuff like Hiroshima, which is also very sobering. Alas you can't take any photo's, which is a bummer. Oh and it is blissfully cool inside the caves on a hot summers day!

Amazing, just wish we'd been given more time in there. This is an incredible museum full of amazing history. Our guide was great and I appreciated being shown around. However on many occasions we'd reach rooms with entire displays and only have 2 minutes in them. I really wanted to be able to stop and read them. An hour is too short!

An interesting visit and tour - frozen in time. If you haven't planned to visit the Hospital in the Rock you should. I thought it kind of sounded a little silly but it was very interesting along many lines. Medical equipment used in WWII, the uniqueness of a cave hospital, education as to how it was used and old equipment (generators, air purifiers, etc). They even let the tourist borrow a cape to keep warm while visiting.

Awesome experience, excellent guide, amazing historical perspective, do not miss it!. Great historical review, amazing medical equipment, history of the building in the caves and so much actual equipment. Incredible views of the various systems needed to keep this hospital running with electric and backup generators. Interesting discussion about nuclear weapons and how these caves can protect those in the event of a nuclear event.
Amazing Place. So much history and amazing when you are down under the bunker, a tour guide is the way to go, very cheap also. a must see in Budapest.

A must see in Budapest. I was impressed about this museum. You can learn much about Hungarian history and about their dramaIt s a little spicy but it worth it!The guide is free (English) and the tour is about 1 hour longBeware! The smell inside is very heavy. And the air is a little rarefied. If you have breathing problems, think twice. I am a little claustrophobic but i was fine

Pretty Cool, one for the history buffs. A neat tour for history buffs, and a look into the past how this area was used, overhauled, used, overhauled, then set aside. When we got there, English tours were happening every half hour, which was great, since we got there a quarter past.The tour kicks off with a quick movie that sets the mood. Our guide was good and energetic, and happy to answer the occasional question. After 8 minutes, we were off to roam through the underground.The tour progresses with several stops where the guide will tell you about what the particular nearby rooms were used for. Now filled with wax figures, you get an idea just how cramped this place was during it's tenure. There is one "surprise" later, which feels real out of place.A brief part of the tour honors Hungary's elite soldiers. All well and good, but a bit out of place for the place and theme.A second brief part of the tour detours into atomic/nuclear weapons, with a clear anti-nuclear stance and lots of artwork by Japanese children about Nagasaki/Hiroshima.The tour goes out to a point in the facility and then circles back to let you end in the lobby. There are certain areas which are off limits, and no way to roam around on your own. There isn't enough room. Several of the monitors appeared to be not working during our tour.The tour ended promptly at 60 minutes. While interesting, the non-Euro price is sort of steep. However, due to the space and it's role in history, this would definitely interest WWII, Soviet and general Budapest history buffs.Location is a short walk from Buda Castle. If done the right way, you'll see part of the cave system not used by the hospital.

probably the highlight of our trip. As I am exceptionally bored with buildings this was a very pleasant change and very realistic. The tour guide was a nice chap with great English who was attentive with the whole group. Amazing history and very realistic. You have to go and see it.

Great historical building with excellent knowledge from English speaking guides.. This is a must for anyone with an interest in history especially WW2 and Hungarian revolution. It is quite chilli down there but you are offered coats. There are loads of weird looking models set up as it would of been in the war, all the medical equipment and supplies are authentic, check the expirary dates. The guides speak very good English and their knowledge is outstanding. It seems like a somber place to visit but do not be put off, it is a fantastic look at how Hungary managed to provide care to soldiers in safety and hidden from enemy bombs.Not suitable for young children and expensive for an hour visit (4000 huf ) but well worth the effort.
Travel back in the History. A very interesting, hidden attraction in Budapest. A must see. Professional set of WWII memories and authentic exhibition of Cold War era hospital and emergency equipment.

Pricey but unique place (better for families). I couldn't leave Budapest without visiting the bunker! Besides, I wanted to have some relief from the boiling weather...The ticket is a bit expensive - HUF 4000 - (30% off with the Budapest card, which is on the other hand not a great deal, so only if you have it..) and the approach is more prone towards an experience for the whole family. Be advised, there are no small coats if your kids feel cold so bring a sweater if they are not fine with the underground temperature.The tour is mainly provided in English so don't worry about that (an initial video is screened with English subtitles). The first part of it regards the areas of the hospital and only the few remaining rooms are dedicated to the nuclear bunker.A room is dedicated to the effects of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki bombs and hidden behind a panel to allow the view only to adults.Out guide proved to be extremely patient with the children asking any type of questions (some were very smart ones though!).It might not be the bunker you would expect but it's worth paying a visit, at least for the big smiles of the members of the staff, very friendly and motivated people.

Almost surprisingly, you MUST see this!. This might have been one of the most informative of our activities in Budapest, and it came as a complete surprise to me. My wife talked about wanting to see a hospital while we were on the Buda side of the river. I was not really inspired by the idea, but had no problem just checking it out. It was GREAT! This cavernous place has such a fascinating history that extends from the Second World War through the Cold War. The Soviets made this a nuclear disaster treatment facility and declared it top secret! Most fascinating was its use during WWII and the tragic and heroic true stories that happened there.You are taken on a thorough tour in language groups. Our young guide spoke excellent English and was extremely knowledgeable and conversant on the history of the hospital. If you are a medical person of any calling, you will be fascinated by this facility. All of the old/original medical implements/instruments are there on display. You can clearly see the horrors of war and the gallant efforts made by the staff under nearly impossible circumstances. I promise...you will not be disappointed!

Very interesting piece of Budapest history. We had a very knowledgable and enthusiastic guide through this interesting and unique historical site. Definitely recommended if you're interested in WWII or Cold War history, as it's unlike any attraction I've ever visited before.
Fantastic. I liked especially how the creators tried to couple together the history of the complex with the topics moving our society today. Very thought through and moving

A very interesting and unusual place. It's not the easiest place to find. With the Fishermans Bastion on your right head down one of the side streets on the left and you may see a signpost, or just ask. There's a lift down to a road on which the museum is situated.The tours take place at certain times with a limited number allowed so check before you go ! You might be able to pre-purchase tickets. The tour begins with a film in a quite claustrophobic room (12mins) and you then proceed with your guide. Ours was a young lady who was very good and knew her stuff. The tour lasts about an hour and you see the rooms which housed the patients, the operating theatre, showers, kitchens etc. The end also takes in the "engine room" and you learn some interesting and quirky secrets.Special rates are offered for seniors,students etc but it isn't expensive anyway. There is a place to have a snack and drink if you have to wait for the next tour.Definately worth a visit.

History well preserved. If you are into history and underground spaces then the Hospital in the rock is worth visiting. The guided tour and the short film is very informative. The souvenir shop offers many military items, as well as a fully illustrated book about the history of the hospital/bunker. Authentic place till the last used-to-be-sterile, sterile gauze.The one hour long visit is barely enough if you are keen on the details. Unfortunately, photography is not permitted. Best approached from the Castle district, just take the elevator (or the steps) at the end of "Szentháromság" street and then turn right, the entrance should be in sight, right away.

Very interesting. Very interesting to visit, but do not expect too much.Some of the things that were shown were not really relevant to the museum, like a helicopter and drawings made by Hiroshima victims.

Very interesting though cold and smells of damp. Bearing in mind where you are, you should expect there to be a damp smell and for it to be cold. We visited on an extremely hot day but they'd run out of blankets and it was cold. Our guide was very good with excellent English and an engaging manner. He answered many questions with patience and grace. Our one reservation was that nobody could answer for us whether the exposed pipes with what looked extremely like asbestos were just a very good artistic copy of the originals or whether they were in fact the originals with asbestos!! Somebody needs to establish this to be able to respond to future visitors.

Thoroughly Enjoyed It. Firstly, I'd like to thank our guide, Eleanora (Nora). She was just lovely and so infomative. The tour was roughly one hour long. It started with a short video presentation. I was amazed at the network of tunnels and rooms that made up the hospital. Nora's explanations made it all so real. Pictures in the rooms highlighted how things were back in the 40s & 50s etc.Conditions were hard, especially during the war. And to think they were expecting a nuclear halocaust too, by making it 'nuclear war ready'...wow It was a great tour, well run. And it's lovely and cool underground!!

Excellent insight into wars in Budapest and medicine.. The tour was interesting throughout. Both the videos and the tour guide explained the history very well. Really adds to the picture of Budapest during the world war and subsequent occupation. Only issue is if you don't have 3G it would be quite difficult to find so download the map before setting off.

Interesting museum and site. This is a rather unique museum, set inside a cave associated with WWII and the Cold War. Very interesting tour and good guide. It would have been nice to hear more on the 1956 revolution and even more on the siege of Budapest. Still, a unique perspective and view from a previous Soviet-block country. Make a reservation because many of the tours fill-up fast. We bought tickets and returned later in the day.

Infomative and Interesting Tour. Made the time to go and visit the Hospital in the Rock whilst I was on the Buda side based on TA reviews. A little difficult to find as not well sign posted lucky I had a read a previous review on how to get there. The hospital had been used for a number of different events in Budapest's history and the tour guide was very enthusiastic and informative and something I wouldn't have had the chance to experience anywhere else.

Interesting Historic tour. Staff were friendly & helpful, ticket price was good.The tour guide spoke good English and was very enthusiastic. This tour is not for people with a delicate disposition, as the wax work figures convey scenes of suffering and pain ( The museum was originally a hospital in the 2nd world war) It is built into the side of a cave, so not ideal for the claustrophobic! We were given a detailed history of the place, parts of the tour I found moving, it certainly makes you think how hard it was for the people there. It was also nice and cool - a break from the heat! I would recommend this tour if you are interested in the history of Budapest.

An informative and interesting place to visit in Budapest!. We visited the hospital with our children aged 11 and 12 in early July and joined the guided tour. The guide was excellent and gave us a thorough understanding of the history of the hospital over the years!

Highly recommended!. We went here on recommendation of a friend, and loved our tour at the hospital. Top tip: use the elevator or staircase down the street from the Mattias Church to find the entrance. Though we had to wait for the 45 minute tour to start (the only way to view the hospital), it offers an important historical perspective of Budapest. The cool air (15° C) in the bunker was also a welcome relief in the summer heat. They provide coats for those who may wish to use them. We had a wonderful guide, who enthusiastically showed us around. I wish we could've had more time too properly look around during the tour, that would be my only criticism.

it was cool in the bunker. however it was expensive for what it was. A little pricy for my liking (4000 HUF each). It was interesting but not particularly exciting. It was cool despite being boiling outside and they even offered coats! Slightly creepy manakins in each room.
Interesting visit. Well worth visiting with very informative guide bringing the history of the place to life. It can get quite cool underground.

Fascinating historical experience. A concise description of the Hospital can be found in Wikipedia under the title Hospital in the Rock. The hospital was built under Castle Hill. Designed for 60-70 patients, it was treating 600 patients during the final days of WWII. The introductory video was very good. The displays were very good. Our guide was very good and spoke flawless English. It really was fascinating. The temperature in the caves is about 60F. Warm overcoats are available if you need to keep warm. My wife and I didn't use the coats. The tour was just about an hour in length. I urge you to take the tour.

Make time to visit. I had so wanted to visit here when we came in December but it was closed for the holidays. Happily it was open when we came in June and we were able to join one of the 60 minute tours. The museum was originally a hospital in WWII and is built into the caverns under the castle. At one point it was being used to treat up to 600 wounded soldiers.It was one of those places where they had creepy waxwork figures (200 of them!) showing how the hospital used to look but it was so interesting. The guide gave us a detailed history of the place and there was so many genuine pieces around to look at. In fact you could even buy genuine items in the gift shop!

Something different to do!. Visited the ' hospital in the rock war museum and bunker with my husband and friends. Apart from being a cool shelter as underground out if the July heat a definite if you like to visit places a bit different from general tourist stops. Tickets for a guided tour cost about 4,000.00 HF or $22 Au but very interesting. Informative guides in different languages and it was an actual working hospital in both 1st & 2nd World wars and a nuclear bunker. Tour takes about 45 minutes located in underground tunnels beneath castle!

Not for the Claustrophobic or Faint Hearted. A cave hospital that was used during the siege of Budapest by the Russians and a during the intensive allied Bombing by the Americans during WW2. Later used as a vaccine production facility, then in 1956 to treat victims of the uprising. This place has an extremely interesting history and is well worth a visit. You get a real feeling for what has passed before in these natural caves located under Castle Hill on the Buda side of Budapest. very educational, but not for the claustrophobic amongst you!

Amazing tour. One of the best tours we've been on!This tour is informative, interactive, and so so interesting. We did not tune out once, the tour guide gave us an in-depth synopsis of the history and experiences of those who lived and worked in the bunker. Highly recommend you check this out while in the Castle District!

A fascinating few hours.. After a little wandering around the quaintness that is the 'Buda' part of Budapest my friend and I went in to this attraction.The ticketing staff were fluent in English and very friendly.The tour guide who did our tour was a very amenable young man whose English was excellent.His knowledge of the history of this place was second to none and you really got a feel for the awful conditions' that were here during World War II.The Hospital has being set out to look how it did during the war and I feel that it has been done well.  All in all I would recommend this as an attraction well worth going to.
A must see. As a nurse, this was a must see and worth every minute of time to visit.Well preserved. Bought the book. Lasting memory for me

This is the place to visit for great views of Budapest. This is the place to visit for great views of Budapest. We went here as part of our Leger coach tour and even though it was pouring with rain you could still get a great view of Budapest

A hidden gem. We were so thankful to stumble upon this amazing piece of wartime history. A fascinating tour learning about this well equipped secret underground hospital that could also serve as a nuclear bunker. Incredible.

The best in Budapest . My daughter read about the museum, my husband & I weren't that bothered about visiting but we're so pleased we did. The tours start on the hour in English or Hungarian, the guide was knowledgeable, friendly & had a great sense of humour. The tour lasts about an hour although it didn't feel that long. The expression on the faces of the wax works were sometimes a little odd but that added to the experience. Interesting, informative & well worth a visit, one of the best museums I've ever visited and there have been many.

It's worth your time to find this attraction. We heard about this site from others traveling for business. The tours are narrated in a few languages. You CANNOT take pics on the tour but the gift shop has books at reasonable prices.

Awesome place, but too rushed. Being nurses, we had an interest in this place. We got there just a few minutes after the hour, and were told the English tour was just watching the video so we could go in with them if we wanted to join. There are warm over coats to borrow as it is quite cool inside. Personally I felt the tour was too rushed, and we didn't get enough time to really look at all the equipment and the displays etc. it was only an hour, and the guide was very knowledgeable, but it did feel like she was just rushing to get us through. The group was very big which meant sometimes those at the end missed what she was saying. It is a very interesting place, I just wanted more time to have a look around at my own pace. I also don't quite understand why you can't take photos - unless it is to ensure the groups keep moving through at a rapid rate?

Avoid the Busses And Be Amazed At Hungarian Ingenuity. This WWII state of the art hospital was built underground so that critical medical care could be provided to those affected by the bombing or fighting during the midst of battle. It's small so the busses cannot be accommodated which means your tour guide takes small groups and gives you a comprehensive overview of this fascinating site.

Early evening visit, July 1st.. I took the 6pm tour on Friday, July 1st. The english guided tour departs every hour, on the hour. Last entry being 7pm. Finding the entrance to the museum could be a challenge. I lucked out and my tour guide from earlier in the day was able to point out, and describe, where I needed to walk to find it. So no trouble for me. You pay at the front entrance/gift shop area. Then you wait there until the tour starts. We had a pretty good sized tour group. I know that any more may have made the tour a bit difficult. But we were able to move along easily and hear our guide with relative ease. It is a 1hr tour. It was great! I loved it and would do it again. And yes, photography is verboten! Too bad, as I would have loved some photographic memories. It was said that they had some newer exhibits in the tour. Those newer exhibits were very good too. I learned quite a bit from the tour. They also have several fun items to purchase in the gift shop. It was well worth my time and money.

Very Interesting, Good Guide & Great Choice For Wet or Very Hot Days!. This museum is located in a former cave system build into the rocks beneath the Buda castle and museum area. We joined an English language tour, which lasted 60 minutes and was well narrated by Bence, our guide. The hospital portion of the tour was very interesting, with several conflict driven emergency periods placing huge strain on resources and staff. There seemed to be many original items which were fascinating and many wall boards and informations which there was not quite enough time to see. A shorter segment of the tour is the nuclear bunker and this is similarly well covered. Overall, well worth seeing and as it is inside, its ideal for escaping extremes of weather or to do and see something different.

Best guided tour ever. The guided tour was perfect in every way. She was moderately humorous yet sincerely serious about sharing a piece of her country's history with you. This hospital is like no other I have seen. It was truly one of a kind and it makes your heart wrench.

Great Visit. Maybe because Robert De Niro visited here or maybe because it was uniquely built into the labyrinth, I wanted to visit this hospital museum before arriving in Budapest. It turned out to be better than expected. Don't miss the little souvenir shop at the entrance - it sells some unique gift items at reasonable price. When we visited, I saw at least 2 more English tours behind us. All of the tours had about 20 people. I could hear the tour guide just fine. So much to learn from the guide. At the end, a large picture of Hiroshima after the nuclear bomb is displayed along with a bunch of drawings by the Japanese civilians who witnessed the bombing. This museum renewed my belief in peace without nuclear weapons. Whilst I agree that the entrance fee is expensive, it is worth every penny. I could not take advantage as I visited St. Mathias Church afterward, but if you show the church's entrance stub, the museum will give you 10 % discount.
Expensive . Facinating place. Great guide and something different from the usual historic sights. It's not cheap though, and was easily the most expensive museum we visited.

Excellent museum . Firstly, do not go to the labyrinth which is in the same area. We visited the Hospital in the rocks after a recommendation from a friend. The museum is very good value for money. When we went the tours were in Hungarian and English. In our group there were just 5 people, so it was very personal and we could ask as many questions as we wanted. The guide was very knowledgeable and was happy to answer the questions. The museum gives and excellent insight into what life was like during world war 2 and Soviet occupation. Inside the complex it is a constant temperature of about 16°, so it can be a bit cold, but a free overcoat is provided for the tour. Very highly recommended.
Definitely a must. So interesting. Guided tours on the hour or half hour depending on the day of the week. Takes about an hour or so to take the tour. Very moving exhibition and informative guide

Fascinating tour of underground hospital facility . This attraction is somewhat off the beaten track but easily reached from st Mathias church.
