With your back toward the church walk down the street directly in front of you (away from pest). When you reach the end you can either take the stairs or elevator down to the next street and turn right. You will reach the entrance to the hospital. An excellent movie with English subtitles provides an overview of the history of the times/ place. You then take a 1 hour your through the facility and end up in a nuclear bunker. It is a little chilly during the tour so you might bring a light jacket but they do provide coats for people that want them. You can get a 10% discount on the cost here if you show your st Mathias ticket. They also have student and senior discounts.

Excellent and impressive museum. Found this museum by accident on tripadivsor. It's quite easy to reach with bus 16 from Deak Ferenc Tér. It's close to a strairway as well so easy to combine with the fishersman bastion. The tour starts with a video that explains the past of the hospital. Once the video is done (~10 minutes) the tour continues with a guide inside the hospital. It's quite cold in the caves but the museum provides coats if neccesary so you don't have to bring any special clothes for this visit. The tourgide we had was very friendly. His english wasn't very good but he definitly made that up by his enthusiasm. He was very communicative and asked several questions to the tourgroup for some extra participation.The hospital itself offers extra tours during the summer between the hours (so we had a tour at 16:30). It's advised to arrive on time since tour groups are max. 30 people. Which is the absolute max since some of the hallways and rooms are very small.The tour takes you everywhere and offers alot of information, mainly because the museum put alot of figures everywhere to resemble scenes from the past. To conclude, the museum is very impressive to visit and gives a new dimension to the city and it's past. It's a shame that the city doesn't offer more of these wonderful museums.

A unique experience!. It was a very fulfilling experience for me. I found a lot more than I expected. It is 15-17 celcius degrees inside; at the door they offer you a coat to keep you warm. There is a heavy smell inside and it is not the best attraction for the clastrophobic people.A huge ammount of medical tools and machienes from the second ww or cold war years are well preserved. The surgery rooms, patient dorms are full of realistic models. I must admit that I managed to imagine what it was like to work there in the hospital during WW2! The video at the beginning has English subtitles and English guide is very cute. She obviously was enjoying her job and everything she told was very interesting. When she mentioned about the water and medical supply shortage I was shocked. They had to use bandages taken from the dead peoples wounds... The hospital was originally designed for 200 people but had to serve 500-700 people during the siege of the city. I can write a whole a lot more but you should go see the Hospital in the Rock. Definitely. :)

Must see. This one hour guided tour is fantastic. It's really surprising to discover this old hospital right under the castle hill, well protected in the natural caves of the Buda side.And it's really interesting to discover more about the history of Hungary and Budapest

Hospital in the Rock Visit. We decided to visit the hospital after reading some of the reviews on trip advisor. We were not disappointed. The tour is led by a guide and there are language options for each tour. Our guide spoke excellent English and provided an interesting insight into the operation of the hospital. A real treasure of a museum with lots of interesting displays and material throughout. There are a limited number of tickets sold for each session, be sure to get there early and purchase you ticket. Prices were reasonable and the museum offers very good concessions for students and OAPs. Gem of a visit.
Really interesting. Nice guide, nice tour and a great museum.It was recently restaured and they even got a helicopter inside.Top attraction I could find in Budapest.

Just see. Slightly off the beaten path and worth the trek. Excellent tour guides who offer real perspective on how injured civilians and soldiers were cared for during multiple conflicts. Well worth an hour of your day.

Cool. This is an extremely interesting museum. It is like stepping back into time. You are required to book a time as you cannot walk thru without a guide. However this site is well worth the visit. Since the facility is underground, it is quite cool (temperature wise). Perfect place to visit especially if it is hot outside.

Excellent resource not made the most of.......... The museum is excellent, however our group was too large and it was difficult to see exhibits the guide was talking about. There is so much to see and read but unfortunately the tour doesn't give you any opportunity to study any of the exhibits. It's a shame it could be brilliant.

Worth visiting, interesting facts and history about this unique hospital . We went here for the last part of our visit to Budapest for the 2nd time. The 50-min tour was great all the time. One can have clear picture how this place served as a haven to all wounded victims of the world War 1I and 1956 revolution. The museum features how hard working doctors and volunteer nurses dedicated their life to treat all wounded shoulders/victims despite lacking of resources. Here I am reminded how noble profession a nurse to be. Definitely worth the price. Tour guide was lively and speaks well English. She was knowledgeable and anyone can ask questions as she said herself I'm passionate about history'. Highly recommended!

This was on our last day. Tours on the hour. I thought it was interesting to see how the bunker came to be created. There are wax figures throughout - sort of creepy to look at. I think the tours are OK - if there a lot of people, the guide is speaking while you are about 50 feet back. But there was plenty of time to see it all. The introductory film was also good. I thought the person who sold us our tickets was VERY informative and friendly.

Imformative, Interesting, Intuitive. Interesting tour available every hour in English. Reasonable entry price, even more so if you can prove you're under 26. All underground so a museum with a difference!

Evil War & working in Confinded Space. You can view the passion of the medical teams working in confined space to save the lives of people injured by the evil of war. The strategies put in place in this hospital to house the injured and to ward off any nuclear attacks. The hospital had all the facilities, from communication, power, air to food supplies to survive the event of such attack. An interesting displays not to be missed.

A uniquely Hungarian experience. We had some trouble finding this location as we had to take stairs down from the Buda castle area to get there and we didn't initially understand that. The English speaking guide was easy to understand and knowledgeable about the history of the underground building. We were taken through the nuclear bunker first (not the typical approach) and then through the hospital, which was used twice; during WWII and also during the Hungarian revolution in 1956. Both areas were very austere. There were several scenarios acted out as we went through the hospital which served to clarify the environment the patients and medical personnel faced. at the end of tour, as we left the building, there was a last scenario that included military transport vehicles and was fairly realistic.I would recommend this attraction for anyone interested in the WWII/communist era.

Absolutely stunning!. We've managed to see all of the top 40 Budapest's trip advisor places and we can say with 100% certainty that this one we loved the most! It was great, the information very interesting and we will definitely come again. Absolutely worth the money.

Nuclear Bunker Museum. Good museum. You pay for a guide to walk and talk you through the important historical events that took place inside the bunker.However, the bunker is on the top of hill. You can get a lift up to the top or walk up stairs that are found on the bottom street after the Vèrmezo park.

Too expensive for what you get. . Overall we did enjoy the 50-60 minute mandatory tour through the bunker and there are lots of of wax figures and museum items to see. We were disappointed with the cost verses value however. 4000ft per adult. We visited the Labirintus (Massive underground tunnel system just a few minutes from the hospital) immediately after doing the hospital and were much more impressed there. 2200ft per adultSeniors, families with young kids and individuals with mobility issues will definitely prefer the hospital in the rock as it is well lit, good paths, fairly easy to navigate.Backpackers, families with teens, couples and adults go check out the Labirintus ( Labyrinth)!!!

Something different. This is a tour you go on which has the benefit of good information from the guide. Worth doing. It's different to the standard stuff. Would benefit from more emphasis on local war than the wider stuff.

Amasing history and beautifully maintained in its cold war condition.. Again had an excellent guide. The tour went through the reception area, operating theatres, wards, machine rooms and all the ancillary bits needed to run a hospital. It was all set up to show the conditions at various times during its history. And what a history WW1, WW2, the 1956 rebellion and the Cold War. Amazing place

Very moving. We had an english speaking guide who took her time to tell the story as we walked through. As a tour it is very well presented and emotionally moving as it tells the story of the wartime siege and then conversion into a nuclear bunker. It is underground for about an hour and cooler than outside, but the time passes so quickly with so much to take in. On the way out you pass a series of drawings by survivors of the Hiroshima A Bomb - not something you forget easily. I would highly recommend a visit.

Interesting and fun. Enjoyable museum with lifelike wax and the original equipment from the era.
Good guides and reasonably priced. One of the better museums I have been to for a shortish time warp back through history.
Worth a visit for something different.. This site is an amazing museum and well worth visiting, if you get the chance don't miss it, gives a great insight into the determination of oppressed people.
A Hidden Gem for Years. I have been coming to Budapest for more than 10 years and never knew this was here. Great history well kept secret. Excellent tour.

Don't miss!. Really interesting, a piece of hungarian medical and war history. Very good english-speaking guides. They took time to answer on questions and was able to give a good experience and informative visit. Don't miss this!

Great place to visit, but very pricey. We enjoyed the visit and the history of how this underground network of caves has been used as a wartime hospital and later as a potential shelter against nuclear attack. However, we felt the steep entry fee (about 17 USD) was about double what it should be.

Hospital in the Rock, Buda Castle Hill. Interesting, English language tours available. Somewhat like the caves of Gibraltar if you've been there. Only used as a hospital at the end of WWII for a few months, but nonetheless an interesting look

Interesting experience, but feels a bit rushed. This was probably about 90% Hospital in the Rock and 10% Nuclear Bunker. I felt it was quite expensive for what it was (we didn't have any discounts) but was still very interesting.The tour takes you through the tunnels in the 'rock', which has mannequins set up to give you a picture of what it would have been like. Very thought provoking and interesting and our tour was great at giving us information as we walked through.I did feel it was a bit rushed despite having an hour in there, and I had to run to catch up to the group as I was busy looking at the posters on the walls and other interesting sights that we were just walking past without acknowledging. There was another room that they had't finished yet, so it's nice to know that the place is expanding, but fear that may make the tour seem even more rushed.However, the place was very good overall, and I would recommend you check it out if you're interested in finding out why and how they build a hospital there.

The stand out unexpected highlight of our trip!. Having read some of the reviews through tripadvisor we decided to drop into this museum. What a find!Firstly it can be accessed easily by walking from the Bastion and Matthias Church to the promenade area which is the edge of the catle wall, where there is a lift or stairs down to the caves where the museum is located. You can also walk down from the castle along the road, takes about 10 minutes to reach it.You cant walk around the museum on your own, you must wait for an accompanied tour, but it is worth the wait.Fascinating, great video first to set the scene and we had a really informative young man who walked us through the myriad of rooms and corridors. One of the most fascinating and unusual places we have ever been. Its cool in there so if you do not have a jacket / cardigan, they provide you with a warm cover.Go....you will enjoy it.

Interesting place to see. Guided tours takes off every hour, you cannot go in by yourself. The tour starts with a short movie and after that you´ll walk through the hospital and the different rooms. There´s a possibility to borrow a coat to have during the tour since the temperature drops a little as you go farther down in the hospital, but if will also do fine if you you have a longsleeved sweater or a light jacket (which I had). The guide was good, she told us a lot about the hospital in a detailed and humoristic way that made it really interesting to listen to. Her English was good and easy to understand. I highly recommend a visit to Hospital in the rock.

Great experience of a true hospital in the times of the war . I have to say I had low expectations with this palace but I was Fascinated as soon as I got in. From the moment you enter the cold tunnels ( like 15 celsius degrees) you get some coats to use you feel in the mood of a hospital and in the war time. Great recreations of every room plus lots of real instruments from that time. You also get a good idea of how much doctors and nurses worked in that small and hot emergency hospital. I will say it's a good experience to take young children of around 12 and plus, yes it's a bit too real, just make you own decision.

Not to be missed. This gem of a museum is worth the stop. During the mandatory guided tour you'll learn about some very interesting chapters in recent Hungarian history. The tunnels were dug for smaller people, but they're well-lit and don't really inspire claustrophobia. The museum is very well designed and contains some of the best examples of medical equipment and technology from the 20th century. Photography isn't allowed inside, but it allows you to focus on the stories time by the tour guides. It does get cold, so bring a scarf or borrow one of the coats provided.
Amazing visit to a Hospital bunker. Well-balanced tour in English. Interesting to listen and see, a lovely tiny shop. Absolutely worth visiting!
Timetravel. We went there with my class in a privat tour. Very very interesting.It is like going back in time. It is unbeliveable. If yoz work in the health care you can not miss it!

Excellent tour. The guide spoke English and after a short film which provided background on the site, he started the hour-long tour through the hospital. Modern wax figures take the place of doctors, nurses, and patients throughout the exhibit, but the rooms and supplies are original. Truly fascinating tour!

Fascinating Tour. This was a fascinating tour of a 1944-45 wartime hospital carved into the mountain of Buda. It was also used during the 1956 Hungarian Revolution. It was designed for 60 patients, but ended up housing 200. The tableaus inside the hospital have to be seen to be believed because they are so incredbily realistic. Unfortunately, no photos are allowed. After WWII, the hospital was converted to a nuclear bomb shelter. This is on my "highly recommended" list of things to do in Budapest.

Very interesting. My wife is a medic in the US Military and she was very interested in how they took care of the wounded and injured during the wars. Definitely worth the tour, it takes about an hour. Call in advance to see when they give a tour in your language, you have to use the tour guides but it is worth it.

Informative and well done. We visited this museum as it's open until 8 at night which gives you more time during the day. Once inside, you are given a guided tour which lasts about an hour. Our tour guide Vera spoke good English and had a good amount of knowledge. For the money, it was probably the best museum we visited whilst in Budapest. Just be warned that it's cold down there!

Interesting museum. We felt this museum was worth the time spent. It is not a traditional museum, as your visit is comprised of a 1 hr walking tour, and so there's no opportunity to wander freely but for us this was not an issue. It was really interesting to hear the history of the bunker, and there has clearly been some effort made to recreate the feel of the past. The walking is not too quick and easy, but if you are claustrophobic this may not be the best attraction for you. Also, children may find the experience a little scary (the waxworks were creep looking!). Overall a great visit and would highly recommend to anyone interested in learning more about this unique place.

Great insight into the relatively recent history of Hungary. Amazing underground hospital and then nuclear shelter used up until 2008. Cared for up to 700 patients at one time.Helpful tour guides. Good reconstructions and well preserved medical equipment

Unique. I have never seen a similar museumWhile a number of the exhibits are in serious need of cleaning/refurbishment this is still a place of history worth visiting There is a mix of themes but primarily the guided tour is about the use of the underground tunnels as a medical facility. The are old medical paraphernalia as well as staged (mannequin) reenactment of what it would have looked like No photos are allowed

A bit dry and felt rushed. As this was quite expensive by Hungarian standard (£10 each) we were expecting a lot. We hoped there would be some interactive displays and more free time to look around.However it was a guided tour and this didn't give you chance to look at everything as you were moved on very quickly at each stop. The guide was good and knowledgeable but struggled to answer questions from the group (were there issues with rats? was one question). I wouldn't recommend it for young children as it's quite cold and the info is a bit difficult for them to understand.

Come here to experience a time traveling museum.. The hospital in the Rock is one of the mot interesting places I have been. Walking through the underground hospital halls, allows you to experience "time travel". The decorated rooms and wax figures allows you to get an idea of what is like to be in a hospital during the war. Quite shocking and highly educative.

Interesting Recreation of war/medical history. Well worth a visit if you're in the area checking out this amazing side of the river. I wouldn't prioritise it over visiting the bastion or the church though. Basically it is a guided tour showing the bunker with a lot of recreated plaster models showing what life would be like down there.

Fascinating. Such an interesting place! Definitely worth a visit. Interesting museum, full of history, never seen anything like it. Very informative guide who spoke English and German. Takes about an hour to go round and you will see loads. Snapshot of a fairly grim but fascinating past. Good gift shop too. Quite tucked out of the way so take a map.
Interesting.. Definitely worth seeing. The tour takes about an hour and our guide spoke excellent English. The use of wax figures and original instruments certainly added to atmosphere.

Very Informative and Interesting. The guided tour was well organised even though we had a large group. The exhibits are excellent with dozens of life sized wax statues and original uniforms, instruments and furniture. The tour was through the original tunnels and caverns so one can really get the feeling of what it must have been like for the medical staff to work under such conditions - very atmospheric.

A Better Understanding of the Hardships of War. A guided tour around the hospital graphically displays the terrible conditions in which the injured soldiers received medical care. A series of underground tunnels were converted into a hospital complete with an ER, Operating Rooms, wards and all the needs of a functioning hospital. Numerous wax figures with terrible wounds bring further home the horror of war and what it does to people, The exhibits are very well done and clearly show the harsh conditions under which the medical staff worked. The guide is knowledgeable in all aspects of the hospital showing all the rooms including the equipment that supplied air and power. In later years it became an atomic bomb shelter and decontamination center before it was finally closed.A must see if you want to better understand the problems that Budapest has suffered over the years.

Very interesting. We wanted to do one guidetour in the weekend we stayed in Budapest. We are really pleased to say we choose this one! It's very interesting and a beetle creepy to walk in this big cave like hospital. The guide was very friendly and spook good English. They did a good job showing how it was over there during the second world war.

Often overlooked but very interesting. This museum is often overshadowed by the more popular Buda Castle and Fisherman's Bastion but it is well worth a visit. Located in a series of renovated caves, it was a functioning hospital in the 1940's especially during the war. The recreations and tour are a fascinating overview of life for the sick and wounded of Budapest during WWII.
Excellent. This is a must see, it is very very interesting, there is a guided tour around it and it is very good
Such an amazing experience. Brilliant guided tour, learnt so much! Was very informative and I am so glad that I included this into my trip. If you are a history/ war buff definitely go and see this!

Hospital n the Rock Rocks. We visited the Hospital in the Rock Museum in June 2016. Visits are by guided tour only. Our guide spoke excellent English and was extremely knowledgeable. She answered all questions even those involving obscure medical instruments. Very educational, learned a lot about the history of Budapest during the second world war and communist era
Disappointing. It's what you'd think walking round a disused hospital would be like. Not much of any interest to see. 4,000 huf so very expensive for Budapest too.

A must see. If you are claustrophobic then don't recommend. But if you not then it is worth the visit. The tours normally go on the hour and make sure you are there at least 10 mins in advance, early mornings seem better time to go. A fascinating bit of history, tour guides knew their history.
Very authentic . The guided tour was really informative and all the originals material used by doctors are still there. The nuclear shelter bit of the tour is very interesting .

Great visit, quite sobering though. Hospital in the rock sits above the city , and is literally that. It was a full operating hospital , in the naturally occurring tunnels within the mountain. Short film before tour was informative about the history, then you tour a short stretch of the hospital , still set up , in terms of the function of respective rooms. ie: operating theatre complete with equipment , and manequins, etc.As interesting as it was, it was quite a sobering experience, as it made very real the conditions and circumstances that people had to endure during times of war. Worth a visit
Interesting. If you are a member of the cold war generation this museum will interests you also if you are a history buff
Fascinating. Very interesting museum built in the rock of castle hill.You hear about the history,sieges and politics.

Learning experience!. Despite it being on the chilly side in this amazing structure the whole experience was quite chilling yet amazing with the occasional sound effects to finding out the complexity of how things were done and managed in this cave system to how the entire hospital was made and had expended over the years. Definately worth booking a tour!
So interesting and worth a visit. Loved visiting the hospital in the rock and finding our about it's history. Amazing exhibits and we would go back if in Budapest again!

Think twice if you walk with a stick. If you know hospitals this is a must, and the guide is very good. However my husband walks with a stick and was more than uncomfortable with the uneven floors and lack of handrails.

Definitely worth a visit. had great time here last week. it was part of our day in the Castle Hill area. check out times of tours first so you can plan your time. tour guide was excellent (think her name was Timmy) and it's really well done. Bit cold b/c it's underground - lasts about an hour. we were without kids but kids would have really enjoyed.

Worth a tour!. We were so pleased we found this place-it's a little tricky to find! If you go to Matthias Church, stand with the Danube behind you, and walk towards the other side of the hill. You should see signs for The Hospital in the Rock, and you can take a lift or steps down to the street, turn right and then you're there! The tours seem to go more frequently in Summer so we only had to wait half an hour. You watch a film for about 10 minutes and then a guide takes you around the bunker. You can borrow an overcoat if you like- it's worth it as it gets quite cold in there! It's quite unbelievable how huge the bunker is- you walk through wide, well-lit tunnels which open onto many different sized rooms containing wax models of doctors and patients, as well as hospital beds, original old medical instruments and features. The guide was excellent, bringing the history of this amazing place to life in an interesting and informative way. You get a real impression of how it must have been to treat the wounded in such difficult circumstances but it doesn't feel too claustrophobic. Definitely worth a visit.

Intersting. We love to walk and explore while on holiday and on one of our days out we stumbled on this attraction, it was reasonably priced and if you are interested in the history of Budapest this makes for a nice way to spend an afternoon.

Rock History. Fantastic historical and medical experience in the rocks overlooking the majestic Danube river. For roughly 5UK pounds you get a fantastic informative tour and history lesson of the hospital built into the rock face. It tells you how and why it was built and how it was used under Nazi and Communist occupation. How the communists wanted it to be a nuclear bunker during the cold war. Well worth a visit.

Great tour, tons of history and information. This museum is definitely worth a visit for both young and old. The tours leave very frequently so one can arrive at anytime and catch a tour within a few minutes of wait time. Whilst waiting the entry has many interesting artifacts on display. The tour begins with a short movie which sets you in the mood. Once inside the tunnels you certainly get caught up in the atmosphere of what hospital life was like underground, and how under the most difficult circumstances they were able to take care of the sick and wounded. The wax figures and rooms are very well done, including some humorous scenes which add a lighthearted touch to the tour. Our tour guide was a mine of information and very friendly. She interacted with everyone on the tour and got us to interact with her as well. The length of time the tour takes is perfect, you are continuously moving so you never get museum legs ( swelling from very slowly moving through a museum). This museum is packed full of history and very interesting information. The taking of photographs is not allowed, but this does not detract from the tour in anyway. The tour guide takes a photograph of anyone who would like a souvenir picture, I find this a nice touch. You can find it later on the museums official website, under the "Visitors" tab.
amazing. Great museum!!!!!Interesting for all ages,the staff is very good and the guides were super!The hospital has a lot of history and we found unforgettable

Return to the past. A great history lesson.. It is one of the things that you must see in Budapest. We went there with our 6 year old kid and he also enjoyed it. It is one big history lesson conducted by a very cheerful and friendly girl guide tour. We saw all kind of stuff there. Surgery rooms, small kitchen, patience's rooms. There are tons of artifacts donated by the founder's family. He was the chief doctor of the place. We saw Nuclear Bunker with all the machinery and solutions in case of the nuclear attack. It was a great history lesson.

Interesting museum in Budapest. We booked a tour of the Hospital in the Rocks based on previous reviews of the Budapest area and were not disappointed at all. The guided tour of the former hospital was a delight as the tour guide spoke perfect english as she described the history of the hospital from when it started to the museum it is today. The tour is approximately one kilometer of walking on mainly level surface for about 50-60 minutes. If you are claustrophobic - it is not for you. Otherwise, you will be amazed that this was an actual working hospital.
You must see it. One of the most interesting sites in Central Europe. Great piece of history of the city underground. Recommendable with children from 10 years.

Well worth a visit. Literally a hospital built underneath castle hill during WW2, this unique museum is certainly worth a visit. 4000 Florints (2000 for under 25s or concessions) for an in-depth guided tour, which lasts an hour, is well worth the money. It's crazy to think that there were up to 600 wounded being treated in here at one point!

Great interesting museum hiding in plain sight. This was my 16 yr old son's choice and I almost didn't do it. I'm soooo glad we followed his lead! This was a wonderful surprise-super well done, very interesting, new information even I didn't know, and different from most other places. Great for kids to see and learn without going brain-dead. Very visual but not dumbed down. We all adored it and talked about it for ages. Must see.

A must visit. This is by far my favourite museum that I've visited in a while. The tour guide had great English and had loads of knowledge, even answering weird questions that would confuse the best of people. The museum is very reasonably priced with a discount people under 26 who live within EU countries. The tour lasted exactly an hour and didn't feel rushed at all. Everything feels very authentic and realistic. The only down side is not being able to take pictures.

Unsung heroes. Being a nurse myself, I was amazed by the heroic acts of these people. It must have been worse than a horror movie, with all the gore and blood. Very bad signage to find it, but well worth the visit.

Preservation of another tkme. The tour is really cool and worth while for anyone who is interested in WW II and Cold War history. It shows the ingenuity of the people to use their natural caves to their advantage, and to save lives. Only downside is no pictures are allowed! This is really a shame because the museum has many examples of original equipment and furnishings, as well as really well-done wax figurines. I'm not sure why they had this rule of no pictures, but it really disappointed me that I couldn't take away memories of this one-of-a-kind site.

A fascinating piece of history - well worth visitng. We were told about this most interesting place by a fellow traveller. It was a hospital in WWII and also actively used in the revolution of 1956. There are hour long tours in English as well and on the day we visited just 12 in our group of English speakers. It was a joy to escape the hundreds and hundreds of tourists visiting Budapest for the day from their riverboat cruse ships.

Guide in too much of a rush for her tea break. This has the potential to be an excellent attraction, with one proviso.The guides must give the visitors the time to look around each of the rooms after they have performed their spiel - and mine didn'tI was in a group of 20 (in the English language group), and as all the rooms are small a group of this size doesn't all fit into the room so some have to listen to the commentary from the outside. And the guide then marches the people at the front of tour to the next room and starts the commentary for that room whilst the people at the back are still looking at what's in the previous room.Either the guide has to wait for everyone to catch up, or they need to restrict the tour group sizes to a much smaller number (like 10). The people behind in the Hungarian language group had it much better, there was only three of them!And it's not like the guide has to be back within the hour for the next group, because as those at the back left she was in the corner chatting with her friends.Considering this is a premium priced attraction, I don't think this was good enough

History buffs' delight. A must-see for those interested in the intriguing, yet sad history of the region. The hospital built into the cave system underneath the gorgeous castle district served as a military and civilian hospital during World War II and as a nuclear-safe bunker during the Cold War. Despite the funky and sometimes gruesome wax figures better suited to a Halloween horror display than a museum, the English language tour is informative and wandering through this underground labyrinth helps bring to life some of the challenges and deprivations the city's populace suffered both during WWII and later, while part of the Soviet Block.

Very surreal. Impressive tour!. A very monumental step back in time whereby everything is as it was. Perfectly preserved. It was very haunting to walk the walls of those who were saved and those who died. I don't think there is anything like this in the entire world.

Nice attraction. some surgical instruments showed, old electro and some waxed figures. We were lucky met with a knowledgeable guide who explain every details of the building. Totally worth visit to everyone

A must see. We were about to wander round the castle district and see the museums but saw this place had their first tour at 10am. It was easy to find and a great place to visit. Very interesting with knowledgeable guides. A must see in Budapest

an hour well spent. For starters, it's a little more pricey than other museums at 4000F but that comes with the mandatory tour guide. The tour through the bunker lasts for about an hour which includes a <10 mins introductory video. The tour navigates you through the vast network of tunnels, showing how the hospital developed to meet changing needs, both in terms of rising casualties and it's ability to protect itself from a new threat, that of nuclear.You can't take photos here but try to stay close to the guide. I was stuck at the very back but with the next group following close behind, you can't always hear your guide.

valuable insight into the war hosptial. We gave the visit to a try after reading interesting reviews it turned out to an unique experience beside the the normal sighting scenes at Budapest. It shows the history of how these unknown health workers who performed many self sacrificing duties to save countless of injuries and it really touched our hearts.

Very interesting museum. This is a recommended place to see. If you are at the Fisherman's Bastion the walk here is less than 5 mins. The tour is about 1 hour and is hosted in different languages. This is a popular place so if you are planning on a tour I suggest turning up 10-15 mins prior to get your spot or you might end up waiting. Very well done and good tour guides get you the full story.

Incredibly informative and unique tour. Stumbled across this by accident when we saw it coming up on Google Maps and were intrigued to find out more. This ended up being our favourite museum in Budapest because it not only gave a good history of the city, but also was just so unique and a great use of the cave system that was already there. The tour guides were very helpful giving a brilliant explanation of the spaces, history and how the use had changed over time. Tip - have some food and drink beforehand as you can't have any during the tour and does take a bit over an hour
One of the hidden sites on the Buda side. This was a great historical and fun site to see if you love military history. Many people are not aware of it, so it is not crowded.

Best Tour In Budapest!. I'm so glad we went on this tour and I would urge anybody visiting the city to do the same. It gives you a real incite into how this hospital functioned during the war!First you watch a short video which is very interesting and then the tour begins.Our guide was very friendly, spoke great English and was very knowledgeable. The whole experience really opens your eyes to how things were and going through the hospital I found was just Incredible.A bit more expensive compared to other things to do in Budapest but you will never see anything like this again and I highly recommend a visit!

Extremely Crowded and HOT. Good place to visit to learn about the hospital built underground in a cave during the wars. Very informative.During our visit in May it was so crowded, the back of the group could not see or hear the tour guide. There must have been at least 30 in our group. Multiple groups were touring at the same time.

Great for history. I found this a fascinating exhibit and it also makes me very thankful for our current medical facilities. Our guide was lovely and it was a fascinating place to learn about broader Hungarian history. Well worth a visit. Tours run for 1 hour on the hour. Try to get to the front for the initial video as we were at the back and I could not read the subtitles which was annoying.
Informative . One hour tour in fairly small groups. A quick movie before the tour was quite helpful. Cold, so dress warmly. Wish the guides made more time for a Q&A session at end.

Great out of the way tour - Tour Guide Outstanding. If you are looking for an hour tour of a underground hospital used during WWII and Soviet time this is for you. The hour long tour is ~$15.00 USD and certainly worth your time and funds. The tour guide spoke superb English and discussed some topics that might be a little sensitive as to relations with Hungarian neighbors but kept the discussion factual and entertaining.

Fascinating Medical Treatment in the Cave Systems. Very well organised, run by some fantastic for guides who spoke perfect English. Well worth the cost of £1.50 each adult! You explore the hospital side first then the cold war bunker side second. Lots of medical artifacts. Hard to image setting this up during World War II and then putting it to use again during the Hungarian Revolution.

excellent. Wel worth visiting, enjoyable tour with guide. Amazing tunnels under ' the Rock' and there are more there not in use by this museum. Fully knitted out from 1940's to 1960's, inginious in its time, and thought provoking. Knowledgable guide and great 'dummies' of the people who worked there and were patients. Enjoyed this , also learning more of Budapest past.

Unique. A great attraction for those looking to learn something about hungarian history. They have an English tour on the hour and at a reduced price of £6 I felt this was more than reasonable for the tour. The tourguide was great and knew lots of information about the bunker. It was lovely to get a feel of how the caves were used as an advantage for the hungarians throughout the war and after as well. The tour takes an hour with plenty of time given to look around as you go.

Interesting visit!. I really enjoyed our little visit to the Hospital in the Rock. As the weather was looking to turn and I had already seen great reviews on Trip Advisor, my boyfriend and I came to the museum after lunch. A lot of people had had the same idea so the initial video screening room was packed full but after that, once we were divided into our 'language' groups then the tour went smoothly and I must say that our guide was an absolute ray of sunshine! She was great, she spoke clearly and knew her stuff! The hospital in the rock is really distinctive as a museum, an experience worth having, especially if you're not someone who enjoys the usual layout of museum visits.

Museum of recent history. A guided tour of a cold war bunker situated under Budapest, the museum provided a good contrast to the surrounding historic museums and an overview of the city's recent political history.

Interesting historical landmark!. Interesting Museum depicting life during WWII and the Soviet invasion in the 1950's. Easy to imagine life during these historical times through the well spoken guide. A must for historical buffs!

Interesting museum. After reading the many positive reviews I decided that I had to try this museum. Did I like it? Yes and no. Do I think it is worth the money? Probably yes. By visiting the museum you learn the story of the first hospital in the rocks in Budapest: how it was built, why and how important it was during the second world. There are wax statues which are very moving and the guide was incredibly knowledgeable and helpful. The only downside is that the place is small and the visit ends quickly

Amazing. . My partner and I went to hospital in the rock last week. If you travel to Budapest you have to go here as the history here is amazing. Absolutely genius how they use to run this we were both amazed by it. We didn't know that the tours run every hour and we luckily got on the tour so be aware of that. Also if you are under 25 and part of the EU you can get a discount. Also take a jacket. Such a fascinating place would love to go back and do it again.
Definitely worth seeing!. Tour guide was wonderful - super enthusiastic and knowledgeable and her English was perfect. A really interesting history. Learned a lot. :)

Fantastic . Very well organised, ran by some fantastic for guides - ours was Bori who did a great job, very informative! An hour long for for £1.50 each adult! You explore the hospital side first then the cold war bunker side second. Lots of artifacts, very interesting, kept moving so not boring at all, loved it!

Interesting Tour, lots of history. Very cool experience to see the history of such a unique place. Tour was very detailed and took you through a lot of the rooms. Lots of setups to show how it looked when it was operating. Not too far out of the way and well worth it.

Interesting trip into history. The Hospital in the Rock is a little hard to find, but worth the effort. From the Matthias church, you go across the top of Buda Hill, to the back wall. Then take the stairs or the elevator to the street below, turn right and walk about 100 yards. If you look up and see a statue of what looks like a naked Nazi, you're going in the right direction.

Weirdly Interesting!. I went to the Hospital in the Rock with a friend while we were visiting Budapest, and it was surprisingly fun! The whole place is kinda creepy, and there is a weird vibe, but I think that has something to do with it being an underground hospital. You have to go on a guided tour, you are not allowed to walk around alone or else you may get lost in the tunnels. Our guide was really informative, and I learned a lot about Hungarian history and WWII. There were also wax figures everywhere imitating people who once inhabited the hospital. It sounds like a weird place to visit, but I would certainly recommend it!

Great Tour!. This tour was one of the best tour I did in Budapest. The tour guide knew the fact behind the hospital and had a great sense of humor.This tour is a great way to see what life was like during WWii.make sure you know what time the tour starts as when we went it was every hour.Highly recommended
Very good exhibit. This was an amazing exhibit. Very realistic displays. Reminds me of the Cabinet War Room in London. Really makes you appreciate what the Hungarian people experienced in WW2

Great Piece of History. A friend wanted to see this so we tagged along and are so glad we didn't! It is situated in the Buda Castle region so it should be added to your must see list. Used as both a hospital and converted to a nuclear shelter, it is wonderfully furnished with genuine equipment, it is hard to imagine how they functioned under siege in such a place.

Very good guide and interesting museum!. This was a great visit!! The young man at the cashier desk was very knowledgeable and spoke very fluent English- very helpful in the purchase of our tickets. Our tour began at 1:00 p.m., and our guide was wonderful !! One tip- the first part of the tour , you go into a tiny room to watch a short film. The subtitles are in English and are at the bottom of the screen- so be sure to sit in the first or second row or you won't be able to read any of it. We sat in the fourth row and couldn't read any of it- but that is a minor part of the tour. Also, stay close to the guide so you will be able to get into the room to see what she is talking about. The people in the displays are very life like - you do a double take as they look so realistic. It is an excellent museum- so glad we went.

A wonderful tour!. We visited this fascinating place with our two children aged 7 and 11 and we all enjoyed it immensely.The history of he caves are of interest to people of all ages but what makes the visit so good are the delightful staff that work here. They are so energetic and welcoming and the knowledge they have to share is fascinating.Would highly recommend.

One of Better Attractions in Budapest!. This place is definitely underrated! It doesn't have the panache of Castle Hill, but it's more enlightening and entertaining than many of the other sites we visited in Budapest. Admission includes a guided tour, which helps make the exhibits come alive. It's a very unusual part of history, and a great way to learn about Budapest in the waning months of WWII and beyond.

Excellent History Lesson. Was well educated in Hungarian history as well as entertained on this excellent experiential visit. Guides were knowledgable and Spoke perfect English. Would highly recommend.

Caves with history. The museum is the system of natural caves inside the castle hill transformed to a safe hospital during the VWII. During the cold war the hospital was rebuilt to a nuclear bunker, at the 1956 uprising the hospital was used again.Before the visit I supposed it is a big underground hall or something like a wine cellar, but it is quite different: many smaller "rooms" connected with long corridors.It is an interesting part of Budapest and also of Hungarian history.

Not great. The tour felt rushed and possibly oversold. A tour in a tunnel was always going to be a tight fit but often people would miss out on the guides talk/info if towards the back of the group, which was often. Not much time to look around or read up on the historical information displayed before being dragged away to a different area.

Although expensive, this is a must see. The price looks a bit on the high side, but the place is totally worth your money. You are taken deep inside the hospital/shelter complex and learn a lot about its history. They've set up a lot of wax figures and you can see a wide variaty of medical instruments and medicines from WW2.

Crowded and rushed guided tour for an expensive museum. We went there during the Easter bank holiday and I think there were too many people. I think it was not fair that they were keeping selling tickets when they did not have enough guides. Also, the timetable was a bit messy, as they were having tour every half an hour and sometimes every hour. When our tour started they wasted long time sorting out how to divide the people into two groups with lots of waiting and disorganization. When finally we started the tour the group was still quite big that it was easy to miss the tour guide words and also have enough time to look at things. You have to follow the guide and every time she was saying "have you got any questions" nobody actually had questions to ask because most of the people were too far to hear what she was saying. The idea of the museum is very good and if it is not crowded I think it is an interesting and valuable museum. However, I learned more at the House of Terror which also costs half the money we paid for the Hospital in the Rock. They are two different experiences but with the House of Terror you can spend your own time to learn about the backgrounds to the events while with the Hospital you should already know what happened. I think they should also have a better customer service especially for the price they charge that is above the average museum in Budapest.
Worth the visit!. Very interesting tour and interesting displays showing how life in this hospital was like. Almost impossible to imagine what people had to endure through those times !

Amazing tour. This tour was probably the best tour I did in Budapest as we had an amazing guide who was very informative and funny! The actual place itself is amazing and you take away so much knowledge. The only thing is that there needs to be more signage pointing to the place as it's pretty hard to find!!!

Good tour, although it was abit rushed. This is a very interesting window on the history f Budapest and the wider war conflicts and cold war.The tour starts with a short video explaining the place and setting the scene.On the occasion of our visit there was a big crowd and we were split in to two. It appeared to be a busy day as there was lots of people around.Our guide was very keen to keep the tour very orderly and was a bit abrupt in ensuring this happened.There waslimited time to linger and experience the place and there is no capacity to view without a guide. We visited this museum as part of a day on the Buda side of the Danube visiting the sites.This is a very interesting window on the history f Budapest and the wider war conflicts and cold war.The tour starts with a short video explaining the place and setting the scene.On the occasion of our visit there was a big crowd and we were split in to two. It appeared to be a busy time of day as there was lots of people around.Our guide was very keen to keep the tour very orderly and was a bit abrupt in ensuring this happened.There was limited time to linger and experience the place and there is no capacity to view without a guide. I would suggest trying to come at a quieter time and you may get a little longer to experience the tour and even ask questions.It is still worth a visit even at the relatively experience price of 4000HUF each.

Very exciting. As beeing Hungarian, I didn't even hear about the museum for a long time. On a boring day we just decided to take a trip into the caves, which was really exciting! Visitors get sometimes shocking informations, how our ancestors survived that terrible war. It is a must to see!

Another brick in the wall. If you are trying to piece together the recent past history (from WWII on) this is a fascinating look at Budapest from 1939 forward. But do the Terror Museum first. Best to piece things together understanding the sociopolitical history. I'm a WWII person so this was a cool visit. An hour well spent.

Great museum. You are taken on a tour through the museum, it was great and the tour guide was excellent, both funny and informative.
The tour gave an insight into how the hospital was run in both the second world war and the 1956 revolution.

Interesting. We chose this museum, because we are intersted in history. Tour starts every hour and they show you the whole hospital complex. Everything was good, we only maybe wanted a little bit more about overall history, bunker and less about the hospital. Overall it was intersting and would go back.
Unfortunatly you are not allowed to take pictures.

A great way to spend an hour. We joined the English tour and were enthralled for every minute. We learnt so much about life in Budapest during WW2 and the Cold War. The wards, operating theatres, lengthy corridors, kitchens etc were very well preserved with wax figures adding an extra dimension to authenticity.

Very interesting medical museum. To visit the museum, you must join the guided tour which start every hour. The tour would start with a video then walking through the tunnel to different chambers. The guide speak good English and the description was informative and interesting. It is amazing to see those medical instruments in the old days and to get to know how they manage to run a small hospital and get through the difficult situation they encountered during the war time. Photograph is not allowed during the tour but they offered to take a photo for the entire tour group near the end of the tour. A must see if you are interested in war and medical stuffs. And don't forget to check out the shop for the old days glass syringe. I got a few as souvenir for my colleagues and they are very happy about it.

Surprising experience. We weren't planning to visit but somehow got in the area and it just seemed too interesting to pass. And I'm so glad we decided to go in! It was like a time capsule, a collection of stories, items and events. The guide was knowledgeable and friendly and the whole 1-hour experience is well worth it. Highly recommend it!

Very interesting tour, but a little bit rushed. A really interesting look "behind the scenes" of two of Budapest darkest eras, WW2 and the 1956 revolution, and the role that the hospital (and later, fallout bunker) played. There were a great number of exhibits throughout which we passed during the tour, and to be honest we'd have needed twice as long to read all the information attached, so it all felt a little rushed. The "worst" part was being told there were another 10 kilometres of tunnels behind some of the doors; understandably they weren't open to the public, but it would have added a little to the "feel" of the place if we could see them at least, particularly as some of them were used as "overflow" when the wards/corridors of the hospital were filled during the siege of Budapest.  Very interesting, however, and well worth a visit.

Very interesting. Situated beneath the caverns of the Buda Castle, we came across this Hospital in the Rock... Only a portion of the long and winding hospital museum was shown, its details were carefully reenacted with waxed figures, some with 'blood', surgical instruments, older electrocautery, anesthesia and suction machines among others were displayed in an operating room/theatre.

Good place to visit. This attraction is really worth visiting to discover the wartime history of the cityThe guides speak good English and answer all questions with knowledge Good exhibits and lots of original bandage packs and surgical instruments

Great tour, learnt a lot about the history of Hungary.. This visit was on our bucket list before we arrived and I was glad we went. We learnt a lot about the history of Hungary however I was disappointed we did not see all the caves. The guide spoke good English. One tip though, if you buy a pass on the hop on buses you get a book of vouchers and this tour is included at a discounted rate.
History buff event. I really enjoyed hearing the history of this place, both during WWII time and the Cold War. The wax figures helped to bring it to life to visualize how it functioned.

Well laid out museum but poorly described. The underground hospital during the war and the 1956 revolution. We were about 40 plus people with one guide and in this narrow confined area it was difficult to hear the guide and insufficient time to read the information. A shame because it has the potential to be excellent.

Bp. 1. Kerület. It is a very interesting program, if you visit Budapest and you interesting about history or medical. It is a guided tour in hungarian or english language. With a lot of figure like in Madame Tussaud . We can listen a lot of interesting information about how worked this hospital during the 20th century. So i thing it is a unmissing programe in Bp!

Great Tour Underground. Easy to find if you've been to the hill in castle district, a 5 minute walk from the Mathias church. A very interesting tour of the many rooms and hallways of the old hospital. Our guide had interesting stories to tell about the inhabitants, how the bunker was used and the history. A must visit if into WW2 history!

One of the incredible sites in Budapest. Being used during the times of World War II, the revolution of 1956 and as an atomic bunker in the Cold War, this is a very interesting place to go and gather a lot of information. The exhibition is wonderfully enriched with wax works, replica of accessoiries and original material from these times.You can actually imagine the oppressiveness when walking through the caves and comprehend the distress that must have been due to lack of space, resources and sanitation.Walking through is almost like a little labyrinth.

A Fascinating and Unique Museum. I've known about this museum for a number of years and finally got around to seeing it. Being someone who enjoys being underground, it naturally appealed to me. I would like to address some of the complaints that have been levelled against the museum.1. It's a cave. It will smell musty.2. My experience with the staff was they were both friendly and passionate about the space and the spirit in which the hospital was run.3. Yes they speak English with an accent, the whole country does. Live with it.4. The museum is not a wax works. If you are spending time looking at the figures and not listening to the story, you are missing the point. The fact that they are not perfect adds to the experience in my mind.5. It was a hospital which operated during Hungary's darkest times. I think they have remained politically neutral, as did the hospital during its operation.6. You didn't like the red dye that was representing blood in the operating theatre? I don't even know what to say....Here's my opinion: A great adventure into the past. Culturally important. Structurally fascinating. Well presented. The tour guide was knowledgable without making the subject matter too dry. Good job.

Very interesting visit.. I really enjoyed this visit. Firstly, because it was the first time that I gad been into a hospital built inside a Rock. Secondly, this hospital was used during WWII and 2 months in 1956. Thirdly, one can see the medical instruments used by that time. Finally, one gets to know how doctors and nurses got provisions...everything they needed it from St John's hospital by risking their lives.

Learn something of what its like struggling to survive in Central Europe.. The caves under Budapest Castle were used as a hospital during ww2 and again during the 1956 revolotion against the Russian invasion. They have also been kitted out as a fairly ineffective nuclear bunker. Walking through the caves you see hospital wards, kichens etc. You can see how crowded, lack of water, ventilation ... The guided tour contains a clear account of this troubled history. At several points I was surprised at how we know the basic facts and feel some sympathy for the Hungarian people, but I hadn't appreciated it from their point of view - for example being under threat of nuclear attack from America while also occupied by Russia.The tour starts every hour on the hour.

Incredible . We searched high and low to try and find the location of the hospital in the rock... And it was definitely worth the hunting as it was one of the biggest gems of our trip :) extremely interesting and very enthusiastic tour guides. We had a male called Lori and he was amazing! Thanks for having us :)
Hospital. In the Rock. Wonderful tour outlining the role this hospital played during the siege of Budapest and the Hungarian revolution.

A must see in Budapest!. We did the guided tour and it was amazing! It makes you feel like you are in the 40's! The tour lasts one hour and they only have it in English or Hungarian. It is a bit overpriced (4000 HUF) but we got the students' discount (2000 HUF).

Very interesting tour, a must do if you're interested in Hungarian and Eastern Europe history.. A hospital and Nuclear bunker in one, guided tour through the endless tunnels of the hospital. Great explanation in English and very good prices. Tours normally start at the beginning of each hour.

Really fascinating place in Buda Castle District!. Amazing place build into the rock face from many intersecting caves. Would highly recommend if interested in the history of Budapest and hospital uses during historical sieges! We had an excellent tour guide who took us from room to room and provided descriptions of each. Make sure you check on a map before venturing over there. I would also recommend stopping just short of the hospital as you walk down the hill and having an explore of the labyrinth caves on your right.

A really interesting look at the Cold War from the other side. A really good guided tour and exhibition that all the family got something out of.Unlike Berlin, the post-1945 history of Budapest isn't immediately obvious. Without the signs, the Museum of Terror would be just another building, and the Hospital in the Rock Nuclear Bunker Museum is tucked around the back of the Castle and you wouldn't find it unless you were specifically looking for it.The guided tour is essential and the guides are excellent. All the guides we met were multi-lingual and spoke English and a number of other European languages fluently. In addition to the guides, the hospital is set up with a range of dioramas with wax figures that really help show how it was used and operated. A fascinating exhibition and well worth seeing.

Interesting. We joined the tour and watched a short film before hand and then took the tour. Our guide was lovely and very informative. It leaves one admiring the strength of people and the goodness of people helping each other out in times of strife and trouble. One has to admire the hard and excellent work they did in the hospital under which must have been horrendous conditions at times. A good way to spend a couple of hours.

I had no idea.... ...that Hungary had such a fascinating history. The Hospital in the Rock is a must see for any visitor to Budapest who has even the slightest interest in history, especially WWII and the cold war. The English language tour starts on the hour every hour, and you can't go in on your own, so it's best to get here just before the hour so you can buy tickets. It's 4000fts which was a little more than we expected (Hungary is pretty cheap, after all) but it's well worth it. It starts with a 10 minute video, and I wondered what the hell we'd signed up for, but stick with it! Your guide will take you through the underground tunnels where you'll see operating rooms and wards as well as the machinery that keeps the place going. The only slight niggle we had was that the group was quite large and some of the people who ended up at the back couldn't hear the guide and started their own (noisy and disruptive) conversations. That's not really the fault of the tour guide or the venue, just people being annoying!
Very interesting. I liked this museum really a lot. For me it is one of the best/ most interesting things to visit in Budapest. Wax figures give a real picture of how it worked.

Very Interesting. Interesting tour(check online for times in your preferred language)I was apprehensive as I'm claustrophobic and hate lifts,locked doors etc,but no worries, all on one level,open,not very restricted in any area,so go ahead if you don't mind tunnels built into rockAs mentioned in other reviews,you need to keep up with the tour leader to make sure you hear everything

Fascinating place. Went on the tour - English speaking guide who was very informative. interesting history of the hospital and a fascinating insight into the cold war era when it was a nuclear bunker.
An interesting experience. We learned a lot, plus adorable tour guide plus creepy wax figures, Geiger counters, Cold War nuclear bunker....what's not to love?!
Fascinating!. Very interesting place to visit, with an excellent guided tour. Well worth the visit, and certainly a must visit place on a visit to Budapest.

Interesting Place with a rich history!. The tour doesn't disappoint. Well worth the money to walk through and see the actual bunker of the hospital even though it looks like a museum inside as they replicated the hospital look. Had the opportunity to try out the siren in the bunker as well! I learnt a lot from the well versed tour guides that were able to communicate in english! Under 26 yo, gets a subsidized price for the tour.

An interesting look into Hungary's past. We went to the bunker on the 13th April, our group was quite large. There were so many interesting different stories and historical items, and we loved our visit :) You can also use an air raid siren which my boyfriend volunteered for - a lot of fun!

Really interesting. We were advised of the Hospital in the Rock when we bought our tickets for Mathias Church which included a 10% discount - upon arriving however the assistant also pointed out that there's a larger discount for under 26's & over 70s are free making this great value.This is tours only and you walk round with a group and your tour guide.You will learn the history of the hospital with wax dummies and real props - very interesting.

Charming time capsule. Just the highlight of my trip. Saw cool medical and wartime history both. Bring a jacket. Great evening choice to combine with a Buda walk and bastion view when the city is closed for the night.
Really cool. An incredibly interresting experience. Tours every hour, reasonable price (4000HUF for an adult, 2000 if you are under 26), great guides that speak excellent English.
Hidden gem. Great tour through the hidden hospital, tour guide was very informative, great displays. Small group on the tour so was easy to see all the displays would recommend.
Facsinating place. Learn about what happened in WW2, the Russian occupation, the 1956 up rising and during the cold war. Most interesting and informative.

Well worth the entrance fee. Decided to visit after noticing a discount on the entry fee with our Budapest card and reading reviews on TA. The hourly tours take you around the underground hospital facility used during the Second World War and siege of Budapest. Our guide Nikki was extremely knowledgeable, speaking perfect English and taught is about the history of the hospital and how it's use changed from its initial construction. An excellent way to spend an hour or so in the safest place in the city.

Hourly Tours. Lots of discount available.. Located on Buda with metro access, this will take you just over an hour. There are so many ways to get discount here, (Budapest card, being a teacher, under 26, over 62...) So check out the website and plan in advance. There is free WiFi, toilets and snack food to buy. This is a tour-only activity which is included in the price and leave on the hour, every hour. Tour guides speak English (plus other languages), but depending on who you get will depend on how good their English is. No photos allowed inside and a free locker for bags. You watch a 9 minute introduction video before your guide takes you away.You will explore the history of the hospital and how it changed into a bunker. They have replicated scenes in each room with wax dummies and real props, at the end you have the chance to use an air siren. Only downside is that there's not much time to read posters or stop and look at each room before the guide moves on, but as we saw, our guide finished with us and took the next group in straight after. It would help if you had an idea of Hungarian history during the war to help you piece together the story of the hospital/bunker. Finally, there are frequent steps and low ceilings. Suitable for wheelchairs/prams and children if they don't mind wax figures or loud noises.If you want to experience the 'natural' part of this cave system, the labyrinth attraction isn't far from here as the bunker/hospital is only the renovated section. There is 10km of cave in total, the bunker/hospital is 1km of that.

A piece of fascinating history. Visiting this museum reveals a very interesting series of underground caves used as a hospital on two separate occasions and then turned into a bunker in case of nuclear attack. All presented in a very compelling way. Definitely worth a visit.

Interesting information relating to wars and Hungarian history. Exactly what it says: this is a tour around a hospital (and nuclear bunker) in a rock (under the palace grounds). It's tour only which start every hour on the hour but reasonably priced and very informative. They have set up the exhibitions well and our guide was excellent. Lots of original artefacts and a good perspective on how it was used through the years. A nice touch was being able to try an air raid siren at the end!

Amazing place to visit. This museum was a great place to visit on my partner and I's trip to Budapest. We got there just as it opened and got a personal guide tour of the hospital. Fascinating and eye opening

Passed an entertaining couple of hours on a rainy morning. An interesting and well run little museum based around a real working hospital with a fascinating history. Through world war 2 and the cold war there is much to see and wonder at. We had a stimulating visit on a rainy morning and it is well worth finding a little time to see this curious little time piece

Fantastic insight to part of Budapest's history. We took the English tour. Our guide was knowledgeable and easy to hear. The tour takes you right down into the wards and operating theater. Very well presented. Maybe the guide could've gone a bit more slowly, we would have like to linger and look at some of the exhibits at our leisure. But well worth the visit. If you're under 26 or over 60 you get a discount.
a must see in the city!. If you are that kind of people who like medicine and history go here! A guide will explain you all the details about the museum during 1 hour. Totally worth a visit!

Totally worth a visit. This was number one on my to do list as I was fascinated to understand what it would include and I wasn't disappointed! No pictures allowed and rooms are set with dummies in positions however it doesn't take anything away at all, you can totally imagine what it was like during the war and resistance and also get a good feel of what it would have been like should a nuclear war break out. Moving stories of staff and patients and even babies being born. Well worth the visit

Historically very relevant and interesting. I went there with my girlfriend, we enjoyed the tunnels and the information given to us by the lady that was guiding us. A lot of interesting facts about how the place was used in the 30's, 40's and 50's. It was really fascinating to see and imagine how things were in war times...This is truly great for someone who is interested in history in general and especially in Hungarian history

Fun and informative. Informative and fun tour. Our guide, Milan, was a great storyteller - mixing relatively unknown historical anecdotes with humorous asides. The museum is very close to the Fisherman's bastion too so if you have time to kill check that out as well.

Mind your head!. A great insight into Hungarian history without really realising it! Informative and entertaining, the guides take you from WW2 to the communist era in less than an hour with a few enjoyable twists on the way.

Interesting and very friendly staff. This was a very interesting museum and I learnt a lot about the role of Hungary in WW2. Lots of wax figures!It cost 2000 forints for myself as I am under 26 - the price goes up a little for those over 26. You have to pay this for the tour - you're not allowed to go in without a tour. Our tour guide was very friendly and knowledgeable, and the tour lasted around an hour.

An interesting insight into their war history. An interesting tour and worth spending the hour or so there, with tours only at certain times it may be worth timing your arrival so not to sit around for too long waiting but they're regular enough and interesting to see how they coped. The air raid siren at the end will bring the child out in every adult

Really Interesing Tour. Really enjoyed this tour. Loads of information from good guides and displays are excellent. Wax figures and historic equipment very good. Teachers go free on tour - should really be nurses! Plenty of nice cafe's about if you need to wait for the next guided tour.
Fascinating insight into history. It was a thrilling and a bit creepy travel back to this World War II era hospital. Fascinating insight into history.

Good to Know a Brief Histor of War in Budapest. The visit inside the Hospital is only carried out by a tour with a guide. Each tour lasts for 60 mins and it starts every hour. There is a limit of customer number in each group.I was glad to have Lori as our guide - his explanation was clear & well summarised. It didn't sound so preachy either, which is a good touch.It was a bit disappointing that no photos & videos are allowed but understandable in order to organise a smooth flow of a tour.I'd have bought a guide book with colour pictures if they had one, but it seemed they don't publish one.Overall, worth visiting.

Unique museum. I visited with my girlfriend in the last open hour. I feared that the museum will be just a shock attraction like the House of Terror, but was pleasently surprised.The wax figures are great and some of them made us smile or have a comment, which lightened the mood between us and the guide (Zsofi, who was great).I gave 4 and not 5 stars because of 2 things:1 hour is really not enough. There were a lot of things we did not have the time to inspect/read. 1 and a half hour would be more suitable I think.The price. Although I am aware that the upkeep cost of such an underground place must be costly, it is still pricey for the average hungarian. For the 7200 Ft price of 2 tickets for you and your (girl)friend, you could visit the Museum of Ethnography, have a walk in the Botanical Garden and after that still have money to visit the Planetarium which would be a full day of tourism instead of a 1 hour guided tour. I do not claim it is not reasonably priced, only saying if you have a limited budget it is a far stretch to visit the Hospital in the Rock.There is a saying "you have to see the House of Terror at least once in your life", I would rather recommend switching that experience for the Hospital in the Rock.

Fascinating Historical Site. My daughter and I were here recently and were lucky enough to get our own private tour. This is a 25,000 -square-foot labyrinthine network of hospital and fallout-shelter corridors built during the mid-20th century. This complex only opened its door to tourists not too long ago. First we were shown a short video and then we were brought through the underground tunnels to see room after room of perfectly preserved WWII medical supplies and equipment, mostly still in working order. There are more than 200 wax figures throughout depicting what the hospital rooms were like. My daughter being a nursing student found it particularly interesting to see the circumstances and the environment that the medical staff had to work in underground. This is a must see historical site.

Worth a visit.. Definitely worth a visit. Guided tour takes 1 hour total. Amazing to see the conditions they had to endure during WW2. Also scary to see the preparations being done on the Soviet side during the Cuban Missile Crisis.
Where is the hospital?. It has the potential to be much more if there was more info in English the price is a bit dear for what you get to enjoy in English. It is mainly targeted for Hungarians.

Interesting nuclear refugee and hospital.. The place has been an hospital since before the II World war. The museum show the history and evolution of this hospital until nowadays. I specially recommend to go if you are interested in the sanitary field as they have old surgical instruments, machines..., also if you are interested in history or army in general.

History of Budapest!!. These is a good experience to get to know one part of Budapest history. These place is for who love history, military, science, geology, because the hospital/nuclear bunker is hidden in a part of a 10.000 km of cave system.

Interesting historical snapshot of hospitals in times of war. The tour starts out with an approx 8min video on the history of the hospital; the video is in Hungarian and has English subtitles but if you're not sitting in the first two rows or standing at the back, you won't be able to enjoy anything but the footageYou're then split into tour groups by language (English and Hungarian) for your trip through the hospital.The tour starts in the hospital wing, with original equipment, original-era supplies and over 200 wax figures bringing the scenes to life. It then progresses somewhat oddly into an exhibition on Hungarian SF with an actual chopper! Finally, it moves into the 'machinery' area, including the decontamination areas for nuclear/chemical attack.The tour guides are quite good, the original and era items combine well with the wax figurines to give perspective and the cave system itself is quite interesting.An odd little sojourn from the other historical tours and museums in the Castle district but quite worth the visit...

Realistic and sad. If you think you have a lot of problems in your everyday life, visite this site and you will see you have nothing to worry about. Nicely presented, well equiped, sad and realistic... I would take my children to see that, when they could understand it.

Care Underground. The hospital in the rock was worth visiting. It takes you through a lybrinth of underground tunnels all turned into hospital during the war. The recreation of the patients and the doctors and the nurses makes the place come alive with the scene that took place during the war. Our lady guide was excellent explaining all the details of the place that added to the charm of the place. There are some fun activities like trying to blow the siren using the old contraption of device that produces wind through a manual rotating fan that in turn produces the siren.
Very interesting!. Anyone in the medical field should see this. Amazing what they had to deal with--poor air circulation, few supplies, crowded wards.
Interesting visit. Although the tour was an hour I felt a little more time to view the exhibits would have been nice, but overall a very interesting visit.

Incredible place to visit.
