This is truly an incredible place to visitIt is not easy to find but you shouldThe price for a "museum" is on the high side but when you enter it you will understand why.The tour guide was absolutely fantastic - she gave a superb description of what was going on.If you want to have a feel of history during the past 70 years (war and cold war) then this is a place that you should visit

A must see. Arrived at opening time to find large group at reception and guide politely asked if we could come back for 1100 tour , this was no problem and turned out to be better sized group for the small passages, very interesting tour with knowledgeable guide ,

Really interesting and great service. We booked this attraction for a school group. Our plane was delayed so we were late arriving, but the staff here were really flexible and positive. The guided interactive visit really gripped the pupils' attention and proved an excellent start to our school trip to Budapest. Friendly and engaging guides, highly recommended.

Quite an interesting place. This bunker was a key stronghold in WW2 and during the Cold War and the history behind it is fascinating, this bunker was classified as Secret until 2002 whereby the Government had opened it up to the public.This is a great place to spend an hour if you like a little history. The tours are every hour and there are two groups, one in Hungarian and one in English. The only downside would be that you have to go around with the group and are not free to roam about yourself so you are a little rushed and if the group is big you have to squeeze yourself around to see things.Just a little tip if you have a Budapest Travel Card then you get a discount on your entry.
Very fascinating . What a fascinating place! Amazing to think it was still in use 60 years ago! Excellent guide - she was so enthusiastic and knowledgeable. Very well done. Definitely worth a visit

Very intersting visit. This is well worth a visit. The tour guides are very knowledgeable and it is unlike anywhere we have visited before. Make sure that you book though as the tours leave at certain times and it was getting pretty busy while we were there. It's also just down from the castle area so you could do both in the same day.

fascinating glimpse into a unique aspect of WWII. This bunker built into the limestone hills of Buda served as a fully functioning wartime hospital during WWII. Great tour guides. Really interesting and well presented. Not for the claustrophobic!

Interesting. I'd highly recommend spending an hour of your time in Budapest at the Hospital in the Rock.Tours are guided and last around an hour. Our guide was very informative with a bit of humour chucked in too.Life in the hospital is re-created using wax models. They really give a sense of how grim things must have been during the war.Unexpectedly, there's even a helicopter inside the bunker.

Hidden gem.. If you want to experience a different type of museum this may be the answer. Essentially this is an interconnected series of caves below Buda Castle hill which was turned into an underground hospital in the 1930's. It subsequently saw action during the siege of Budapest in 1944/45, the Hungarian revolution in 1956, and the height of the Cold War. You can only experience this installation on a one hour guided tour. The tour itself takes in numerous original exhibits and our guide certainly knew his facts. A memorable and thought provoking look at fairly recent history.

Definitely worth a visit . It might be a little of the beaten track but this was my favourite attraction in Budapest! You can only go round as part of a tour which run in English on the hour. Our guide was very knowledgeable and she spoke exceptional English. If you're under 26 you get a 50% discount, but make sure you have your ID on you to prove it! Lots to see with exhibits spanning WW2, the Hungarian Uprising and Cold War, including original medical equipment and a nuclear decontamination bunker.

A must see . It's a very interesting museum in a cave some was used as a hospital during the ww II. It was well equipped for war injuries and it has also a part of nuclear bunker. They have guidet tours in English and Spanish. It is not allowed to take pictures inside. I paid 4000 huf for an ordinary tycket and was worth it. The only downside of the visit was the pretty large group of people but the guide was very careful to get herself heard of everyone so she made the best of it.

Place with a lot of history. If they focused on hospital exhibition and nuclear bunker, it would be an excellent place with a lot of interesting exhibits and thrilling details from last century's 40s, 50s and 60s. No idea why suddently, in the middle of the tour you get to see a military helicopter and hear a story of Hungarian NATO soldiers saving an American in Afghanistan? It simply does not match.
great for health and history fans. very interesting, you can find out more about WWII and about the work of nurses and doctors in such hard conditions, with a lot of old equipment to see
I recommend it. It was really great and I recommend it to everyone to visit it. It takes an hour with internation guide. And If you are under 26 you get a 50% discount!
interesting. what an interesting place to visit and only can been seen with a tour that run every hour on the hour you can not take pictures inside

Interesting mostly for unusual setting. Take the little street which goes from Matthias Castle and Fishermans Bastion straight back away from the river. There are stairs which go down, as well as an elevator, Castle Hill. At the bottom, turn right for a very short distance. In Castle Hill, there were a great number of small caves. Some of these were further excavated and many caves were joined together to form what initially became a hospital complex and later a nuclear fallout shelter bunker. The only way to gain entry is with a 4000 Ft ticket for a guided tour. Tours are at the top of the hour in either English or Hungarian. You begin with a brief film, English subtitles, about the history of the complex. Afterward, you go with your particular language guide on about a 40 minute tour. Interesting for medical/device history as well as a very limited history of the Soviet siege. About 200 figurines portraying life in the hospital. The Museum shop has a number of army surplus items - like 1970 gas masks for 2000Ft - for sale.

Inspiring. Worth finding this museum below the Caste walls. Amazing labyrinth of caves used as a hospital during WW 2 and later as a nuclear shelter. Good guided tour in English with time to take in all the stories. Over 62's get half price entry (2000 Ft)

Fantastic museum. Easy to find from Buda Hill as it is sign posted, take the elevator down and it is to the right. More on the pricey side in comparison to other museums, 4000 for adults and half price for under 26 (worth taking a driving licence around as many museums will give discount on under 26)Had a lovely tour guide called Sofi (don't think I'm spelling it right, sorry!) who was lovely and very knowledgable. The tour was fast paced but not rushed. It was busy and it was quite noisy from groups of school children but otherwise the museum itself was fascinating. The guided tour was in English and lasted an hour.World war 2 hospital underground and nuclear bunker. Great to find our about Hungary In WW2.

overpriced. The only way you can visit is by guided tour which takes about three quarters of an hour . The guide did his best to keep us interested in old manequins dressed as patients or doctors and nurses covered in blood , and the the top secret nuclear bunker this maze of tunnels was to become . Quite a long walk and very poorly signposted on how to get there . Its about £10 each which I though was overpriced compared to other things in Buda

Great for History, War, and/or Medical Buffs. Fascinating museum with guided tours only. Guided tours leave hourly on the hour and require arrival five minutes prior to start. Plan accordingly. Tour guides are extremely knowledgable and enhance the experience.

surprising attraction. This was one of our favourite places...packed with history of ww2 casualties, and the sterling work done by Surgeons and Nurses under the most awful conditions, our English speaking guide was very good and it was an enjoyable experience...Well recommended.

Really different and interesting.. We found the Hospital easy to locate using the maps on the hill.Had already read online about tours being on the hour every hour. We arrived and went on the 1pm tour with about 10 other people.The guide spoke very clear English and told us everything that we could have thought of to ask as she guided us through the Hospital.It was interesting to hear and see how the Hospital had been used and changed over time.Definitely worth a visit.

Interesting Caves Under The Castle Hill. Very interesting good information and guided tour. Gave areal sense of how grim war can be. Underground hospital created out of existng caves then enlarged more recently to be a nuclear shelter.

Interesting (but claustrophobic). If you can imagine how it felt to live here or be a patient here, you got what you paid for. It is a suffocating experience (even beyond "just claustrophobia") and not very nice (but hey the hospital wasn't that either)

Hidden Gem. I had read about this attraction online and we made it the first place to visit on our arrival. It was extremely interesting and the guide spoke excellent English. We thoroughly enjoyed the experience.

Very interesting museum. Fantastic insight into the city's periods of turbulence when the hospital was used. There is a good 8 min introduction film at the beginning and they provide warm coats before going into the hospital tunnels for this who needs extra warmth. The exhibition is well presented and the guide was very knowledgeable.

Thoroughly enjoyable and interesting!. Came across hospital in the rock by chance whilst we we're visiting Buda castle. It sounded interesting so we thought we'd go on the tour. We both thoroughly enjoyed it and was like nothing we'd ever been to before, a bit of a difference from the hospital we both work I'm! Our guide was really enthusiastic and taught us a lot. One of the best things we did while in Budapest!

The pain of history wrapped around a Mme Toussaud's Wax Museum Exhibit. This is an important stop on any tour of Budapest to understand the strength of the people and the literal pain of history experienced by the people of Budapest during the Nazi and Communist occupations through much of the twentieth century. The wax figures portraying the wounded along with military and medical figures are at times ghastly and evoke memories of a Halloween fright house. The twenty somethings on the tour seemed to experience this as they would a similar movie themes attraction at Six Flags. The historical message is rather stark, but meaningful.

The Most Unique Thing We Did on Vacation!. This is a really neat museum with an interesting story. Surprisingly well done and so interesting to walk the tour of these underground tunnels. Not cheap - but worth it.
Cold War + WW2. If you like those wars you are going to enjoy this museum, it was greatly organized and unlike other museums in Budapest, it is not only in Hungarian...

Interesting history lesson. How often do you get to go inside a nuclear bunker! Use the budapest card for 30% discount. Our guide (Esther ) was really knowledgeable with perfect English. Don't expect mad as madame Tusards, the wax work dummies are just to give you an idea of who is who.. doctors, soldiers, nurses etc. The tour is about 50 mins long and you are escorted through the 1km of tunnels quite quickly. Definitely interesting for adults. I think most young children would be bored, you can't touch things or take photos and it is more a situational history lesson.

Superb - a must visit. It should be called Hidden in the Rock as its quite tricky to find, however once you discover it, you lose yourself in the history of the hospital.All the staff were super friendly and we fortunately got there just before the guided tour started (all the tours are guided and you aren't able to do it yourself). The tour lasts for an hour and you start with a short video about how the hospital came about, and then you head your way through the labyrinth of corridors and rooms displaying many original medical artefacts in rooms re-enacting how it would have been in its day (cramped mixed wards, operating theatres, X-Ray rooms etc). Despite it being 'underground' you don't feel claustrophobic. The rooms are well ventilated and well lit and the guide reminds you that you aren't underground as the hospital is built into a hill, which is actually an elevation.Really good value for money. An absolute must, and would thoroughly recommend it to anyone visiting.

Really interesting . This museum was like nothing I had seen before, really interesting. Some of the wax works were a little odd but over all it was really good. Also, as a teacher I got in free!!! You have to prove that you are a teacher so bring something to show

Interesting, different, retro gifts.... I was wary of this visit as I'm quite claustrophobic, but I was actually fine. It is a bit dated, but that seems to add to the curiosity of the place. It has been a hospital and a nuclear bunker, and was a secret for a long time. There are quite a lot of wax works, which might be creepy for some people. Worth a visit if you're in the vicinity. Gas masks, etc for sale in the shop!

Great museum - worth a visit!. Tour guide was friendly and knowledgeable. They had guided tours in various languages and kept the groups small so that all can hear and have space. Really interesting piece of history!

Interesting Tour . This is a very interesting tour and brings to life conditions in Budapest during the Second World War and later during the 1956 uprising.We arrived just as the museum was opening and were the only visitors so had our own "private" tour. Our guide was Dea who's English was excellent. She was very knowledgeable and I didn't feel that we were being rushed. I can understand that it might be more difficult in a larger group.Well worth a visit.

Poor Value for Money. Hospital in the Rock was an interesting attraction but pricey! Although we were the first group of the day to do the visit, at a quiet time of year, I felt we were being rushed from one room to the next. there wasn't enough time to look properly at the exhibits. Besides our guide spoke English with a very strong accent and I found it frustrating trying to follow what he was saying.Bearing in mind there were only 4 of us in our group, I dread to think what it must be like at a busy time in the Summer.Not good value for money.

Very Interesting. The hospital is very well done also the tour guide has a large amount of knowledge and is happy to answer any questions,it was amazing to see everything set up from operating theartres to kitchens etc. of just how difficult it must of been for every one at that time..I would recoomend the tour,not so much for young children though.

Medicine, ww2 and cold war in one bunker. There was no movie shown on my visit but the hour went well without it. Most of the tour had no new information for me as a military history buff but I can imagine most people being fascinated by the exhibit.

Fascinating and informative tour. A short 8 minute movie (english subtitled) followed by a 50 minute tour of the facility. A good guide and a really interesting story and experience. Highly recommended and unusual tour.

A fascinating piece of history. This was well worth the entrance fee. The museum is full of original medical equipment and the tour takes in all the main parts of the hospital and machine rooms. The guided tour is mandatory. I was lucky enough to be in a group of only three. Our guide really brought everything alive with his in-depth knowledge and interst in answering our questions. His English was excellent too.

Interesting museum. On a cold wet afternoon, this proved to be an interesting hour out of the rain. Excellent re-enactments of a chequered historical background from 1944 to 1962. Well worth the trek up a steady incline from the river.

Interesting part of Budapest's history!. I'm glad we visited here, was a little unsure as mixed reviews but I'm glad we did. Tours are on the hour, there's a short video and then you have a guided tour around the hospital - if you are into your history then well worth a visit. Seen over comments saying it's hard to find - we had no problem. There are tourist maps dotted all over the place which have everywhere numbered, so easy to locate.There is a little lift in the bank that takes you down to the entrance of the museum (or steps if you prefer!)
Interesting place!. An interesting place to visit that shows different satges of the facility development. The wax figures are helping to understand the reality of those times.

Really cool attraction, a little hard to find.. If you're up by Matthias Church, many signs point you in the direction of the HITR, but once you get to the end of the street and get the choice to go right, left or go down, you should go down (either by elevator or stairs), then go right. You can only go by guided tour that leaves at the top of each hour with the last tour starting at 7pm.Many rooms have wax people depicting what happened in the hospital and our guide got the scare of the day when there was a maintenance man changing a light bulb in the operating room. We all had a good laugh at that one.

Must-see part of Budapest's history. We visited this museum because it sounded interesting and was recommended on a walking tour. It actually turned out to be the highlight of our trip.It consists of a one-hour guided tour around the underground hospital where we learnt about it's history as a WW2 hospital, a secret bunker during the cold war and it's use during the 1956 revolution. The staff were really friendly and welcoming and the tour guide was very good, including answering our questions. Our only negative would be the tour came across a little rehearsed, but this is to be expected when they were conducting the tour in English rather than Hungarian.You get a discount with the Budapest card, but there's also a better one if you're under 25.We would definitely recommend this museum if you're looking for something a little different while in Budapest!

Fascinating glimpse of the past. I would thoroughly recommend a visit to the Hospital in the Rock. You need to pay for the tour to see anything but the tour is absolutely worth it. Our guide really knew her stuff and gave us a fascinating insight of the history of the facility. From caves developed for a WW2 hospital to a role in the Hungarian Revolution as a hospital to it final role in the cold war.The tour lasts around 1 hour 15 minutes and is highly recommend. Couldn't resist buying a gas mask as a momneto for around £5!
Highlight of the trip. This was fascinating. Our guide was excellent and very knowledgeable. I was amazed at what actually went on underground. Well worth a visit

FANTASTIC !!. This tour is extremely well run,there where many people on the tour so split into two groups to avoid over crowding, you walk around 1km through the tunnels but it's at a slow pace so you don't realise. The rooms are set out well and truly amazing to see. The hospital and the bunker are just fantastic and engineering marvel. If you visit no where else this is a must see !

Fantastic place. If you're in the castle district you must go and visit this place. The guides are really knowledgeable and it really still feels like a hospital. If you're a teacher take some ID as you can get in for free.
Very interesting with good guides. The tour is well organised and the guides are informative.Well laid out, wax dummies a bit below Madam Tussauds but do the job.Lots to see.

Very interesting and educational visit. We had read about the museum before going but still were not entirely sure what to expect. The tour lasted about 60 minutes with a guide- might be worth checking when the tours are as I believe they are on the hour. We turned up just in time to begin the tour. our guide spoke excellent English, was very knowledgeable and was clearly passionate about the hospital. The tour was excellent and we were able to get a real understanding and feel for the hospital. I would definitely recommend a visit to this museum- you can easily tie it in with a visit to all the famous landmarks of the castle district (a 2 minute walk from the Matthias church via a lift)

Interesting!. We had planned to go to this museum long before travelling to Budapest. I was thinking that the tour would give access to the bunker tunnels, but it doesn't. Despite this fact, it was a nice place to visit. Loads of history chapters that I've forgot and I could check all the hospital details. Everything is well preserved and the guides are very kind!

Very interesting.. We had a guide with us wh spoke good English but spoke quickly. I would have liked a little more time to look at things in more detail but it is an excellent and unusual attraction.

interesting. This is on the Buda side and difficult to find at first. Also, it's extremely difficult to find transport back to the nearest train station. We walked 15 minutes to a bar, purchased a drink, and they booked us a taxi. The whole experience in the hospital last 60-90 minutes and was incredibly interesting. Everything looked very authentic and as though very little changes have been made to the hospital. Wax figures etc made it really easy to picture life inside the hospital, and the guide was very knowledgable. At the beginning, there is a 10 minute historical video to watch. I would recommend placing the project at a higher angle as the whole room were dodging through the video to read the English subtitles through peoples heads. I really enjoyed this trip and on the day, there was a deal for under 26 year olds which made it 2000 forint per person so definitely worth it! The caves are also next door for you to walk up.

Excellent . A very interesting and informative museum actually contained in the original hospital which was built just prior to WW2 and sadly saw plenty of use during the siege of Budapest and in the Uprising in the 1950s against the Communist regime. You actually get to walk through the wards and view operating theatres etc Much of the contents are original and they claim to have over 100 waxworks taking the roles of doctors, nurses and patients. These were slightly creepy but didn't detract from a very good tour led by an excellent and well informed guide.

It's free if you're a teacher. . We decided to go just because it sounded pretty out there that they actually had a hospital in a rock. It was above and beyond expectations! We are both teachers and so got in for free. The staff were friendly and very passionate about this historical tour so you can't but help join in with the excitement. Our tour guide, called Sophie, was so animated she literally MADE the tour. A must see!

Very interesting tour!. This hospital tour was very interesting and it was great to see all the original equipment!! The tour guide spoke very good English and was very informative! Definitely worth a visit in Budapest!
Pretty cool place to visit! . Had a really good tour of the bunker. We learnt a lot. The tour guide was lovely and wasn't afraid to answer any questions.

Brilliant!. You must make time to go to this fascinating museum; tucked behind the castle the hour long tour is informative and gives you a great insight into the city, it's history during war and revolutions and is certainly something unique to do while in Budapest.I went with someone in the medical field and they absolutely loved it, I got the history from the guide and a running commentary from a medical perspective from the person I was with.A great place to spend an hour!

Definetely worth a visit. The tour starts off with a movie, after which you get a guided tour through the hospital part of the cave system. Movie was informative, but the guide also gets back to a lot of the information given in the movie. Our guide was good. It was fun to see the different tools and machines down in the museum-like guided route. Please buy a gas mask for 2000 fl - I regret I did not!

A fun visit. Really informative tour of a very interesting place. Good way to learn about the troubled history of a fantastic city, all in the context of an incredible and authentic bunker. Unlike any other museum you'll encounter! Not the cheapest place, but the cashier asked us every possible question to get us discounted entry - half price for people under 26! Well worth a visit when around the Castle District.

Thrill seekers, come!. The small groups are guided, and every corner you find new amazing objects, historical facts and It makes you feel how it could have been to live/work down there. You won't even realize time has passed during the tour.

Very impressive and effective to better understand an unknow aspect of war. You are interested in the reality of medicine and surgery in times of war and conflict: this realistic and documented museum is for you. We learn how health services (surgeons, doctors, nurses) in Budapest have faced twice in the twentieth century to the consequences of terrible fights against German and Russian invaders. And how they coped with it in precarious conditions and with incredible dedication. The operating rooms that were installed in the caves under the Buda Castle are restored, with the original surgical equipments of that period : impressive and instructive. You can visit with teenagers as there is nothing shocking and it helps to open minds ... Great !

Totally unique museum experience. This was a real gem of a museum and although probably the most expensive museum on my trip (at 4000 HUF) I can understand why the costs are so high and would certainly say it's worth it. You have do go on a guided tour for safety reasons and these leave every hour (in English). It starts with an informative video about the history of the place before you spend the remainder of the hour touring the hospital, secret cold war stuff and other exhibits. The history is fascinating and they have done an excellent job re-constructing the rooms. The guides are also very good and speak excellent english.

Some odds.... Very unusual tourist attraction, but well worth of visiting. Participating is restricted to small guided groups, so be prepared to reserve time for that. Our guide, a young lady, spoke English quite hastily and not loud enough, so we, an old couple, could not hear everything she spoke. And why she took photos of the group in the end of the tour? Got a feeling like being somehow registered...?

A must see museum for history lovers. I would recommend this museum when traveling with kids/teens, it is a unique experience walking through the caves and cellars bunkers, which used to be a hospital. It is a guided tour, takes about an hour. Although if having a fear of confined places, may not be a fun pastime for some.

Good tour. A good tour of what it was like under the city with an excellent tour guide, a good history lesson ! However it felt a little rushed , I wanted to read and ponder on it all , that might just be me ! Well worth a visit on a damp day as we did . There only so much of buildings you can look at !

Really interesting and excellent tour guide. . A really interesting trip! Start by watching a short video of the history of the hospital then are taken round in small groups with a guide. The guide had fantastic English and was really engaging. Really interesting trip, would highly recommend.
Going deeper underground. Wax figures are a little bit creepy but I really liked the whole experience. It was also a good chance to know Hungary's history bit better.

Utterly fascinating.... This really is such an unusual place. It's pricey by Budapest standards but well worth it. You wont see anything like this anywhere, well nowhere we've been to anyway!The tour is very informative and they use the waxworks well. Nice little gift shop if you really need that gas mask!

Absolutely fascinating, definitely worth an hour of your time!. This is one of the museums I HAD to see when in Budapest, and should be on your list of to-do's as well! By far the most fascinating tour, interesting history and a sudden realisation of the difficult timeline surrounding Hungary. Was able to support and fill in gaps in the history offered at St Stephens Basillica and Mattias Church. Be aware that you have to go on a guided tour (as not to get lost in the cave system) and therefore the price reflects this. European travellers get a discount if you're under 26 which makes things a lot cheaper. However, definitely worth full price admission in my opinion.
Very interesting. A little hard to find but worth a visit. A short film presentation followed by an hours guided tour in English around this former hospital and later Cold War nuclear bunker

Fantastically quirky & educational. Highly recommend this unusual museum! Perfect dose of historical context to help provide a deeper understand and perspective of the town. The museum is a little quirky (wax figures), but, through the story of a very unique cave hospital, our amazing guide provided a captivating history of the challenges the local community has faced/overcome in the past 100 years. I am NOT a war buff and rarely would pick this type of activity, but I am SO glad I did, and would recommend it to anyone.
Worth a visit. Very reasonable prices, half price for those under the age of 26! You have to partake in the guided tour which was very informative. It is definitely worth visiting.

Takes you backup time. My wife was more keen than I was, but good that we went. Quite an experience to see how the hospital was set up during WWII, and later used as a bunker for a possible nuclear attack- though not sure people would have survived.Would definetly recommend - while in the castle district its a bit tucked away, but you can take the elevator down from the top and then it's about a 50m walk.Good to appreciate how people survived the times! Take the time out. Tour lasts 60mins. But do check what times they run it. It can get cold down to 15c in the tunnels and they have jackets available, but I would rather not wear jackets which have been worn by others - but that's me.

Excellent place to visit. Very reasonable entry price (under 26 year olds get half price entry, about £5).This entitles you to a guided tour of the museum. The guide was very knowledgeable and friendly, ready to answer any questions the group had.The tour lasts about an hour and you learn loads of information about how the hospital was run and what went on.Definitely worth a visit when in Buda.
Interesting. In general it was a good experience, interesting story. Note that you have to do the mandatory tour that starts every hour. We had a group that wasnt that big. Explanations were good.

Interesting place to visit. 16 of us visited here as part of our sightseeing activities in Budapest and this was definitely a favourite. Our guide Nikki was very informative and told us all about the history of the hospital. Would highly recommend a visit here.

Surprising facts about a special history. This museum accepts only groups; every hour you can join a tour for an hour, English spoken. We thought the group was too large, so we missed some of the explanation. But there is enough to see and learn about Hungaria history during WW2 and the events in 1956,

Fascinating...... Reasonably priced and includes an hour long guided tour in English. The guides are very good and give you a detailed history of both the development of the hospital,its role during WW2 and then onto the conversion into a nuclear bunker during theCold War. Thoroughly recommended.

Enlightening and informative!. Absolutely wonderful. A genuine learning experience, with wonderful guides. Our guide spoke wonderful English, and was very informative and both funny and sombre at points depending on the subject matter. The museum itself is a really cool visit, it's surreal walking around the operating theatres and machines down under the ground, let alone thinking about how it must have been during use when overtaxed and overfull. A brilliant way to spend an hour. For English speaking tours at least, they leave every hour on the hour, so best to get to the Museum for about ten minutes to the hour.

Worth visiting!. We had a great time on this tour. No pictures are allowed to be taken but they do take a group photo for you to go on their website. The tour starts on the hour every hour (check the opening times before you come here as it closed at 4pm). Our tour guide timi (not sure how it's spelt) was great! Really friendly and informative. Definitely recommend visiting this place.

Favorite Tourist Spot. The Hospital is one of my three favorite tourist spots in Budapest (the Opera House and the Synagogue are the other two). It's perfect to visit when the weather is hot or rainy, since it is indoors and a bit chilly. The history of the hospital is phenomenal!

Interesting. Really interesting place and not too pricey! Only issue is that the tour felt slightly rushed. This may be due to the size of our group, as the guide would quickly move onto the next room before everyone got a chance to properly look around.
great tour. very reasonable rate, great english speaking guide, sooo interesting, definitely one of the highlights of the trip!
Different to our NHS. Worth a visit to this different type of hospital plus the surrounding area is full of bars & restaurants

Unbelievable. Our hotel (Butterfly Home) recommended this to us. We were amazed and overwhelmed by it. Gives you an excellent tour of an "underground" hospital and how they built it and kept it vital during WWII and after. I believe children (10 and up) will appreciate it too.

Pleasantly surprised . The tour was really interesting and educational. It is a very unique experience which I was surprised to really enjoy. The guide was very knowledgeable and I came away knowing a lot more of Budapest's history.

Pricey but interesting . Quite difficult to find! If you head to the castle wall to the left of the church there is a set of steps and a lift go down here and then turn right.
The tour is quite pricey but is very interesting.
We were pleased we went but also pleased we had discount!

Unique Hospital deep under Budapest. Take a guided tour (the only way to visit) to see how the cave system beneath Budapest was developed to provide a Nuclear proof hospital that treated many casualties during the wars and siege of Budapest. Thankfully the Nuclear decontamination protocol and equipment on show has never been put into use.Wards, operating theater and other rooms are illustrated with many figures and period equipment. There is even a display of an entire set of surgical tools that were unearthed in an ex-practitioner's attic after his death and donated to the museum.Totally fascinating.

Great Historical Experience. Interesting to see the history from the other side considering this was used as a nuclear as shelter from the US nuclear umbrella. However, that is not really mentioned in the tour considering there are many Americans.This hospital was used much more as that just that during the revolution which is really what this tour is about. It's a great historical tour more than just about the actual hospital.
Excellent visit.. Great and unique experience from the start, Guide was very good and full of knowledge. The place itself is one of a kind. Well worth going.

Hospital in the rock . This place was fantastic , it was 4000 huf per adult to go in this included a guided tour. The young lady who had taken the tour was very knowledgable . This is a must see to visit .

Excellent visit. Very interesting. Lots of authentic exhibits. The scale of the Museum is fascinating. Guide was knowledgeable and well informed. Lots of dioramas.Fascinating for children and adults alike. Lots of surprises. Very worthwhile visit. Would strongly recommend it if visiting Bucharest.

Facinating. You get a guided tour in the price. The guide was helpful and spoke excellent English. It is a quick paced tour so it doesn't drag on and on. Lots of information on the way round, but expect to read it all as you won't have time. Tip: go to the labyrinth cave before or after. It's cheap and there's a surprise activity which we stumbled upon.

My favourite excursion. Okay so it wasn't the easiest to find. You will have to walk over the other side of the castle. Once you find it you will have to wait for a tour to start. Check before you go on the website. They are usually on the hour.The tour is well worth it's money. It's informative and so different from many museums and attractions I have visited.Learning about how it came to be was fascinating. A definite must on any trip!
amazing. very nice overall expierience. guided tours in englisch deutsch and magyar. very impressive to see how the managed to help so many people during the war, in difficult circomstances.

Best place to visit in Budapest, An absolute must see!. Found this place after looking for stuff to do in Budapest. Trip advisors weren't wrong. This place is absolutely fascinating. You go round on a tour with a guide who gives lots of information. The wax work models are a little creepy so I was glad we weren't going round on our own! The tour takes about an hour. You can't take photos inside the building. Really makes you think about what the conditions were like during the second world war. Thought provoking. Well worth the entrance fee.

Great find!. This was a neat little museum! Quite unique and the hospital was actually used during WWII and on and off until rather recently. The tour is about an hour long and unfortunately we could not take pictures. However they do take a group photo at the end of the tour that you can get off their website for free which is neat.

Amazing experience IN the Castle Hill. We went on a group tour and as we were listening to the guide's tales we could imagine the life of the people who worked or convalesce there. A must have experience for people who love history and WWII.

Unexpected highlight. We chose this tour to get out of the rain and I am so pleased that we did! This was probably the best experience we had in Budapest. The tour is very reasonably priced, is longer than you expect when you walk in and the tour guides are very knowledgeable and friendly. You learn a lot about how the hospital functioned and what happened to Budapest during the war.

Go here during your Budapest visit. Hospital in the Rock hosts a tour every full hour during their opening day, and a tour takes about an hour. Some would say it's rushed, but I think it is a perfect amount of time; short enough to hold your attention, long enough for your to learn a lot and feel the atmosphere. You are not allowed to take pictures in the bunker, with is actually nice, because everyone is much more attentive. Our guide was very animate, fun and doing a top job in sharing the story of the hospital in the rock, with both passion and emotion. I almost teared up, but I also laughed and felt repulsed at times, and it is not every day you get the possibility to feel so much in an old bunker, between ancient medical equipment and lots of wax dolls. So what's it all about? Go see for yourself.

My favorite site in Budapest. Hospital in the Rock is not as well known as other sites in Budapest, but it was a unique experience and we really enjoyed the tour. We visited over the Christmas Holiday so it was very crowded and large groups were being pushed through, but def worth the visit!
Fascinating place. Such a good trip. This visit was well worth the money. You get to see a short film and are then shown around by a very informative guide.

Well worth a visit . Located in the castle district makes this an easy place to visit, and definitely worth it! Lots of interesting history about the siege in Budapest and all the different uses for the underground caves. Lovely staff. Tour was given in English - not sure about other language options.

Really interesting. A hidden gem that gives great insight into life in Budapest during the siege and WW2. So many of the rooms have been preserved and there are wax figures throughout so you can get a clear idea of what life was like at the time. We had a really great English speaking tour guide as well, she was very informative and polite. Definitely worth a visit.

very interesting would highly recommend. Tip try have voucher for discount . we didnt have one but many others did. very good english speaking tour, as a nursing student i found it very interesing and wondered could i have worked here at the time. went with my boyfriend and he really like the history of it
Back in time. Our tour guide was awesome. I only wished we could take photos. If you are a teacher, you get free admission.

Hidden gem. The entrance is not that obvious to find. It really needs a sign board at the top of the hill. Maybe we just missed it. From the column in front of Matthias church you should walk down the street with the church at you back. When you reach the wall at the viewpoint there is a lift. If you look down the cliff you will see the entrance below slightly to the right. Take the lift down.The staff was super friendly. The bunker has so much to see and all displays are well kept and explained.

Makes you appreciate the dangers during the Cold War.. Very nice guided tour that starts with a movie. Gives you a real sense of the dangers that were present in this part of the world durning the Cold War. A great example of engineering and a good place for those not old enough to remember the Cold war to get some insight into the time period.

History. Walk around the tunnels and the different chambers that were used as a hospital since World War II. You can't go on your own, you have to follow a group. We were lucky to have a very friendly and interesting guide who would make the tour really interesting and worth. Sometimes I wonder how we human beings are able to do the things we do :(

interesting Little Museum. Very interesting museum.English speaking guided tour throughout the whole hospital giving lots of information, taking about an hour.However I would have liked more time to stop and browse, there is lots to look at, especially if you are interested in medical items, and I would have liked to aske about some of these, but unfortunately you do not get a lot of time to do this as once the guide has finished talking about the room you are moved on to the next one. Still, very interesting and work a look.

Very very interesting!. Not far away from the Matthias church. Just walk down 2 streets and take the elevator down. The entrance is to the right after exiting the elevator. The fee is reasonable for the amount of work they put in restoring this place! Very interesting historical data of the tunnels dag a few decades ago. The guided tour is very helpful (begins every hour), providing interresting pieces of information! Not at all tiring, the tour begins with a small video projection, in it you can also see original footage from various years. It is subtitled in English. After the video a guide escorts you to the various rooms under the rock. Pictures and videos are not allowed, so keep your eyes and ears open! The walk is almost 1km long but not at all tiring. Try to keep up with the escort, because in a big group you cannot hear her if you stand too far away. See original equipment and imagine the conditions under which so many people tried to help their compatriots in the last decades. A group photo will be taken at the end of the tour from the guide, you can download it free of charge. The place is simply amazing! Buy something from the store (to support them and keep the place open). One of the most interesting alternative thematical museums I have visited. A really hidden pearl!!!!! Do not miss it!

MOST INTERESTING. We visited this site and found it to be one of the most interesting places to visit. The tour starts by showing you a film about the tunnels. You are then taken around by the guides who give a very descriptive tour of the tunnels. If you are interested in history then this is a must.

Excellent tour enjoyed it more then I thought. We had the English tour. The guide was very knowledgable and proficient in English. The tour was very enlightening and you felt the memories. Tours start on the hour,no photos are allowed which is too bad

Fascinating place well worth a visit. This is a 50 minute guided tour around the amazing World War2 underground hospital also used in the 50's for the uprising later turned into a nuclear bunker for civilians but luckily never needed.A top secret establishment until. 2002 & then opened as a museum in 2008.Really interesting but low ceilings steps & about 1km to walk around all original features.

Time travel to WW2. I have never been any place like this before. This was a fully equipped hospital in the caves under the Buda castle. Amazing to hear the stories, the historic background, take a peek into the life of the hospital during WW2. if you are interested about history, or just want to something interesting you cant see anywhere else this must be on your list.

Awe inspiring. My favorite museum in Budapest.The entrence fee is a little higher than other museums in the area, but thats only because you can't get in alone.The museum is on the buda facing side of castle hill, very close to mathias church and fisherman's bastion, there are a lot of nice ( although very touristy ) shops on the way, and if you have time - and its not to crowded, its nice to windowshop.There's a staircase and an elevator that goes down to the museum, and signs everywhere on castle hill.The museum is absolutly amazing.You enter the caves with a short movie. We watched it with english subtitles, and felt that we missed something, but everything you miss in the movie the guide can give you and much more, so we enjoyed the historical scenes.When we entered the caves we were surprised to see the amount of medical equipment preserved, and the life sized wax figures of doctors, nurses and wounded, we really felt that we could understand what happened.Our guide (anika I think her name was) answered all our questions in very good english, and showed great knowledge.Then we went to the nuclear bunker and concluded the tour.I only wish we had time to wander by ourselves after the tour, and go over all the wonderful exhibitions more thoroughly, but apparently many people get lost in the caves.
Great tour of a fascinating place. A unique attraction. The tour is worth the entrance fee; our guide was knowledgable, and explained the various depictions well.

Very interesting. Interesting tour with a good English-speaking guide. You will get a lot of facts about history of this complex and everyday running of the hospital. You will also see the technological part of the bunker (filtration, Diesel generators etc.), but this part is rather shorter. The tour takes about 60 minutes. The guide also explains a bit of really bloddy Hungarian WW2 history, so it is easy to understand who was who etc.

A really pleasant surprise. This pearl is situated at the backside of the castle its entrance even hard to find. I had no expectations but this was a really nice surprise. The museum contained the history of a hospital built into the rock of the castle area. Good guide.

Very interesting museum.. You get a very good idea how a hospital was run in a cave in wartime. The doctors and nurses had hard work. It was altso interesting that the cave was used long time after the war.

Hospital in the rock. Very interesting museum. The exhibits were very life-like and you get a very good idea how a hospital was run in a cave and under what difficult circumstances the doctors and nurses had to work. Must visit!!

Unique museum. If you have an interest in WWII history and/or medical history this is well worth the visit. Nicely organized and presented re-creation of the hospital and atomic bomb shelter built inside Castle Hill. Wax figures and relic equipment bring the hospital back to life and make the tour as realistic as possible. Knowledgeable English speaking guides and a short film are well done.
HOSPITAL IN THE ROCK. Amazing experiance! First you get to see a 8 minutes video and then you get the tunnel-tour. Must see when visiting Budapest.

One of my favorite museums, ever. I generally don't like museums. Walk around, look at art I don't understand or stuffed birds I don't care about, see pottery that was significant to some significant person I don't know... As a general rule, I avoid museums. But this museum - it was really and genuinely fascinating. They do tours every hour on the hour so it's more like a guided visit to an attraction than a museum. Visiting this museum gave me some appreciation of the trials the Hungarian people went through during WWII and under the Soviet Regime. The exhibits were thoughtfully put together, the guide spoke clear English, and the history was so interesting. It is truly a hospital AND nuclear bunker in the cave system under Buda Hill. Skipping this attraction is truly doing a disservice to your visit to Budapest. It was one of my favorite parts of my 21-day trip - that should say something!

Really interesting historical museum.. Hidden away in the rock so you really have to look for it but this museum was really interesting a lovely way to spend a few hours. You are guided around in a group, not too big in size so you can ask questions if necessary. Would be ideal for a rainy day. (August 2014)

Worth a visit. If you only have a short time in Budapest I would recommend visiting this museum. We had a english speaking guide who explained in great detail all about not only the hospital and it's uses over the years, but also the history of Budapest and gave a real insight into what it was like living in the city during the revolution.
Interesting attraction. Good way to understand the political implications of the last 100 years of Hungarian history. Excellent English-speaking guide, well presented exhibits.

Fascinating piece of History!. Okay this is not an easy place to find and somewhat frustrating to get to. The easiest way is to ignore all the signage on the outside and go direct to the square around the Matthias Church and it is to the left with the Church on the right. There is even a lift to save you walking down the stairs. It took us forever to find this.So worth the effort. The tour is fabulous, the history fascinating and the tunnels go on forever.A great insight into the ingenious use of space and how and where many lives were saved by so few.Very enjoyable.
Well worth the visit. Remarkable to see how all of the was engineered in such a small place. The guide was very nice and very well informed.

A moving experience. Well worth a visit. We visited recently as part of a three day trip and really enjoyed the experience. The tour lasts around 1hr and you walk in total around 1km inside the caves although the walk is easy going. We started the tour with a short video followed by a guided walk around the hospital with a very informative guide who explained the history of the hospital in great detail. We strongly recommend this moving experience to anyone visiting Budapest because it is just awesome!

Interesting.... Here they offer a 60 minute tour in English. It starts with an introductory film about the hospital, which is very informative. The tour then shows you around most of the caves. However, today most of the caves are national park therefore do not belong to the hospital anymore and we cannot go into them. The tour guide was very lovely and helpful, however, her microphone was very patchy! It was very interesting learning about the history of Hungary and this hospital in the rock.

So interesting. A really interesting place to visit - the hospital itself is fascinating and the English speaking tour guide was very knowledgeable. Some bits are quite cramped so if you suffer from claustrophobia this may not be for you! The gift shop is well worth a visit too for extremely cheap souvenirs.

Tourist sheep. This former soviet bunker hasn't lost any of its authoritarian charm with the modern tours. No photos, herded through in large groups with no time for appreciation, and a guide who was partway through the next spiel before the whole group was in the room.A shame really as the history was interesting, and the details of the space itself warrant closer attention.

Great insight in life at the hospital. Found the video which starts the tour and the tour itself very informative of the life and history of the hospital. As others have said they don't allow photos..I wish they would say why, not that it would change anything it just might make it make sense. We live in such a visual world I can't share this part of the travels with anyone. They do take a group photo at the end you can see on their web site but it doesn't show the experience. And I didn't find anything in the gift shop at the end of photos, post cards, or guide book to buy to help fill the visual void. But that being the only con would recommend it for persons who like what I call living history museums, tells the history by showing what it was like. You can get a real sense of what it would have been like down there.
Must see!. WoW! Amazing place to visit. Very impressive how this hospital saved many lives during WWII and the revolution of '56. We had a very enthusiastic, knowledgeable guide too, Niki.Must see!

Highly Recommended. This was one of the best attractions we visited in Budapest. It is a really interesting story behind this hospital, so if you want to know more about the history of Budapest around WWII and later it is a must! Our guide was exceptional, and made this a really nice experience. You can only go in as part of a guided tour, so when you buy the tickets you might have to wait a bit until the next tour is on. You always start it with a short documentary about the hospital.

Interesting recent history. I had read about this museum in the travel section of our newspaper in Australia, and this visit lived up to the travel review. A hospital built in a cave system gives a unique perspective of war, and the hour long tour was interesting and informative.

Great little museum. . I have to thank Niki, our guide, for a great tour. She spoke excellent English and had a lovely sense of humour as she led a large group through what could be a pretty grim bunker. Coming from Aus, the idea of nuclear bunkers is pretty strange to us. The Hospital in the Rock began as a war hospital in Buda but was set up during the Cold War as a nuclear shelter. The museum itself is relatively new. The wax figures, while a bit 'old school museum' give you a good picture of what the hospital/shelter would have been like. The tour takes an hour and is very informative. It is obviously all underground and might be one to avoid if you don't like enclosed spaces. I'm really glad I did this tour. If you have a spare hour or so, give it a go. It's so different to most other tourist attractions.

A bit of history. Guided tours start on the hour, luckily we arrived at 20 to so not to long to wait.Learnt a little about Budapest during the WW2 and the October Revolution, the conditions in the hospital must have been horrendous, a reminder of what war can bring - lets have PEACE

Good Visit. A bit different from the Normal Tourist Attractions tell the story from when it was built as a Hospital and during the Cold War etc. Very interesting guided tour by a competent English speaking Guide. Free if you are 70+

Totally worth it... . Went here not knowing what to expect. The tour was very interesting, and the guide was able to answer all of our questions. Hospital, nuclear bunker, history, it is completely worth it. The wax figures provides am amazing perspective of what the facility was like during the times it was used. Highly recommend if you are in Castle District.

Amazing in a thousand different ways!. This was one of my favorite places that we visited during our 3 days in Budapest! I am a nurse, and my hubby is a nuclear engineer, so we may have had more interest than average, but this place is amazing! Built as a hospital in caves during WWII, and then repurposed during the revolution, and again during the cold war. I love how creative they were in using what was available to save lives. They even had 7 babies born in here! Well worth the time and money.

Interesting example of hospital care under siege conditions. The museum is not easy to find. Its on a lower level from old Buda. Access is by guided tours only which take an hour. The display of the cave hospital used during WW2 and the 56 uprising is very interesting as you are escorted through a rabbit warren of underground corridors.

Not worth the visit.. While this was something that I had read about online and wanted to visit, I found that it really wasn't worth it. It was difficult to find with confusing signs and you have to walk around in group tours. You can't just walk around on your own or with friends.

Very interesting your. You are required to take a guided tour of the Hospital in the Rock, which I often find are a drag. Not in this case. The tour guide was fantastic and the timing (~1hour) just right. Highly recommended.

Memorable and Unique. Never one to shy away from a War Museum, nuclear bunker or caves, this place had an intriguing feel of all of the above. The guide was very informative and it was fantastic being led deeper into the rocks, retracing steps of the past and not knowing what to expect around every corner.

Not for the squeamish. Interesting re-creation of the functioning hospital, WWII German Command Headquarters and communist nuclear refuge for the People who Matter. The conditions at their worst are well staged, with decent waxworks. One waxwork's fingers fell off as our guided group arrived, which some found spooky. Interesting, informative and different.

Inspirational Museum. This is a rather young museum as it only opened in 2008. During a one hour tour you get to visit the underground hospital and nuclear bomb shelter. Everything is made very visual with the help of wax persons portrayning the doctors, patients and military people that occupied this place that was hidden from the public for so many years. This museum doesn't get subsidies so go and see this place so they can keep up this wonderful place. If you visit the museum with your Budapest card (like we did), you'll get a 30% discount on the entry price.
Hospital in the rock. Hi visited today worth a visit very interesting amazed how big. It was tour on the hour took app one hour interesting amazing place a must to see

Amazing.... Realistic atmosphere was perfect. I think you should see this amazing place. Our guide was so kind and funny girl. If your way come around there, join this enjoyable activitiy, definitely.

Worth the visit for more recent history. If you are interested in the history of Eastern Europe from WW2 to the Iron Curtain this is a must see. The tour lasts approximately one hour and our guide was very knowledgable and seemed to be genuinely enthusiastic about her subject. It gave some idea of the horrors that the city endured during the WW2 and the 1956 uprising.

Interesting if rushed. The Hospital in the Rock is fascinating and worth a visit. There are lots of interesting exhibits and our guide was well-informed. I didn't rate this experience as excellent or very good because you rushed through the hospital too much - there really is little time to actually study the exhibits properly. There is also a bizarre modern day exhibit of a military helicopter in the hospital that just makes no sense. Also, the restriction on photography is just greedy. This museum has the potential to be fantastic but as its currently orgainzed it just does not work well. There is also a totally incongruous display glorifying military medics (complete with helicopter) that is out of place in the museum. It was also frustrating not to be allowed to take photos. This is a fascinating place to visit and the staff are friendly so it is well worth a visit.
Strange but a MUST. Impossible to describe, just don't miss this place. the guided tour takes an hour. Check for the English tour times. Buy the hypodermic pen in the gift shop. Buy several. Mad !!

Wow, opens your eyes to so much. A tour of the Hospital in the Rock is well worth the time if for nothing more than to open your eyes to the misery the poor people of Hungary have endured over the years. Knowing that the Castle (no longer there) was invaded 31 times over the last few hundred years and then went through first German and then Russian occupation in more recent times, and then to walk around the underground tunnels that were turned into a state of art hospital during the second world war and then became a nuclear shelter during the early 60's is amazing, well worth a visit

Interesting, but tour group was too large. The hospital in the rock is definitely a visit. You can only visit it as part of a tour, though, which we didn't know. It's actually better that way - there's no way anyone who didn't work there would know how to get out once you'd gone in! The tour is interesting and provides some good history to the hospital. The mannequins make it feel less authentic if anything but it was still interesting to see what it might have been like to have been working in the hospital or there as a patient. The tour guide was informative but had obviously done quite a few tours that day already - she seemed slightly bored. The tour group was also way too big and there were times when we couldn't hear the tour guide because we were at the back/in another part of the room. It was also a little rushed, especially at the beginning. But definitely worth a visit!
Hall price under 26. Hall price under 26 years.2000 or 4000.So Nice muséum. Guide had a good work.So many scène in the hospital. Some person in bed, in opération room, Some soldiers...
Great museum . Stumbled upon this museum while out exploring. Really fascinating and unique, would recommend, tour guide really helpful too.
Worth a visit. Friendly guide who spoke English very well. It's cold down there, so remember to bring something warm.
One of the best museums. This museum shows in details how it worked 50 years ago. The place is very atmospheric and worth a visit. I was upset as taking photos was prohibited.
Very interesting.. It was a very nice visit with a pleasant guide, lot of things to learn. It's a bit cold down there, so don't forget to bring some clothes with you if you're cold sensitive.

Very interesting and worth it. My boyfriend and I visited this museum and it was fascinating and really worth it. The tours start on the hour every hour and you can't enter without a tour, so do remember that when you visit as we were 40minutes early and there isn't anything nearby to look at so we just waited on a bench by the entrance. Our tour guide was great and very informative- the visit gave a detailed insight into what life was like during WW2 and beyond for this underground hospital and the wax figures capture scenes from this time. Their giftshop is pretty quirky too and you can buy a genuine gas mask/ mess tin from that era if that's your thing!Really really glad we went and would highly recommend it. If you're a teacher in the EU you can get in for free if you can show a teacher's card, and if you're under 25 entry is HUF 2,000 and over 25 is HUF 4,000.

Well worth a visit. This was a very interesting museum.Entrance is by guided tour only and the full experience is 60 minutes. To be honest it could do with being longer as it felt rushed - big group moving round some small areas with a lot to take in.The experience starts with a short film. This is in Hungarian with English subtitles. These are at the bottom of the screen, so if you need them try and sit at the front or on the first row on the raised block.Then the main tour started. Our guide was Nori, and her English was faultless. She spoke clearly and at a good volume so could be heard anywhere in the group. We moved through the hospital seeing how it was used during WW2 and the 1956 revolution, then on the way back we saw the equipment that kept it operational such as the water and air systems.Lots of information about the use of the rocks as a hospital, air-raid control centre, and then it's later design as a nuclear bunker.Informative, interesting, and well presented.

A fascinating must see in Budapest.. This was terrific. Timed tours by competent guides walk you through an under rock labyrinth whilst explaining the uses of the facility during the Second World War, the Cold War that followed it and the Hungarian uprising. Exhibits are fascinating and the whole experience well worth a trip.

Too expensive . This might have been the strangest museum I've ever visited. I didn't really like it. The wax figures were creepy as were the fake surgery scenes. I thought it was very expensive (4000 frt per adult) for a one hour tour. However, our tour guide was fantastic and I give kudos for her to keeping the tour upbeat.
A gem, definitely worth the visit.. This is great living piece of history. It doesn't take long, and my wife and I learned a lot on this tour.

Must see attraction. A must see place. Worth visiting. Have in mind that English tours starts every 1 hour so if you go at past 15 you must wait 45 minutes for the next one. Ticket price could be cheaper but its worth visiting. Many thanks to our kind tour guide. She was very kind and her English was excellent!

Underground labyrinth with history. We joined an English speaking tour of this venue which lasted about an hour.The guide, Andi, spoke excellent English and certainly knew her stuff. As we were somewhat vague of Budapest's history at the end of the Second World War, this was an eye opening visit to some of that history in an amazing facility, really well recreated with surprisingly life-like wax dummies and interesting exhibits.There were also items relating to the 1956 Uprising and to the Cold War, especially during the Cuban missile crisis.Whether you know your Hungarian history during these periods or not, this is worth a visit.

Fascinating look into history. I love anything that goes underground so when I read about this, I had to visit. They only allow tour groups to visit but do have them in English. It is an hour tour and while some might find it a bit costly, I thought it was worth it. You do not see the entire tunnel system that was used for the hospital and bunker but you do get an appreciation of how this system was used. There are mannequins for show as well as artifacts and displays of different aspects including surgeries and wards. You can also try out the warning system which is loud.

What a surprise to find. This Museum was close to out hotel and sounded quite different from some of the other museums. The Hospital is actual in caves under the Castle hill. The 1 hour guide tour in English was informative and historical in nature. Rooms were layout as they were when this was a working hospital. 70 plus mannequins helped to tell the story. Glad we went, and only 7 Euro with senior discount.

Best part of our trip. Visited after a friend told us about this. We arrived a little early for the tour but this wasn't a problem. I believe they start on the hour.Discounts are given if over/under certain ages and for students which is good. The tour itself takes about an hour and our guide was really good. It does involve some walking and is inside the caves so some people may not enjoy this.This was probably the best part of our trip and would recommend if interested in history.

worth the time. Made from old caves, that were linked together. Puts the war into perspective, and makes you wonder what they went thru. The cost is minimal and there is a family discount. The guided tour starts off with a film and then you and your group are lead thru the tunnels. The structure is built into the side of a hill. I was told the caves are approximately 50 to 60 feet underground.

If you like history don't miss this. It is not promoted but an excellent attraction. I do not understand why the main tour companies not promote this gem of a museum. So much history dating back centuries. You have to see this museum with a guide, there are no self-guided tours. The guides spoke excellent English (and I believe other languages) and were open to questions. The one hour tour was a little rushed - but I guess they need to stick to times given that space is limited and it can get busy.

Fascinating & Unique. I visited this museum after coming across it on TripAdvisor and I'm so glad I did. It was a wonderfully unique chance to see inside a building that played such an important role during the war and revolution. English tours are on the hour but there's plenty of cafes just up the hill if you're early. You can't take photos so soak up the atmosphere and imagine what life was like downstairs during the tough times of the World Wars.

Crowded and superficial. We decided to visit the Hospital on the Rock to do something different as Matthias' Church was closed to the public. Contrary to the publicity displayed, there was no tour available in our native language. We got there, paid the 4000 HUF fee and waited half an hour. The crowd (more than FORTY PEOPLE) is then gathered in a movie theater as the late-comers rush and disturb the video. But... the screen is quite low on the wall and the video has not been dubbed into English. Reading subtitles is fine but as the chairs were high and from the position of the screen, they were unreadable, concealed by the backs and heads of the people sitting. First frustration. Then, the tour starts. The no-photo rule appears out of nowhere. The guide, Zsofi, had a very good English but the tour lacked practical information about the daily life downstairs. It was very claustrophobic to be surrounded by that many people in such small places and sometimes the guide was simply inaudible. I regret it, it could have been a fun visit. The entrance fee is huge though and I wonder where the profits go.

An Experiance. Its well worth a visit especially if you are in the castle district. As you walk around the ramparts towards the military museum (well worth a visit) you will come to a small lift. Go down a floor and the entrance is 20 yards to your leftThe guided tour takes under an hour and brings to life the conditions that the hospital worked under during the world war two siege

Fascinating and well worth a visit!. The Hospital in the Rock is fascinating and well worth a visit. The displays and wax figures create a great atmosphere and the history of the hospital is interesting. The only downside is that you have to go through the hospital as part of a tour group and while our group was small and the guide was friendly and very knowledgeable, there was too little time to fully appreciate all the interesting aspects of each diorama and area - there was so much to see in each room and we would have liked more time to look at things. There is also a totally incongruous display glorifying military medics (complete with helicopter) that is out of place in the museum. It was also frustrating not to be allowed to take photos. This is a fascinating place to visit and the staff are friendly so it is well worth a visit.

Step back into dark history. This is a quite unique place to visit and brings back a recent history that can be quite chilling. A lot of effort has gone into recreating the atmosphere of an over stretched hospital in very cramped conditions set deep into a rock. The guide makes the tour interesting with plenty of facts and opportunities to ask questions. Knowing that you are ending up in a nuclear bunker from the cold war is extremely thought provoking. I have never come across a museum like this before but am very thankful to have made the time to visit.

You are stupid if you do not visit that..i mean that... We found this at tripadvisor.we go to matthias church and we found a.hospital next to that so we thoughy thay it was hospital in the rocks but it was not..we need to walk some meters away and or to take the elevator or to go from some steps down.we ask a young lady at the desk of the entrance office that was a fantastic amd kindnperson because we wanted to pay in euro or fr we change our mind but was helping and kind.then told us that the guide tour is 13.00 and we decide to wair for 30minutes.the price was 4.000ft (believe me is good)however until 26age tou have a discount or if you have the base budapest card you pay only 2800ft ir if you are doctors teacher again a discount.we start at 13.00 exactly time and firat we see a small video and then we start the tour inside thenhospital that was secret until 2002.i am sorry but i can explain to you what we see.the hospital was working.we were back at the war..back there we feel like them.we still feel the taste and the feeling of the people there.also we have to give congratulation to our guide that just today make our guide toue there.i can not remebwr her name but zhe was fantastic.we could all the people understand her english was simple and kind lady!just congratulation to all of you.the best experience ever in busapest
Very Interesting. A must to any one medical especially ! Very interesting guided tour throughout . Several hundred wax models make it even more interesting

Educational Tour. A must see in Budapest!. This was recommended to us on a bike tour that we did on our first day in Budapest. We hadn't heard of it before but thought it sounded interesting and it totally lived up to our expectations! Entry fee is 12 euro per adult but there are many reduced price exemptions to reduce this fee (teachers, OAP's, students, under 26 all get free entry). This attractive is a fully preserved hospital in the caves beneath Budapest castle, the tour is very interesting as all equipment, rooms of the hospital are preserved exactly as in its working days. The tour lasts for approximately one hour.The only reservation i would have is the pace at which the tour moves, I would have liked more time to read and look at the displays.Overall this is a must see! Budapest castle & Matthias church can also be taken in at same time as all these are located in close proximity.
Fascinating!. As a medical professional, seeing this amazing structure and to hear how many patients were cared for under such difficult circumstances. Don't miss this!

Must-do in secret Budapest. Amazing! The entire complex is fascinating! The guided tour shows the many aspects to the hospital and its evolution through the years. The exhibits are extremely well done and I recommend it (except for children under 12). The wax figures are a little creepy and there are some graphic scenes. Interesting to see all the functioning parts and how it can still be used to this day! Location of top secret Cold War bunker!

A must-go when in Budapest!. At first I was all skeptical about going to attraction although it was very mysterious ... "what's this Hospital In The Rock" I thought to myself... But when we were there, we were amazed at how well-maintained the place was since the war-time in 1900s. It has lived through several decades now and the hour-long tour in the hospital was like a blast into the past! Tip: I would recommend going to this place on a weekday, evening time. Much feels for the hospital :)

Loved it!. A very informative and impressive lesson in recent history. It was also very cool inside on a very hot day which was much appreciated. Highly recommend this tour, especially for any military vets, nurses, or doctors.

It's a tunnel. It's a well done tunnel, however I was not very impressed by it. I didn't really appreciate all the wax statues in it, as they don't leave anything to your imagination. Historically speaking it is an important site, I get that, but I would not feel to have missed something so important if I had not visited it.

Such determination and resolve. Despite a ginormous ventilation system, the heat, the awful smells must have been unbearable. I was in awe of the dedication and resolve of everyone who ever ook care of patients at the Hospital in the Rock.

A must-visit in Budapest. We took the hour long guided tour here as part of our minimoon in Budapest and would recommend it.It was insightful and interesting and our guide Gabi was absolutely fantastic!It's close to many other attractions including the Fisherman's Bastion.

Interesting and a little bit different!. Visited here during the afternoon and ended up on a not too crowded tour. We debated on whether it was worth 4000HUF for entry. We were not disappointed. We saw the mock up wards and operating theatres used during the war and battle of Budapest. They still have original equipment down there (including an x-ray machine). It was hard to imagine the conditions they must have coped with. The tour continues after the hospital and includes information about the use of the caves as a nuclear bunker and the original ventilation systems. Finally, they let people have a go at making lots of noise with a portable air raid siren. Very fun but very loud!
A place you must see. So glad we visited this place.So much history attached what one didn't know about Budapest you do by the time you leave,and seeing how it was run underground was amazing .
One of the best museums in Budapest. Very Good, Interesting and informative tour by the guide. Gives a real insight into the history of the hospital.
visit during the summer. visited on a very hot day, was nice to walk in 16 degrees, well prepared interesting exhibition, good program

Definitely a 'must-visit' if you're in Budapest!. Fantastic place to visit. The tour gives you a really good insight into Budapest's history. There are loads of original items in there too so you really get a feel for how it was when the hospital was in use. Our guide was fantastic - really knowledgeable and spoke brilliant English. It was quite a walk away from where I was staying but was definitely worth it. The price was also really reasonable - I couldn't fault anything!

Great visit. Timmi was informative, creative, comical, answered all our questions and delightful. Visit took exactly an hour and we were amazed at the conservation and quality of the location. Really enjoyed the pre tour video too although at times didn't have time to read all the sub titles. We'll bring family and friends when they visit us. Very enjoyable time.

A nice activity on a rainy day. If you are here a few days you could fit this museum in. As a nurse and doctor to be traveling it was a nice experience. It was very informative and cool seeing the old instruments and hearing the history of the war and how this underground area was made into a hospital and then bunker. Our tour guide was great. It lasts about an hour.
Fascinating history. You get areal feel for the history of the hospital and it's importance in different stages of Budapest's history. Great rainy day activity as well.
