So interesting. This was a real fun experience with serious overtones and we learnt a lot about Budapest during the war and beyond. The wax figures are fun and make the place "come alive". So cheap too for a proper guided tour in English. A very unique attraction.

Very interesting. We found out about this attraction from the Lonely Planet guide. The admission fee is quite steep, but if you're under 26 you get a discount and it's free to teachers (so bring proof!)A very interesting walk around the hospital. You have to go as part of a tour, but it is a very good tour! A good pace with lots of intersting facts. The waxwork figures are very effective and help you to imagine how the hospital functioned in the second world war. Well worth a visit, especially if you want an overview of how WW2 impacted upon Budapest.

An interesting underground visit. Decided to visit the Hospital in the Rock one rainy afternoon, glad we did as it was really interesting and informative. No photos are allowed. Although the guide does take a group photo at end and you can access it a couple of days later from their website. I found the English group quite large, maybe it was very busy because of the weather, but it meant we all couldn't get into some of the rooms and hear the guide. Also meant couldn't read the bits and pieces on the walls because of the number of people standing up against them.Before the tour there is a 10-15 minute film to watch which is in Hungarian with english subtitles, again very interesting but if you are not in the front two rows you will struggle to read the subtitles as they are at the bottom of the screen. I had to peep between peoples heads in the front row and I was in the second row. A few people did comment on this in our group.It's well worth a visit though.

Interesting view into the past.. This was an unexpected find. We had a very informative and lively guide and we were glad we had tried it. Yes the wax works are a little disconcerting but it really helps to re create how it must have been in the hospital at the time.

History comes alive. After eventually finding the hospital in the rock we were surprised how well preserved it is and how interesting. Nikki, our guide brought it to life in an amusing way and we were able to imagine what it must have been like during the war.

Interesting and poignant . I really enjoyed this tour. It was very informative and interesting. Some parts were quite moving and unbelievable. The staff were very friendly. It's definitely worth a visit if you are in the area.

Brilliant. First and foremost - if you're a teacher / student / under the age of 25 the chances are that this tour will be free. We turned up and completely expected to pay the £10 approx. fee for the tour (you have to take the tour) but the cheerful assistant behind the counter asked if we were teachers - we are - and he gave us our tickets free of charge.The tour itself was comprehensive, covering a range of decades all underneath castle hill in the caves/hospital. I would highly recommend.
An interesting and unique attraction.. I've never visited anywhere quite like this and I doubt I ever will again. Extremely interesting, our tour guide was fantastic. Highly recommend!

Good history lesson. Interesting tour. The guide spoke very fluent English and gave good answers to the groups questions.
Must go place to experience Budapest's history during the great war.

This will teach you a lot about Hungary. More than a kilometer long and part of the underground network of Buda. An emergency hospital built in the 1930's, a Red Cross hospital during the siege, a bomb shelter during the Cold War, and still maintained for emergencies in a city subjected to 31 sieges from the Golden Horde to the Soviets. Well worth the hour tour.

Interesting but worth the money.. We took the tour based on recommendations. The woman at the counter was very friendly, but we were surprised how much the tickets were (4000 ft or $15). The movie and tour guide were interesting and informative, but the whole experience wasn't worth the price of admission.

So interestinf. Guided tours are on the hour and last for an hour. The guide was very friendly, doesn't rush, is very well informed and gives the opportunity for questions. The Hospital in the Rock is a must visit for Budapest.

Informative and amusing. We visited the hospital in the rock in October, guided tours are on the hour only so ensure to arrive 15mins before the hour to book. Admittance is expensive for non- concessions, the wax figures are funny and wonky with weird expressions but the tour is informative and interesting. If you are 26 or under you get a reduced rate so ensure you have some ID to prove this. Photos are not permitted as they would probably put people off from going! Funny though- just wish it was a little cheaper
One of the best. You take the guided tour and the guide shows you the hospital, their technics, and tells you all about the war and the crisis

Peculiar and Exciting Little Piece of History. If you are in Budapest, you simply must do this tour! It is a little steep in price compared with other attractions, but I assume this is because you must visit as part of a guided tour - and really, it is worth it!Underground Cave system - emergency hospital WW2- emergency hospital 1956 - nuclear bunker - super secret Soviet hide-out. Whats not to like!? Great little exhibits give an idea of what conditions must have been like - your imagination can fill in the blanks!The tour lasts exactly an hour, with around 1km of walking done. The guide was great, and I got the impression that she was really excited to be able to tour people in this complex.Very unusual. Pick up an authentic gas mask if you fancy at the end. Slightly older kids will love this.Also - if you visit Mathias Church first, you can get 10% discount on the entrance fee.

Interesting. An underground complex used as a hospital in WWII and nuclear shelter during cold war. Tickets were around 13€ pp for 1 hour guided tour. It gives an overview of the war history from Hungarian perspective and state of medicine science back in the 50ies. Wax figures make it more real.
Informative!. Tour was great, instalations of the museum bring you to the period we all think was long time ago - World War ll. Tour guides are great and very welcoming! Highly recommended!

interesting must see tour. Im a bit of a history buff and this tour seem right up my alley. We hopped onto the tram and rode with the local Saturday morning shoppers around the city over the Danube stopping behind the Castle on the hill . After a 10 min walk upwards we came to the rear of the Castle area walking straight into the entrance of the Hospital. Inexpensive well organised tour starting with a short video, the pleasant and informative guide who spoke perfect English then guided us around the Various sections of the Hospital and Bunker . Each section included Wax Dummies dressed in period costume , historical medical equipment setting the scene . Incredible the think that this hospital treated 1000s of civilians and solders during WW2 and the revolution of 56 . Pictures line the tunnels showing Shocking devastation the city suffered.must see tour

Great find! Very interesting history!. This was a little gem we only found out about after arriving in the city of Budapest. So interesting if you like war history. There are wax models in each room to show you what it would have looked like when in use. A great tour to do while in Budapest.

Highly recommended. Not particularly well signposted, (turn left with St Mathias church facing you, walk to the wall then take the steps or lift down), but a really interesting visit. Very atmospheric with a really good guide. You have to have the guided tour, and they are in English or Hungarian on each hour

Great museum. I didn't know about this place until I got to budapest. The place has a very interesting history and the guide were very informative. The tour was about 45 mins which was worth the money.

Very interesting piece of history. Bori our tour guide was very knowledgeable and gave an excellent tour. It was fascinating to learn the many different uses the hospital served over the years, and to see the history from a medical viewpoint intertwining with the horrors that were happening all around. I do not feel the need to go through labyrinth tour next door now.

An unusual museum. This museum tells the stories of the hospital built into the caves of the Buda hills. The hospital was used during World War II and during the 1956 uprising. It is hard to imagine working here in the throes of battle with the technology of the era. Well worth the time and entrance fee. It is a little hard to find, so look for the signs.

Must do in Budapest. Hospital in the Rock is run superbly by volunteers. The history of the hospital is fascinating, and the guides are informative and engaging. Unfortunately no photography is allowed inside, but the "gift shop" has some unusual souvenirs. Original compasses and gas masks from the cold war. Very well worth the visit to this quirky attraction.

Had no idea. I had no idea this existed in history. You are led through a series of tunnels seeing a preserved WWII hospital. Going from room to room, seeing very old equipment and wax figures as people, it made you get a sense of how it really was. Made me really glad I didn't have to use that hospital back then.

Fantastic. We visited Budapest for 4 days at the start of October My son had previously been there and recommended that we visited the Hospital in the Rock. Im so glad we took his advice as the tour was fantastic . Our guide ( sorry cant remember her name ) was very knowledgable and was able to answer all questions directed at her. The Hospital is steeped in history with many fascinating stories attached to it. If you visit Budapest this is a must see thing to do.

Fascinating view of the past. Went here in September 2015 on a very wet day in Budapest. It was a fascinating guided tour with a very engaging and knowledgeable guide. The place has been preserved to an outstanding level and it's well worth an hour of your time.

A unique experience. You'll find the Hospital behind St Matthias church, down the elevator and to the right. We didn't plan on going to the Hospital so once there it was a nice surprise. I think the entrance fee was around a couple thousand HUF for two people (they have some applicable discounts but none applied to us). The Hospital is a very important piece of Hungarian history during the World Wars and also the Cuban Missile Crisis. A lot of heroic doctors and nursing staff made the difference in many lives during very difficult times. It's really great to see them remembered in this way. The staff are young, knowledgeable and friendly. This is a guided tour and takes an hour. It's amazing how large the underground facility really is, at one point the guide will give you a point of reference from above ground so you can visualize where exactly you are. Worth a visit during your Buda Hill day of activities.

Very nice tour. Niki has given us a great tour, and explained everything very well. The tour was very impressive and reminds you that situations as the the ones that happend over there should never happen again. The museum did a great job in bringing you back to the time the hospital was used. Only improvement I could give was to let guests take pictures so they can share the experience.

Interesting and Informative. A one hour tour of the underground hospital of the 50's. Lots of displays of hospital scenes, tons of medical equipment stored here from the 50's. Our guide spoke English well as most people do here in the Castle District. Neat place to visit but if you are pressed for time the Military Museum here in the district would be my first choice.

Interesting tour but a bit quick.. This was a fascinating visit into Hungary's turbulent and recent past. The Hospital in the Rock served as a safe zone for the sick and injured of Budapest, and the many Jewish doctors that worked there (WW2) and during the many conflicts this stunningly beautiful city has endured over the past 100 years or so . The place was later put to use as a nuclear bunker/hospital during communist times and served the civil population once again during the Hungarian uprising of 1956.The wax models, in my opinion were superfluous to requirements and some reminded me of my aunt who is downright scary! Our guide was a young, fit and probably hyper-active guy called Milan, lovely guy, spoke perfect English but could have given any Olympic sprinted the slip in a race. His tour was very informative and he readily answered any questions put to him but it would have been better if he could have done the tour at half speed rather than the full throttle he did on the day, However, this doesn't appear to be Milan's fault as the lady who did a second group tour was quicker still and had long since finished before Milan. Message to Milan, cut down on those fizzy drinks with e numbers in the ingredients, drink decaffeinated coffee and tea, and don't under any circumstances eat any more M and Ms, chocolate or peanut!!Well done Milan and well done to the municipality for opening this interesting glimpse in to the recent past to the public.Budapest is a great city and the people there are among the most friendly in Europe and prices are still very reasonable but go discover for yourself and say hello to Milan for me!.

Very good and informative tour. This was a very interesting tour - Niki was friendly and knowledgeable. I found some of the mannequins a bit unsettling, but maybe his was the point! Teachers get in for free, which was a bonus!
Fascinating for medical people. We were happy to spend time here during the very hot days in July. It's interesting and also a tad claustrophobic. The guide was informative and friendly.
Interesting. A very interesting tour of a hospital used during the war. It is built into the side of a mountarin. Very good tour to see how they managed to work so far into the earthside.

Interesting . Our guide was very nice. Showed us around the bunker and is really interesting imaging how things would have been at the time. They give you the history of the hospital, they recreate the different situations with mannequins and they have the original equipment used at the time.Really, really your money's worth! You can imagine yourself at that time and under those terrible circumstances and you wonder how they did it (a hospital originally designed for 60 patients ended up with 600!).

Visit this Hospital!. I had to visit this hospital again, and I'm totally full of honor to the people who built it and worked in this place! As a nurse educated by Red Cross in Norway it was very interesting to walk around in this museum, which was built and worked during the second world war. This hospital was also reopen during the Russian invasion in 1956.First you get video with orientation and telling the story about the hospital before you start the walking in groups with a guide. It is absolute possible to understand which conditions they worked during. It is not allow to take pictures during the walking, but it is possible to look at pictures on internet.

Fascinating. Situated on the Buda side of the city , and certainly worth a visit . Truly interesting , with a guided tour that lasts roughly one hour . A kept secret until 2002 . Should you go on the sightseeing tour bus you receive a discount booklet ( there was a substantial discount for this museum ) Excellent !
Interesting. a guided tour is compulsory. They are pleasant and describe in detail events that happened whilst guiding you through the tunnels. A good insight to what Budapest went through.

Amazing.. The hospital was established during the latter years of WW2. It was later used by the Soviets as a Nuclear bunker. Low cost (adult Huf 4000, over 62's Huf 2000 and over 70's free!) Well worth a visit.
A great experience. Niki showed us around & was very informative with a terrific sense of humour. A very interesting visit & well worth going to.

Fascinating insight into this unusual historic asset. We had no idea what to expect with this tourist attraction, but were awed by the extraordinary ingenuity of the hospital and the stories of compassion against the odds. By comparison to many other attractions in Budapest it seemed a little expensive, but well worth the £10 we paid.

Interesting although bit expensive. The tour was interesting and enjoyable and available in English. I thought it was a bit expensive compared with other attractions in Budapest.
I was disappointed that you are not allowed to take photographs anywhere.
This hospital is similar to the one in the tunnels at Dover Castle in Kent, England, but I would say these are better,

Loved it!. This may have been my favorite thing in Budapest. The guide was very knowledgeable and the place has a fascinating history. This is a really unique place -- I mean, when else are you going to go inside an underground WWII hospital that was converted into a Cold War bomb shelter?
Interestingly different!. Well worth a visit when you are on Castle Hill and provides an opportunity to see the other side's view of the cold war!!

A New Perspective. This must be one of the most unique travel experiences anywhere. I felt that I understood the WW II and 1956 history better than by any other experience. In a way I felt like I was there. And then to see the soviet era bomb shelter - it was impossible not to flash back to my grade school civil defense exercises (me being of a certain age). This experience was very personal for me. Perhaps it would be for you as well.

A cold war museum. This was interesting and I suggest incorporating it into your Castle Hill tour. It's a guided tour only with an interesting Russian occupation history. According to our guide and maybe said for the largely (if not fully) American participants…it was also a bomb shelter to protect the East from the West during an atomic war. Was odd to be on the other side of the circa 1960 propaganda :-)

Well worth a visit. I found this attraction on Trip Advisor and decided to visit with my boyfriend. It was so worthwhile and holds such an interesting history. There is a discount for under 25s but is fairly cheap anyway. The tour lasts an hour and takes you through the various decades that the hospital was used in - starting with a video. This was great - tour was done in English, which I think take place every hour.
Interesting. For those in the health professions this is fascinating. Some of the equipment I recognise from my early days in medicine.
Underground Hospital.. Very much enjoyed seeing the conditions that people had to work in during the war. Reminded me a lot of the Churchill war rooms in London. Very well done .
Interesting to visit . It is an interesting place to visit as it tells also the history of Budapest while showing the ways people were treated during the wars.

Outstanding visit!. One of the best 1 hour tours anywhere! Start with the short movie, then do a 1 km walk through the replicated hospital, wax museum style, real antiques and hear great stories, some happy, good stuff all.
Great show! Realistic and fun. No Dracula.
worth doing. we were whizzed through with a guide, would have liked to have pondered longer at the artefacts but got a good history lesson
Highlight of budapest. Budapest is filled we beautiful architechture .. but for information and things that captured us this was our highlight ... we both came home and said it was our favorite point

Good tour. The one hour tour give you an idea of how things were in the hospital during the 30's to 50's. Nothing too earth shaking, it is an old hospital facility built into the limestone caves beneath castle hill.It cost $4000 Forint, so look for a discount coupon from the hop on/off bus or a Budapest card. Not allowed to take photo's inside so that was a bit of a disappointment.
Very realistic Museum. Fascinating insight into how the War effected the Hungarians first hand, with very realistic mannequins to illustrate the story of the Hospital in the Rock.
Not just for history buffs. What a fascinating place to visit. So much history, and the knowledge of the tour guide was impressive, definitely worth a visit

Glad the Weather Made Me Seek out the Cool. After spending the morning at Vajdahunyad Castle, I took the metro to Deák Ferenc tér, and despite the warmth of late August, I decided to walk over and up Buda Hill. However, by the time I reached the top I was in desperate need of some cool and decided that this location would offer that (in fact it provides jackets for those less well insulated than I). Since this place was on my optional list, I am glad the heat made the choice for me.Quick navigational note, if you reach the top of the hill from the funicular or straight up from the Clark Adam ter, and you walk towards Matthias Church, you will see a sign to the left of the first restaurant, pointing out the way to the museum. This will start you walking down a hill, along Palota, where you will soon run into a fork. Take the right hand option, which starts you climbing again into a residentially looking area. There is also an elevator, for those closer to the church.With the number of younger people visiting Budapest, it is a smart that 25 and under is half price. For those of above that and not yet at 62, it is expensive for Budapest. More a price I would expect in the part of the world with which I am more familiar.Starts with a 5-10 minute movie, for my tour it was in Magyar (or I assume so) with English sub-titles. This gives a good background on the facility, when and why it was used. From there you are led through the tunnels on a 45 minute walk (covering a decent distance, but not a difficult walk), where details are added to the videos.In ways, I found much of what you see is similar to what is seen when visiting a warship (HMS Belfast or USS Midway). While at the same time offering a great book end to the Churchill War Rooms (that I visited last year). Similar purpose, but in so many ways completely the opposite (from the side and type of people it housed, the front line aspect, and so on). Like much of Budapest, it provided a history I did not know and have spent little time thinking about.The only issue, it turned out to be a big group. This led us to get strung out in some of the narrow passaged or rooms, which meant you were not always able to hear the tour guide start an explanation of an area.

Fascinating tour, well worth a visit!! . Tours leave on the hour so we popped back after looking around the rest of castle hill. Very glad we did. Really informative tour of the history of the hospital, from the guide who really knew what she was talking about and was very friendly. The part of the tour about when it was a top secret facility is especially interesting!! If you are under 26 take your passport as they give a 50% discount. Really worth it anyway though.

Fantastic place to learn what Budapest experienced during difficult times in their history.. Can't recommend this place enough! Fantastic. Guided tour lasting about 1hour, taking our group through the vast tunnels & passages that were transformed firstly into a hospital as was the safest place during various battles above ground, then extended to include a nuclear bunker ( luckily it was never needed for real), but was chilling to see the gas masks & fortified doors! Please visit as Budapest's history has to be told, we must never forget what these courageous people endured, right up to relatively recent years.

Worthwhile Experience. This is an excellent attraction to get a spit from the hot weather, an average temp of 55F. Good displays and interesting guided tour - note you cannot tour by yourself. A real eye opener to Budapest's history and the brave individuals that supported and worked at this hospital.

A Remarkable Part of the City's History! . A short video introduces you to a fascinating part of Budapest History. A knowledgable guide escorts a party through a remarkable glimpse of the history of this remarkable hospital.All set in tunnels and rooms self sufficient within the rocks. Room sets, operations theatres and surgeries, all inhabited with life size models of key characters, doctors, surgeons, nurses and the wounded. Wards, patients and staff showing their part in daily life. Kitchens, stores, even the nuclear bunker planned by the Russians and the Decontamination Procedures should it be required. All accompanied by a useful commentary by a guide.The tour took approximately two hours. Not for anyway who might feel anxious about being shut away without natural light or underground. Could also be a little chilly!Helps understanding about the long and demanding history of Budapest, peace and wartime.Well worth the small payment.all shown as life was really experienced.
worth a visit. we got very interesting tour and it is not boring for even a minute. very educational and interesting!
Great way to spend an hour. Great experience. Atmospheric and educational - brings home the reality of conditions during those few months in 1944/45. Staff lovely too.

What a find . We wouldn't have tracked this place down without TripAdvisor, as it is slightly off the beaten track. Unsurprising as if you're building a hospital in a rock, the list of possible sites is quite limited.Anyway - we had a first class hour-long tour of the former hospital / nuclear shelter. The conditions were cramped, simple, cool and a little damp. Quite how anyone got better in these conditions is beyond me. But it was fascinating to have this window into a grimmer bygone world.There are lots of waxworks, some of which were quite naff. Don't let that put you off.Bizarrely, there is also a small contemporary section on a Hungarian SAS team that saved a U.S. soldier in Afghanistan injured by the Taliban in 2011. It sat awkwardly with the World War hospital bunk beds. Don't let that put you off either - we really enjoyed the tour.If I was going to be critical, I would say only that the tour was a little rushed - and the group could have been given a little more time to look at the rooms. Still, it was very good.

Excellent. My wife, infant son and I visited this important piece of Hungarian history today. We found it fascinating how the former Red Cross facility evolved over time from WW2 to the Cold War. The experience takes the form of a 1 hr guided tour which we found to be informative and engaging. The museum contains mostly original artefacts and displays which added to the experience. The tour is stroller friendly for much of the duration with some stairs to navigate toward the end. We must thank the guide and group for your patience and understanding when our little one begun to tire.

Disappointingly closed (while they said the contrary). We came the day before the National Holiday, and were disappointed to discover that you can visit this museum only with a guided tour, which starts only every hour. We couldn't wait that long, so we asked if we could come back the next day, even though it would be a holiday. The staff said of course it'll be open.We came back the next day, on the National Holiday, and it was open but only for special guests. Very disappointing and unfriendly staff who cannot provide the simplest information.

Well Worth A Visit. Really enjoyed the hospital visit. You get a guided tour and it really brings home the conditions which people had to suffer through the war. The tour lasted an hour and both my wife enjoyed every minute of it. The tour guide spoke excellent English with a good sense of humour

Great tour under Buda castle hill. The tour lasts 1 hour and tours are every hour from 10am until 7pm. You get 33% discount with the Budapest card, but it's 50% off if you're under 26 so we just did that, which made it 2000huf.Our tour guide spoke good English and was very informative even with a large tour group. It was good to hear about the uses throughout different periods in Budapest's history.However, I am not overly keen on exhibits which have lots of poorly made wax figures!Tip: the 7pm tour is done by torchlight, except on Saturdays. Spooky! Also many other attractions in Budapest are closed this late so a good option for evenings. Visit the castle afterwards for beautiful views in the dark. Tip: be careful if you're tall, there are lots of small doorways and head-bumping opportunities!
In use not so long ago.. This is a must see, a real working hospital in the late 1900. Just to comparison to today's hospitals is amazing. And some countries would love to be as well equipped today.

Fascinating place to visit.. If you are interested in history and Hungary's past, this place is a must visit. It is highly interesting. Would love to have been able to take pics but unfortunately not allowed.
a bit of unknown history. After reading about this attraction on Trip Advisor, my husband and I decided to visit. It was an excellent tour and very informative.

Interesting tour. Enjoyed our visit to Hospital in the Rock. Very informative and gave you a real feel for the conditions which were endured in the city. The tours were with an English speaking guide. Unfortunately our group was quite large and the guide didn't wait for everyone before she started talking so unless you were at the front you missed some of the commentary. Two smaller groups would have given a better experience.

Great exhibititon, but would have liked more time. This is a fascinating exhibition that I never knew existed. The tours are on the hour, but make sure to arrive in good time as they fill up quickly at weekends. Our guide was lovely and very informative and she spoke very good English to the group.As our group was quite large, I would have appreciated more time to be able to look at things in detail and read the exhibitions on the wall. We were herded pretty quickly between rooms and didn't get very long to look as there is so much to take in.

Hospital history. Interesting guide tour and if over 60, half price, if over 70 free!Directions to the hospital could have been better, but well worth a visit and they have tried to give it a realistic presentation with wax statues old equipment and a seemingly endless supply of bandages!

Interesting Hungarian history.. This is a very interesting historical sight, it is definitely worth the money. It was £9 per person but because we had a ticket for the Matthias church and fisherman's bastion we got 10% off. If you have any interest in history I would definitely recommend coming here. The guided tour was very informative and our tour guide spoke good English. They have kept the hospital as it would have been in the past and this gives you a good impression of what it would have been like when it was a working Hospital. It was nice to go somewhere and appreciate it’s history. They have some good souvenirs to buy such as original Hungarian gas masks! This is a good way to spend an hour of your holiday, there were free toilets to use and chilled drinks available to buy. I would recommend it.

A part of history worth exploring.... This was a great experience. The tour guides were knowledgeable and painted a vivid picture of what life would have been like in the hospital during WWII and beyond. A little more time allowed to fully explore the exhibits would have been appreciated. Overall, this is a fascinating museum well worth a visit.

Brilliant!. Agi our tour guide was fantastic; she gave just enough information to keep us interested but didn't let the tour drag on. The Hospital itself is unlike anything I have ever seen, it was a really good insight into the history of Budapest and their role in WW2 and beyond. I definitely recommend!

Hospital In the Rock--- WOW. The Hospital in the Rock is an amazing experience. You really get an understanding of the agonies these people faced and the history. Truly worth doing if you like history. Giving you old nurses capes was a great way to really fit in.

Learn about what went on. First of all, Gabi was a great guide. Although our group was large, she kept us together and no one was left out. She spoke clearly and loud enough in well spoken english.One's appreciation of the subject has to do with his/her interest in the history of Budapest and the tragedies that occurred not long ago. We were fascinated by the tour. This is an earnest depiction and forces one to consider the strength of the human spirit to persevere. We combined the tour with a pop up to castle hill on the same day for an easy two-fer. The glorious weather didn't hurt when up on top either.
Excellent tour guide who spoke good English. A very interesting film and tour which took about one hour. Gave a true feeling of the horror of war

Adventure Budapest . This museum absolutely makes you aware of how hard Hungary has worked to rebuild after the tragedy of wars. It also reminds you how recent the constant fear of nuclear attack was for Hungary. We were not sure we wanted to do this tour especially my wife. We both came away very glad we did the tour. As unique a museum as you can find. The passionate staff provide a look at how hard life was in WWII and the other acts of war including 1956. This facility was kept Top Secret until 2002 and developed as a museum in 2008.

The exhibit itself is awesome but the execution terrible. First to "welcome" you is the cashier who looks like she'd rather be anywhere but there talking to you. After that you go directly in a small room for the movie; very good, sets the mood. Then the real tour starts. The guide also didn't seem to want to be there. Our group was too big (around 15 people) to have everyone close enough to the guide to hear everthing she said. It also didn't help that she didn't wait for everyone to be in a room before she started talking. It felt really rushed, no time for questions or to stop and read the information on the walls. At the end of the tour the guide smiled for the first and only time.

An hour well spent. Have visited underground hospitals before and this is by far the best we have seen. Plenty to see and this is complemented by an informative guide.Not only does this attraction have history prior to it's development as a hospital but also later on through the Cold War period as a nuclear shelter. A shame photography is not permitted but that is understandable as it would hold the tour up considerably.A must do when up in the Buda Castle area.

Well worth a visit. We went here as we couldn't find the entrance to the labyrinth, so gave this a shot instead. was a really interesting tour, the rooms were set up as they would have been in the 40's with wax work patients! definitely worth a visit.

Excellent museum. Worth a visit.. Amazing place, we joined a tour which lasted around an hour, in which our guide took us through caves showing mannequins dressed as patients, nurses and doctors whilst giving us a good descriptions of what happened there, as well as giving us a good history lesson. Well worth a visit, Easy to access, just have to mind your head at times. Not scary (unless you have an overactive imagination!)

What a place - you must go here!. Travel back to WWII and get ready for the bomb to hit Budapest! With a few wax figures, and a great deal of actual materials, they tell the story of how this place was turned into a WWII hospital at the height of the war when the Soviets were bombing this general area daily. The strength of the doctors and nurses (as well as the wounded). Also, they have a little sense of humor about it thrown in, which adds to the enjoyment of learning history. Reminds Americans how long it has been since we've had a war fought on our own soil.

Interesting and moving tour through an amazing facility. These caves were adapted for use as a military hospital during World War II and used again during the Hungarian Revolution in the 1950's. It was then preserved and strengthened for possible use in the event of a nuclear attack during the Cold War. The excellent guided tour through the facility was eye-opening and made that difficult bit of Hungarian history very real. Photos inside the facility are not allowed, even without flash.

Informative and interesting . Agi was brilliant as our guide and was very passionate about the museum and it's history. The tour was approximately 50 minutes long and you were moving constantly arounds the rooms. Would definitely recommend this.... definitely worth the walk up the hill!!!
interesting and charming. Interesting place, nice guided tour by friendly staff, historical interest, but very charming too, Madame Tussaud but then more sympathetic and realistic, really charming

Educational experience with real insights into Hungarian recent history. this is thoroughly recommended. The tour takes something over an hour. It is preceded by a film, giving the historical background, and then the guide walks the group through a maze of underground corridors, linking different parts of the hospital, with impressive tableaux that give an impressive experience of what life must have been like during the various wars and civil unrest over the period. The final section of the tour ends in the underground nuclear bunker and is a chilling reminder of what might have happened in the 1950s and 1960s.

Interesting and thought provoking. The tours of the hospital are every hour on the hour and you have to see the attraction as part of a tour. They provide tours in English. You start the tour with a short film about the hospital then proceed with your guide around the facility. Very good tour guide who spoke English very well and made the tour interesting with a bit of humour thrown in. The hospital has been set up with wax dummies dressed to show how they would have used it when it was open and it also has a couple of rooms with exhibits related to the hospital which are interesting. It was good to see the old operating theatre and it made me flinch when they showed 2 tables in the same room with simultaneous surgeries taking place! Apparently this was usual practice.... As was the closeness of beds and sharing of beds by some patients when the facility was overcrowded during the revolution. No wonder loads of patients died from infection! Good to see the old x Ray machine and old anaesthetic machines and the size of the wards and beds which were on top of each other.

Not in our guidebook!. We saw this on a board near the Fisherman's Bastion and decided to explore. They run guided tours on the hour which starts with a short video explaining how this secret place has evolved.The guide spoke good, if rather fast, English and my one criticism would be that the tour felt rushed. We would really liked to have had a chance to look at all the exhibits rather than whizz by them!Interestingly I was chatting to a young man from Budapest on our flight back to London and he had never heard of this place so it really was a secret place!!

Interesting and Educational Tour. Hospital in the Rock is an interesting tour. We had a wonderful guide who answered many questions from people in our group. I would think that it would be especially enjoyable for those in the medical field or WWII enthusiasists.

Interesting Yet Also Slightly Rubbish. The Hospital in the Rock does indeed have a fascinating history owing to its unique location and different usages, but is curated in an old fashioned and frankly laughable manner. Waxworks always look absurd, and the horror show displayed here detracts from the power of the story, and left me stifling inappropriate giggles. After viewing a few rooms of what can only be described as an underground hospital filled with waxwork dummies, it all became a bit monotonous.The historical angle is also somewhat nuanced to gloss over that tricky Axis alliance, and instead celebrate the heroism of the 1956 uprising. The incomprehensible addition of a helicopter - an uncommon site within most bunker facilities - was apparently there to honour Hungarian Special Forces. Nothing to do with the actual site whatsoever. The coverage of the change of use to nuclear bunker was brief to say the least.At 3600 fl, it's not cheap, the displays are ludicrous and old fashioned, with some of the information about the site's usage either notably downplayed or irrelevant. With a more modern and interactive approach, and an abandonment of the necessity of the tour guides, this could be a worthy tribute to the legacy of the site.

A great museum. Visited tMuseum as part of a group tour and was well worth the visit. Depicts the various stage of the hospital during the history of Budapest and the hardship under which it operated. Highly recommended

Unusual piece of war history, well displayed and told. The many adverts for this in the castle district have maps showing the way to it which we couldn't make sense of, so it was hard to find. You need to go to Holy Trinity Square, line up the central monument in front of you with Matthius church behind you and then go down the street straight ahead until its end at which you will find both a covered stairway and an elevator to take you to the next level down at which you turn hard right to reach the entrance to this attraction.You can only inspect on a tour, so in the high season, visit early so that if current the tour (hourly) is full, you can book a later tour & return for it.The use of the natural caves in the hill for an underground hospital during WWII and then nuclear bunker subsequently is well illustrated by the use of dummies in conjunction with genuine uniforms & equipment.

A most unusual museum!. This museum, located under Castle Hill, was one of the most unusual and memorable experiences in Budapest. It was created in the 1930s from a series of natural caves under Castle Hill. The hospital served a critical function during the siege of Budapest in 1944 and the failed revolution in 1956. The tour is excellent, leading you through the reception area, records room, wards, kitchen, and operating theater. You will never see anything like it anywhere!
Fascinating. Fascinating underground hospital from WWII and later era. Good look at some cramped medical rooms and dated equipment. Amazing how resourceful the community was.
intriguing. A fascinating insight into an underground hospital dating from the1930's. An hour long guided tour explaining the detail and history of a turbulent time in Budapest's history.

1st visit. the visit was interesting as the guide explained step by step what and who used the hospital throughout its history, there were a lot of things to see inside, unfortunately you were unable to take any photographs

Great Museum in the Castle area. This was a good museum with an English speaking guide, showed how awful it was to have been injured both during WW11 and also in the 1956 uprising. The only downside was I felt we were rushed through so you didn't get a chance to look at anything for long
Secret hospital from the II. WW.. The hospital is very interesting, but the tour was so fast, it should be longer. Great experience for everybody.

interesting tour for an hour. Enjoyed an English language tour of the Hospital in the Rock, as there's an interesting story to the place. Unlike some other reviewers, didn't find the place to be cold or chilly.However I would like to offer a suggestion to the facility's staff: when nearly everyone visiting wants to take the English language tour, then you might want to add an extra English tour guide.After watching a short introductory movie, the staff asked that Hungarian speakers go with one tour guide and English speakers go with another tour guide. The two Hungarians in the audience essentially had a personal tour, while everyone else had to somewhat struggle to hear the lone English speaking tour guide. It wasn't the fault of the tour guide. It was simply because the English speaking group was too large.Regardless, we enjoyed visiting the Hospital in the Rock, and recommend it as an interesting hour in Buda.

Very interesting and well done.. This isn't as big as some of the others e.g. The Channel Islands, but it is very well done and our (English speaking) guide was excellent. The exhibits are well staged and there's plenty of them using genuine items from WW2 and the Cold War.Our group was quite big, c. 40 people and you're not allowed to take photos, but other than these minor points; a great attraction.Tours are every hour, on the hour, and there's a small gift shop which also sells genuine Cold War items e.g. Gas masks and compasses etc.

A nice historic attraction. The hospital in the rock was a nice attraction, especially if you're into the history of medicine. Some of the dolls were a bit weird looking but overall there has been a clear explanation of what happened there during WWII and just a bit about AFTER WWII (also interesting but probably confidential...)+ As an Israeli, the siren at the end was as creepy as hell.

Interesting information about the war hardships. That's when visiting such places here that you realize how fortunate you are as relieved experience the horrors of war. Both the Second World War that the Soviet occupation exposing the Budapest and its inhabitants for the atrocious hardships and privations. A very interesting history lesson.

Interesting & Informative Tour. A really interesting tour, which started with a 10 minute video (with subtitles) about how the hospital started. We had a really good guide who spoke perfect English & was very informative. Some of the hospital scenes can be a bit gruesome & a young lady feinted & had to leave the tour. I would highly recommend this tour, which lasts just over 1 hour & is about 1km long. It is all underground & may not suit people, who suffer from claustrophobia.

interesting and informative tour, well worth a visit.. Lovely English speaking guide escorted us around this fascinating hospital. Gave an insight into the hospital and the bravery of those who worked there.
Took about an hour and reasonably priced (one of the hop on hop off bus companies has a 30% off voucher in the discount booklet).

Unique and worth your time. Recommended by our free walking tour guide. Unique experience, very memorable. Your entrance comes with a tour guide which was a definite plus. The wax figures are a little creepy at first but you get used to it. It feels like you are going back in time. The background noise of bombs and sirens helped achieve the effect. Lots of war museums focus on the soldiers and combat but this gave a different perspective. It paid tribute to the health care workers who diligently did the best they could in overcrowded circumstances.

Interesting but rushed. The hospital is quite difficult to find. The English speaking tour begins on the hour with a short film explaining the history of the place. After this, the tour of the hospital begins with the knowledgeable guide.The group was large and we found that unless you are near the front of the group it is possible to miss the guide's explanation of the rooms, settings, etc as you might still looking at an exhibit but the front of the group has moved on. We felt that there was not enough time to look properly at everything on show and it felt very rushed. You are not allowed to take photos. There is no café as such, just a fridge with drinks. Fascinating place but more time needed to appreciate the exhibits.

A must if you are in healthcare or a history buff. We were provided an English speaking guide. She was great and enjoyed interacting with visitors. You aren't allowed to take photos inside. Well worth your time.

Unique and unusual. Very special and unique museum in Hungary and maybe in Europe. Very good guides, the tour is about more than an hour. Begins with a movie about the history of the hospital. Some wax figures in the rooms, 2000 sqm, and 10-18 meters under the streets. Very interesting the air-conditioning, and the defense from an nuclear attack.Lot of volunteers was helping the doctors and sisters, when the hospital was crowded with injured soldiers and civils. At least its stunning, interesting and sad.
Nice visit . Nice to visit but the group was much to big! It gives you an nice idea how to hospital works in time of war. We only can recommand it.

What an incredible piece of history. This is well worth a visit to get a better perspective on just how life was during WW11 and the Hungarian Revolution of 1956. The 1 hour guided tour tells the story of the difficulties of medical/nursing care during enemy occupation and the use as a nuclear bunker. The displays are well done, and the Guide spoke with compassion of the difficulties of the times. Thoroughly enjoyed the experience.

A "secret" emergency hospital.. This is a hospital / nuclear bunker created in the caverns under Buda Castle in Budapest in the 1930s, in preparation for the Second World War. It's now a unique museum, complete with wax figure of hospital staff and recreations of treatments and day-to-day scenarios during the siege of Budapest in 1944 and 45. The history has grim stories of using recycled supplies from corpses as supplies dwindled during the siege. Designed for 60-70 patients, at one point it was treating over 600! It's an interesting guided tour particularly for those with interest in medicine. No photos allowed.

Rocky Hospital. The Hospital in the rock is below the Buda Castle & joins it through a labyrinth with the tunnels underground.The hospital was used in the 2nd world war specially in the long seize of Budapest in 1944-45,during the 1956 Hungarian Revolution & later during the cold war it was supposed to be a secret nuclear bunker in case of atomic blasts.It has 200 wax like figures along with original furniture,medicines & medical equipment for you to breathe in those crisis periods! It was thrown open to the public only about 14 years back.It has 200 wax like figures

Interesting. Not many people know about the Hospital in the Rock, but the visit is worth it. You can see how they managed to help injured people and also visit the nuclear bunker.The visit is in English, they don't have them in Spanish. I don't know if there are others in another language. As it's 80 meters underground, you might need a jumper even during summer.

the history of Buda in the last decades in one unique space. Hospital in the rocks its not your traditional museum. Its more an attraction. The wax figures are old and you don’t have a lot of multimedia elements. Just the figures and some very good guides. But hospital in the rocks is unique. For the caves underneath Buda castle but mostly for its history. Good for all families.

Too rushed. Hospital in the Rock is an interesting place but I have much rather walk around myself than a guided tour. The guide was knowledgable but it was so rushed. You barely had a chance to look at the re created rooms before you were moved along to the next. It's overpriced for what it is.
Excellent. Once we located the hospital (signs were a little misleading), an excellent visit and brilliant tour guide in Milan. Really enjoyed it. Would definitley recommend.

Just to pass time before the flight out, but glad we didn't miss it.. Real 'Cold War' feel to this set up. Budapest was devastated at the end of WWII, and this Hospital remained operational through 'Cold War'.

Very eye opening. I didn't realize how Budapest played a role in WW11 and I'm glad we decided to go to this tour, because we almost didnt. Our tour guide was very nice, and she had seemed to know very well what she was talking about and what to do during the tour. I would recommend this tour if you're on the Buda side of Budapest, and if youre in Pest, then make the short journey over and do it!
Very interesting. Very interesting, especially if you like history. Only con is you cant use camera to take pictures..

Unusual Museum touches on History, Medicine, WW II, Revolution. If you're interested in the history of medicine, Wartime medicine, WW II, the Hungarian Revolution, or the Cold War, then this unusual museum is well worth the visit. Also if you're interested in something "different" than the usual tourist stops. They developed and enlarged the existing cave structure to create a hospital, which was used during the war and again during the revolution. I thought the wax figures would be cheesy, but they successfully give a better idea of what it must have been like when being used. Agree with others who say to get a seat near the front for the film to read the English subtitles. Guides were clear and willing to answer questions.
What a surprise!. This historic place near the Matthias Church is most interesting for people interested in WWI and WWII historic places.
Sombre experiece. Very interesting, genuine place, where secrecy, kindness and charity was winning for a long time, until a tragic event shortly before the end of WW II.
Week in Budapest. Very interesting. Don't let the cheesy wax figures on the website fool you. This was very interesting with little cost. Totally recommend!!
Great spot when it is hot outside!. We enjoyed this tour, especially as a respite from a hot summer day. They showed us different uses of the caves under the castle district which was interesting.
Interesting piece of history. It was a very thought provoking and interesting visit. The guide was very knowledgeable and it gave a great insight into a 'top secret' hospital and bunker.

Eh. So this spot was once a hospital during WWII (when the Hungarians were fighting on the Nazi side, not that they'll stress that), and then a nuclear bunker. A lot of waxwork effigies don't actually bring it to life...nor make it all that interesting.

A must see attraction. If you're into fallout you're gonna have a blast. The souvenirs are awesome. The staff is professional and the museum itself is interesting. The wax figures and medical tools look very authentic.

Very interesting site. We joined an English-speaking tour on a Sunday afternoon. While there were a lot of people in our group, the tour was worthwhile as it is a really interesting site with an incredible history. The tour lasted about an hour, but seemed quicker as it was so interesting.

Hidden gem. Literally - you won't easily find this so look hard, it's worth it. Hungarian history comes to life in this hospital built into the side of a cliff during WW2 and used again during the 1956 revolution.

Size of the group was way to big. . As in many other reviews mentioned the amount of people in the groups are way to big. In many parts of the cave the space is not big enough to squeeze all people in. If you are at the back of the group you don't understand the guide. Another point is that they have to wait at some spots to get all the people together therefore they have to rush from one spot to the other so that there is almost no time for questions. Other than that it was a very interesting and informative tour.

An exhaustive visit to a secret historical site!. Young and prepared local guides will accompany you during this 50 minutes-tour (after a brief introductive movie). The Hospital is situated in Buda, so you can plan your visit when you go there for the most know attractions such as the Castle or Mathias Church. The guides introduce you (in a perfect english), to the history of these secret emergency hospital and nuclear bunker created in the caverns under Buda Castle during WWII. In approximately a km, you will find different rooms (ORs, patient rooms, laboratories) with original machines and instruments still present, and patients, doctors, nurses and soldiers actions are recreated by accurate mannequins. Very interesting and fascinating! If you want an alternative view of the city, and are interested in medicine and history, don't miss it!

A Very Moving Tour and Experience. This is perhaps the most moving attraction and tour I have experienced in my travels.The tour lasts approximately one hour, maybe a little more. They have recreated very effectively the various facilities within this underground hospital, built in a series of caves originally as a safeguard against nuclear warfare. During the second world war it was set up by the Red Cross with the potential of handling 40 wounded per day. In the height of the war the were handling over 700 wounded soldiers a day.They have staged the many rooms you will see with manequins that depict the unbelievable circumstances and living and operating conditions the doctors, nurses and patients endured.It is a very moving experience and it should not be missed.

A Must do in Budapest. It was a little hard to find and on a hot day, we nearly didn't bother, but glad we did. Lovely and cool inside, in fact they give you coats to wear if you find it too cool. Very well done and surprisingly moving at times. Not able to take photos, which I found a little perplexing, but was the highlight of our time in the city.

A very interesting relic of history. This was a very interesting tour of this underground hospital. Through period displays it showcases first the world war two era and then the era of the cold war under Soviet rule. We went on a tour which took around 45 minutes and gave us a good overview of this strange place. If you are in the old city, I would recommend this.

Interesting piece of history!. Very interesting guided tour! Takes around 45 minutes to an hour. A lot of the original machines and instruments still present. It was crazy to walk around picturing the chaos!

Interesting & perfect on a hot day. Interesting part of Hungarian history. We decided to go mainly to get some respite from the heat yet thoroughly enjoyed the guided tour.Teachers go in for free. Groups of medical professionals - min 15 people & prebooked - pay half.

A must. I went there with my mother...let me just say, she s not into vistiting that much as I am. Well she adored this museum...and i did too. The guide that we had knew very much about the place and his english was perfect. Everything in Hospital in the Rock is so authentic, and you will also find out some secrets about the place. If it was a single thing that i didn t like, that was the fact that i wasn t aloud to take photos...but that s the policy and i m not necesarlly complaining about it.

Very interesting, enthusiastic guides. I really enjoyed my visit to the Hospital in the Rock. The whole tour was very interesting and the guide enthusiastic and engaging. I would defiantly recommend this experience.

The most interesting thing in Budapest. A thing I liked the most in Budapest.Takes a bit of time and patience to find it, but absolutely worth the visit.A great tour with a very interesting guide(there is a tour every hour).You won't believe they could have built a whole hospital in the underground cave system.Haven't seen anything like it before.I really enjoyed it and would highly recommend it.

A very interesting look into the past. We visited the Hospital in the rock when we were in the Castle district, we found it very interesting and a contrast to the other attractions that we had visited on our trip. It was well organised , with a one hour tour , with an English speaking tour guide, it gave a good insight to the workings of the hospital through some very hard times and the transformation into a nuclear fall out bunker. Try and leave some time when in Budapest for some history, this fits the bill.

Educational - not for fun.. This is an educational visit. The guides were very knowledgeable. However, this hospital was used during WW!!, and then designated for potential use during a nuclear attack. Most of the rooms were very realistic, so not for everyone. The hospital would not be on your normal tourist agenda.
Past, Present, and Future---great broad perspective. This tour was surprisingly informative and interesting and a great activity on a hot day since it is very cool in the caverns.

A marvellous site, little known.. Been to Budapest several times, how we missed this little gem I don't know. A remarkable place of an ex-secret hospital in tunnels underground. Used in secret during WWII and occupation, there'seven a full blown helicopter down there. Operating theatres, surgical wards, boiler rooms, too much to mention. Take a peak at their web-side. It's an escorted tour and full value for a good hour of mind boggling sights.

Don't miss the opportunity to visit it. It's one of the most interesting places to visit in Budapest that has a lot of things to give you! It has guided tours in english so as not to get lost in this huge labyrinth of history and in the same time you get an amount of information about Hungary! It's really touching because you realize how difficult the last 80 years were for this country.

Refuge from heat and crowds with interesting stuff. Firstly, in August, this was cool. Thank goodness. They offered us cloaks as it is 17 degrees or so (centigrade). The history was well explained by a guide, and interesting, spanning the second world war and the cold war period when the place was set aside as a nuclear bunker. If you like the more off-beat places that give you a different angle, and you've been up castle hill, then why not drop down a little way to this? I would.

Great place to visit. Fascinating to see how this hospital in the rocks was created and its history! The tour takes an hour and is in English (it leaves on the hour) and starts with a film of the hospital before taking you through the tunnels. Amazing to see how it managed through the turmoil. Finishes by going through the nuclear bunker. Great trip - but not for the claustrophobic.

Fascinating museum. Walking around the Buda Castle area, I saw this museum advertised and a quick look on TripAdvisor meant it was somewhere I wanted to visit. It is below the main castle area (you can get a lift down if you don't fancy walking down the stairs to it).Great tour guide who knew her stuff and gave a great history of the Hospital In The Rock. Just a shame photos aren't allowed.

And We Still Have Wars. A series of natural caves were expanded and lined to create the "Hospital in the Rock" It was used during both world wars and the revolution. The facilities were primitive and unhygienic.  Many died through infection when there were shortages of water and bandages. To overcome the bandage problem they were taken from the deceased and reused. To accommodate the wounded, beds were pushed together to enable three to lie in two beds. The more serious patients were placed on the outside so as it was easier for the nurses to treat them. When the beds were full, patients lay on stretchers on the floor.Tip:- at the beginning of the tour a film is shown. Sit near the front to view the English translation. Kayjohn

Very Informative and Intriguing. This tour was great! The only downside is the boring video to start the tour off but the setup once inside the hospital is fantastic. You definitely get a feel for what it would be like once you were inside of the hospital. We did this during the summer and it was a great way to escape the heat as well. I highly recommend this tour.

Very realistic - worth the trip!. Paid a discounted fare to enter - there are several different tiers of discounts. If you are under 26, you pay 2000 forints. While the guide appeared to be going through the motions, I thought the exhibits inside were very realistic and gave a very harrowing angle to look at WW2 and the Cold War. Highly recommend this place if you like to mix in a bit of history - albeit a somewhat sombre dose.

Very entertaining and informative visit. Amazing combination of history from WW2 to Cold War and beyond. Tour guide has excellent English and really knew her stuff. Incredible the conditions those patients,doctors and nurses had to put up with!

Well worth the visit. This one-hour tour offers a fascinating tour and a brief glimpse into Hungary's challenging recent past. The hospital, built during WWII is the centerpiece of the tour, while in later years the area was also used as a nuclear fallout shelter - and specifics are also highlighted along the way. Very educational. Quite compelling, even a bit scary if you will. We took our young child (6 years old) - which we do NOT recommend because it was quite a frightening experience. But for adults? Excellent. Tours in English and Hungarian. Well done.

good attraction. Very interesting Museum, shame your not allowed photos.Seems like they original idea was a museum you could walk round yourself, but is now a guided tour only which means you can't stop to read most of the info boards. Lovely and cool in the summer heat.

Interesting but not with little kids. First of all: bring a jacket! We were there when we had 38 degrees Celsius and we were freezing in there. Interesting story behind the hospital, but i would not go there with kids as they have those wax figures which partly look a little shocking. It was a nice experience but I would not visit a second time as there are so many amazing things to do in Budapest.

A Real Eye Opener. Amazing how the doctors.. nurses etc were able to carry out their work under such conditions.. if you visit just one place when in Budapest it should be here.Created in the caverns 50 feet under the Buda Castle there are approximately 10ks of interconnecting tunnels and caves that served as a hospital during 1944/45 used to process the wounded and dead during this time of war.. many died and the dead had to be taken out under the cover of darkness and buried in bomb craters.designed to treat 60 - 70 at any time records show that as many as 600 were housed and treated at one stage which resulted in food and medical supplies being exhausted.. Eventually horses were brought in .. killed and used a food source for allThe tour takes round an hour during which you will see original medical equipment hospital wards as they were then and about 70 gory wax figures depicting conditions .. as per my title it is an eye opener to observe how people attempted and survive the Nazi invasion

A "Secret Gem" Under the Castle. This was an hour-long tour with more than 70 life-size manikins that allowed you to experience a hospital during WWII and then the fear of nuclear attack during the Cold War after the hospital was converted to a shelter in case of nuclear attack. The guide was amazing. My 13 year-old grandson loved the fully-assembled helicopter and Jeep, deep inside the cave system. I had to occasionally look away from the realistic operating rooms showing victims of the War.

Spend a couple of hours engrossed in the history of this building. A visit to the Hospital In The Rock is a must.It takes you through different phases of its life as part of the history of Budapest. The hospital dates back to World War II and was operational during the 1956 Revolution to treat wounded civilians and soldiers. In the late 1950s it was expanded to withstand chemical and nuclear attacks during the Cold War. Interesting to compare their fear of us and ours of them during the cold war.

A top spot if you are a history buff. This was the Nazis/Hungarians last stand during WW2 in Budapest. They eventually tried to escape and either were captured or were killed. During WW2 it was a hospital/base until the Soviets arrived in the Siege of Budapest. During the Cold War it served as a bomb shelter and also a hospital. Now it is pretty much a wax museum displaying what went on here in the last 100 years.

Great experience. This museum has a very entertaining and unique way of preseting this building's past and also some adjacent history considering Budapest. It's something that sticks to your memory. The guides were friendly and spoke great English. Also, the souvenir shop is nice! I really liked it. I really loved it and I would recommend anyone to visit it during their stay in Budapest.

Time capsule. Unique kind of time capsule: reminders of ww II, soviet occupation, hungarian revolution (1956), cold war and atomic threat. Friendly guide, could appreciate a little bit less haste (tour takes less than an hour)

Unique experience. It's not often you get to see something unusual - this was the one and only top-secret hospital!It began as a safe place to treat WWII war casualties (being converted from natural underground caverns) and to see original hospital equipment and recreations of original wards complete with wax "people" is fascinating enough; but then when Hungary was annexed by the Soviets it became an experimental Atomic Bomb radiation treatment centre. Spellbinding tour!

Very interesting and informal tour. Wasn't sure what to expect when we visited here but at the end of the tour we were glad we attended.You start of with a small video explaining a few things then you get a guided tour with a knowledgeable guide, whole tour takes an hour.It's well worth coming to find out about a little bit of history of this place that didn't become public knowledge until 2002.

Not reliving war or revolution (you never lived it), but actually experiencing.... A totally unconventional museum or hospital. No matter if your interest is museum, history or medicine, or other, this place and story will smoke you. It starts with just caves, and includes war, revolution, hospital care, and nuclear war. A highly interesting place and story.

A must-see in budapest. It's incredible to see how so few people changed the lives of so many.
A very interesting exhibition with wax figures illustrating life "in the rock".
Worth Your Time. Worth the visit if you would like to learn more about medical history in the past and their plans for the future.

Very interesting. We joined an English tour at 1pm. Firstly we were put in a room to watch a short film about the hospital's history. The film was in Hungarian with English subtitles which were at the bottom of the screen so fairly difficult to see when sat down. After the film we were offered coats to borrow as the hospital is a little cold. Our guide spoke excellent English and was very knowledgeable. The tour was interesting and lasted an hour, the only criticism was that the group was large so at times it could be difficult to hear the guide and some members of the group were slower to catch up. Overall very good and well worth a visit.
Awesome History. This place was hard to find, but it was awesome! They have tours in English with knowledgable guides. It's like walking through a time capsule. No photos allowed!

Visit another timelap. This is a very different experience from others I have had. You walk in the cave seeing different rooms and the guide tells you the story about the hospital under world war 2 and the function that the hospital had in it. The guide was very god telling this story so when you came out ind daylight again, it was almost like you had beed in another world. Hop on/of buses stops nearby.
Hospital in the Rock. This is a wonderful museum that really brings to life the travails of Budapest in very recent years. Well worth the admission. Bring a sweater as it is chilly.

Amazing Hospital. This is a truly fascinating place for the medically minded - an entire hospital built into the limestone caves under the castle district of Buda. It was built in the 1930's and was stretched to the limit during the siege of Budapest in the Second World war. During the cold war the communist regime kept it top secret, to be used as a hospital and nuclear shelter in case of nuclear attack. It is now a very well maintained museum with regular tours in English and Hungarian. The clinic rooms, wards , operation theatres are all exactly preserved with original equipment and wax models of staff and patients.The huge generators which provided the power and fresh air apparently still function. Unfortunately no photography is allowed inside, and the tiny souvenir shop has no postcards either. If you are a doctor or nurse and have ID to prove it you get a discount on the entry fee. Not for the claustrophobic, though!

Unique Experience. We stumbled across Hospital in the Rock while in the area for the Fisherman's Bastion - I'm so glad we did as this was not in our guide book and we would have missed it otherwise.The Hospital in the Rock is a huge cave system which was a hospital during various states of unrest in the city. It was also a nuclear bunker, although did not have to be used for these purposes. The tour around the hospital takes around 1 hour, and is reasonably priced for this amount of time - lots of discounts are offered for under 26, over 65, students etc. The hospital features several exhibitions brought to life with wax work dummies. I personally was not overly keen on the wax works as I love to visit places that are hugely authentic and reasonably untouched. However, that's just my personal preference - I cannot criticise the wax works themselves which were so realistic and a great way to bring the exhibition to life if you're into that type of attraction. My only other complaint is that the tour groups are quite big. It was hard to hear from the back, which meant we had to look at things quickly to ensure we stuck near the guide and didn't fall behind. Perhaps this is less of an issue if you avoid a midday tour in August! All in all I would recommend this attraction for a unique, interesting experience.

Hidden gem!. So worth a visit! I don't want to give too much away and ruin it - but so much medical history to be seen. Truly amazing and hard to concieve the awful conditions the doctors, nurses and patients had to endure. Brilliantly recreated with wax, really bringing it to life. What makes this tour though is the guides. Ours was fab (sorry don't remember your name!), so enthusiastic and passionate about the subject. A lot of original equipment is housed in the museum; from drugs, to chloroform to instruments and machinery. A must, especially if you have an interest in Medicine! Personally I enjoyed more than the Terror Museum.

Nice way to cool off. We arrived 20 minutes before another tour so we had to wait. The tour starts with an orientating video, don't sit in the back of the room. The video is in hongarian with english subtitles, you can't read them in the back. The museum tour is interesting. It can get chilly in the caves so they provide large cloakes. It's a nice way to get out of the heat for about an hour. Major bonus: teachers living in the EU can get in for free!
No expectations, big surprise. Not sure what to do on our last day in Budapest. The tour was very informative and a good pace to see everything in one hour.

Photos not allowed inside. The one hour tour thru the Hospital in the Rock (on Castle Hill) explains its history and usage from inception thru the war years into modern day when it was "taken out of commission" .displays are set up very well, complete with wax figures and the tour guide did a fantastic job relaying history in a nut shell
Unique museum. If you are open to see some unique places in Budapest, this museum is one of the best what you have to visit.
Great experience. Very interesting, you can learn a lot about history. I think there is no more place like this in Europe.

Very interesting. Supervised tour through the structure. Very interesting history. Tour could have gone slower near the written pieces on the wall but it was a large group. The intact supplies and operating rooms are worth the money to get in.

One of Our Favorite Tours. Maybe it was because it was raining outside, however, this amazing place was well worth the visit. There are tours in English and the tour guides have a great way of covering the history of this most recently a hospital. Its history goes back as far as the castle though it has seen many iterations since, all of which were interesting.

This is a one hour tour and very realistic. When you go in you will notice how cold the rooms are. Take a sweater if it is cool. The hospital is just like it was in the 40's and 50's. The charactors are very realistic as well

Very interesting!. This was one of the most interesting places we visited whilst we were here. The history is very interesting and gives you an insight into the history of Hungary. However I would have liked more time to take everything in, the tour is a guided one and felt a little rushed. However the guide was very knowledgeable. Tour lasts for about 50 minutes and although it is cool around the site this was a welcome break from the heat of the day.

Interesting place to visit. Good hour's tour started at 11am. Very amusing/disturbing mannequins illustrate the story! Incredible to think of the thousands of ill and injured people living, eating, washing, being operated on and sadly dying in such a cramped environment.

overrated. this is just a bunch off odd wax statues, placed in several rooms around a tunnel. while the history of the place is exciting, the tour was boring. the siren at the end was the only fun thing here. I only recommend this place to doctors or nurses.

Very interesting. This is one of the most interesting attractions in Budapest. It's a 45 minutes tour of an old military bunker hospital from the second World War and the Cold War. The guide was friendly and informative. There's a rebate for health workers (doctors, nurses, etc.). They say it's cold inside the bunker but it's not that bad (we were there in July), you don't need a coat or anything.

Amazing. We visited here whilst on a four day city break and if there was only one place I could re-visit, this would be it. The guided tour with Johanna was interesting and informative.Wax figures helped illustrate the story and helped bring it to life. A definite must see!

Interesting Look Into Hungarian History. If this is the only museum that you visit in Budapest, it is definitely worth it for an understanding of Hungarian history especially during WWII. The museum is a bit off the beaten path on the Buda side of the city, and therefore not as many tourists know or care to find it. The museum offered a very real look into what life would have been like and the conditions of the "hospital" during WWII. The wax figures, although slightly creepy in the dark really helped to capture a sense of life during that time. Our tour guide spoke great english, and was very willing and able to answer any questions that we had during our tour.

Not what we expected. When we arrived there we noticed that it was a really big group for a tour. The group was almost to big to be guided by a single tourguide. Also the story was very rehearsed in stead of spontaneous. Next to that we didn't really have time to stop and look at the attributes inside the museum, which was dissapointing.
Informative. Went here on a very hot day so it was a relief to have a tour in the cool.It was very interesting and the guide knew his stuff.Good for young and old and a decent admission fee.

Unique tour of special place is extraordinary. Husband is a doctor, so he wanted to see this. I was skeptical. Turns out it's quite unique, lots to see, we had a GREAT tour guide who spoke English loud enough to hear and understand even in our very large group. The wax figures helped a lot to visualize and appreciate what happened here. Very interesting. Also nice and cool on a warm day! Teens also enjoyed it a lot.
Very interesting tour. Exhibit well done, tour very moving with lots of history. Very visual and accessible for teens. Tour guide was really good.
