Coolest thing going on the Buda side. For a unique experience, and especially for WWII, military, or medical buffs, this place is a must see! Too hard to explain, but it consists of hidden underground corridors used during and after WWII as a hospital and hiding place. google it :)

Interesting exhibition and good guiding. . Museum about the hospitals history. The different rooms are made alive with wax figures. Guiding in English or Hungarian. Very interesting if you have an interest in medical history. The children anyway found it interesting.

Unusual museum of a hospital built in a cave. Odd wax figures!. This was a very different type of museum, and very engaging for teens. The hospital was built underground and used during WWII, then as a Soviet nuclear fallout shelter. The original hospital equipment and rooms are there, a bit creepy, but gives a sense of the craziness there during the siege and WWII. The wax figures are not exactly well done, more of a caricatures of the historical figures, but interesting to look at. The nuclear fall out shelter that was added is interesting and almost comical about how little people knew about the effects of radiation. The tour includes a guided narration that is informative. You get to try out the air siren and to see the boiler room that operates to this day!
Best museum we went to. This place was a great find. It's hard to locate but worth looking for. The tour guides were so enthusiastic and it was quite eye opening.

a little dark. a bit dank and damp smelling; the guide was good though the tour felt a bit rushed. I did learn more of recent Hungarian history and it was interesting to have some idea of what the cold war was like 'on the other side'.

Quite unusual..... This is probably the strangest hospital you will ever visit, built into a mountain for safety during WWII and used again during the uprising of 1956. The visit must be with a tour, available in English, limited in size to be manageable. It takes about an hour. Our guide was a young man who did an excellent job of telling the story of this unusual place.

Do not miss this!. After the dissapointment from House of Terror, this was such a treat for us. So much to see and learn and quite cheap for what you get. I won't give up any spoilers but be sure to visit if you're interested in history/war/medicine. They also have a souvenir shop with prices so low you'll have to take one of the gas masks home with you. Great experience guaranteed!

Surprisingly good tour in Buda Castle. We took the hospital in the rock tour by chance as we were just wandering around the castle and happened to be at the entrance as the 1 hour tour was due to start. Definitely worth the visit and let's you really see into how life was during the second world war for the many German and Hungarian troops under siege in Budapest at that time. It is a very comprehensive tour even showing the nuclear shelter that is built inside. It is not the happiest of tours as the hardships endured and the sacrifices that doctors and nurses went through were amazing. A very good 1 hour trip if you are around the Castle District. Check the timings as you don't really want to be hanging around waiting for the trip as there is not much around that part of the castle.

Awesome. Really awesome museum, price is not so expensive beacuse live english guide is provided. Great place to visit to learn about history and to see original medical instruments from ww2. Definetley place to visit while in Budapest.

Amazing tour, great guide and overall experience. This is my #1 recommendation of what to do in Budapest. The hospital and the tour is situated in the caves under Buda. Our tour guide, Niki was hilarious, entertaining, and very knowledgeable. The story behind the Hospital in the Rock and the history that you learn about it and the city was fascinating. The tour was moving as you see where all of the patients were kept and when you hear about all of the stuff the doctors and nurses had to deal with. Strongly recommend it!

Unexpected and pleasant surprise. We stumbled upon this whilst visiting the castle district and I have to say it was one of the highlights of our trip to Budapest.It brought to life the harsh reality of what went on in Budapest during WW2 and the Cold War. The reconstruction of the wards and operating theatres made it easier to imagine what it must have been like to work under such severe conditions. The guided tour is in English and Hungarian only and some may find it a little claustrophobic but I can thoroughly recommend it.

Quite different story of Budapest. We took the English speaking tour with an excellent and humorous guide. It was a fascinating story of Budapest under siege, courage and appalling conditions. Amazing geographical foundation for siting the hospital here. Well worth a visit when you are in Buda and have the time

Very surprising and unusual tour. This is a unique hospital that saved thousands of lives in WWII and beyond. Then prepared as a cold war nuclear hardened facitlity to take care of hundreds of casualties. The tour starts with a subtitled captioned film and then goes on a tour through the entire facility. As a retired USAF nurse, I found it amazing how the heroes who worked here saved so many and how such a unique facility was builtTruly amazing

Recommended. Nice museum about the hospital throughout the last centuries. The guided tour is mandatory but the guides speak very good english, which is not so evident in hungary. Discount for students.

Very nice museum with visualized rooms. Very nice (and cool in the hot summer) museum. Every room in this cave was decorated as it supposed to be during the hospital years including equipment and human-like dolls. Absolutely an must-see.

Unique and historical part of Budapest. This is a unique part of Budapest. A historical site of the city, a must visit attraction. I was deeply touched by the tour. Anna was a really good guide and told us a lot of information about the place. During my visit I traveled back in time and I could imagine myself in the 40'. A lot of people, even volunteers were working here to safe as many life as they could. Sometimes the hospital was overcrowded and there was a lack of medicine and pills. They did their best as Anna said they are heros in our eyes.The guided tour is about 50mins long! Some people might find it a bit scary because they show the real (original) - exact thing what happened here.My visit was unforgettable. Thank you for the experience!

Very interesting. Really enjoyed our visit. Good to learn some of the history of the Czech Rep during and after the war. Our guide was interesting, informative and spoke very good English. Nice and cool on a hot day. Lots of exhibits to see. Worth spending a couple of hours here when in Budapest.

Scary for little kids but interesting. This is an interesting glimpse into a lost world -- great for Cold War buffs. My 6-year-old found it very frightening (gas masks, sirens, graphic bloody mannequins) but otherwise worth the trip.

Great if you like weird unique historical attractions. This place is on the backside (easy ~5-7 min walk, including short stairs or elevator) of Castle Hill. It was a hospital at various times, plus an emergency shelter, atomic bomb shelter, etc. Lots of history here from WW2 through Hungarian independence. - tours start at the top of the hour. You must take a tour, cannot visit on your own. Tours take ~1 hr, including a short film. If you're early, you can wait there (there are some chairs), or walk back to the top of the hill and shop or get a snack to kill time. - cool (not cold) inside -- nice on a hot day. - there are medical exhibits (it was a hospital at times) and there are a number of waxwork dummies, so if either of those freak you out, you might want to give this a miss. - the floor is uneven in places, and the ceilings low, so watch your step.

Informative yet different. My partner and I visited the Hospital in the Rock yesterday and found it to be both informative and interesting. Our guide Laura was very knowledgeable, spoke good English and was easy to understand. It is a one hour tour of an old WW2 and then Cold War hospital initially used by the Red Cross. Represented by some aged looking yet funny mannequins, it depicted life in the hospital at that time. Special mention to the gifts available in the shop afterwards - we got a working gas mask and small furry toy representing a disease associated with a clapping sound...
Good tour. We had a good tour of the museum, its a quite quick walkthrough in the historical labyrinth but gives you a glimpse on Hungarian history and miseries of war.

Must see!. I visited this museum on a free day in Budapest and had a wonderful time. My friend and I went when it opened right at 10am because you have to take a guided tour through the museum and English tours are offered every hour on the hour. The tour starts with a movie describing the history of the hospital/nuclear bunker. It is in Hungarian but with English subtitles. After, our guide took us through the museum. Coats are provided if needed because the caves make the museum a cooler temperature. The guide was easy to understand and very knowledgeable. You learn about how the hospital was used through viewing wax figures and furniture set up in the rooms as it was during the 1930-1960s. You even get to see the machinery that was brought in when the museum was used as a nuclear bunker. The only thing that would make this place better is if you could take pictures inside or even if they had pictures available in the shop to buy because it is such a cool place! Definitely worth a visit while in Budapest.

A great museum. This is a facinating museum, groups are guided through the vast tunnel network on the hour by excellent English speaking guides ( other language guides seemed to be available also). The exhibits give you great insight into the hospitals past during the Second World War, Cold War and revolution. The museum is full of original hospital/ medical equipment from the 40' to the 60's. Entry costs are good value, Dr's, nurses and other hospital personnel can receive a discount on entry, although this may be difficult to prove is you work oversees....overall highly recommended.

Unique Tour of Cave Medical Facility. This would be of particular interest to any hospital or medical professional. Our tour guide was interesting and easy to understand. She shared the history of this underground cave hospital and it was illustrated with life-size figures in each department of the medical facility.

Wonderful escape from the Buda Heat. We found ourselves with a couple of hours of free time while on Castle Hill and saw the signs about the Hospital in The Rock, and the greatest "Bunkers" of history. So we took a chance and found the tour and the guide both exceptional. We waited about 20 minutes for the "English" guided tour, but kept occupied by the interesting items available in the "shop". We were very tempted to purchase a genuine cold war era gas mask for our Son, or even one of the original glass syringes as an oddity. In addition to the fascinating history of the Hospital from WWII, the Hungarian Uprising of 1956, and the new additions from the cold war, the bunker and caves are a desirable respite from the 100 degree heat of mid July.

Fantastic . A really interesting place to visit when in Budapest for those interested in some history. You must go with a tour guide and our guide was really helpful and very funny. Around 15 degrees inside, it was a nice cool change from the heat in summer.

Hidden Tour. I've got to visit this place when the electric gone off. It was dark in there and we have been guided by a friendly guide that explains a lot in details on every spot we went. The experience is great, probably is because of the darkness. Interesting place to go and learn some history.

Great history and a must for us medical professionals. This tour through the underground hospital in Pest was a highlight for me- imagining how it was made and then utilized during WWII and the Communist revolution was intriguing and they have done a great job of recreating scenes in these small confined underground rooms where doctors and nurses saved people's lives. The tour was informative but too large of a group- stay near the front or you won't always hear the guide since you are walking through small tunnels and rooms (to be in the front of the actual tour, sit in the back when you first watch the movie). Grab the wool coats they offer for free at the start too- it was chilly (even though it was 90 outside) and I was glad I had one. A different type of attraction that is well worth it!

Very interesting - Good tour guide. We went here with a group of 56 boys on 2 organised tours. The staff were very friendly and patient and the boys were very interested in the history of Budapest and the surrounding cave system. A worthwhile visit if you are organising a tour or going solo. Our boys even decided that gas masks would make brilliant souvenirs!!!

Brilliant Tour. . This tour was recommended by our hotel staff and we were glad they told us about it. It was a brilliant place to see. So interesting and the tour guide was great which made it better again. I would advice anybody visiting Budapest to visit this place as its just brilliant.

Intersting place. Unfortunately not possible to take photos, but the place itself is really interesting. The english speaking guide was so lovely with a terrible accent... :D but anyway great to visit. Btw it was quite cold there, didn't want to leave :D

interesting, informative and unique. The tour we were given at this museum was very informative, covering the biggest and most important of the cities past 80 years of history. It has a unique aspect that it is heavily involved in the second world war, and the cold war, as well as key events specific to Budapest (Seige of Budapest and Hungarian revolution). As well as the historic aspects, the displays of the medical side are also very interesting, there is a lot of old medical equipment which shows the changes in it since the times.The tour is probably about an hour long, but well worth it, its a bit cooler in there at around 16 degrees Celsius, which in the summer months is very nice to be cooler, but some people may want to take warmer clothes, although there are some coats available. For me the biggest problem was not being able to take photos, but actually this did mean that i really took in the contents of the tour rather than just taking lots of photos which is what i usually end up doing.

Interesting and engaging. we are not big museum-goers, but this one was really interesting. You have to go in with a tour, ours was in English and the guide's english was very good and she was really friendly and made the tour interesting. There are lots of wax figures representing all the staff and patients that have been resident in the hospital at some point, lots of equipment and machinery to see. You can't take any photos.It's about 15-18 degrees down there and the tour lasts about an hour so if you go in summer, take an extra long sleeved top if you often feel the cold. It is a pleasant relief if it's 35 degrees outside though!The entrance was 4,200 ft (about 14 euros) full price but they quickly offered discounts to medical professionals, teachers, military, students and pensioners!

A secret place. We stumbled on the hospital when wandering around the castle district. Amazing that the Germans did not find it during WW2. When you have done the tour check out Cafe Miro above ground near where they supplied the water for the hospital.

Very cool and unusual attraction. I generally like to check out underground exhibits when they exist in a city. Hospital in the rock was no exception. It served as a hospital and bomb shelter during the war and is a great look back into history.
Excellent!. I visited this museum on recommendation from our tour guide. Great value for money and a nice way to get out of the heat. The guide was fantastic.

Fascinating piece of history. This was a nice cool break from the heat wave of July.
The caves were used as a bomb-proof hospital during World War 2 and afterwards.
Doctors and nurses, bring proof of your professional status and receive a discount on admission!

A must visit. This time capsule is not all that well advertised which is a great shame. We found it to be one of the most thought provoking experiences of the whole trip. When you've seen the museum and churches on Castle Hill follow the signs to The Hospital In The Rock for a unique experience.

An interesting underground hospital museum. To start off with, the hospital is a nice place to escape from the current heat. Within it's underground bunkers and rooms is a refreshing 15-18 degree environment. The history of the hospital and it's inhabitants is expressed through the apparatus and wax statues that litter its halls along with the information given by the mandatory tour guide. It gives a great glimpse into how some Hungarians experienced WW2 and more importantly the siege on Budapest. Would recommend it if you want to try something different.

Super amazing!. This is quite a different experience.. Lovely museum.. Very well done with wax statues and old medical apparatus. Fascinating! It's perfect to go on a hot afternoon to avoid the heat. Hour long walk underground ..

Underground historical hospital, but a bit cheesy. We decided to visit this hospital/Cold War bunker museum in the sweltering heat wave of Budapest. Although it says that the tours are on the hour, every hour, the tours are actually every 30 minutes. You are first shown a short movie regarding the history of the hospital/bunker and then a guided tour is provided. Our tour guide spoke very good English but seemed a little bit bored and rushed. It was her fifth tour of the day and she was probably ready to go home. Although there are many interesting artifacts, the wax figures simply look cheesy like mannequins in Third World countries.  The historical information provided seems to have a lot of gaps. They quickly gloss over the fact that Hungary cooperated with the Nazis and ignore the fact that they aided in the extermination of 500,000 Jews. Then, in another section, they ask for pity and sympathy when they were bombed and the city was destroyed by the Russians at the end of the war. There is no photography and a discount is provided if you are a nurse or doctor, with appropriate id.

Most interesting museum in Budapest. EU citizen over 70 gets FREE entrance. Visiting Budapest for the first time, we are doing 6-night whirlwind tour of the city till all 10 toes ache every night. Of all the major sites & dozen museums we visited, I liked the Secret Hospital & Bomb shelter the best. Yes, the 1-hr guided tour is in a large group, but stay close to the guide and you learn a lot and feel transported to how it was then as a hospital during the war. We visited during the sweltering heatwave, so the cool temperature inside was a real bonus.Reason for 4 star instead of 5: The guided tour is on scheduled program, so you have to wait till the tour starts, so you will need more than an hour total.GENERAL TIP FOR MUSEUM GOERS: Most of museums in Budapest are FREE for an EU national over 70 years old. Have some form of ID as a proof.

Very worthwhile to visit. This was definitely the most interesting thing we did in the Castle Hill area. It was slightly hard to find from the top of the hill, and required walking down a steep flight of steps (though there's a lift if you need it, I believe). Our group was not too large on the day we visited, so we were still able to hear the tour guide and see everything. The wax figures are a little hokey, but they do add to the atmosphere. The tour guide was pleasant and spoke English very well, though his spiel was pretty canned.A truly fascinating part of history! I was very happy we convinced our family to join us - everyone who went on the tour was pleased with it.

An interesting insight into an underground emergency hospital of WW2.. This is a little off the usual tourist trail of Budapest, but for those with a particular interest in medical history (like me) it is a must! The Buda hill was naturally full of small caves in a network, and this network was converted into a fully functional hospital for use during the Nazi attacks of the second world war, during the siege of Budapest. Later, it was prepared as a nuclear shelter. The tour takes place at hourly intervals, so you need to book ahead, and it is a little chilly in the cave network. Much of the original equipment in the overcrowded wards is on show, and in operating theatres etc. along with the remarkable engineering to keep the air fresh and the water flowing. Excellent guide. Note, if you are over 65 and an EEA citizen, you get reduced entrance rates, and free if over 70 and from the EEA.

Interesting hospital. My husband and I enjoyed our tour of Hospital In The Rock. While learning the history of this complex of caves was interesting, the wax figures lent a "wax museum" feeling to the experience.

Crowded . Myself and my two children (11 and 13) went on the tour on July 14, 2015. I was really interested in the hospital section unfortunately the tour for the English group was at 30 persons. ( the other group was only 7 I wish I could have understood Magyar )We could not see what was being talked about until after she had done all the talking and had a hard time to hear or learn about these parts of the tour. By the end of the tour we weaseled our way closer to the front ( hard to do in such tight - spaces) so we could hear and see what was being said. It is a fascinating place and incredible to realize what state of the art it was for its time and to be in caves underground what history. You can not take pictures so that makes being able to hear and see the exhibits as they are being talked about important.

Historical Site but a little disappointing!. The hospital in the rock was an interesting concept during world war II. It was a site I was interested in viewing but was a little disappointed. They had us in a group of approximately 30 plus and led us around from room to room with a guide who would provide limited information on the use of the areas. You didn't have much time in each area to explore. I would have liked to have had more time rather than getting moved on to the next room. On the positive it was was interesting and fascinating to see.

What a fabulous experience. I was given reduced entry fee as I am a nurse. Extremely interesting with an excellent guide. Sad we were unable to take photos and there were no information booklets or post cards for sale.

Can't tell it's a hospital. After leaving the castle we walked right past the Hospital in the Rock. Instead of going into it we just read the sign in front of it. We were lucky someone pointed it out to us.

An interesting historical sight - a definite must visit. Definitely visit this sight. This is an old WWII hospital turned Cold War bunker located in Budapest's naturally formed underground caves. It is now set up like a museum. You can see original medical instruments, communications devices, posters, etc. Guided tours in English. Very informational and interesting.

totally one off and a must see. Tours every hour on the hour . Tunnelled out of the Castle rock and still with all the old hospital equipment inside. A Hospital turned Cold War Nuclear bunker hidden from view for many years. Excellent guided tour but a shame you could not take any pictures.

Intersting. Visited here to see how it was in the "Cold War" . The tour takes you through some interesting aspects of life in Hungary, and how it operated both in World War 2 and after under the Soviet Rule.

Worth of seeing. Tour started with short review video which was squeesing history of the hospital. Tour itself was very exiting. Inside the tunnels were many wax dolls, gus, helicopter and original medical equipments including x-tray from the fourthies. Tour itself was smooth and exiting. After tour there is possibility to buy old army stuff like gas mask for 4eur price. Definately worth of seeing.

Best attraction in Budapest!. This really was a fantastic experience for an extremely low price. There was a short video on the history of the hospital to watch before the tour began which was very interesting. We were shown around by Rudi who was very knowledgable and friendly. We were able to visit the actual wards and operating theatres that were used which were all brought to life by wax models. There was an opportunity to work the sirens which were very loud! We also could see the generators in the deepest point of the caves. I would highly recommend this tour.

Interesting. We decided to go here after finding out that the Buda Castle Labyrinth was closed. The tour was quite interesting, and the tour guide's English was excellent. It is a bit cooler down there - which is a nice respite from the midday heat in Budapest - so bring a cardigan.

Very cool. Great way to spend an hour or so - very interesting hospital with great history. Hard to imagine what life must have been like. We visited when it was very hot outside and the temperature underground made for a pleasant change. We had a good knowledgable guide who spoke very good English.
A good find. Quite hard to find this interesting museum, built into the rock. Chilly inside, but you are provided wit a blanket. A good way to learn Hungarian history. Really enjoyed.
Dramatic. As a nurse I found this hospital very interesting. The challenges the doctors and nurses faced are overwhelming. Very well put together museum.

Friendly English-speaking tour guide. Our tour guide was brilliant and incredibly informative plus we all got together to take a group photo at the end! Tours run on the hour but we arrived 30 minutes early and they advised we buy our ticket straight away in case the tour sold out. Definitely gives you a lot to think about, especially the fact that it was going to be a nuclear bunker and was kept totally secret until 2002. My boyfriend didn't enjoy it as much though, so it may be more for someone that really enjoys history.

Damn cool!. Hospital In The Rock has that perfect balance of history and fun... our tour guide was lovely and really well informed, the hospital itself is both really creepy and really cool, and it is worth it just for how cold it is down there! English guided tours run every hour and take about 45 mins.It only costs the equivalent of a few euros and is definitely worth a look if you are going over to the Buda side anyway, although I wouldn't set aside time for it if you have a lot to cram into a short trip as the other attractions there such as Fisherman's Bastion and St Matthias Church are more of a must-see.

Amazing tour. Great history lesson!. We loved this tour. So informative and interesting. We found out about it from another tourist in Vienna so we made a point of going. The medical tools and machinery were fascinating.

hospital in the rock budapest. Very very interesting. Really enjoyed this. Coast very little to enter and the guide was very knowledgeable. The toilets are very basic but that was fine not somewhere to sit andhave coffee. The history of the place is fascinating would recommend visiting

great, must see. The hospital in the rock is a very unique experience. The tours start on the hour every hour and they are in English and Hungarian. There is a short film to start then the tour guide takes you through the hospital. Our guide was informative and friendly. There are still original medical equipment and stuff and our guide told us about the history of the hospital and the things that have happened there. It’s a definite on the list of places to visit in Budapest. Its best to buy your ticket in advance to avoid waiting for the next tour. Also you can't take photos on the tour.

A must do trip. Very interesting with friendly informative staff.
This place is very impressive and it's history very moving. Our tour guide was brilliant and so friendly and knowledgable.
Remember to take Id as there are discounts for students, under 26 years old and teachers.
One of the best sights of Budapest.

Remarkable!. This fantastic little museum was one of the highlights of our recent trip to Budapest. It is signposted from Castle Hill, but the easiest way to find it is to take the small pedestrianised road off the square outside St Matthias Church. At the end of the road is an elevator in a wall and the museum is just to the right at the bottom. Entry is by tour only, English language tours are on the hour every hour and it's worth noting that they offer a discount to health service personal so take some ID with you.The hospital was created during WWII by linking together naturally occuring caves in the Buda hills. They stay at a constant cool temperature, but thick jackets and coats are provided in case you get cold, there is no need to carry them with you if it is warm outside.The tour takes about 50 minutes and the guides lead you through the caves visiting the fully equipped emergency room, operating theatre and wards where patients had to 'top and tail' in bed to fit them all in. The wax dummies are rather dubious, but they actually add to the atmosphere.Experiencing the cramped conditions and seeing the basic equipment of the time really makes you appreciate the dedication of the medical profession at the time, especially considering that it was a Red Cross hospital, so they treated all those in need regardless of which side they were fighting for. Remarkable!The hospital was only fully functioning for a number of years. With the advent of the Cold War, parts of it were then converted into a nuclear bunker. It is still fully functionable and for this reason no photographs are allowed during your visit.Well worth a visit.

Another gem in Buda!. On one of our many jaunts to Castle Hill we decided to go see the hospital in the rock.Wow!!! it is amazing! They give you a guided tour (not possible otherwise), and really bring it to life. There is a video to begin with and then the guide takes you into the caves divided up into rooms including an operating theatre!There is a tourist information bureau in the main square (Szentharomsag terre) and they will tell you exactly how to get there. It's walking distance (a beautiful walk).

Pleasantly surprised. A really interesting and informative tour around an old WW2 hospital and nuclear bunker. It was reasonably priced and lasted about an hour, we were taken around by a tour guide as it's like a maze down there and our guide was very knowledgable and polite. No negative points to make about this attraction.

Very interesting. This is a must for history enthusiasts. Formed completely under ground and fully out fitted for surgical and care of patients. The guides are well informed, and cover the discovery, initial use, the outfitting for WWII, the revolution, up to modern time usage. Older wax mannequins, not the best work around, and very graphic. It is chilly, wear a jacket or sweater (they have coats available, won't suggest it). Well, worth a visit.

Fun and informative . My family and I visited last year but would definitely go again. The staff were informative and helpful and my 6 year old enjoyed the experience. It's a must if you travel to Hungary

Best of our 3 days in Budapest. Almost didn't do this due to lack of pre-information, but glad we took the time to travel on the vinicular up the hill to the Hospital in the Rock. This to me is a NOT-TO-Miss site about how medical needs were handled in secrecy during World War !!. Superb value.

Fascinating Visit. This underground hospital and former nuclear shelter site provides a fascinating insight into its wartime use as a hospital and post war use as a nuclear shelter. The English speaking guides are very good and informative, and a lot of trouble has been gone to in order to touch on many aspects of fairly recent history of the site and of Budapest including excellent displays. Located close to the Castle on Buda, entrance fee very reasonable, time needed for a visit roughly 1 to 1 1/2 hours.

Such an interesting experience. Visiting this museum was one of the nicest and most interesting things that we did during our stay in Budapest. The hospital and its history are VERY interesting, and all the staff are very, very passionate about it.

A unique experience. We stumbled on this as we were walking around the castle district. What a find! Really, really interesting part of Budapest's history. I highly recommend it. The only down side is that picture taking is not allowed.
Fascinating!. A fascinating look into the provision of medical services during times of war and nuclear threat. Very enjoyable visit with an excellent tour. Also a chance to cool down!

Wonderful and Unique. I saw this in a guidebook and wanted to check it out since I'm a nurse. They accept the local currency along with euros, and card. My boyfriend got a discount for being a young EU member, and I got a discount for being in the medical field. There were other discounts as well, but all you need is to bring proof to use them. Tours start at the beginning of each hour, and there are about 30 total walking through. You start with an intro movie and then break into 15 people to walk through the wards. The tours are in English. They provide coats since it gets cold in the hospital. This is great for kids too, the ones on our tour loved the wax figures and seeing the supplies instead of empty rooms. There is also a little gift shop and food and water. I really loved the information!

A unque hospital. Out of ancient caves, a hospital was built for use during WW II and the cold war. It's fully stocked. The tour starts with the history of the caves. You are taken into the hospital and can imagine what it would have been like.
The Hospital in the Rock. This is an underground hospital used during the revolution and cold war. It has artifacts on display which were used when it was built.

A Worthwhile Insight into Important Budapest History!. This is definitely worth doing. You learn the history of this unusual and important site on Castle Hill. It's amazing the different uses that this location was used for over the years.

A very interesting sight in the Buda castle. Puppets not as in Madame Tussaud, but almos........t and a lot better, then in the Panoktikum, (also in the Buda Castle), interesting historical facts and tools from a time of the war, that you might not see even in a museum.

Unusual. Because I am a surgeon, it was specially interesting for me. Beside that, I got a entry discount (for the doctors, nurses, teachers..). I saw all this old instruments used for the surgery during WWII down there. My girlfriend is not in medicine and she is not history lover, but anyway, she found the place interesting. Only 5 min walking from St. Matthias Church.

Glimpse of the past!. a very interesting glimpse into the past and Budapest's history. The wax figures were a little strange at times but really painted the scene for how life was in the hospital - it's like a living museum
Hospital. An insight to how they managed because it was a red cross hospital they treated everyone no matter what side
Step back in time. You get a sense of how tough times were with bombs falling during the war. And the hospital became a shelter during the cold war. so it is really quite an interesting place

Interesting from a historic perspective. The guide gave lots of little facts which made the tour worth wile. We where puzzeled by how far doctors etc. will go trying to do something for injured people

Something completely different. Missed this museum on our last visit but so glad visited it this trip. A hospital was built in the rocks in the castle area and used during WW2. It was been realistically turns into a unique museum. Tours operate every hour on the hour from 10am. Cost 1400HUF, 1000 for those 62+ well worth a visit

Great Visit. I really didnt no what to expect ,i found it interesting but found the person giving the tour more intrested in there phone messages than telling people about stuff i found the story's about the war facisinating
Hospital in the Rock. This is an amazing story. Graphically told. Our guide was exceptional. This exhibition has to be viewed otherwise the storyline would be hard to comprehend.

Weak. Hungary has a fascinating history, of which this hospital is part. But the tour is very mediocre and does not bring that history alive. The best part was the introductory video. The guide had some interesting factoids, but mostly said little more than, "This was the registration room ... This was the women's ward ...", and the displays do not make up the deficit.I wouldn't quite say I regret going, but there are better uses of your time and money!

history revealed. Very interesting well set up historical site detailing what went on there during the war years tour guides were very knowledgeable and there were actual films of the hospital during the war

The Hospital in the Rock. A very interesting trip - the guide was excellent - you felt she was not just 'reading from a script' but had a depth of supplementary knowledge. Free for over 70s/half price for 62yr + and need your passport to get these offers. Plan to get there early to book your hour long trip for later in the day as it is very popular.

Amazing Tour. The escorted tours are timed and limited numbers of people. We got our reservation and came back for the timed tour. The tour guide was knowledgeable and entertaining. The hospital was amazing, if you have the time don"t miss it.

Interesting bit of history. This unusual hospital, literally built into the side of a mountain, was fun. There is a good, 15 minute orientation film to watch prior to beginning the tour. It's very chilly inside (they do provide wool capes), but it was fascinating to see state-of-the-art medical care of the 40's and 50's. About 100 very lifelike wax figures of doctors, staff and patients really add to the atmosphere.

Better than expected!. We had a few hours to kill and could not get in the Parliament. We tried this and got a discount for being a teacher and nurse and had friendly service. The best part was learning all about Budapest's history. We enjoyed seeing something very special and unique there.

Excellent tour. A very interesting tour of the hospital that was built in the caves of buda during ww2. Our tour guide Nora was very informative and enjoyable to listen to. The subject matter can be sobering at times but that's reflective of the history of the area. By the way, it's really not that cold down there ;-)

Fascinating History in the Caves Beneath Buda Castle. A one-hour guided tour takes through the emergency hospital that operated in the caves beneath Buda Castle during the Second World War. You will see examination rooms, patient wards, operating rooms which contain original furniture, instruments, and equipment. The exhibit is enhanced with wax figures which serve to reenact events of the time. You will also see the Soviet Cold War Bunkers that operated in the 1960's. Our tour guide was great and the tour takes about 1 hour.

An Amazing Look at Resourcefulness. It is hard to imagine the labyrinth underneath or the conditions under which people worked to save lives until you take this tour. You start the tour with a movie, and then your guide leads you through the hallways, patient areas, operating rooms and so on, all within what used to be a cave system. (The small caves were mapped out and then connected to each other (brilliant) and then the idea of a safe hospital was born but it became more than that.) This is roughly an hour tour, worth every minute.

Brilliant - highlight of our trip to Budapest for us. Wow this was an amazing place. Engineering marvel great preservation of recent history. Tour guide was great very knowledgeable and answered everyone's questions with ease. Well worth a visit

Fascinating!. This was a former hospital carved into caves in the rock, which later became a secret Communist bunker. You start with a short video telling you the history and then get a walk-through of the hospital and Communist bunker areas. The hospital has actual equipment of the era, along with some creepy mannequins representing the medical staff and patients. There is a lot of history here and it is fascinating to learn. Tour takes about an hour. You do not need to make reservations ahead of time. Tours are in several languages - an English tour was offered right as it opened at 10 a.m. which is what we took, and there were only about 9 people in our group. Part of the tour loops back on itself and at that point the place got very crowded with large bus and/or cruise tour groups, so if you can get there early I would recommend it. It's a little chilly in the caves. They do offer some heavier jackets for guests to wear (very Communist-era looking coats) but I think it's better to BYO. You cannot take photos in the caves.

Must visit. Excellent tour in every respect. The guide and information was superb, the place itself, underground and cold lent to the atmosphere of the tour. Probably not on the top of the list of places to visit but it should be.

ambling. always wanted to go across this bridge, as have gone across its smaller brother in Marlow, England.Not disappointed as views both ways are excellent, you must then go up the lift to the Castle to get views below of it....lovely vista over Budapest..

Historical view of medicine. Unique experience to be thrown back in time - an underground hospital with life size mannequins dressed in original uniforms. Surrounded by Red cross boxes of materials ..... a very interesting journey

Well done creepy museum. Highly recommended to visit. Well done tour and well structured and maintained museum underground. Some parts a little creepy which makes it more attractive and interesting. I bought a 13 yo with us and it was eye opening for her. If you have 2-3 hours do not hesitate and join this tour.

Very interesting . This tour was quite interesting and provided insight into the Hungarian citizens roles during world war ll and particularly the importance of this specific hospital during the siege of Budapest. The tour guide was great - multilingual and was able to answer any and all questions people had. Note: if you have severe mold or mildew allergies or bad asthma, I wouldn't recommend going as the ventilation is poor.
A must-see!. I've never seen anything like it, so i'd definitely recommend a visit / tour. It's incredibly built and maintained well as a 'museum' for tourists to see. A must-see for sure!
If you have time it worths!. Nice tour, you can imagine how the hospital works during the war. It most me terrifying!! You only can enter if you go with a guide. The tour takes aprox 60min

A bit of Castle Hill history. This attraction is featured in Hungarian and English. It runs about an hour and is walking distance from St Mathew Church. Tunneling under the Buda Hills were used as a safe place from war where the sick could be treated. It has some WWII ,56 Revolution, and cold war history. Interesting. Tours were on the hour.

Hospital In The Rock - A Tribute to Those Who Served. Always interested in WWII history I was glad to see the hospital was located close to my hotel. Ticket desk gives discounts, one is for seniors, ask to see if you qualify. English tours were either every hour or half out depending on the time of day. No picture taking allowed during the tour.Interior areas were reconditioned to show exactly how it was like back in the day. Real equipment is displayed, mannequins depict how the people were.I really enjoyed the tour, the guide did a very good job explaining what it was like to work under very tough conditions without all the medical supplies needed. Many people survived the operations, died later from infection. They did the best they could with what they had.

An amazing piece of history. We visited the hospital today and it was an amazing experience. A complete maze of tunnels buried deep in the rock. The place was captured in time and had an erie atmosphere - you expect the wax dummies to come alive and talk to you ! It is a throwback to a bygone age -WW2 and the Cold War. Well worth a visit.
Very informative . An unusual tour in Budapest telling about some wartime history. I found it especially interesting as it was so unexpected.

Nice tour!. Very nice tour, very well done! The hospital is definitely a must-see as it reconstructs the hospital as in World War II. The tour guides explain everything very well, and the tour lasts for more than an hour. It is very interesting to experience the life in the hospital. Very well suited for all ages!

Surreal time capsule. We came across this place when we visited Buda Castle. The museum is located within the castle grounds, however, was very difficult to find due to the lack of signs and tourist information.We arrived just past the hour when a tour had just started. The staff we very friendly and allowed us to join this tour (rather than waiting for an extra hour!). This was one of the more authentic preserves of Hungarian history and I would recommend it for anybody who wants to experience a slice of real cold war history.

A step back in time. One of the most interesting sites in Budapest. Underneath the Buda castle lays a network of caves that were used as a hospital during World War 2 and uprising against the soviets at 1956. Today the museum in the cave illustrates how the hospital operated with the help of some of the original equipment and wax figures. It gives you a very good image of the life during these warsIt is very cold inside, they do have overcoats to borrow, but I would recommend to bring your own.. Highly recommended.

A glimpse into the hidden history of Budapest. Found this museum almost by accident after strolling down from the castle and I was glad I did. Hewn into the hill beneath the bastion, this is more a stroll through a forgotten side of Hungary's history. From the welcoming staff, perhaps surprised to see visitors, through a fascinating guided tour which went beyond the staid stuff one expects from a museum, the Hospital in the Rock allows you to see just how the Hungarian people survived in the last days of the second world war as well as feeling the sort of paranoia that existed under the Communist regime. There's a wealth of artefacts from both times as well as a series of evocative tableaux recreating the atmosphere. Time and money well spent. Take time to have a look in the "gift" shop which contains, not the usual tourist tat, but genuine Cold War memorabilia priced much more reasonably that anywhere in town

A Little Gem!. Found close to the castle. There was a lift down but it was out of action, so 4 flights of steps to walk down and up again at the end. It was a guided tour in English and an hour. It was lovely and cool down there. The history of the hospital was very interesting with good exhibits - patients (dummies) with blood and gore and much more. Even a helicopter! Worth a visit.

Life-like models and an interesting talk. Really interesting to see how this hospital was used during the war with life-like models showing what conditions were like when causalities were at their highest. The tour guide was very knowledgeable and bought the events of that time back to life. Worth a visit.

An absolutely fascinating place and a real slice of history. Normally I shy away museums and the like, I just switch off and get bored. However the Hospital in the Rock was a fascinating place where I possibly learned more about Budapest history in an hour than I did for the whole week I was there. To hear the stories of how the hospital came about and some of the conditions they had to work in, it's a miracle itself how anyone survived. The sheer grit and determination of everyone who worked and helped there is a real example of what pulling together in times of trouble means. I genuinely discovered a new found respect and admiration for the people of Hungary after learning what I did in that hour at the Hospital in the Rock.

A cool interesting place on a hot day. This was fascinating and amusing with lots of waxworks some not really connected with the hospital.one tableau political another of wartime rescue with a full sized helicopter underground! The hospital was used 1944-1945 when siege in place and again after 1956 revolution. Then later in a part we also visited there was a nuclear bunker with decontamination area. You can get a reduced rate if you can show you work in medicine ,doctors nurses etc also if over sixty

Hidden Gem. Most Hungarians aren't aware of this part of their history or its significance from WW II thru the Cold War. A great example of Hungarian ingenuity and determination in the face of such dangers. The hospital doctors and volunteer nurses (some of royalty) should be immortalized for their sacrifices and struggle to save lives regardless of which Army with limited supplies and austere conditions. Tour guide did a great job at explaining everything in English and well worth an hour of your time. Understand cave system can be a little cold but they offer you use of coats for the tour.

One of a kind. How often do you walk underground a find a hospital? The display inside was excellent, esp as everything (except for the wax models) was authentic. Coats are provided as it is cool inside during the tour. The information given by the guide was very good. The only reason I have not given an excellent rating is that I felt herded along a little too much.

Interesting health care system. I really enjoyed the visit and learning about the use of this hospital during WWII, the 1956 Uprising and the Cold War. The mannequins were a distraction from the source of information available. I especially liked seeing the original medical equipment since I'm a nurse. Overall would recommend a visit and if you get chilly in the caves you can borrow a nurses cape or military jacket

Very interesting!. It is a hospital built with the technology of the last century. Apart the fact that it was used by Nazis, it remembers us how medicine was during this period. Different concepts about infection, surgery and all below earth level.

Fantastic!. Don't miss this wonderful opportunity to take a walk back in History. Fantastic real life displays with an excellent guide who gave a wonderful understanding of the realities & the hardships of these times!
Great visit.. Had some great information...would recommend. Had a group of university students and they found it very interesting. Fee was also reasonable.

Absolutely incredible. So interesting and informative - good guide.Only guided tours no freelancing. Definately NO cameras, Parts of the site are still in use, Not just a Hospital, also a Nuclear fallout shelter during the Cold War, an element of security still exists. It can get cold inside compared to outside, visited last weekend - 34 outside, 15 insideGiven an early Birthday present - free entrance for 70 plus, my wife paid a pensioner rate. They asked for passports or photo ID to verify age - saw I would be 70 in four days and let me in free - result !!
Very interesting history. This is a great place to learn about the siege of Budapest during WWII. Got a true feeling about the difficulty of these times.

Like a walk in to history. This guided tour is very interesting and enjoyable. It is like taking a walk in the past. Our guide Niki was absolutely fabulous, very informative, funny at times and had a superb command of the English language

Lovely guided tour. The entrance is cheap compare to what you are getting. About an hour of guided tour, lots of facts and war time stories that you wouldnt otherwise learn about budapest. Great for those who are interested in war time history.

1 kilometre. I never enjoy wax museums, so the figures did ruin much of the experience. Yet, it was thrilling to visit such a clandestine and well-functioning intsitution. It's amazing what humans are capable of!

A little odd interesting museum. Tours start on the hour throughout the day. Our guide Anna was knowledgeable and entertaining as well. The history of the hospital is interesting but I really enjoyed the wax figures or mannequins. You'll get to see lots of different surgery and patient rooms, the power plant, the nuclear fall out areas, etc. My one disappointment is that photography is not allowed. It's especially nice to visit when it's hot outside as the internal temperature is probably about 60-65 degrees. They have coats available (free) to use for those who want one. Informative movie to start the tour. It takes about an hour and is well worth the 3600 HUF Its only a couple of short blocks from Mathias Church/Fishermans Bastion

VERY interesting and worth the visit!. First it was 15 degrees cooler in there which was a nice relief. This place is amazing and the history behind it is as well. The guide was very good and well informed. What they set up here back in the 30's for use during WWII, the short lived 1956 Hungarian Revolution and even adjustments made for the Cold War era is very interesting. I would definitely put this on my list of places to see in Budapest.

Don t miss it!. We were really impressed about what they did there. Is a very nice time capsule and they put a lot of effort in making it. It was definitely worth our time. Johanna(I think), our tour guide had exceptional language skills and she was very pleasant. I would not recommend it if you suffer of claustrophobia or if you do not speak English. The stories and the explanations were really important.
Amazing tour.. This is an amazing tour of a hospital which was first built to treat civilians and then a war hospital. Later to be transferred into a nuclear bunker. Definitely worthwhile visiting.

What a way to see what WW2 was like. This time capsule is well worth a visit. Excellent tour guide helps you understand not only the conditions of this unique cave-based hospital but the Hungarian viewpoint on the war. Rarely is the losing side of history depicted -- it is here and you'll see Nazi uniformed waxworks depicted here as they acted in kidnapping the prime minister's son and how that led to Hungary's continued alliance with Germany.

A different kind of museum. A different kind of museum for those who like a more experience-like approach to history. Biased of course since it deals with a difficult part of history, (the dolls of the museum wear hungarian uniforms and nazi military ones), but interersting nevertheless. Be sure to follow the guides who will help you make sense of the exhibits, tours come in half hour intervals and expect spending at least 45'/1hr. Reduced entry with Budapest Card.

Church in the rock was quite a find..... We saw the church in the rock on day two in Budapest, and it was a real find. We enjoyed the walk through and the quaint souvenir shop at the entrance/exit. I recommend taking the time to see this site.

Original sightseeing in presidential area!. Although it was a bit difficult to find, it was absolutely worth the visit. This former hospital is totally situated underground in the rocks. It´s +/-15 degrees inside, so pullover is recommended (although you can borrow old, muffy capes). For 3600 HUF you get a 10 min video and 60 min English guided tour. You cannot take pictures but they post a group picture on their website
Eeirie experience. Small tour groups that is not well known. Easy to get to if at the Fisherman's Bastion although steep steps - lift being commissioned as we where there early May. Very interesting

Major surprise. I had never heard of this 'attraction', I don't think it's very well promoted, it;s even a bit hard to find, but when you do get there..........well worth the visit. It's fascinating to see what was built there and what has been happening there, for most people hard to envisage, I would think. Brilliant tour !!
A hidden gem. Over in the 'Buda' area of the city. Easy to miss but well worth a visit. Tours on the hour. Very interesting and surprising as to what you see.

unexpected, superb. These caves were built into an elaborate underground hospital fortified against Allied bombs during the Horthy regime before and during World War II and then shielded (more or less) against anticipated nuclear radiation during the Cold War. The hospital's period ambiance and equipment has been beautifully maintained. An inspired staff member has gone to infinite pains to create a mannikin world of medical and military personnel and their grimacing bloodied patients. It's a medical geek's dream: storage rooms of 1930s medical supplies; operating rooms equipped with original blood transfusion machines. The excellent tour guide didn't gloss over realities. During the war the hospital "employed" enslaved Jewish doctors. When water failed, or power failed, everyone crouched in the stink in the darkness. I was amazed and moved by the detail and care that went into this museum and tour -- and very grateful that at the end in the gift shop we bought a surplus WWII gas mask and walked out into the sunshine.

Needs some dusting. This tour was really good, worth seeing this amazing Hospital and the tunnels that were created during the War. The only thing I would say is that it needs a bit of cleaning. Everything is dusty and so therefore the atmosphere can be musty at times. I thoroughly enjoyed the tour and it was worth seeing.

Interesting so - so. Difficult to find. No obvious signs from the hilltop. Shows the hospital's survival from second WW and Communist occupation. Like a wax museum with surgical room and hospital wards.
Excellent tour not well known. Excellent tour only 1 hour long but well worth the time. The bunker is quite large and not all is open to the public. If you like history you will enjoy it.

Fascinating. As a health care professional I was excited to visit the Hospital in The Rock. It was fascinating and well worth it. The museum has many supplies and equipment from the period. You must take the provided guided tour and tours were provided in English or Hungarian. My only complaint, as we moved from room to room the tour guide did not wait for everyone to get into the area before she started speaking. She did nothing to hurry people along or to even assure everyone got in. People just kind of stood wherever they wanted, and in some of the smaller areas, other people could not get in to see or hear. My suggestion would be to stay close to the guide so you can see and hear.

Interesting place. Nice attraction, very interesting. Guide spoke good English and was very helpful. Tour took about and hour and covered the facilities time as a hospital and as a nuclear shelter. Photography was not allowed during the tour but the guide offered to take a group photo that could be downloaded from the web site.

A Unique tour !. I would definitely recommend this tour for people with a love of history. The story of the hospital reflects the history of Budapest during the 20th century.....W.W.11, the 1956 revolution & Soviet history. The tour is well presented, with English speaking tours starting on the hour. It commences with a short film on the history of the hospital., followed by a tour through the hospital. I would recommend this tour as the hospital is such a unique, well preserved slice of Budapest history that you would not find anywhere else.

Interesting Tour through WWII. Loved the tour. Hadn't read about it but heard about it and wanted to see it for ourselves. Great history lesson and very interesting to see - and definitely worthwhile.

Interesting and insightful. The tours are guided and set off on the hour. Takes you through the history of this little hospital built into the Buda cave system originally for civilians, then during WW2, later in the Hungarian revolution and then as a cold war nuclear bunker. As you're not allowed to take photos, a group photo is taken for you to download free at their website. Top tip: teachers, nurses,doctors and members of the armed forces get in free, all you need is some form of ID. My teachers' union card was enough.

Unexpected find. As tour books indicated, one of the hardest things was just finding this place even though there were some signs on Castle Hill. We passed it by going down the far side of the Hill and then came back to it. We were able to get an English speaking tour shortly after we arrived--with our tour guide being a young woman from Russia!. Fascinating to see how Hungarians dug out old caves and turned them into a hospital, and later a bomb shelter for use during WWII and the Cold War--and how they dealt with the changing politics in their country.

First class immersive experience. No pictures allowed. This might bother some people, but its a great idea. It allows you to really listen and take in the scene. After a brief video we through on authentic wool cloaks and went into the depths. Lots of cool vintage soviet style equipment and the guide knew a great deal about the inner workings. There is some really sneaky stuff you get to learn about, I wont spoil it. The mannequins are well done and very emotive. It is a quick hour and a great way to get out of the summer sun. Favorite part was the guy on the toilet, look for him.

Yikes!. This was very interesting to me as a nurse and history lover. It would have been a terror to be either staff or patient during WWII here, sad but also inspiring. Burials done at night into bomb holes just outside. Then used for as nuclear bomb shelter for potential nuclear war.

Fills the time. The operators must have seen similar establishments abroad, and decided to create something here to make some money from tourists. Has certain points of interest, and it's a convenient add-on to a half-day program in the castle area - no more than that.

An excellent tour. Only costing us two about a fiver each, it was a very good way of spending an hour and half deep in Hungary's history and war-time exploits. Our guide was excellent. There was so much to learn about east/west politics/divisions. The waxwork dummies are dreadful, but appropriate ! I would really recommend this tour.

the best place i visited. Everything was great. the guy who show us the place, the museum itself. You need to walk a bit from the buda castle to go there but it is worth it. Please note that it has the tour every hour, so you have to be there around 15 minutes earlier to book it.

make time to see this. This tour starts with a video giving the background of the place first as a hospital, then as a bunker. You'll hear about the Siege of Budapest, in particular, and its effect on the hospital-- the stuff the staff did to keep the place up and running, without supplies, overcrowded, and with a war going overhead, is just mindboggling. The tour also covers the shift with the Cold War of turning the place into an emergency underground bunker. I heard some people complain about the cost, but I thought it was worth the money, and they have all kinds of discounts. Ask. There's probably something that applies to you. Guide spoke great English and was very understandable.
Very Cool. Surreal looking to just walk by. Budapest is full of these little surprises. I didn't spend much time just walked by, but worth a look and some pictures

First rate attraction... a must see!. I had heard about this tour several years ago after coming to Budapest my first time in 2007, and wished that I could have seen it. Now, my second visit to Budapest, I decided it would be the first thing we visited. I am so glad we did. This really takes you back in time to see history of a truly unique hospital that was used during difficult war times. Definitely a place for anyone who has been involved in health, education, Military or anyone else who loves history.
Very interesting . The Hospital in the Rock was very interesting and the tour guide was excellent. If you go to Mathias church and the fisherman's bastion first, you get a 10% discount voucher.

An unusual and fascinating museum. This museum is unusual and tells the story of how natural caves in the castle hill were transformed into a hospital and later a nuclear bunker. The wax models make the place very real and one can only admire the ingenuity and perseverance of the Hungarians in the mid 20th century while under attack.
Interesting place. Really interesting history and specially if you're working in hospital or in healtcare. You can get a discount if you're teacher, doctor or nurse.

Very interesting . This was a very interesting "museum " to visit. Tells the story of how the Buda half of the city dealt with the horror of ww2 and Cold War period. The tour was a bit speedy but I would definitely recommend a visit.

Terrific tour - great insight to Hungary in and post WWII. This hour long underground tour showed how a hospital was established in the cave system under Buda Castle district. It was in use in WWII and Hungarian crises post war and in the threat of a nuclear strike.

Great tour, very interesting and educational. This hospital in the caves under castle hill is very interesting. The tour is about one hour and it is excellent, very educational and informative. Highly recommended. Your learn how the Hungarians protected themselves from the Nazis and the Russians.
Out of the way but worth it.. A very unusual and slightly quirky museum, but captures a lot of history. Be sure to check not times and languages of the tours as you must enter with a guide.
Excellent tour guide!. Very nice people at the front desk, excellent tour guide, a lot of authentic equipment from WWII and 50s and other interesting stuff to see. Good value for the money.

Excellent!. They spontaniously split up the group into two when more tourists showed up for the tour than expected. Made the tour so much more comfortable. The knowledgeable guide spoke excellent English and German. The exhibition itself was incredibly interesting.

Very interesting. Visited here on our last day in Budapest and so pleased that we did. Very interesting and well designed exhibits to show the history of the cave system and its use, primarily as a hospital.
Tour lasts about 1 hour and well worth the visit

Fantastic. If you like history a place you must visit. We were a small group taken around by a very knowledgable guide. Everything in the hospital is original and in very good condition so adds to the feeling of going back in time.

Worth a visit. The guide was very informative with excellent English. Really interesting to experience what it must have been like to work in the hospital and the awful conditions both staff and patients had to endure. Takes about an hour and you will probably need a jumper as it's quite chilly.

It is one of the most beautiful sights of the beautiful Budapest. It is one of the most beautiful sights of the beautiful Budapest, pity the guide speaks only English or that there are headphones with comments in their own language. Only for this 4 stars.Very interesting tour for a fair price. Tour guide spoke very good english. Would highly recommend to visit.

Great visit. This is amazing. They do guided tours that leave on the hour every hour. English is spoken and this is a real education. The history is amazing, from the old hospital you go to the nuclear bunker part - a real thought provoking trip. A must vivit.

great. the tour was great plus i loved the place.
i totaly recommend to visit
i dont rate excellent only because you were obligated to follow the group(i would stayed at least half an hour more) plus it wasnt possible to take photos

Only so so. Too many people in the group to be able to appreciate the photos and displays. More folks coming after you. So keep moving. I wouldn't recommend this. Too many other lovely sites and experiences very close by.

Journey through time - definitely worth a visit. We found this tour far more stimulating than walking around the rest of the Palace grounds. It was fascinating to see how the facility had been used during the last century and how real the "cold war" actually was. A truly unique experience. Better than "not another spa....."

Fascinating tour. This was a most unusual and interesting tour of an underground hospital used during the Second World War and the 1956 Hungarian Uprising. The extensive labyrinth of rooms and corridors includes the historic hospital fittings and lifelike wax models of patients, doctors and nurses. Our guide was well informed and engaging. Highly recommended.

A Fantastic Wander Through Time. Being a nurse myself I was entracned by the history of this place and how they managed to run a fully functioning hospital down there. It's well worth the time and small entrance fee to step back into history and explore this facinating place. There were people from all nationalities and age groups so I would say it's good for everyone. They split us up into language groups so we could better appreciate the tour. The guides were lovely and full of history about the hospital. This was a must for me and I wasn't disapointed.

Glimpse back in time to the Cold War. A very interesting site to see and not be missed while in Budapest. This is a historic site that goes back in history from the dark days of World War II to the Cold War... It should be seen and remembered.
Wish we had more time. This is one of those places, where you wish you had more time explore all of it. As it is now: you are given a 1-hour tour of the place. Fascinating adventure back in time.

Disappointing. Interesting place and its history, but the tour was very disappointing. The video that you see at the beginning is in hungarian with english subtitles which you cannot see properly if you don't seat in the front. The group was too big, we had to squeeze inside each room and were rushed to go, so we were not able to see the exhibits properly - not that I was interested in them as they were mainly medical equipment. And plenty of wax mannequins. I was bored and happy when it's ended.

Good 2 in one experience.. We wanted to see the so famous caverns that lie under the city. There are two options, you either go to the Labyrinth or come to the Hospital in the Rock. Your entrance fee comes with a tour guide and a fairly thorough explanation of the scenery. An old, top-secret, hospital that was used during the second world war. Fully recommended.
Don't miss this tour.. Great tour - quite remarkable to see how the cave system had been used over the years. Follow the signs from near the Matyas Church as it can be hard to find.

The building was fascinating. The tour, however, was pretty poor. Hospital in the Rock is a really significant part of Budapest's history. Located on the Buda side, the once-active hospital is now a tourist attraction. The tour itself was rather disappointing. For the first part of the tour, you watch an informative video that gives you some context about the hospital. It was from this that I really learnt about the hospital. The tour itself had too many people, the tour guide wasn't very good at projecting her voice and overall, the entire tour had a rather claustrophobic feeling about it. The gift shop at the end was peculiar. It sold very little in the way of merchandise, and was more like an tiny overpriced corner shop. All in all, I am glad I visited, but I wish the attraction limited the amount of people who go in at any one time.

Interesting but not really worth the visit. As an afterthought we visited this attraction while in the area. The price was a bit high per person, but for an hour we thought why not. The hospital itself is interesting as a place, but the display and guide is perhaps not as fascinating as it could be. Each stop is laid out as it was with wax models capturing a scene; the guide says a few words, and then you shuffle round the display for a few moments before moving on. It is interesting to a certain point, but the novelty of the place wore off after 20-30 minutes, and the guide really didn't inspire too much interest with his text – although there were a few very good details in there, just a shame they were the exception rather than the norm. The history is interesting, but you could probably learn more from reading elsewhere and skipping the actual visit.

WWII plus Iron Curtain days come to life. We're old enough to remember the days of the Iron Curtain, if not quite old enough to have lived through WWII. But to tour this hidden hospital built to withstand bombings and possible atomic bomb radiation effects was a step back in our memories of the 50's and 60's. The one-hour tour was well-guided, and my only regret was that we didn't have more time to take it all in.

Excellent informative tour. Guided tours only every hour so get your timing right. The tour goes 18 metres underground in parts so it will be cold but they do provide you with authentic nurses cloaks and Coates you have to give them back! It's very informative gives you real insight into the use of the structure as a hospital during the war and the Hungarian uprising in 1956 and as a nuclear bunker during the Cold War very interesting would recommend you include it in your visit to the castle district.
worth a visit. Organised Tours - on the hour and approx. 1 hour long! Very interesting - but felt it was a bit rushed, Could have done with a bit more time to take it all in.

Best kept (almost) secret in Budapest!. For those who (understandably) complained that the groups are too big and the tours too widely spaced (1 hour intervals), be advised - as of April 2015 tours are offered every 30 minutes. For those who try to find this tour using a town map – good luck! However, it’s easily located by walking directly away from Matthias Church (Castle Hill) to the stairs & elevator. Our guide Sophie was knowledgeable, professional, articulate and fun. English skills are A+, spoken loud and clearly enough so that the whole group was able to follow everything she said. This relatively small (1 hour) tour is one of the best kept secrets of Budapest. The underground facility served a vital purpose during WWII and again during the bloody Hungarian uprising in 1956. Then, during the years of the cold war between the Soviets and the USA it served another very secret purpose. Since my wife and I were children doing “drop and cover” exercises during those turbulent years it was chilling and ironic to hear about the threat of nuclear war from the Hungarian point of view. It certainly never occurred to anyone of my age that people in Hungary were afraid an attack from the USA! Now we have a new prospective and a new way to relate to these wonderful fellow citizens of our planet.
An Eye opener. This is life that no one wants live. But live the wounded had to be treated here. it shows just what can be achieved when the situation is desparate.

Great Tour. This was an excellent tour. Our tour guide was a nursing student who was immensely knowledgeable and we could tell took a special interest in the history of the Hospital in the Rock. It's definitely worth the time and entrance fee.

So cool. This is like something straight out of a Bond novel. A hospital powered by diesel dug into a hill... that's all I'm giving away..Well worth a visit especially in summer when the temperature is soaring outside.

Nice tour, but big groups. Went here during our city trip two months ago. It was a nice tour, a lot of information, but the group was very big. We were told that we had to be lucky with the guide, since some have a very difficult to understand accent. Nevertheless, we did not have any problems with ours, she was very understandable and pleasant to listen to.

Nice piece of history. We enjoyed the 1 hour guided tour- which is a requirement to visiting- located in the castle hill area. It is a great piece of history and the wax figures helped in replicating what the hospital may have looked like during the various war times. Understanding how this hospital functioned underground - how air supply was brought into the caves , food brought in and water supply was very enlightening. It is worth the visit!

Totally unexpected. An amazing place to see and so well preserved. Sad we weren't allowed to take any photographs, although I understand why they ask you not to. Crazy network of tunnels all with realistic (as much as it can be that is) setups with doctors, patients and nurses. You really did get an insight into how difficult those conditions must have been. The siren and helicopter were great extras we weren't expecting to see (and hear!).

Amazing Hospital built in a cave under the castle rocks.. Gripping tour of a 60 bed hospital formed underground to treat war victims during WWII. This became a secret place for rebels against the soviets in the 1959 rebellion and later became a nuclear bomb shelter. Medical staff treated from 60 to 600 patients in these sunless, dank corridors. Amazing heroic efforts by doctors and nursing staff.

Hospital in the Rock. I enjoyed visiting the hospital in the rock. It was a network of underground caves where the sick and wounded were put during WW II. They had a replica of the patients as well as the staff. The wax figures were in the period clothing and vintage medical equipment was something to see. It was also used as a fallout shelter in case of potential nuclear disasters.So glad it was found again and you can view the museum.I would recommend visiting.

Not the greatest, but interesting. The tour lasts about an hour. Most of the tunnels are like they were when the Russians left. Lots of low passages and figures in wards. To many people in a group made it crowded and closterforic for some people.

Must visit.. Located in the castle Hill could be a little tricky to find.They have hourly guided tours.Our Guide Anna was really good and she made the tour really interesting.If you are a doctor by profession and if you carry any proof with you(Id Card ,visa page anything mentioning that you are a Doctor)you could get a discount on the ticket prices :)
Interesting. Great tour! Not to be missed on a visit to Budapest. Very informative. An amazing insight into the trials and tribulations that the citizens of Budapest have suffered.

unique hospital. Very cool hospital built and used only sporadically. Modified to be secure in case of nuclear fallout but was really mostly used during the 1954 revolution and also during the "liberation" of budapest by the communists. The tour is great and interesting. They give a discount to healthcare professionals. Tricky to find though! You have to go down the stairs or around the wall from castle hill because the entrance is at the bottom & back of that hill.

A must see. i thought that this tour was really interesting. It starts with a short video in Hungarian with English subtitles to set the scene. You are then taken on a tour of the facility. You see the triage rooms. Operating theatre, X-ray, wards, and other historic displays explaining the history of the hospital.You also see the nuclear decontamination rooms and how they stored water and energy. This tour would interest anyone with interests in medical, historical, wartime, nuclear or engineering. An all rounder!My only downside is that it seemed a little rushed because there was so much to see in a short space of time allotted to the tour. Also not for those with a fear of mannequins!
