excellent tour and artifacts. took this tour because I am in the medical profession. it was very interesting. I did not know this place existed. the history is fascinating and incredible that people recovered from their wounds.Senior citizens only pay 1/2 price. cannot remember the fee.

recommended by friend. Probably the best tour we had been on this holiday the staff were all really friendly and knowledgeable. I found the hospital and all the stories of it's past totally fascinating, the wax figure did make me chuckle at times and glad I got the opportunity to visit this place. The sovanier shop was very cheap and reasonable I really wanted to buy a handful of bullets but thought twice about it in case I got stopped at the airport on the way home. Is a must on the things to do in Budapest

Great getaway from pouring rain or hot sun. This was a great trip back in time. The WW2 and Siege of Budapest hospital brings to life the dreadful conditions Hungarians had to endure during their turbulent recent history. The nuclear bunker is attached and comes complete with alarm and decontamination rooms. My 10 year old and 14 year old boys loved it.

A hidden gem. This is a great attraction if it is raining or too hot. It is both a reworking of the old WW2 and Budapest Siege hospital as well as a nuclear bunker. My children enjoyed the gory wax works in the hospital part of the exhibition and the nuclear bunker complete with sirens, iron doors and decontamination rooms. Overall, a real sense of Cold War fear and intrigue brought to life.

Worth the visit. See what it was like during the 2nd world war, many other conflicts, but also up through the cold war. Ask about other bomb shelters around the city and consider how the bunker and others like it were set up, but also how inadequate they were for the actual population. This is worth a visit.

Interesting place to see. I was quite impressed with this place. The tour is about an hour. But we definitely learned alot about what and when it was used. Our kids (7/9) also seemed to really enjoy it as well. You are not allowed to take pictures in there so that was a bit disappointing, but I was told it was to keep the tour going.

Unique and fascinating. The Hospital in the Rock is one of the hidden gems of Budapest - something which is normally skipped by a lot of tourists. However this hospital figures prominently in the history of Budapest during the World War 2 seige of Budapest. Its a fascinating tour of an erstwhile hospital cum nuclear bunker and helps get a glimpse of the paranoia and the times of the war. A must do for history afficionados

Interesting and entertaining tour. I did not really know exactly what we signed up for here, but it is basically a 1 hour guided tour in a hospital that is built under the city and is supposed to be nuclear proof. There are wax figures and old equipment etc illustrating how things looked (during world war 2), and the guides are very knowledgeable and you can learn a lot of interesting facts about how they built this very unique hospital, as well as what happened here during WW2.I would definitely recommend this as part of a day on Castle Hill, as it was quite entertaining and somewhat unexpected experience

Have you ever visited a nuclear bunker and a secret hospital at the same time?. Now you can do it in Budapest at the castle district. This museum is something unique. Not only in Hungary all over in Europe. You can visit the secret bunker hospital with guided tours every day between 10:00AM-8:00PM.

Interesting and scary. Yes, scary to see how the situation was during WII. What people had to do to help others and to survive. It's a good place to good to remember that Budapest had to suffer a lot during the war as we call it now: collateral damage.

Loved it! . This place is amazing. There's loads to see and slightly frustrating that you are whizzed in and out of each area before you can take everything in. You aren't allowed to walk around on your own and although the guides are wonderful they simply go too fast. However, because we read others reviews beforehand we knew this, so made sure our eyes took in as much as possible very quickly. Really worth it.

A fascinating visit into the past. It was fascinating for me to see the Nuclear dress and protection gear used by the Communists. So different from ours. The story of the wartime hospital was interesting.

Worth a visit. Unique experience with great guide. A little expensive for Budapest (about £10) however if you are a nurse, teacher, military or under 26 there are great discounts if you have ID to proove profession

Must Do!!!!. I have been there several times as local when I have a chance to take my foreign colleagues and friends around Budapest. It tells a lot about the history and the little team who runs the site they are extremely committed and enthusiastic to tell all the history of the place. You will enjoy it very much if you want to understand better of the Eastern Europe related history.
Mm. I expected a lot more. Nice guide and some interesting objects but with such a historical significance and entry fee the exposition could be made better.

Well worth a visit. Fascinating tour of underground hospital from the second world war and the cold war of the 1950's including the Hungarian Uprising of 1956. The knowledgeable guide spoke excellent English and the various tableaux had been well set out and brought the visit to life. Good value and well worth an hour of your time. Different tours feature different languages so worth checking in advance to get the right time.

A Hidden Gem...Literally!. Maybe the best thing that I experienced in my 6 months in Europe. The hospital in the Rock is like nothing you have ever seen before. Completely hidden in the hills of Budapest the hospital remains an outstanding tribute to the history of the city. Preserved in a form very similar to how it existed the day the hospital closed you get to see everything. If there is anything that you do while in Budapest this is my suggestion!

Very interesting and informative . My husband and I went here last week based on the reviews we read and were not disappointed. The tour takes a full hour but there is a wealth of information about Hungary during WWII and the Cold War periods.

Favourite part of Castle Hill. We managed to miss this on our first visit to Castle Hill because it's down a hill and around some construction (as of March 2015). But it was definitely my favourite part of Castle Hill. it gets quite cold in the labyrinth, so I recommend bringing a jacket. Our hided tour started off with a short video - make sure you get a seat in the front if you want to read the subtitles! We then entered the hospital. Our guide was really great, and able to answer the majority of the questions about air ducts, using it as a bomb shelter, and other questions about medical and hospital procedures. Before this, I didn't know very much about Hungary's history in WWII and afterward, but this is one of those places where you get it all. Definitely recommended - don't miss this if you're a history buff.
Fascinating historical insight. Guided tours leave on the hour. Reasonable price and really interesting all the way round the tour - despite some questionable mannequins that help relate 'atmosphere'

Oh for more time. If one could close ones eyes and imaging the pain suffering and relief within the caves. The guide was most informative and my only regret is that the tours by their nature do not allow you to look at all the instruments and machinery on display in fine detail. That said it was most informative and the wax models really gave a feel of life in 1944.

Excellent Slice of History. I found this museum very interesting with its original decor and fascinating history. The instruments and bandages etc are all authentic from the 30s to the 60s, which adds to the history of the place. Seeing the conditions of the past makes me realise how lucky we are today. To think this place was used as a hospital for WWII and the Hungarian uprising. Then a nuclear bunker and it is all preserved. Just a pity I couldn't take any photos to remember it later.

Something out of the usual. Interesting and something different. The guide was good and made the tour very interesting. The idea of using natural caves for an hospital was clever, and turned out to be very useful the last year of WW2. It amazing how many patients they kept there - it must have been terrible. The preparations in the sixties to make this a place to escape to in case of a nuclear war was a surprise.

Step back in time!. The Hospital in the Rocks is built within natural caves under the Castle hill.This tour will lead you through a maze of rooms and corridors which still has original furniture and equipment from WW2 and the 50s. The presentation is well done using many wax figured dressed up as doctors, patience and soldiers. Very realistic!The entrance is located on the other side of Castle hill. Tours start every full hour and last about 50 min.Well worth a visit!

Favorite attraction in Budapest. This place is fascinating, it was probably my favorite attraction in Budapest. What you have here is, well, a hospital and fallout shelter in a rock. The first part of the Hospital is exactly that, it is dedicated to recreating a WWII era hospital, not only that but it shows progression, up through the cold war to the present day. The second part of the complex is even more fascinating; a cold war nuclear fallout bunker. Fully decked out with air filtration system, water purification, fall out showers, everything. It really is a brilliant place, well worth a visit. Friendly pleasant staff too, they give discounted entry to medical staff too!

Don't miss it. Fascinating site, really worth going to. Enthusiastic, well-informed guides take visitors on an hour long walk through this underground hospital. The medical etc kit on display is interesting but the theme that most resonated with me was (as in other places in Budapest) the incredibly harsh history of the country over the last 85 years.
Great insight and very interesting. Loved it! Definitely worth doing to get an insight in to something slightly different. A well guided tour in English and very informative.

Long Winded. Lots of information provided on this trip, however I wasn't fond of the 25 minute video at the start. Even though we had opted to go on the 'English Tour' the video was in Hungarian with English subtitles, which would have been fine if we weren't at back without our glasses! Some parts of the tour are interesting, and some parts you wish you would have never bothered. If your attention span is short, I wouldn't recommend this trip,

Steeped in history and worth a visit. I love history, especially when it concerns WWII, so I made the effort to get to this museum while in Budapest on a business trip. The entrance fee is fairly reasonable: around $10-12 USD, less than $10 for physicians, military and law enforcement. This fee includes a guided tour, lasting approximately 1 hour. My guide was a very good speaker, her English was more than adequate, and she provided an excellent level of detail about the museum.I really enjoyed seeing all of the original equipment and features of the hospital dating back to the 1940s. The fact that this facility began as a hospital and ended its service life as a nuclear fallout shelter is fascinating, especially considering its location.My only complaints about the tour process are that you are not allowed to take any photos and we didn't stay long enough at each stop for my liking. This could have been due to the fact that we had approximately 10-12 people in our group, and the passageways in the facility are small, so in the best interest of all, the guide elected to move just a bit faster.Regardless, the Hospital in the Rock will be loved by any history buffs and is a great addition to your Budapest touring plans.

Reminder of WWII and the Cold War. Brilliant displays in the original setting.Very good bilingual tour-guidesIt is unfortunate that you can only tour the facility with a guide in a group settiing so there is no opportunity to linger, read the posters, etc.

I finally made it here on my third trip to Budapest!. History at it's craziest! One can only imagine the tragedy of this beautiful city and the terrors of this hospital bunker. The authenticity of the hospital and it's uses are spot-on. There are quite a few outdoor stairs to arrive at the entrance unless one takes a taxi and is dropped at the door. My guide spoke better English than most Americans and certainly more proper English than most Americans. At times, hearing was an issue because there was another group right behind us having a German tour and we could hear that guide.
Putting things in perspective. It was creepy and fascinating at the same time. Also if you have sensitive ears you might want to bring earplugs ;)

Authentic, historical tour experience of underground hospital/nuke bunker. Best historical tour ever. The Hospital in the rock has guided tours every hour, in different languages. (They only have guided tours because it's a maze down there).  The later tours after 10 and 11 seemed to have larger groups, so might be a good idea to go during early times or maybe later times.They have a gift shop that sells real gas masks and other vintage military goods like chow kits, helmets, compass (one that I saw) from Hungarian and Czech army surplus supplies from 50s and 70s, history buffs and military antique collectors rejoice!The tour itself was very cool and informative. They take you through all the parts of the hospital, reception, operation rooms, showers, beds, machine rooms and tell you really cool facts and point out different tidbits. The guides obviously are very good at what they do and are genuinely interested in sharing the history of the place.Every room was setup with realistic wax figures dressed in historical clothing, soldiers, nurses, bloodied bandages..There's even a funny part in the middle but I won't spoil the surprise..Lockers and cabinets were all filled with actual stuff used during hospital's time, big glass bottles still filled with old chemicals and medicines.Definitely a must do while in Budapest. The only downside is no photographs but your guide will take two photographs of the whole group and post it to the website in two weeks.Watch your head, low ceilings but everything is very walkable and well-lot.

Interesting place to visit. I would rate this much higher if the tour guides had better English. I went here on two separate occasions with people who were visiting me in Budapest and the visits were very different. The first tour guide had good English language skills, was personable and spoke loudly so people could here. The second tour guide was basically impossible to understand and spoke so softly that people could not here. The information shared on both tours differed and should be standardized.So, I think that this attraction is worthwhile visiting but the guides should be better trained, especially since a lot of non-native English speakers take the English tour. I am a native English speaker and have lived abroad in multiple countries so I am used to people speaking English with heavy accents and I found it almost impossible to understand one of the guides. My first visit was with my elderly parents and they enjoyed it and were able to easily navigate through the visit. They also enjoyed the visit because it was cooler inside and a nice break from the heat. There were discounts for senior citizens with EU passports, nurses and teachers.

Creepy. Maybe I'm just more claustrophobic than most people but I didn't like it that much here; you are forced to take a guided tour and although I appreciated knowing I wouldn't be getting lost down there, an hour was a long time to spend in a tour group of 30+ people (by my estimate, and I used to give guided tours). The tour itself was also nothing special. The entrance fee is quite high. The wax figures aren't the most skilled I've seen, which I guess is because we weren't at Mme Tussaud's, but I wouldn't have minded seeing some rooms without wax figures. And finally, the surgical instruments and bandaged wax figures with bloodstains were just too much for me. I guess I should have known what I was getting into but I thought it was overpriced and kind of tacky.

amazing. went on visit to hospital in the rock the only thing is your not able to take any photos inside, and if your a nurse or doctor or teacher you get admission by reduced rate or student you just have to show i.d worth a vsisit

Dont take ill. This hospital was something else, as we wondered round it just made you think thank goodness medicine had come on a long way and that I didn't have to endure what they had to in the past. The history of the place was fascinating. The guide we had spoke excellent English and was able to answer any questions really enjoyed this.

Step back in time (wartime). 10 Kms of cave system, thermal heating together with foresight and engineering skill and you have a wonderful resource.Before the second World way a hospital for 60 was created in the rock. Subsequent events meant that several hundred wounded were taken there for the care of the Red Cross.On visiting you travel through the caves where life-size models and their equipment give an excellent, tho grim, idea of how it would have been. good audio guides provided.Not to be missed!

A must for history lovers. This is a great way to learn some amazing and interesting history. If you are a helthcare professional you will enjoy it even more. A whole big hospital and shelter built into a cave system, it's not something you see every day. The guide was friendly, spook good english and had a good knowledge of the history.
Very interesting. The Hospital is a little difficult to find but very interesting. Giving an unusual insight to the city's history.

unusual and very interesting. Unique? Combining history, medicine, waxworks, radiation fears, old technical devices and the thrill of the hidden-something for everyone.Tours are on the hour worth remembering so you do not go up and down too many times.If you think of the Bastion as the front then this is at the back down some stairs and then right. It may also be useful to know that they take Euros. Unmissable

Stunning journey back in time. If you are interested in the history of Budapest and you are willing to relive the - sometimes painfully vivid - scenes of a WWII hospital and Cold War nuclear shelter, don't miss this museum. It will make you think and probably leave a bitter taste in your mouth, but certainly a very valuable and (literally) deep experience. I don't think it's suitable for anyone with claustrophobia.

Great museum, well worth tracking down. Close to Fisherman’s Bastion and the Royal Palace, the Hospital in the Rock is a little hidden away, but is an unusual but must-see attraction in the city. The tour consists of a 15 minute video about the history of the hospital, and then a 45 minute guided tour of the premises, where you get to see pretty much everything – from the wards, to the operating theatre, to the machinery rooms. It’s an incredible place bearing in mind it’s situation inside a hillside – and the presence of a full helicopter in one of the rooms is pretty amazing – and the fact that much of what is displayed is original means that it’s easy to imagine what life in the hospital during WW2 must have been like. Our guide knew his lines, but lacked a little personality.
History in the making. A really interesting and factual visit. Having had a caretaker to look after the hospital until relatively recently it has not been disturbed. Well worth the time to seek out.

An interesting place. This was a really interesting place to visit and covered a lot of Hungary's history and the use of the caves and tunnels. We found the English group slightly too large especially for the small tunnels and rooms. There are a range of discounts for visitors including for those with the Budapest card and those under 26 years old.

An interesting was to experience the history of Budapest. Following previous reviews we found ourselves at the non impressing entrance of Hospital in the Rock. Crossing into the museum we had an extremely interesting and adventurous guided tour that took us through some of last decade's horrible history of Budapest which is embedded in the history of the hospital.
Very Different. We just a a short time at this attraction but were impressed at what we saw and if we return to Budapest would like to spend longer exploring.

Recommended to everyone.. . We have been there in July of 2013.. I think we were so fortunate to take the last tour.. If I've lost the chance of seeing this I would be so frustrated.. The tour is well organized with guides who speak a very fluent English with joy and ambition to serve.. The historical background was mesmerising.. They are explaining every detail of the facility and even let you try a few of the equipment.. It's a bit cold underneath the ground but there are coats in case you don't have anything to keep you warm but they are a bit old and don't seem very clean(they are serving thousands of people every day, what else can you expect) but it's totally worth your hour.. I am a doctor of dentistry and I am super excited and satisfied with the tour and details.. It's better than the art museum in the castle imo.. In arts museum even the attendants were not able to speak English other than "no, yes, okay"

Amazing Museum. I really enjoyed my visit to this small and underrated museum. Although I had seen it mentioned in some guide books, I know it is not always well publicised. I must say this really out did my expectations, I loved it. The groups tour guide, Agi had lots of knowledge and a good understanding of English and made the journey around the old hospital very gripping. I was visiting solo as my other family members don't like small spaces and I didn't feel uncomfortable being there on my own as the groups are a good size. For those of you who are nervous that these spaces might feel enclosed, they are actually quite open and it feels like being in a basement rather than deep underground. I learnt a lot about the history of Hungary through the last 30 years and there were lots of interesting models and pieces of medical equipment on view. I preferred the hospital section to the nuclear bunker area but both were eye-opening. Well worth a visit, the staff were friendly and it has been one of the highlights of my trips to Budapest!

History buffs, take note. Caves turned into a hospital? Secret bunkers under the old Castle district? In this well-written tour, guides walk you through the vast underground facility and its history. Aaron was a good guide, displays were clear and interesting, and there was a good introductory video. Gift shop is unremarkable.
Decent museum. We enjoyed this little museum, you are taken round by a guide and the tour took about an hour.Very informative.

cold war ...warm welcome. Quirky and really interesting alternative venue. We went for the ten o clock opening and were two of four on a tour...when we came out it was busy. Good move. Dupree guide who brought the history alive. I bought a genuine unused anti nuclear mask...1500 f equivalent of four pounds fifty. Brilliant

Fascinating, and a great guide. We really enjoyed our visit to the Hospital on the Rock. There is a cheaper entrance rate for EU citizens if you have proof of identity, so the price was very reasonable. English tours went every hour, on the hour. We were left to watch a short historical video (in Hungarian with English subtitles) before the tour properly started. You are told NOT to take photos, so bear this in mind. Our guide was very enthusiastic and tried to engage us by asking questions, and was happy for you to ask things too. She was very friendly and did a great job considering the other tourists in our group were not the most cheerful bunch!!Everything in the place is original which was fascinating, and there was a good mix of humour and seriousness/information. I'd recommend visiting this place after having got your bearings of Budapest itself, as you will appreciate the guide's explanations better when they refer to specific places.The historical aspect came right up to the present day which was interesting, and there was a really cool helicopter which they had to get down there in pieces and re-build for their exhibit! The mechanical areas were less interesting to me personally (generators, machines etc) as there was no real emotional or real life stories to go with them like in other areas.The tour lasted an hour, and were were not rushed around. There is a small gift shop where you can buy original gas masks, cutlery etc as well as drinks/small snacks.

Disappointing . I was looking forward to the hospital in the rock after reading all the great reviews, but I have to say I was disappointed. The guide seemed uninterested and not very engaging. Although an interesting place I wouldn't recommend it...unless of course there was a more enthusiastic guide.
Something different. We loved our trip to visit hospital in the rock. The guide was fantastic and it was a truly unique experience.
Interesting. Interesting little place. Glad we paid the small entrance fee. You are allowed to take photos inside.

Fascinating place. I found the hospital in the rock really interesting. Loved the fact that they had all the original hospital paraphernalia. Most of the dummy figures look terrible, not that it's a complaint though, they just don't really add much to it. Worth a visit as it's such a unique place.

Incredibly rude staff!. After struggling with the door with baby in a carrier, none of the staff even made the effort to indicate they were open, instead they just carried on chatting with one another. On asking if it was open, the young girl at the desk replied "seems to be" in a really smart mouth tone. May have seemed to be to her but from our perspective, their personal socialising and laziness it didn't "seem to be" to us. May be a good attraction, but frankly didn't want to hand my money over to these rude girls at the desk.

Very interesting worth a visit . We had been recommended to go here by a friend as a must see museum in Budapest! It cost around £10 to get in and you get an hour tour with a tour guide! It's very interesting and an excellent museum that shows you exactly what it was like when in use! It's done really well and worth a visit!

Great fun. We arrived just in time for an English tour, I wasn't sure if the price would be worth it but it was! A kitschy, weird, awesome place. Not so much museum as a recreation of how it looked where everything is original but the dummies. We learned a lot and the history of the place is fascinating, how it's purpose changed through the years. It was really cold down there but we were already bundled up so didn't mind it. They have old wool cloaks for people to wear if needed, I really wanted to wear one!

Brilliant. This was an excellent trip through time. The information provided by the guide was great. However I felt the tour was limited in that there was a lot of interesting facts on posters etc around the walls etc but very little time given to read it. There were also some very interesting exhibits but unfortunately I felt rushed through to the end.

Historically interesting. The tour guide spoke great English, and we learnt lots of facts about Budapest and the hospital that we didn't know before....also more info on Budapest as a whole.The only downside was that it felt slightly rushed - maybe just because there were quite a few of us whilst we were there, but certainly worth a visit.

A highlight of Budapest. Visited this museum with my husband on Valentine's Day and benefitted from an endearing "two for the price of one" special offer. We thoroughly enjoyed our tour, with a helpful, knowledgable guide, and found the waxworks and vast collection of original hospital equipment absolutely fascinating. This was one of our favourite attractions in the city and comes highly recommended. Tip: Due to renovation works the entrance is tricky to find. Follow signs from St Matthias Church square and then ask, because it is well worth a little persistence.

Very interesting place. They do the tours in groups with a guide either in English or Hungarian. You get a walk through the place while lot of interesting and historical story is being told during the way. All the equipment is original from the 40s to the 80s and the place is full of wax models to make it realistic,which it is. You can see great staff and can even try out an air raid siren.

Fascinating place.. Very interesting place to visit. The tour takes an hour but at times it did feel a bit rushed. This is probably why you aren't allowed to take photos. After getting off the bus (number 16 I think) maybe I'm a bit stupid but I found the signs to get to the place were numerous but highly confusing. They seemed to have arrows pointing in about three different directions! It did take me quite a while to locate it after asking several people and taking a few wrong turns!Despite these minor points, I'd definately recommend a visit there as it is something quite different to most museums.

Very interesting history.. My friend and I were told about Hospital in the Rock by someone we met at one of the baths. I'm really happy that we were able to fit it into our plans. Budapest has such a fascinating history and Hospital in the Rock is a place that has been influenced by the modern elements of the city's history; from being a hospital during WWII to a soviet nuclear bunker, it is a must see. The guided tour was informative, without being boring. I wish that we had been allowed to take pictures while in the actual exhibit.

Stunning. The hospital inside the rock is stunning. There has been 600-700 patiens in small space in the WWII. Guide was exellent and spoke good english. Museum is a little hidden, Buda-side behind the Chutch of Mathias, but you really need to find it. Must to see!

Really enjoyed this!. I found this a very interesting tour and would definitely recommend going if you have time. It's not immediately obvious where it is but with a little trial and error we found it just as the final English tour of the day began. Wax models and authentic medical supplies combined with a fascinating history made this one of my favourite experiences in Budapest.

A most interesting tour!. Despite the entry price being a little steep compared to many other historical attractions, the tour of the Hospital in the Rock is one of the most interesting things we've seen in Hungary. Highly recommended! Be sure to check ahead of time to determine when a tour will start. They offer tours in several languages, but the tours don't start every 15 minutes. We didn't check in advance & had to amuse ourselves elsewhere for about 40 minutes the tour we wanted started. That was OK, but we could have time our arrival better if we'd known to do so.

Very Interesting Tour. This is a very interesting place to visit. The hospital is built in the natural caves under the castle hill in Buda. The tour was given by an English speaking guide who was very knowledgeable about the history of the hospital.I would highly recommend this tour because it provides an interesting background into: the hospital's design and use during WW2, its use as a nuclear bunker during the cold war, Hungary's history during WW2 and after and the advancement of medical technology over the last 50 years.Discounts are given for students, pensioners, those under 26 and medical professionals.
Well worth a look. Take a guided tour of the hospital and bunker. Fascinating insight into what was achieved and what went on during Nazi occupation.
Good tour!. The hospital on the rocks is really interesting, in the tour you walk in the caves, see reproductions of the situations lived in the war and learn about the history, it's worth going

Disappointing. Having visited a nuclear bunker in Prague, we where all excited about visiting this place. Unfortunately it didn't live up to expectations and I found the wax? dummies slightly off putting. There were no photos or video allowed but they did take a group photo and published it online for free. This place is not cheap either, although not a complete waste of time and money there are better museums and other stuff to do in Budapest

Wonderful. Check the detail as crossing the Bridge.
There are spectacular views of the Castle Hill and the Parliament - from Pest to Buda, cross on the right side of the Bridge to see the Parliament.

Unusual but too fast. The hospital in the rock is an interesting place which you can only visit as part of a tour. Tours start on the hour and guides speak either English or Hungarian. The tour covers the building of the hospital, it's use in WW2, use as a nuclear bunker and its use as a hospital during the 1956 uprising! The only real,problem is the guide went a little too quickly and we didn't get to look at everything which was a shame. However it is still worth a trip

Very interesting piece of history. We visited this attraction with a 14 yr old and a 20 yr old. The tour starts with a short film of the hospital's history and then takes takes you through the underground hospital informing you of the history. The guide was very informative, however it was a large group and on occasions it was difficult to hear him. The exhibits were interesting with the equipment used in the war. We were taken through the route a patient would have taken in entering the hospital. We worth a visit if you are interested in hospitals and a very unusual hospital.

Over priced and mediocre tour. it could have been a better experience. With an hour long guided tour, i expected the tour to be very profound and with a lot of detailed information. But to be honest, the first 10 minute film basically tells you everything, and our guide did not go much further beyond the introduction film. She told us what is what when leading us from one room to another, but the explanation is quite superficial and general, as plain as reciting a passage from a book. When I pay 3600 HUF to have a professional guide, I expect something more than that. Maybe some interaction with the audience? Maybe a smile on her face? Maybe giving some interesting story one could not find by reading wikipedia? Rather, i saw a guide who did not show much interest to her job.With such an experience, I would not rate it as a thumb up or recommended thing to do. Maybe it was just because of our guide.Feb 17 2015, in the 4pm English Tour
Interesting. This hospital / nuclear bomb shelter was interesting to walk through and the tour was given in English.

A "must see" in Budapest!. This is a very special peace of well kept history in the city. It's very impressive and worth every penny!Glad to have been here. The tour-guide explained everything in good English.

An amazing place. Hard to imagine a hospital in the caves during the war that treated the wounded and the extreme conditions that the nurses Doctors and volunteers worked in. The medical equipment that is on display is incredible. I thoroughly recommend visiting If you are in the medical profession or Military take some ID with you and you will get a discount to get in.

Great value and interesting.. Loved the tour around the building. The Guide was informative and I didn't feel like she was simply doing her job. I felt her love for the building and the services offered .It's fascinating.

Worth an hour of your time. Part of our walk around Castle Hill, we popped in to this attraction. Tour in English starts on the hour and cost us 7,200huf for two adults. It's quite a fast moving tour and takes in the converted caves used as a hospital in WW2 and the Hungarian Revolution and as a nuclear bunker during the Cold War. Each 'room' has a tableau bringing to life what once occurred there and there are countless historical artefacts reflecting hospital and war history. Our guide had very good English.

Hospital In The Rock. We went here last year when staying in Budapest for a weekend. The guide was great, really informative, knowledgeable and fun. The tour was well planned and very interesting. A really good way to see a bit of wartime history.

Humanity under pressure. This is a great historical adventure. It has been both a hospital, and a bomb shelter, and there are some wonderful exhibits here of how, even in the darkest hours, man strives to assist his fellow man. If you have any connection to the healing arts, this is a must-see while visiting Budapest. Our Hungarian friend's father is a Physician, and he had never been here. He also rated it: Great!

Hospital in the rock. Again great view of hungarian history and how they were prepared in case if nuclear attack.huge labyrinth type underground building with many creative (for that time) life supporting ideas placed in hospital- great view back in history of war,medicine.again my personal opinion is that tour guide could ve a bit simpler as the whole tour seemed she's trying to talk in british accent which she didn't do too good and should stick with hungarian accent which actually nice enough.

Very impressive. I have to say that I was not very convinced in investing my time visiting the hospital. After we went I changed my opinion and will tell you that is a must if you are visiting Budapest.We got an excellent guide and learned a lot. It is an impressive place, full of history and very well manintained

underground hospital!. Saw it was one out the top underground attractions and have it a go. A really interesting tour! Lots of history about Budapest through the second world war and Russian occupation, it's use as a hospital and nuclear shelter. Highly recommended as something different!

Unique and interesting. The hospital is built into the cave system under Castle Hill. It is pretty fascinating to think that patients used to be cared for in this makeshift hospital. The rooms have been well preserved with actual medical equipment. Only draw back is that you can't take pictures inside

Breath taking. The staff were very friendly, and the tour of the hospital was amazing. I can't begin to imagine what it would have been like when the hospital was at its full capacity.A very good history of the building was given. It is unfortunate that we weren't allowed to take pictures, but it was a great experience.

Interesting insight into the Hungarian perspective of WW2. We really enjoyed the interesting tour of the Hospital in the Rock. It gives an interesting insight into the atrocitiy of war from the perspective of the Hungarians in Budapest and the bravery of the doctors and nurses who worked there. Very powerful experience. Well worth a visit. Make sure you pick up a virus (you'll know when you see it!) =)

Very interesting if you are into dark tourism. I really enjoyed this museum and really glad I went! The 1 hour tour is brought to life with wax models which adds to the spookyness. Make sure you sit at the front or middle of the theater room when you watch the short intro film otherwise you may not be able to see the English subtitles.

Fab!. We visited hospital in the rock today after it was recommended to us by someone staying in our hotel and I am so so glad we went! It was fantastic start to finish and costs next to nothing. The tour guide (Sophie) was really friendly and spoke very good English which made the tour more enjoyable as we understood everything that was happening. The tour lasts about an hour and would be for anybody really! Thoroughly recommend going, it really opened my eyes.

Must for WW2 and Cold War History Buffs and any one interested in Hospitals and Medical Services. Went with my 8 year old son, tour lasted about an hour and moved along at enough of a pace that he kept seeing new things so wasn't bored. Having an interest in history and working in health I found the tour interesting and got a slant on Hungarian history and the siege of Budapest that was new and interesting. Certainly if you work in health or hospitals also a very interesting tour.We went on a Monday and there were only 4 people on the tour so we had time to ask questions and the guide was friendly and informative.Note that if you are taking children being a hospital a lot of the rooms have dummies with bloody bandages and my son found that a bit creepy. Children should also be encouraged to go to the toilet before the tour starts.Only museum I have ever visited where the souvenir shop sold gasmasks!We walked from the large tramstop, but a quicker way would be to get the bus to the fortess and go to the stairs on the far side facing away from the Danube and Fisherman's Bastion, go down them and walk along the road.

Interesting tour. Interesting tour but would have liked longer to stop and look at the displays. Felt very hurried at times. Nurses and doctors who visit get a reduction in ticket price but need to take proof with you-ID badge.
A hidden treasure. This was so interesting being shown around all the rooms that they used underground during the war. The attraction really gives a flavour of the war years and we loved it.
Very interesting tour.. It was very interesting to hear the story of the tunnels, from time to time, all the changes and upgrades. A little cool in the tunnels but a fun way to spend a hour.

Informative and interesting. Unique attraction which really brought the Nazi occupation and the Cold War to life. As others have mentioned, you can only visit on a guided tour, which made sure you got lots of information, but our guide seemed a little bored and I felt we were rushed through rather than really get a chance to look around properly. Nevertheless, well worth seeing.
awesome. this was really cool and when learning about ww2 in school I never even heard Hungary mentioned but this is something I would have definitely want to hear about!
Eye opener. Although hard to find well worth a visit as fantastic guided tour in English. Very informative, fascinating to see and a great hour of easy listening. Appeals to all ages

Worth a Visit but Could be Better. This is an underground hospital/nuclear bunker built during WWII. It's on the Buda side of the city, near Castle Hill. It's slightly out of the way of the main sights on Castle Hill so you'll need to keep an eye out for it.The only way that you can see the place is by a guided tour. Tours leave on the hour and last an hour. Full priced tickets cost 3,600 HUF. We got a 30% discount as part of a hop on - hop off bus tour (Budapest Sightseeing). The tour starts with a short film on the history of the hospital/bunker. It's in Hungarian with English subtitles. Try to sit near the front as, due to the people sitting in front of you, it will be hard to read the subtitles otherwise.The tour guide spoke perfect English and was knowledgeable. However, the tour group was quite large (25 people) and as the area is quite cramped the ability to spend much time looking at the exhibits was limited. As someone else has mentioned, it would be far better to be allowed look around by yourself with an audio guide. Also, no photography is allowed. I'm not sure why this is the case.It's worth a look simply due to the uniqueness of it being an underground hospital but with a bit of a reorganisation it could be greatly improved as an experience.

Well hidden, but found by chance. We were visiting the Buda side of the river, St Mathias and Fishermans Bastion. While waiting for the coach we walking around the hill and found this historical treasure.The staff there are very knowkedgeable and passionate about the hospital. No language barrier and we bought a very informative book also.

Very informative. Hiya just back from a few days in Budapest went on the tour because of the good reviews to get to the start was quite a walk from pest and a lot of it was uphill .you watch a video at first then get given ear pieces to listen to the guide which again was great so you walk for about 45 minutes looking into the rooms laid out as they were used for hospital style so very good for the price and of interest to all just be clear its a lot of steps to get there if you walk:)))

Fantastic place to visit!. It is one of the most interesting places in Budapest. It is a hospital and a bunker at the same time, it was used during the war. It is in very good condition and it has got big amount of original medical tools from that period. It is a place that impresses you. The museum close at 20:00. However, last entry is at 19:00. The tour lasts approximately 1 hour and it includes a short video to bring you into that period. The tour is in English and Hungarian. If you want more information such as how to arrive and so on, please visit my blog: http://leavingfootprintswithyvette.blogspot.hu/search/label/Hungr%C3%ADa%2FHungary

Well worth the visit. Check their website for the current list of tours as you cannot visit this by yourself. It is an amazing facility and it's a very interesting tour but if you are at all claustrophobic you should think twice as the halls and rooms are small. The guides speak very good english and really do know their history, but they also do tours in other languages as well. Very well done and well maintained.

Learn live history WWII. Best surprise of our Budapest visit was this hidden gem which even taught my teenagers in an impressive lively way about the cold war and background info on WWII. Go and experience it by yourself!!!

Amazing museum. Loved this museum, very well presented. The guide (Sophie) had fantastic knowledge about he history of the hospital/nuclear bunker. The exhibits were well displayed and the whole place had a real atmosphere...you could imagine the horror of working there and being a patient during WW2 and the Cold War years. Don't miss this museum!

Intriguing and poignant. The Hospital I the Rock provides an excellent insight into life in the city during the Second World War and the Cold War. Excellent renovation and full of fascinating equipment and artefacts. The guiding is excellent. Probably unique.
Very intresting and informative. Very intrrsting tour and informative. We learned about the history of hungarian regim during the dark times of human history
Underground gem. This second world war hospital which served the German army mostly is a very good insight into life at the time during the war. Not well known and is worth the price of admission.

Well worth a visit. Very informative tour. Guide was very knowledgable and I came away feeling like I'd learnt something. Would have hated to have been a patient though as the conditions they went through were horrific.

Intensely interesting. I'm so very glad we were recommended to visit this attraction. It does not appear on many tourist pamphlets or the like, but it definitely should. We went to the last tour of the night and it was not busy at all, just us and one other couple. The tour guide led us through the labyrinth of the underground tunnel system explaining the history of the site as a hospital during the war. Many figures were set up within the various rooms to demonstrate their use, and medical relics from the period were on display. Well worth the small entry fee for such a unique experience.

Astonishing!. An amazing experience! He had no great expectations, but it was really amazing. If you are a student, there´s a discount, then the ticket costs 5 euros approximately. They make a short presentation in documentary form at the beginning. Is not bid, but worth it as an introduction. The tour of the hospital and the bunker is sensational! There is a guide that explains everything in detail. It is very interesting and you can see all real objects and equipment, some still are operating. A good choice for those who like history of World War II and also the cold war.

Fascinating!. This tour was truly fascinating from so many perspectives. I was not aware of the long Soviet siege of the city near the end of WWII nor of the fact that this hospital was reactivated to assist Hungarian rebels in the 1956 uprising against the Soviet Union. Incredible engineering on display and the tour guides gave an excellent tour in English. This tour is more than a hospital, it shows you the resilient nature of the Hungarian people against the greatest challenges!

Very interesting WWII and Cold War history.. This was a functional hospital at one time and was completely overwhelmed during WW II. It later was a secret shelter during the cold war. The tour takes you into the bowels of the cave system which is much more extensive then just the hospital portion. There are plenty of rooms with the actual medical equipment used during the 40's and 50's with was statue mannequins posed throughout. The tour takes about an hour and I believe it was completely worth it. Its a unique side to Budapest you would not always see.

A Little Gem. We went here as my friend is a nurse so it sounded interesting and we glad we made the effort. We luckily turned up at the right time as tours started on the hour and we coincidentally got there at 11.59am otherwise it would have been a long wait. It also wasn't the cheapest for an hour long entertainment but my friend got discount with nurse ID and to be honest it was totally worth the price as it is so different and real. Our tour guide was friendly and spoke good English. The tour was informative and captive. You really get a feel for the place and what went on there in the war and the decade straight after. If you stay or take a trip to Buda I would definitely go here. I also think this would be really good for children to see as well.

100% WORTH IT. If there is one attraction to visit in Budapest is this one! The entry price includes a guided tour which lasts about 45 mins - 1 hour and is INCREDIBLY INFORMATIVE. The tours start on time at the hour so make sure you get there shortly before so you do not have to wait a lot for the next tour. The team that works here has done a really good job in attempting to recreate the WWII days so you get a good grasp of the history of the site.
WELL WORTH A VISIT. This attraction is well worth a visit, especially if up that way. It's an unusual attraction so well worth the visit!

Fun attraction. The Hospital In The Rock is a little out of the way, however, worth a visit. The tour guide (English speaking) was very good and gave an insightful narrative to the history, purpose and function of the hospital. You don't see too many hospitals build in the side of a hill.

Interesting stories. Went there for an afternoon tour and it was entirely booked (30 people per group) so we had to wait for the next group which departs the next hour.The guide was clear and pleasant but seems like she had memorized the entire script and spit it out without really feeling it.Despite these two issues, the information was really interesting if you like to hear war stories and how they operated back in the days.There are some wax dummies here and there with blood on them to illustrate the hospital so it might be disgusting at some parts but it's not that ugly really and the dummies' faces don't look very real anyway.
Worth a visit. This attraction is worth a visit if you are interested in history and especially war stories.Price was satisfactory.
Must see! . So interesting! Incredible to walk through the hospital and our tour guide was excellent - spoke loudly and clearly and was very knowledgeable. Tours run on the hour.

Great experience!!. A very interesting place, very nice numbers and you enjoy every minute of it. It is always very interesting to learn something new and discover hidden places. There are student discounts in place so bring a student ID.This place gives you a lot to think about and shows you other aspects of history.It's worth the money and worth the time. And if you study medicine or whatever it might interest you even more.

Fascinating tour and attraction. I enjoyed this tour very much, it's always interesting learning about the history of a location your visiting. It's amazing to think that all of this was built in a tunnel!! The tours are every hour on the hour. You may want to go and buy a ticket for a certain time and then go walk around Castle Hill instead of trying to walk in at the last minute. I was in a tour with about 25 people which I thought was too big of a group but maybe that is what they have to do. I tried to stay next to the tour guide so I could pay attention to him as the people in the back of the group were talking a lot.

Interesting tour. This was a well laid out guided tour, definitely worth the money & the time. Lots of historical facts to make you think, maybe group size could have been smaller but obviously a popular tourist location.
Hidden, historic experience. This is a genuine, small museum which shows you a bit of breathtaking history. A must-go. Remember to book your guided tour beforehand.

A very interesting museum. I visited the museum on the evening of 17 December 2014 with my family. It was a little hard to find but we eventually made out way there after seeking directions from the locals. Guided tours are mandatory and there is one every hour if I recall correctly. The tour was interesting and started with a great 10 minute film about the history of the hospital. The next 50 minutes were spent going through the labyrinth of tunnels and viewing the ultra-realistic depictions of the hospital. Our guide was very patient and explained the exhibits in a very interesting way. There were quite a few interesting displays inside the museum, such as a depiction of a typical surgery and a drawer full of surgical instruments from the past. There was even a huge helicopter located inside one of the rooms. One of the highlights of the museum was the portable air raid sirens which we were allowed to try out. In the final part of the tour, we were able to view the machinery that kept the hospital running, although we were not allowed to touch them as they were still fully functional. At the end of the tour, there was a small souvenir shop selling interesting souvenirs like a piece of the iron curtain and even actual gas masks. We would definitely come again in our next visit to Budapest!

Very interesting and unique attraction. This underground bunker style hospital has really interesting history behind it. The whole thing is filled with original medical equipment and wax figures playing the role of doctors, nurses, and patients which all serve to give you an idea of what being in this unique place while it was in operation must have been like. Very cool if you have interest in medical history, Hungarian history, or WW2 history. It's also good to know that although they do not have student discounts, they do offer discounts for medical professionals (nurse, MDs, EMTs, etc).

An interesting site. i am always looking for someplace that illustrates real life in an area. Hospital in the Rock certainly shows the creativity and resilence of the Budapest citizens. The tour illustrates both the preparations for emergency medicine in World War II and the 1956 uprising. The film at the intro and the English guide were good.

Hospital in the rock. Excellent guided tour of the hospital/ nuclear bunker. Worth visit for the waxworks and siren. The historical facts portrayed gave an insight in to the tremendous work undertaken in difficult conditions, The old ambulance was well preserved and the operating theatres were amazing. Not to expensive and well worth the visit.

What is tourism without a history lesson?. I went to Budapest with my friends as a day trip from vienna. I had the GPS set to the castle which i was eager to see along with the beautiful view from the hill. We found this museum while searching for a parking spot. How lucky we were. We booked the tour with hesitation because we did bot have any prior knowledge about this place. The staff were very helpful taking their time to explain to us what is inside which made us excited to go in. The 10 minutes video is a brief story about the place and its history. As other reviewers said, the room is small and sitting in the back is bothering because you wont be able to read the english subtitles. As the tour started our english guide started taking her time in every room to make sure everyone in the group sees it all. She was loud and clear that you can hear her even at the end of the group. She was very informative and answered all of our questions. The place is amazing with the history it beholds about the war and post war period. It is great to be in such a historic location to know what happened in WWii from the Hungarian perspective. I would highly recommend this tour. The downsides of this tour are being a full hour underground without being able to leave when you like. Some people feel bothered of this, i was fine but i wouldn't have handled more. the ventilation is great and the temperature is good. You do not need to use the coats they provide.
Interesting. Nice museum, guided visits in english, student discounted and peculiar souvenir shop (there is the possibility to buy original gas mask from cold war!)

Very interesting insight into Budapest during the war. We went to the hospital because it was open and we were cold and wet. How pleased I am we did as the tour is fascinating. The hospital is very well presented and the tour guide was excellent. Budapest struggled during the last year or so of WW2, being Nazi allies when things were going badly and the Russians occupied the city the situation became very tough but this hospital took in all sick people, regardless of nationality which has to be admired. Very interesting tour, highly recommended.

Really interesting tour. This is a very unique tour the like of which we had never experienced before. The tour takes you all around the underground hospital and support facilities, The tour guide we had explained everything in great detail and took time to explain a lot about the background to the hospital. Really worth doing.
Really interesting.. Really interesting tour. The guide had very good English and she gave lots of information and great little stories. Well worth a visit.
Interesting . Worth a visit as the model they made in the hospital made it more vivid, which reminds you of the war period together with the sound in the cave.

Amazing.. Simply put I do recommend. The guides speaks number of languages, English tours are easily available. So no problems there. Tour guides are informative, helpful, understand the history, easy to understand, and eager to share knowledge. We had Anita who was excellent.It is kind of humbling, for an Australian, to hear what Europeans went through during the war, soviet occupation and revolution. Tours are an our or so. But well done with lots of informant and original medical equipment.
Expecting more. Staff was lovely although I think the price is to high. Exposition it self was ok but nothing too exciting.

Incredible!. I strongly suggest to pay a visit to this pearl. i found the hospital in the rock the most interesting attraction in Budapest so far. Guided tours starts every hour and guides are very knowledgeable.

Fascinating and Chilling. One hour guided tour is the only way they let you in, guide spoke excellent English and was enthusiastic and patient. Tours start every hour on the hour. Tour gives a brilliant insight into the sadness and horror of two world wars and makes you realise how close we must have come to a nuclear catastrophe during the subsequent cold war. Exhibits and relics are very well presented. Really gives you something to think about.

What a surprise!!!. How enterprising and brave these people were to have the forethought and inguinuity to create a hospital underground,used both in Civil wars and world war 2,when occupation by Russia and invasion of Germany was at its peak..Handwashing and sanitisation were first discovered here by the doctor in charge, and surgery,with aseptic methods was in place.It was also a place of protection for Jewish children and families that were hidden and escaped thro different methods.It was also a place of refuge ,when it was feared that Atomic warfare from Cuba may take place.Fresh air systems were put in place with massive underground water tanks free of contamination were set up .Amazing place....

A piece of Budapest most tragic yet interesting history. Former hospital, it's a very nice building to visit. The guide is perfect, speaks perfect English and leaves you your time to look around. I think it's the best bunker I've ever saw...and I saw plenty.
A must see!. If you like history. This place is unique and it really brings you back in time. Worth the detour. Highly recommended.

Brilliant, an interesting guide tour of an unusual sight. This tour lasts a about an hour and is worth taking. This is not like anything else you will see and is informative and really interesting. To get there, head away from fishermans bastion to the wall, then down the steps at the wall and turn right... It is just down the road, not very far. This is worth an hour of your time. Our tour started on the hour in English.
hospital in the rock budapest. great tour guide, fascinating story and all new info to us. would recommend, especially to medical people!

The Museum that sets the standard.. this place doesnt allow Photograpsh so ive tried emphatically to explain to my friends the sheer scale of the place. its 2500m of underground preserved history. with 15,000 real life artifacts.. i dont think, ive eevr been anywhere thats ever given such a wide range of real life history, from the World War 2 hopsital, to the air-rade command function. the fully diesle powered air changing system and of course its darkened cold war functionality. I got the sense the Hungarians arent too prooud of their history in the last 100 years. but they sure as hell should be proud of the heritage this jewel underground is. certainly was my favourite discovery of our short break in Budapest.
Great place. Lovely place to visit. One hour guided tour. Very informative to see how the hospital worked during the Second World War and after.
for war stories lovers. very well presented but has no air...you can't take pictures but at the end of the tour the guide will take a group picture.

Well worth the stop.. Had the pleasure of attending this tour today and was humbled by the experience. First, the service was lovely - everyone we spoke with was quite kind and accomodating. The tour guide was especially impressive. She delivered the tour with a certain reverence to the place - and she wanted her guests to feel the same. The tour really helped you feel how devastating WWII was to Budapest - particular to the people who were not soldiers. It also highlighted how hard it was for the hospital workers and patients, and why it was so vitally important to the people. Best tour of the entire trip!

Alright. Nothing too write home about but still worth a wee visit before going up too the citadel,It is very small inside but well laid out and quite interesting especially if you are religious as I say worth a wee visit

Fascinating look into time. Such an interesting experience and one most North Americans cannot fathom. Very well done and authentic representation of a period in time not so long ago. You must see this when up on Castle Hill. Well worth the stop.

Stunning. It was really stunning. It was a bit tricky to find the adress but because of the name of the place it wasn't that hard, we knew it would be in the mountain. It started with a short film with all the info and then the guide walked us through and told us about each room and different events. The guide was superb and I really enjoyed it!

A treasure which needs to be seen. Take an hour and do the tour. Tours start on the hour. Medical history from the 50's through to the 80's. You will be interested and get some surprises as well. Ever been in a Nuclear bunker.
Extra Time. When you have seen the other sights, this is a great place to visit.It is right by the Buda Castle and takes maybe 45 min to see
Very Informative. The guides were all very helpful and new their stuff. Overall a very well spent couple of hours. Shame I didn't buy one of the masks!

Good tour. Sziklakórház Múzeum or Hospital in the Rock is worth going to see. it is part of the Castle Hill caves network and this secret subterranean hospital was used extensively during the WWII siege of Budapest and during the 1956 Uprising. During the Cold War it was also a nuclear bunker The tour lasted and hour and was 3600 HUF and our English speaking guide was so polite, friendly and knowledgable, answering any questions put to her.

must visit. a local friend recommend this place , in Egypt we don't have many places to tell the story of the world war 2 , for us it was just great the materials , the tour guide , every thing was amazing , a lot of information , it is very nice i think also for families
REALLY Interesting visit!. This is an excellent trip and explores an area that features highly in the history of the city of Budapest.Well worth a visit - Highly recommended!

Well worth a visit. My husband and I had visited quite a few tourist attractions in beautiful Budapest but in our minds the Hospital in the Rock was the best and well worth visiting. It was quite an emotional experience as it certainly brought to life the horror of war and in particular not only the suffering of the people of Budapest but also the incredible bravery. Not to be missed.
Enjoy the life in the worldwar. In this museum you could feel the days of your grandparents during the worldwar, poignant and interesting.

Different from the usual museum!. Excellently thought-out displays with all original items from the period. Quite gory but very interesting. Very good guides and a small selection of original items to buy, eg gas masks.

A very nice experience. This is a very interesting museum and a slightly different experience compared with the palaces and the churches of Budapest. The museum is built inside the real underground hospital that was built during the Second World War and was functioning during the war and during the cold war afterwards. Being there under the ground and feeling the cold and the moisture of the place sure gives you a real impression of how the things were back then. And the guide was just amazing. Speaking fluent English she enhanced the experience and made it feel even more real.It's 3600 HUF per person for a tour of one hour, and it's totally worth it. The tour is departing every hour. When we arrived there, the next hour tour was fully booked, so we made a reservation for the next one and meanwhile took a walk around the castle. Make sure you bring something warm to wear, since it's quite chilly down there.

Don't miss it. It is a moving museum away from the glamour and tourism of the palaces. The history of the place the guides and the walking tour give an in depth insight into the history of Budapest from 1938 onwards through the second world, the cold war up to the present day. The guide was superb.

Interesting bonus. En route to Buda Castle, chanced on this incredible Hospital museum and joined a tour straight away. Saci, our guide, was a knowledgeable polyglot, very pleasant and happy to answer our questions. No photos allowed but a nice surprise at the end was the guide photographing our group (that you can download from their website). Post-cards would have been welcome - none available due to maintenance works.

Very interesting. For 3600 HUF you will have a tour in a hospital bunker built at the begging of WWII. If you are a fanatic of WWII or the cold war you definitely don't want to miss it. However, if you are just a tourist you'll receive some very nice information about the recent history of Budapest. Definitely worth the visit!.

Very cool and a "Not to miss!". We stumbled upon this place as it was not in our tour book. It was my husband's favorite thing and reminded me of the one below Eagle's Nest. Tip: The guided tour starts on the hour, so get here about 10-15 minutes early so you get checked in. They do cap the number at 30 per tour and you are not permitted to take pictures. The tour starts with a short film that gives some historical background, then you have the guided your which takes about 40 minutes. Tip: With the Budapest Card, we paid 30% less for entry. Get the card. You get discounts on admissions plus metro, tram, and bus access.
a bit of hungarian history. Nice visit. The place is just outside the castle's wall, easy to find. The guides are kind and able to answer some extra questions.

Very Informative & Interesting. A very interesting museum on the Buda side. You are taken on a tour around the hospital and shown how it became a nuclear bunker after the war. The guide was very informative and spoke excellent English.

Kitschy but fun. The visit started with a short video about the history of the hospital. The area where we toured was pretty musty smelling. The various rooms were set up with mannequins and equipment to show what life was like back then. Some of them were pretty creatively arranged. It was an interesting little museum. Given that they don't allow photography, I wished that they had some postcards with photos in the very limited giftshop.

Very interesting place and tour. Tours start on the hour every hour throughout the day and are in English. If you are 25 or under make sure you take ID as you get in for half price. They show you a video at the start of the full history of the hospital which is very factual and sets you up for the tour. Our guide was amazing (there are multiple reasons as to why the tours are guided and why you can't just wonder through by yourself, however she tried to take her time so everyone had optimum opportunity to look at everything) she told us lots of amazing stories and facts and asked us questions to get us involved too. The wax figures are a bit basic/odd but this does not detract from the overall experience. You are not allowed to take pictures which is a shame but the guide takes a pic of everyone together when there (you don't have to be in it) and you can get it free off the website. A very eery place, full of history and stories. I would definitely recommend visiting, worth the money.

Well worth the time. Hospital in the Rock is located in a small part of the tunnels and labyrinths that spread throughout Buda Hill. Access is a short walk down from the top of Buda Hill. A part of the tunnels were transformed into a hospital during WWII and also used during the 1956 Hungarian Revolution. This was a highlight of our stay in Budapest. Entry is only with one of their guides and the tours begin on the hour. We learned a lot about the 20th century military history of Hungary and the tour brought Hungary to life for us. Most of the hospital rooms and equipment still remain. Well worth the time and effort to visit.

Interesting Place. Was an interesting visit with some really cool history. I thought the dummies that were set up were a little strange, but still was a neat experience. Milan was my guide... he was really energetic and knowledgeable.

well worth it. This visit was even better with a power cut and having to use torches. You get to see the theatre, wards, equipment and the waxworks are mega tastic. The hospital was actually used during the war and was overcrowded. You could almost feel the claustrophobia (but not quite) Guide was very knowledgeable. A fantastic visit
Interesting. A good way to spend an hour. It is with a guide and I would have liked to spend a bit longer looking at things but can understand why you can't.

Very interesting . The tour guide was very knowledgeable which made our visit both interesting and eye opening. The prices are very reasonable and visiting this museum was one of the best things we experienced whilst in Budapest.

Interesting well done tour. They take you on a guided tour, on the hour, and it was well done. Interesting hearing about the history of the place, seeing the WW2 setup, and the cold-war setup. What was most interesting, was that the hospital was used during the 1956 revolution. Kind of like seeing an "ancient Turkish underground city", but, one from the 20th century. The mechanical aspects were interesting too, we enjoyed it very much.

Really amazing. What they did during the second world war. And after. Quiet an emotional journey to see what people endured during these times .. and yet so many today have a lot to be grateful for. Truly amazing .

Worth the visit. For a quick over view of this hospital during WWII and the Cold War do not miss this. I was amazed at the labyrinth below the city and the hardships during those times. The mechanical/logistical operation in all aspects was just as fascinating as the medical part. I would have liked more time to view all the demonstration rooms, but the tours are only an hour long and you are given a lot of information in that time. There is a short film in the beginning that needs improvement. It is in Hungarian and the subtitles are on the bottom of the screen, so only those sitting in the front row of chairs can read the subtitles.

ok a bit quick. This is one a good place to visit and most interesting. Its fairly expensive to get in but well worth it. The only thing I didn't like was the speed of getting around. I would have liked a bit more time but well they are very popular so they really can't afford to let you stop too long. If you have been to The underground Hospital in Jersey then give it a miss.

You never know what's below your feet. You wouldn't realise the history that existed below your feet as you walked up on Buda Castle Hill. Unless the weather is bad or your aren't able to walk too far then don't feel the only way up is via the Funicular as over to the right are a set of steps through a tree lined path to the top. Once on top follow the signs to the Hospital in the Rock. You must have a guided tour and these are on the hour which is worth knowing to plan your time - we were just lucky with our timing. No photos allowed inside but worth the visit to see the various wax works depicting the history from hospital to nuclear bunker through the various disputes (including WW2, the seize of Budapest, the Cold War). Not to be missed on a day in Buda.

Very interesting. Interesting and unusual tour. Friendly informative guide who speaks good EnglishTour lasts about an hour. They are on the hour so make sure you factor that in if visitingGift shop/waiting area can only be described as odd

Fascinating place - pity about the organization.. Part of the castle complex. Difficult to find - if it was signposted we didn't see them and finished up asking a shop keeper. The subtitles on the introductory video are low down on the screen so make sure you get a seat at the front if you don't speak Hungarian. The guide told us that all the exhibits were originals but didn't allow sufficient time for us to look at them so we did feel quite rushed. Having said that we found the place fascinating and we were glad we went. Be sure you check out the different ticket prices. I got in for free and my partner for half price but you need proof of age, ideally your passport. Finally the wax works they use in the hospital are gruesome. If my doctor or nurse looked like them I'd run a mile.

Curious and Historical. Labyrinth of halls very interesting. Man size puppets real expressive. Journey to the 2 World War. Sounds imitating the ones from the period and also real instruments and clothes used on the war.

Awesome experience. Not the average museum, definitely a memorable experience. Friendly and professional tourguide, the staff was very friendly and helpful in general.They offer a warm coat, since it is ~15 degrees (Celsius) inside, but even though it was very nice weather out (so we wore shorts and a t-shirt), we didn't really need them.

An overlooked sight. In many this was a great experience to see.. A very skillful guide called Gerda showed us everything in this secretly hidden hospital underground the buda mountain. If you are interested in hospitals, history, the cold war and the story about Budapest this is a must

Engineering at its best. We visited Hospital in the Rock in early October. What an amazing place and the histroy very interesting! They do guided tours only every hour on the hour. Well worth a visit to see!
hospital in the rock. The history that surrounds Budapest during WWII and the Cold War is incredible. This hospital shows what the people of this amazing city had to endure to remain safe.

Must see - Nothing else like it!. We were made aware about this attraction from a small 'voucher' like booklet we received when we booked a bus tour of Budapest. Im so glad we went!Musuem is unique, never seem one quite like it. It was used as an emergency hospital during the war and the whole idea of it being uderground in the castle walls is amazing. The wax models give an idea of how cramped it really must've been when times were hard. Our tour guide Timi (sorry for spelling?) was so nice and knowledgeable, able to answer all questions and even through in some jokes too. The place is fascinating and the tunnels just keep going! Well worth a visit, cant believe its not advertised as much as some of the other museums.From what we understood its ran on a volunteer basis and the only money made is from tickets and andy gifts bought from the shop! Would recoommend in a heartbeat, tour probably lasted just over an hour.

A must-see attraction. This hospital was used as an emergency hospital during the second world war and the Hungarian revolution in 1956. I think it was opened as a museum in 2008. The details and the facial expressions of the objects there are just fascinating, as they tell us the stories of patients, how they got supplies, the siege and the people who died from infections. No photos are allowed in the hospital.

Unique Tour. We didn't know about this exhibit until we arrived and did some checking - it hasn't been promoted like some of the other Budapest attractions but is definitely becoming more popular. Just a short walk from St. Matthias (several blocks), this is a little known facet of history - a complete hospital built into the stone caves on the Buda side - was mainly finished in time for the 1944 invasion and apparently was used both by the Hungarians and the Germans (although the 2 types of patients were treated separately). Hallways and rooms stretch deep into the rock and the guide was extremely helpful in explaining the history and use. Following the was, it was also used during the cold war as an emergency escape and treatment hospital for those who might be affected by a nuclear explosion. Weird but fascinating. Book early in the day as the space is small and can only contain so many visitors.

Unique and Fascinating Museum. One of my favorite experiences in Budapest. Would not miss this museum. You have to visit as part of a guided tour. It seems like the museum is becoming more popular, so it is best to buy tickets earlier in the day. I showed up at 1:30 to try to buy tickets to the 2:00 tour, and it was already booked. Tours are offered at the top of the hour in English and Hungarian (split into two different groups) and last about an hour. The hospital was used during WWII and again during the late 1950s.
