The hospital has many items from the 1950s including surgical equipment, instruments, switchboards, generators, gas masks, etc. These items along with the tour guide really bring the experience to life.

incredible place, to help understand history. very well explained guided tour. You can't imagine a so big hospital in the caves under Buda. Very very interesting. Unfortunately only English spoken tour available (beside Hungarian, obviously)

Propaganda brought to life...... This is a really interesting place and we could have spent longer if allowed. It contains some of the old equipment and shows scenes of its operating theatre and wards, a bit eerie with some of the mannequins but it does bring it to life somewhat. The guided tour was good although I think there were too many people allowed on this as you have to squeeze into some rooms in order to hear the guide. She gave good detail of the care provided during war time and thereafter along with detail of the Nuclear bunker, bringing to life how propaganda was used during those times. Definitely worth a visit but you have to book a time slot which I assume start on the hour every hour so arrive in advance of the hour you wish to visit.

Exquisite tour. I would highly recommend a visit to the Hospital in the Rock as it provides great insight into the role of Budapest in the war. The tour was very informative and enjoyable and the guide was great. Overall a great experience had by everyone I visited with.
Fascinating Museum. This museum is great, really interesting. The tour guide was very informative, and the displays really bring it all to life. Definitely worth a visit.

Atmospheric! . This is definitely worth a visit! Interesting history of the battles going on outside, Red Cross history and the original nuclear decontamination rooms. The whole complex needs to be seen as part of a guided tour at no extra charge. Tours normally start at the hour, and are very informative. 100% worth the money, around £5 if under 26.

Don't miss this. I could have spent longer in this interesting place. The hospital was created from tunneling into the rock. It still contains some of the old equipment and shows scenes of its operating theatre and wards. The guided tour brought to life the difficulties of providing care during war time. It was a successful project, providing decent air quality, water, food and medical care.After the war it was kept in case of nuclear attack.

Amazing place. Fee is 12€, but the place is worth it! (and there are many discounts: disabled people, students, seniors, health professionals)Very interesting and didactic. The wax museum style makes it very real.Although most tourist guides don't say a word of it, I consider the "Sziklakorhaz Muzeum" a must in Budapest.

Amazing!. Being medical professionals, we loved the Hospital in the Rock tour. We had just completed an 8 mile running tour and the last thing my husband wanted to do was climb back up the hill to get to the site, but he was very happy I convinced him! Timea was our guide and she was extremely knowledge and a great tour guide. The hospital has been restored to even include wax figures to make it even more realistic as it is no longer functioning. We got a discount for being in medicine which was a nice plus.

Awesome expo and tour. Brilliant expo of a truly fascinating place. The original hospital in the natural cave system beneath the castle has been converted into an excellent display of what the hospital was like. Very well put-together tour and display. I'd definitely recommend this.

A great tour of a hospital built underground for use during WWII. This was close to our hotel and decided to take the tour. Very interesting. Used during WWII, then opened again during the cold war of the 50'-60's. I would recommend it to people interested in WWII history.
Interesting. I'm happy we out this on our plan of sights in Budapest. It gives an interesting history of the hospital that is unique. There is a discount for medical professionals.

Very Informative. If you are interested in history, this is a must see. We truly enjoyed the visit, it was well done, informative and was one of the highlights of our visit to Budapest. Also, they provide discounts for members of the military, serving and retired (regardless of the country where you served), free for teachers, free for people in the medical field, as well as discounts for a number of other occupations.

Hospital in the Rock. I visited this attraction for the first time today, with my adult son. It had been previously been visited my oldest son and his fiancee earlier in the year.On arrival, the staff on the desk, were very pleasant, and spoke very good English. The tour was given in English, to a very high standard, and did not give the impression of a well prepared script. The guide was open to questions at any time during the tour.The guide gave lots of information on the different usage of the tunnels and rooms through the years. Rooms used for specific purposes were well presented with wax dummies wearing copies of clothing and uniforms from the appropriate era, and some original equipment where possible. In addition there were information posters and photographic displays, some of which had English translations below the Hungarian.There is a shop at the entrance selling a number of items related to the use as a hospital and as a nuclear bunker, the prices of which were on the whole, not particularly expensive.The only reason I have only given a 4 rating is that I would have liked a bit more time to be able to read and study the posters and related text that was on the walls of various rooms. That said, I do think it is worthwhile visiting.

Very educational. We visited this due to the reviews on trip advisor and it did not let us down. Our tour guide Saci had exceptional knowledge of the history of not only the hospital but also of Budapest. A lot of the reviews say it's very cold, but I did not need the poncho and I found the temperature fine. Only downside is the group we went with was quite large, and a lot were pushing to get to the front of the exhibitions. Excellent set up though, and very reasonably priced
favorite attraction in Budapest. This is a great place to visit and gives a fascinating insight into Hungarian history in the 20th century. A must see

Really interesting. The one hour tour through the caves of the hospital is absolutely a must see. They talk you through the many different eras and the role of the hospital. The cold war bunker stuff is interesting but the world war 2 era was best. Well worth a visit

Underground structure. The coolest thing about this attraction was learning about the underground structure in Budapest and its use through history. That said, it was fairly expensive and you are required to take a tour which was longer than I needed to be in confined spaces.

Overpriced and no photos allowed. The hospital is a very good place to visit and see the history first hand. There are lots of mannequins and they do really bring the story to life. It is a must visit attraction of the castle hill area. It played an important part in the WW II and beyond into the cold war when it was rejigged as a nuclear bunker. Most of the material inside is original and authentic.The downsides are that you need to join a tour, which runs on the hour so you may have to wait. They also don't allow you to take pics inside which I hate. The charges are expensive -3600 HUF, for what the attraction is worth. If you go to the Matthias church they give you a 10% discount voucher for the hospital ticket.
WWII underground hospital. An interesting trip.Wax figures helped to give it context (surprisingly)Underground hospital from WW II and Cold War. Well conducted tour. Reasonably priced family ticket.

Unbelievable accomplishment. This was such an interesting place to visit. Totally amazed at how long this place was kept a secret and how large the facility was. Hospital wards, an operating room and residences are just part of what is hidden here.

The best museum we visited in Budapest. Very interesting place, opens your thoughts about history... WW2... political situations in Europe during cold war. Everybody should see this and let it affect!The ticket price was OK and the quide spoke fluent english. You'll see things what you can see only in very few places in Europe.NOTE: you are not allowed to take any photos inside!

a hospital bunker. Never seen before!. It's start with a short inforative film witch give you the basic information you need to understand. Under the castle, they build in the old cave a warhospital for civilians. During the battle of Budapest, everybody dropt in. Lateron it was used during the revolt in 56. After that, a concierge maintaned this place, so we can see it 'ready to use'. This place is so unique. They do real efforts to make this visit interesting. Unfortently are gentle guide didn't know very much about the medical instruments, but her enthousiame made everything OK You visit this hospital, at that time state of they art. Later they add an entery provide with a anti nuclear corridor.it's rather cold in the bunker (as always); so take something to keep you warm with you. (or borrow one of the military capes you can use)For us, this place was more facinating than the castle above. Pity you are not allow to take photo's. And the shop doens't provide any book in English
Fascinating. Very informative tour of the caves under Castle Hill, sadly they had run out of English guide books.

Quirky, informative, engaging. Go.. I'll be honest I wasn't sure how much I would enjoy seeing effectively an old underground bunker, but this is well worth the trip. The tour was really useful and although it takes an hour it romps along at a rapid pace and is over before you know it. The caves can be chilly but you can borrow a military style cape for the tour and you can have a go at an indoor air raid siren. There is lots of equipment in situ so you do get a feel for how it must have felt to be there when it was operational. There was a no photo rule in place when we were there, however they do take a group photo which goes on their website. If you wear the cape, you get an awesome photo.The gift shop is bonkers. Coming from the UK the concept of selling off original items is strange, but certainly would come with much higher price tickets. Original gas masks, bandages, map case and all sorts of strange surplus is available for a genuinely unique souvenir. Lastly, the English speaking guide (Sophie) gave an interesting and engaging talk throughout the tour. We left with a sense of understanding Hungary's recent past and the challenges that face it now, which is quite an achievement for such a short tour. We were in town on business and knowing what the families of our colleagues have lived through and how this must have shaped their lives was very humbling. Points to note - I would have no problem bringing children here, however due to the nature of the building (excavated cave network) I wouldn't bring strollers and those with mobility difficulties, especially wheelchair users, may struggle. It would be worth calling ahead as the staff do speak very good English.

worth keeping in memory. Most attractive is the fact that it existed in reality not so far from us. Don't think a second and use this opportunity to visit this place so to touch, breeze in, see and understand all the threat of wars can bring and that not every one is saved. Visas in Soveit passports sold in the museum shops are copied from the current Belarusian ones! ))

One of the memorial hospital. I hope you visit this facility and participate in the guide tour. The guide will tell you about the history of the hospital and how scary the war was. And you can see the medicine and the items which were used at that time. You can't take pictures inside the cave, but the guide staff took commemorative photo at the end of the tour. You can check the photo on the WEB site of this hospital.It's not easy to find the entrance. This hospital is the opposite side of the Donau river. You will find here with walking along the wall.

A different experience. This was really interesting. I didn't know what to think about it at the beginning, but then the place is something so different from everywhere else. The guides are wonderful and I learnt a lot of things I had no idea about the history of Budapest.Imagining all that people sick, needed surgery, and all those doctors and nurses closed inside that tiny cave-like hospital was pretty chilling. A really interesting visit that I would recommend to any history lovers.

Love love loved it!. One of the most interesting museums I have ever been to, shedding light on Budapest's history from the world wars through to soviet rule and the present. Tours in multiple languages which are included in entry price. Great guides and great price! I would say that it suits every age. My parents loved it, I did and so did my little sister :)
Interesting!. The museum has been made great. Very alive, and the guide was really good. There is a map placed serveral places so you easily can find the place.

Very interesting!. We found the hospital in the rock with the help of signs in English and Hungarian. It was slightly more pricey than other places within Budapest but if you're under 26 you get in for half the price which was great. The English tour guide was very informative and friendly. I found out interesting facts and information about the history of Budapest and Hungary. The wax figures throughout make the hospital seem that bit more real. It does get slightly cold but they offer army style coats if you are cold which was good. Definitely worth the visit and price :)
Beautiful. The museum is amazing!!!It was interesting to visit it and to learn the history behind it! It is a must to see in budapest!

Chilled!. This is worth the admission price just to escape the Budapest sun.Its also a very interesting tour of caves under the Buda hills converted to a wartime hospital and later converted to a cold war nuclear bunker.Informative guide helped to communicate a sense of what the place was like for doctors and patients alike and some interesting stories about how the place was concealed when it was a top secret facility.

Interesting war time Hospital. This is worth the price of admission! Hospital was used during WW II. The hospital is carved into rock. It is interesting to see how they maximized the limited space that had. Admissions, operating rooms and 3 wards. Also a morgue.

An interesting museum . This is an interesting place to visit and is certainly one of a kind. Our guide was informative and told us about the many uses of the cave. This place is worth a visit but being something warm to wear!

Loved hearing the hospital stories. I really enjoyed this museum, I found it on foot but I do agree with another review re signage (there wasn't any)I think it equated to about £6 for entrance, I got a nurses discount. The discount is offered to nurses and doctors with I.DTours leave on the hour in English, you do have to stay with the guide but in a warren of underground tunnels and my sense of direction that is no bad thing.I thoroughly enjoyed seeing the scenes in the wards and theatres and hearing the stories of the wounded, and the conditions the staff worked under.Following the closure of the hospital the cave became a nuclear bunker.My only slight negative would be that had I meandered alone I would have spent longer in each room but I guess that's not true of everyone and I appreciate they need to accommodate lots of people.Worth noting the temp in the caves is about 16, a welcome relief from the august sun ;)

Really impressive and different!. It was a surprise for our teenage daughters to have the chance to see a real part of World War 2 history become alive in front of their eyes! Our guide was perfect and with perfect English told us stories, secrets and unknown parts of Budapest's history. The Hospital museum is the closest thing to reality and it really fascinated us! Fully recommended!

A fascinating journey into the past. The hospital makes use of the ancient tunnels under the Castle Hill and was used during the siege of Budapest in 1944. It was then designed to be used as a nuclear shelter. Tastefully maintained including wax figures, a tour of this complex is well worthwhile and excellent value for money.

Unique history experience. Very interesting guided tour inside a hospital bunker, used during WW2, and later on by the russian regime. You cannot go by yourself, but the guide tells interesting stories all the time about the place, so i guess it wouldn't be half as interesting if you were allowed to stroll around by yourself!

Hour's tour well worth it, was classified until 2002. The hospital has a varied and interesting history and was heavily involved in WW2, the siege of Budapast, when Nazis were trying to hold the river crossing against advancing Russians, the cold war, including 1956 uprising. There are many waxworks in situ which bring the original instruments, furniture and equipment to life today from what was a relatively short time ago.Its existence was a state secret until as recently as 2002! The must see in my view when visiting Buda.Half price for over 60s as well, £5 entrance.

Great for history buffs!. Interesting visit. I didn't even know the site existed until it was mentioned by a tour guide. The tour is just under an hour, and given in English at the top of every from about 9:00 to 19:00. Tour begins with a short video to give a historical context and general overview and then continues with a guided tour of the facility which is tens of meters underground. You can't walk around freely but the tour covers most of the important rooms. Theres a discount for students, medical personnel, teachers etc. so be sure to ask for one. After leaving, try looking for the generator exhaust pipe in the street above ground.

Hidden gem. Guided walking tour through the hospital, after 7 pm with flashlights that give you an authentic impression. Wax figures everywhere and replicas of hospital scenes during WW II, really touching and sad experience. :( Guide lady was talkative and her stories were educative but only one thing bothered me: sound of siren at the end of the tour. One of the visitors was allowed to activate it so it reverberated in such a small space so that we all had to plug our ears. It was really anxious moment for me but luckily it happened at the end of the tour. I recommend this hospital to everyone except small children because at times it can be a little bit scary for them, all that blood, wounds, unconscious wax people, gas masks, medical needles etc.

Very interesting visit, well worth while. It is well worth visiting this hospital which is an eye opener and a reminder of wartime conditions, in this case both from 1944/45 and the siege of 1956. The tour, which lasts just under an hour, takes you round the wards, operating theatres etc as they were at this time with displays such as the bandages used, which went out of date in 1961! Several waxwork figures of doctors, nurses, patients are in place which gives a very good feel for how things must have been. The end of the tour takes you through the nuclear bunker as well. The visits are all with a guide - we were the only two English speakers when we arrived and we were taken around separately with a guide who spoke excellent English.

Potential to be excellent. An incredibly interesting and unusual place, the guide was helpful and the tour was very educational, but unfortunately the tour was too big and unless you were at the front for the entirety you missed out on a lot of what was being said. Also there are many interesting original collections and exhibitions that you do not have time to look at as you are being walked through. Think this place would benefit a lot from an option of an audio guide so you can walk around at your own pace. However would recommend if you are visiting the Castle Hill area anyway.

Fascinating unique experience. This is a must when visiting Budapest. Excellent guided tour which lasts approx. 1 hour. You get a real feel as to what it must have been like at that time when the hospital was in use.
Our young lady guide was so knowledgeable which certainly added to the experience.

A fascinating historical tour!. Definitely recommended. This is a unique time capsule that is well presented and makes it easy to imagine the dreadful conditions the staff must have worked under.
It was also interesting to see the Cold War arrangements from the other side, so to speak.

An interesting hospital. There is an guided tour in English every hour. It is very interesting to see and hear about the hospital in the rock.
You can not visit the hospital in the rock on your own.

Great experience. Very knowledgeable guide whose English was very very good. Lots of memorabilia and exhibits to look at. Learnt a lot about the uses of the hospital and experiences of the Hungarian people during WWII, 1956 uprising and the Cold War threat. The cool of the caves was a welcome relief on a very hot day which just added to the experience (though they supply jackets if you need them as the tunnels get rather cool). Very much worth the entrance fee. Only draw backs were the largish group (it is peak tourist season after all) and some difficulties were had hearing our guide present due to the echoing in the tunnels of other attendees conversations and the proximity of another tour group (different language). Thanks for a great experience!
Interesting insight into twentieth century Hungarian history!. A good value, well designed tour! Friendly tourguide, good location, well worth the entrance fee! Please go :)
Fantastic. Definitely visit here, was amazed. Really interesting. There was no English book at the end to buy as they had run out which was a shame but I liked the whole thing.

Really interesting tour - very different. This is a really unique attraction tucked away in Budapest. The guides spoke really good English, and the tour was very well constructed. Really engaging and the temperature of the caves was a welcomed break from the humidity. I would absolutely recommend it.

Unique experience. It is a unique experience to be able to see that such a hospital existed and to be able to see how it functioned. It is well set up and well guided. Although our tour had too many people. Especially enjoyable is the historical significance of the place, and how many people do really get a chance to go to a nuclear bunker like this one. Also, try out the interesting things in the museum shop, quite unique. Overall enjoyable, but not something that will be the highlight of the trip.

Really unique attraction. Very interesting attraction. Not something you can do anywhere. And on a hot day, the coolness of the caves was a welcome break. The history of the place, both WW2 and the Cold War was fascinating. I even liked the strange wax figures.

Interesting if you have the time. This was an interesting experience but not one I would rank as a must-do. It is only possible to visit by guided tour. Although advertised as an hour, the tour lasted only lasted 45 minutes.
Fabulous. It deserve to visit 100%, the best choice is the 19:00 flashlight tour (full darkness inside), it is more fun and misterious.

A must for anyone interested war time history.. Great value for money as it included an hour tour with a knowledgeable and friendly tour guide - Akos was fab! Really interesting look into wartime hospital care. Plus the capes make it even more authentic!

not the norm.... This place is definitely worth finding and visiting. Tour the old hospital / nuclear bunker with a knowledable guide. Walking through did feel like a step back in time - a oddly horrifying glimpse at what it might have been like during the seize of Buda. Those who attempted to provide medical care in those circumstances are worthy of respect. The tour gives you wool wraps to keep you warm during the tour. I am not sure you need to bother with these (especially if you go during the summer). I enjoyed being able to read the English subtitles on intro movie - so you might want to sit forward for the film. No photos allowed inside - so if you are schleping a camera around - don't bother for the inside.

Superbly odd museum off the beaten track. This is a truly odd place, but probably the highlight of my trip. It is an abandoned hospital and nuclear bunker buried under Buda. The tour is very interesting, and the museum is full of all the original apparatus, with add mannequins made to look like the real people. One of those truly memorable experiences - I couldn't recommend it any more highly!

Brilliant!. This was a guided tour of Budapest's secret hospital that helped see them through the end of WW2. It is set up as a wax museum, which really adds to the understanding of how it was used and the conditions that people endured to give and receive care during the war. The tour guide knew his stuff. If you are a doctor, nurse or paramedic, bring your ID because you get a discount on the price! Wear a coat or sweater because the caves are chilly, but they do have some coats to loan.

A bit different!. I thought hospital in the rock was an excellent and interesting museum. A bit different, too! The tours are on the hour and last 60 minutes. There are plenty of cafés to enjoy a drink if you just miss a tour (like we did) and wait for the next one. You can only visit the labyrinth of rooms as part of a guided tour and our English speaking tour guide made it an enjoyable visit. It can feel quite chilly once you're deeper into the rocks, but there is an opportunity, at the start of the tour, to borrow an overcoat, if you don't have anything suitably warm with you. Wax figures and mock-operation scenes give a real feel for what it must have been like, working and surviving, in very difficult and trying circumstances. Some of the scenes are quite bloody and graphic and may be unsuitable for young children. You are not allowed to take photos in the museum, but a group photo is taken by the tour guide and posted to their website as a reminder of your visit.

Worth a visit. An excellent historical tour that gives one a glimpse of the pressures that the medical staff dealt with during the war. Aside from the various maze of caves leading from the triage rooms, operating theaters and medical wards, one has to admire the engineering to keep the hospital running - the air and water purification systems together with the anti-radiation mechanisms make this a true marvel

Hospital in the Rock, Buda, Hungary. This is an "off the beaten path" tour, but, one of our top excursions in Budapest! We took the funicular up the hill and then walked to the Hospital in the Rock. It is a bit tricky to find, but worth asking locals for hints to reach it! Built during World War II to house their Hungarian injured, reopened during the 1956 Uprising, it is so well done. They have reenacted each hospital room with wax figures as surgeons, nurses, patients, etc. I am a nurse, so was really interested in viewing this hospital. However, my family, thoroughly found the tour fascinating, filled with incredible stories of working under extreme conditions and successfully caring for the sick and injured. Pack your nursing or MD license and get 50% off the entrance fee!

Highly recommended to visit. If you visit Budapest don´t miss the opportnuity to join a guided tour in the Hospital in the Rock! It is worth every minute you spend there. It really touched me to hear about the circumstances under which the heroes of everyday life worked there to save the lives of thousands of strangers without caring about their own. It is as if you still can feel this spirit there and the tour is really interesting and professionally guided. Thanks a lot for an exceptional experience!

Interesting preservation of history. Would have liked to tour this on my own as wanted to look at it at my pace. Interesting looking at the hospital area but not as interested in the machinery area. Need to watch you head as there are low areas and pieces of piping etc jutting out.The video clip at the start is informative.Wear sensible shoes and if you feel the cold take a warm top as it is a constant 15 degrees.

Interesting, but needs developed. This attraction was interesting. It charts the hospital's development from the 30s through the War and into the Cold War. Guide gives good background to what happened, but visitor is left feeling that more could be offered, for example wax works are very amateurish and the tour felt rushed maybe because it was the last tour of the day.

Another amazing bit of Budapest's history. A fully functional WW II hospital inside caves? With its own air, water and electricity supply? That was subsequently converted into a nuclear bunker during the Cold War? Really? Only in Budapest!!Our family (inc daughters aged 11 & 13) loved this somewhat spooky and certainly fascinating peek into some of the tougher moments of Budapest's 20th century history. There's no other way to see this than to take the guided tour, which runs hourly on the hour. The tour was good, very informative, providing insights into the very difficult circumstances that surgeons had to work under, and also some of the engineering problems that such a facility had to overcome. Some very dramatic photos, posters and other archives, from both WW II and Cold War eras.Highly recommended, also as a break from the summer heat!

Hospital with a difference. Please do not let the setting of this marvelous hospital deter you from taking a guided tour. It is built in the caves on castle Hill and is truly unique.It may appear claustrophobic but it is not at all. The guides are excellent and the experience of viewing what was an excellent hospital in its day is very worthwhile. You will be so glad you went - honestly!

Cool bunker experience. My teen son and I took a tour in June during our visit to Budapest. Guided tours are offered in English hourly There are many discounts available (teachers, doctors, nurses, military & more) and the cashier asked me if I qualified for any of them. Tour is preceded by a short video. They have woolen capes that you can borrow to keep warm while you tour the cave which is quite cool. The purpose of the bunker is explained well and the displays are interesting. There are new rooms/exhibits since I was there 2 years ago, which was a nice surprise. My 14 yr old son thought the hospital in the rock was really cool and enjoyed our visit.It's easiest to find the hospital in the rock from Castle Hill. When you're standing in front of St Mathias church take the road to your left which will lead to a long covered stairway. At the bottom of the stairs go right and the hospital will be on your right. If you are using public transportation you can reverse the above directions and catch a bus from Castle Hill or go right when you leave the Hospital in the Rock and about a block or so later on the left there is a huge staircase going down. It's not marked, you just need to look for it. At the end of the many stairs, go through the park, taking the fork to the right and head for what looks like a parking garage. The metro stop Deli Paulyaudvar is there.

A hidden gem. This was a surprisingly interesting visit. We arrived 5mins after the English tour had departed, but we were taken to join the group. Our guide, Judit, was excellent and the tour was so interesting. The time flew by and it didn't feel like almost an hour in length. The wax models were a bit creepy and this is not a tour for anyone claustrophobic. The best bit however was the temperature - it was wonderfully cool in the hospital, unlike the 30 something outside!

Get your timing right. Once an hour they run a guided tour so get there by 50 minutes before the hour ... Otherwise go and find a bar before descending the steps. However, well worth planning a detour from the main castle area. The tour talks to the 2nd world war, Cold War, Hungarian rising etc and gives you a feel for the turmoils of the past this country has gone through. Only slight disappointment is that you are not given some time to explore at your own pace.

Hidden Hospital. The Hospital in the rock is hidden in 2 ways-firstly quite difficult to find, and secondly a labrinth of tunnels and rooms. We had booked in for an English tour, and started after a short film. The group we had comprised about 20 people, so not too big or small. Mrs JB, a teacher, was offered free entry-not quite sure of why but they asked the question upon entry/payment, so just double check if that is your occupation. We new of the Hospital, but not the histoy behind it. It has lead us to reserch further of what transpired not only within the hospital, but in Budapest itself over the last 100 years. The tour itself was very informative and quite fun, and we quite enjoyed the mix of fact, ficton?, models, displays, and real life exhibits from bygone years. We were there in Spring, so it was quite cool inside-they offered coats for those that required. We were able to draw on our experience and information gatehred at the Hospital, when we visisted other sites around Budapest. PS Follow Aileen E's post re directions, as this is exactly how we found it(after some searching of our own)

Unique, informative, worthwhile!. Set aside a whole morning or afternoon for this exhibit - it's well worth the visit and will give you an astounding view on the war time happenings of Budapest.It's down the side of a hill - the easiest way to find it is to go to the Matthias Church and walk down the road perpendicular - down the side of the Burg Hotel. From here you reach a wall and a set of stairs down the side of the hill. Down these stairs, turn right and it's right there in front of you. Not difficult if you walk around either.Inside it's cut into the rock, so will be cooler than other attractions. Bring something to dress appropriately.The tour guide was informative and passionate. He answered any questions we had about the exhibit and frankly my tour was one of the best things we did on our holiday. The video about Hungary was in Hungarian with subtitles, he spoke great English.The attraction has been finished to a great quality, with some ancient painting only just found last year! Of course the attraction is about Plagues, illness and hardship as it's a Hospital. If you have any idea what you are going in for you will have a wonderful time.

Hard to find and Scary, if you ask me. We tried to find this "Hospital in the Rock" based on a recommendation by our tour guide, but we were exploring on our own at this point on foot and searched around FOREVER to find the place. The signage was not good at all, it could somewhat be contributed to the fact that they were doing some construction in the area, but still! Then, we finally find it (it's down the other side of the giant mountain that the St. Stephan's Cathedral is on, by the way), we pay the entrance fee to go into the first part of the tour, which is a video, in Hungarian, about the history of the hospital, and we were weaving back and forth to try and read the subtitles on the bottom with all the people in front of us, only to read about plagues, quarantines, and more that have happened there, how the spaces are really small and it's cold and damp (but they provide you with suspicious looking coats if you'd like), that you can get lost because it's such a labyrinth, and then they show some clay or wax models that are supposed to mimic what patients looked like.... yikes! The history was cool and all, but the whole situation just wasn't for us. Plus, the tour is an hour long and you can't duck out early because you'll be lost in there! Overall, I can't really say what the rest of the tour entailed, but I didn't lose any sleep over skipping out. Good luck if you go! lol

Interesting building, informative tour. On the day that we visited it was 36 degrees and we walked up a steep hill to get here. I was relieved to find that the hospital was just 14 degrees inside, it was the only time I managed to be cool for the entire holiday! That aside, it was probably the most expensive museum we visited but the guide, Rudolph, was interesting and made it a worthwhile visit.

A monument to unknown heroes . At the beginning we thought it was a bit expensive, once out we was glad we spent those money. It really is a journey inside 60 years of story, seen from the deep of a tremendous reality. Really suggested! And the english speaking guideTinea (hope I remember it correctly) well, she is the best!
Hospital in the Rock. Hard to find but worth the visit. Really cool history and an awesome place to stand in that history. Great guides who are informed and invested in the museum.
Informative and Engaging. Hour long tours in Hungarian and English every hour make this WW2 and Cold War Hospital/Bunker an incredible journey into the past.
Cool for older kids. This was a cool find in Buda. The history was very interesting and touring through a hospital built in a cave system was cool. It was a good experience for the whole family.

Interesting Tour. We followed the signs to locate this museum, which is a bit out of the way, but were glad we did.Following a brief movie, we joined a small group led by an English speaking guide who was very enthused and personable. Due to the chilly temperature in the underground setting, everyone is urged to wear a green loden coat/ cape , available from a rack at the entryway. Everyone winds through the tunnels and pathways which include rooms for surgery and medical equipment, as well as a nuclear bunker. The guide was very informative in describing the hospital's work and offered background on wartime Budapest. This was a good change of pace after viewing many castle interiors!

Must see, fascinating with a great tour guide.. We went at 6pm for the English tour and there were 6 people in our group.It was absolutely fascinating, so glad we went. It is a war hospital under the ground and you can see a nuclear bunker. Has been restored very well, you cannot walk around freely but our guide Fruszi was informative and it was a worthwhile tour.Really recommend you go, entrance is 3600 HUF each (£9) or discounted if you have any ID to prove you are medical or armed forces personnel.

Really interesting. Interesting place to visit in the Castle district - it was highly recommended by our walking tour guide so we popped along afterwards. We hadn't realised that tours left on the hour, and having arrived at 6.10pm we thought we might have to wait another 50 mins but we were told we have only missed the introductory video that we could catch up on at the end so that was great. We didn't have any of the problems that other reviewers have mentioned about tour sizes - we were 6 on an English speaking tour and had lots of space! I would say the tour guide hurried us a bit but there was a lot to see and he was extremely knowledgable! A piece of history that is worth visiting. Wasn't sure about the sale of actual items from Hospital and Czech gas masks in the shop.http://www.sziklakorhaz.eu/en

Interesting but tours need to be capped!. The Hospital in the Rock is a really interesting place though, in my opinion, quite expensive by Hungarian standards and, as such, I expected better. Unfortunately you're not allowed to roam freely through the system of tunnels and instead you have to join a tour - when I visited there were two tours running at the same time (one after the other) with one led by an English speaking guide and one Hungarian. There were at least 20 people on the English speaking tour that I joined at 3pm on a weekday afternoon and only a handful on the Hungarian tour. In hindsight, I wish I'd just joined the Hungarian tour as with so many people in our group, it was a struggle to see a lot of the rooms (most of the areas are very small so not many people can reasonably fit in) and I could barely hear our guide - when I could hear her I really struggled to understand what she was saying as, though she tried to speak clearly and make herself heard, her English was pretty poor. It didn't help that lots of people in the group were talking over the guide in their own languages. I feel strongly that numbers on the tours should be capped at 10-15 people as I'm sure that if I'd actually been able to see more of the hospital and hear what the guide was telling us, I'd have enjoyed it a lot more.

Must-see. This museum is definitely one of the best. Only done through guided tours, you experience life in the hospital as well as its many other uses through the years. The guide is very good and informative.

Very Interesting Bit of History. This tour only lasted about an hour but it was extremely interesting. They offer tours in English and the tour guide was very knowledgable about the history of the hospital built in the caves under Budapest. The history not only includes the use in the second WW, but also during the cold war. They do provide overcoats (free) to wear during the tour as it is quite cold.

Fascinating but tours should be capped at 15 people.. I wanted to love this experience. I find the entire place fascinating, and this could be a remarkable tour. I'll explain my issues with it, as you may be able to avoid the things that bothered me to better enjoy yourself.The intro video is actually really well done and informative. It gives you a lot of background into what you are about to see, and I feel like it sets it up to where you need very little additional information. After the video (spoken in Hungarian with English subtitles), they break everyone into two groups - a Hungarian tour and an English tour.I strongly believe they should get a count for each tour BEFORE you break into the groups. We had 19 people on our English tour. There was one family of 5 on the Hungarian tour. I have no problem with the division of languages being done this way and am grateful an English tour is offered, but I really think there should be a max of 15 people per language tour.I am not a pushy person, so, while I started toward the middle of the group, I quickly was pushed to the back of the group. Because you are in a cave system with small rooms, I'd often not get to see anything until the group was moving to the next room. By the time I got to see anything, the tour guide had usually already started explaining about the next room. So I consistently missed explanation and sometimes couldn't fit in the room at all until another person left.Another thing impacting my enjoyment was that not everyone on the English speaking tour spoke English and spoke over the guide. I had an Italian couple next to me, and the gentleman was constantly translating for the female. So not only did I start off by missing what the guide was saying due to the size of the group, but I also missed part of what she was saying because of chatter within the group (much more likely to happen in large groups).Had I known this going in, I would have just joined the Hungarian group of five people. I wouldn't have understood anything the guide said, but I think I would have enjoyed this tour a considerable amount more had I been given time and space to look around. The video established the scene before we went on the tour. I honestly don't feel like I heard the tour guide provide any information that added to my understanding of what I was seeing. For me personally, the size of the group detracted from my enjoyment more than the tour guide added to the enjoyment. I think you will get more from this tour seeing more than hearing more.I also think they should send the smaller tour in first. The group of five was always directly behind me, so I always felt rushed whenever I finally got to see something. It naturally takes 5 people less time to see something than it takes 19 people to see something. But the Hospital in the Rock is really a neat and fascinating experience. I just would have really really enjoyed it more if they capped the group size at 15.
A must see. One hour tour through a fully functioning (back in WWII era) hospital and cold war ear air raid shelter. Fascinating for history lovers and physicians.

Fascinating. A great time spent learning about the history of the hospital during the 1940's-60's. The place is packed with original medical equipment and the tour guide was very interesting to listen to.Would strongly recommend a visit whilst in the Buda Castle District.
Gifts. Loved it but as we were not allowed to take photograph I expected to purchase cards in a gift shop. They didn't have any

amazing and appalling. I loved the way the guide, a very young girl, explained all the good things that happened down here but at the same time I felt the horror that could be felt for all those who were crammed there in this labyrinthic place. If you feel claustrophobic, avoid visiting this hospital

Worth it, go!. Super interesting. The place is hard to find, we almost gave up looking for it since we knew that we had to arrive on the hour to be there for the tour. It is behind Budapest Castle, down some steps and to the right. Leave enough time to look for it. My husband is an M.D. and he really loved it. So much better than the usual museum since you are actually in the cave and you see the materials in the actual locations. Guides were knowledgeable and spoke great English. Take a jacket, they have these coats available, but I don't know how often they are cleaned so take a light jacket with you.

Hospital in the caves under Buda Castle. This was a good experience and interesting to see how expansive this hospital. It was built in a series of caves under the Buda Castle. It amazing how expansive it is. Experience is between Average and Above Average. It was something different to see but in comparison to views over the Danube and the museums in the Buda Castle it kind of pales.

very interesting and educational. we visited the hospital very unexpectedly but it was worth. the staff is amazing, very professional and they really tell everything you need to know for an interesting visit of this site. it is not crowded but i think it deserves your attention!!

Hidden gem. Had stumbled across this on the net - a bit of out the way but well worth a visit. 1 hour tour through the corridors under the Castle rock telling the story of the Red Cross hospital helping with the war effort.Guides are friendly and speak good English. Couldnt resist buying a replica gas mask in the gift shop

Well worth visiting. My other half and I had tried to find this the last time we went to Budapest but could find it so this time we made an effort to find it. Not the easiest place to find but it is worth persevering as the tour and information is brilliant. We spent a fascinating hour or so there and thought the whole experience was brilliant. The tour guide was very informative and we learnt a great deal about the hospital as well as Budapest.

A Very Cool Place on a Very Hot Day. I wanted to visit this museum because the Hilton Front Desk Supervisor, Laslo Csakvary, had been interviewed and mentioned this as a truly unique destination. It is hidden within the caverns below Castle Hill and served as an emergency clinic during World War II, then was transformed into a secret nuclear bunker in the Soveit era. You will literally travel through time as you can view the original fixtures, medical equipment and the appropriately dressed wax figures in period uniforms and costumes. Then have a wonderful lunch at the Baltazar restauarnt that is nearby.

Don't miss this fascinating museum. Make sure you allow enough time to visit the Hospital in the Rock when you are exploring the Castle Hill area. This underground hospital is under the Buda Castle and was a functioning hospital during World War II right up until 2002. During the cold war it also functioned as a nuclear shelter. There are excellent wax figures depicting doctors, nurses and patients in the wards, operating theaters, clinics and other rooms in this extraordinary hospital. You can only go in a group tour which takes about 50 minutes and leaves every hour. The commentary is good and older children loved it. As a former health professional I would have liked a private tour at a more leisurely pace, but I was happy to have seen this amazing hospital.

Great piece of history!!. This is definitely somewhere you should visit when in Budapest. Our english guide was very good and very informative and kept us all engaged. I took the local bus over the river to Buda and so i didn't have to walk up the steep hill to get unto to the castle area. The hospital is located behind the castle complex and is quite hard to find in my opinion. Although once you're on the the road 'Lovas Ut', the crowd of people surrounding a wall is the give away of its location.In any case, it's a wonderful bit of Hungary's history and well worth visiting. Was a working hospital that was used during the second world war, and also during Russia's occupation of Hungary during the revolution. Pretty self explanatory, its a hospital with a cave system. Lots of rooms, lots of wax figures to show what it would have been like and a nuclear bunker. Bring ID if you're a medical student/doctor/nurse/teacher as you will get discount on entry which is handy. I forgot my medical student ID because i didn't know but they still offered me the discount.Takes around an a hour for a complete visit.

Fabulous. Very very nice museum - you must go there because you cannot imagine how a hospital can work under the ground. The illustration is very real (yet not scary in any way) and the guides are very nice.We loved it and recommend with all hurt.
Amazing !!!. Would definitely visit this place when in Budapest. Our guide Milan was very informative but also witty and funny. So much history, amazing!

Great history. This is a very interesting place as it served many different purposes over the last 60-70 years. It was especially interesting being a nurse and seeing the unbelievable conditions that people once worked under. Make sure to bring a badge or some proof of your position to get a discount if you are doctor, nurse, or teacher. My husband, being a nuclear engineer, also enjoyed it as it once served as a nuclear bunker.

Don't miss this .... fab tour !!http://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/Attraction_Review-g274887-d2169533-Reviews-Hospital_In_The_. I just about made the last tour of the evening, the very kind girl on the desk let me jump on the end of the tour that was just starting to move off ..... this tour is packed with lots of historic reference and information and the 1km underground walk through the Buda Hill is just amazing .... its some much more than just a museum, our guide was very informative and knowledgeable and whilst the complete tour takes about 1 hour you find yourself not noticing the walking as you are soaking up all the information and folklore .... very enjoyable !

Well worth a visit. Budapest has had it's fair share of conflict and occupation, and The Hospital in The Rock has seen much of it. A really interesting afternoon visit, starting with an introductory video before taking a tour of the network of tunnels.Each part of the hospital has been recreated to show a different part of it's history, from the Second World War through to the Cold War.The tour guid was very helpful, and happy to take any questions and give extra insight into any areas of interest. Highly recommended to anyone who is interested in the history of the city.

Free for teachers!!. I like a bargain and getting in here for free was a bonus! had to prove I was a teacher so take some I.D (NUT card will do ). You are guided round in groups on the hour which is fine but as another group were behind us we didn't have time to really take in the information on the walls. A really interesting tour. Would recommend.
History lesson . We can't recommend doing this enough, so much history in this little hospital. The staff are some of the friendliest people in Hungary and give a brilliant tour of the caves.

One of the best attractions in the world. This was one of my favourite visits to a museum of all time, mainly because it didn't feel like a museum at all. The natural cave systems under the Castle Hill area in Buda were utilised to create a system of rooms and caverns that were converted into a First Aid post. This later became a small military hospital for use during the air raids of WWII, and was later briefly used during the rebellion of Budapest against the Soviets. During the Cold War, this labyrinth of caves was further converted to become a nuclear bunker, still to be used as a hospital, but with all of the appropriate equipment to treat people after a possible nuclear attack on the city.The hospital itself still contains much of the original equipment that would have been used down there, some dating back all the way to the 30s. Some highlights are things like xray machines from the 1950s, and operating tables that were actually used in the hospital. Each room is set up with wax figures to depict how equipment would have been used, who would have been using it and how many people there would have been down there. The sheer amount of equipment and things is incredible, and there is far more than you can see and take in during a 1 hour tour.The only way to see the museum is with a 1 hour guided tour, offered on the hour every hour during the opening times. Two tours leave within 5 minutes of each other, one in English and one in Hungarian. I took the 11am tour on a Sunday, and there were about 15 people in my group. Be sure to stick closely together, as the man following me was slow, and ended up not following me and the rest of the group around a corner, resulting in everyone behind me getting 'lost'. One American guy in the group was heard to exclaim "We're gonna be stuck in here forever!", and honestly, it is a labyrinth. It's also worth noting that this place is definitely not wheelchair friendly, as there are stairs in numerous places and narrow corridors. Because of this, please also consider how appropriate it is for you to visit an enclosed and sometimes small space - there is no 'fresh' air, only the air that the ventilation system pumps in once a day, and there are obviously no windows as you are deep underground. Anyone with issues of claustrophobia should probably not visit - I have never suffered fro claustrophobia but by the end of the tour even I was feeling a little uneasy.However, all safety considerations aside, this is an amazing attraction and should definitely be visited by anyone who comes to Budapest!

Fascinating history lesson. The tour starts with a short video that provides background info, then the tour guide leads you through several rooms of the secret underground military hospital. There are waxed figures with appropriate uniforms that take you back in time. Recommend taking the morning tour.

An Unusual Use of Extensive Buda Hills Cave System. There is a seven mile labyrinth if caves in the Buda Hills. One of the uses was building a hospital in these caves. This hospital was used extensively during the war. It was later cared for by a family who raised there 2 Hospitality desk in libby so it was quite easy to get any questions answered children in the abandoned hospital. It was only recently rediscovered and is now open for public tours. Try not to get in a group larger than 10 as it's difficult to hear the guide and see the rooms. I was on crutches so I just took a taxi up and back
A must-see. This museum is unique and really nice.All the exhibitions are well-preserved,the tour is really informative.They, also, show in the beginning a small film to prepare you for what you see.

Amazing look at medical history during wartime Hungary. This is an amazing place to visit. If you have any interest in wartime medical stories and the history of Budapest during the war this is a must see. The curator of this museum is to be praised for having an absolutely amazing collection of wax figurines life-size to replicate the hospital conditions that existed during the second world war and thereafter. Well worth the cost of admission and our tour guide was delightful.

Gave me a real sense of what it would have been like. What an experience. I work in the health industry so was really interested to visit. My partner doesn't work in health but he thoroughly enjoyed it too. Got a real sense of what it would have been like during WWII and revolution. Tour guide was full of knowledge. Loved the discount for health workers too

The Biggest Underground Shelter I Have Ever Seen. Fascinating history of a hospital shelter built to serve 60 patients that housed over 600 at its peek. It was used during WWII, the German era, communist period and the revolution in the 60s. It was refurbished as an A bomb shelter, but never was needed. Disc. with bus pass or over 62. Tour in English every hour and you get to spin the air raid siren at the end if you want to.
Fascinating story. The story of this hospital is moving and well-presented. Worth a few steps down from the Var-Castle District and a guided tour.
Well worth a visit.. Guided tours in English. Very good displays which made one appreciate what happened in the past .Parking nearby or a 5 minute walk from nearest bus stop.

The best site visited on the trip (apart from the spa!). Don't let the cost of the entry ticket put you off (~£10 for an adult/£5 for a concession, or if you are a medical worker, teacher or serving soldier/veteran). This is well worth the visit!English tours are conducted bang on the hour, and are a 10-15 minute walk from the Castle and Fishermans Bastion.The tour starts with a 10 minute video (subtitled in English). I've sat in on many short films in the past at museums but this is one of the few that was actually interesting and concise, giving an overview of how the hospital came about as well as an overview of Budapest during the world wars.After the video you will be taken on the tour which loops all the way around the hospital, moving from WWI/WW2 to the cold war era where it was transformed into a nuclear bunker.The guide was very knowledgeable and was willing to ask any questions, and the entire hospital remains kitted out with the original hospital machinery and cabinets, along with waxwork patients and medical staff to bring it to life.

Fascinating Expereince. This unusual museum experience is in the cave system under Buda Castle and English guided tours are on the hour. Its not the cheapest place to visit but it is worthwhile. The history covered basically spans its use as a secure hospital during the Second World War and its subsequent use also as a Soviet era nuclear shelter. The hospital rooms and wards have been recreated with original equipment and the place is populated by mannequins in period costume to illustrate the often desperate conditions.Our tour guide spoke superb English and bombarded you, in a nice way, with facts and figures; she even kept her composure when asked "when did they drop a nuclear bomb on Budapest"!?!All in all well worth a visit.
Worthwhile tour. Being so close to the hotel it was worthwhile, castle hill is a good place to visit and gave u very good insight into the significance of the hospital in WWII.

Very interesting. Great history lesson. The way the mannequins are set up really allows you to picture how the hospital was used. It wasn't too claustrophobic either. The only real drawback was their strict policy on no pictures. They will call you out in front of the whole group if you do take a picture.

Not cheap, but best view of castle labrinth and WW II history. There are several ways to see the cave labrinth structure under the Castle hill of the Buda area, but I think this is one of the best ones I recommend. There are few others including dracula themes ones, but that is a bit contrived and not as realistic as this one.This is viewed by tour only, English tour going on every hour and lasts little over an hour. There's a movie about Budapest and the war and the hospital. This was used as the bunker hospital for several occasions. You can see the various rooms (staged with was figures, but with real equipments of old) and learn the history. Just walk down the steps from the Buda Castle...

Unusual insight into WWII. You start and finish in the gift shop, the contents of which will have more meaning and interest once you’ve done the tour. The tour starts promptly with no waiting for you if you need to go to the loo beforehand – so be quick ! It’s fascinating to see the use that this labyrinth of caves, hewn into the hillside, were put to during the war. And you get an inkling of what it must have been like to have been based there. The hospital ward with the wall of silver medical kits looks more like an art installation.The thing that we found disconcerting, and hard to empathise with, is that the display mannequins are dressed as Nazis and the tour guide talks about them as the “good guys”. Now I realise Hungary had a different experience to many western European countries during WWII, with regard to the Communist forces, but it’s very perturbing to hear history from this point of view.That aside, the caves and their history are interesting and worth spending an hour in. If you carry on down the hillside when you come out you’ll find a couple of good restaurants and you can either get a bus back across the bridge to Pest or take the lift back up to the Castle & National Gallery.

Very Good and informative. It s a must visit place, the history has been well preserved specially that wheel chair from 1940. The tour guide is also very helpful. I even bought a 1940 original gas mask for 1500HUF, which is usually selling for 4000HUF just in central castle district. Usually one does not see original stuff in restored/preserved places, but it wasnt the case here as a lot of stuff was jenuienly antique.

Interesting. This museum it is situated under the Buda hill in the labyrinth's cave.If you are doctor (wihh valid ID card) you get 30 % discount.The visit is guided and at the beginning you see a movie about the place.It was hospital during the war (WW2) and bunker during communist era.It's decorated with wax statues representing injured soldiers (stained with blood), doctors, nurses, german and hungarian military officers.Besides there are medical devices and equipments of that time.During the visit you can hear sounds like bombardment and air raid.With little bit imagination you can feel the atmosphere of those time.Shooting is not allowed.

Hospital in the Rock. Excellent tour guide who really new her "stuff". No questions unanswered. Well maintained, more than just a museum, and the advantage of having life like wax works made the atmosphere very realistic. Also a pleasant change to see some of the behind scenes, with the boiler room, switch board area and the war rooms. Money well spent to know what was and is happening to allow the general public to carry on with a normal life.

Unique. What an experience! I would recommend this to everyone that visits Budapest, very interesting whether you work in the medical industry or not. You walk around the museum with a tour guide who explains the functional change of the bunker and the history of Budapest during the WW2. I would have liked the tour to be slower as I wanted to take everything in and really appreciate it.

Great Tour. I'm really glad we chose to see this museum, its unique and extremely interesting experience. The tour runs every hour and lasts about 50 minutes. Our fantastic tour guide was Dea - she was very clear and engaging, she was also very knowledgeable and welcomed questions. I would definitely recommend to anyone interested in WW2 - Cold war history.

Incredible experience. We stumbled upon the unimposing entrance while walking around Buda. Had no idea what it was or what to expect. We joined the next guided tour into caverns going deep into the mountain with a guide who spoke excellent english. Originally used by Hungarian patriots defending their country, it was taken over by the Nazis during WW2 and then by the Russians in the 1950'sAreas of the caves are furnished as they were during each occupation showing the use of each section complete with wax mannequins dressed in period uniforms. They claim to be the largest wax museum in the world. It is cold in these caves, bring a jacket

Hidden Gem. A must if you're in the buda hill area! A guided tour runs every hour, so try to time it so you're not waiting too long for it to start. The cave systems are a bit colder, and while they do offer coats to wear on the tour, best to bring an extra sweater. This was one of the most memorable sites we visited because of how unique it was, and the history behind it. Our tour guide was very through in explaining all the different rooms, and the historic significance. Many of the rooms were set up as they had been during the war, with fake blood, wax mannequins, and even original furniture.

Great experience. When visiting this attraction, you should be aware that it's a conducted tour which goes every hour. We had to wait 20 minutes or so, but there are a few benches outside so it's not a problem. The tour itself is very interesting, showing the conditions that this hospital operated under during and after the war. The only minor criticism is that it would have been nice to spend a little more time viewing the exhibits etc., but you really need a guide to explain it all, so time was of the essence.

almost missed this one!. i was about to miss/skip this one, but decided to go anyway. some may find it boring, but I found the tunnel system interesting. the place is well made and the tour guide spoke great english. recommended!

Unique site and experience. I am admittedly a public health nerd, so the idea of seeing a hospital built in an underground series of caves had immediate appeal. The place is really well done and contains tons of old medical equipment and machinery. Photos show that the wards appear almost as they were and the place really does have a fascinating history. For me, the wax figures added an unnecessary element of cheesiness. The place has a cool enough history and enough original artifacts to stand on it's own without the figures, but I guess it may add something for other visitors. Otherwise this is a completely unique site and an experience I highly recommend.
Feels very authentic . Nice display of machines, wax dummies and medical instruments. Guided tour of 1 hour. About 15 $ entrance.

Amazing place and a must visit. You have to take the time to visit this place if you are in the area. It's an amazing place and the tours are excellent. Our guide was Tina and she was both funny and very informative. She had me moved to tears at one point. I have such admiration for the Hungarian people for what they have been through and still trying to build lives for themselves. This is a first class museum. We will go back again and again.

Great hideaway. Really interesting place to visit, fantastic history and amazing tunnels and facilities built into the rock. Superb guide who really brought the whole tour to life. Be sure to take your student, emergency work id etc etc for a great 30% discount!
historic lesson. worth a look just to learn a little history of a hidden hospital around the times of the world wars and also to get a realistic view of what went on

Great piece of history. I'll admit it, I was hesitant to spend time and money on this one, but it turned out to be an interesting place that provided me a lot of background history on Hungary. I was wandering around wasting time when I stumbled upon it, and the only reason I decided to do it was because of the reviews here on Tripadvisor. That said, I have to contribute myself! The only way to see this place is by guided tour, which in this case is absolutely worth it. Without the knowledgable staff I would have been clueless. Definitely give it a try! Good for families, as well!

Great tour!!. This was a great tour, very informative and the tour guide spoke great English.
The museum has been well laid out and preserved and gives a great insight into war history as well,

Was ok but slightly overpriced. It was about 13CAD for an hour guided tour that was mandatory. Found it interesting but went a bit too quick and not enough time to look around and see all the different old medical equipment. Maybe go I you have more than a few days in budapest.

Very interesting and informative. Guided tour of Hospital in the Rock was great, our guide was very informative about the whole site, spoke great English and most importantly was passionate about the place. Hospital built into the natural cave system under Buda Castle during WWII served as a place of sanctuary, safety, air raid defence operations, military planning centre and a hospital where they treated everyone regardless of who they fought for. After WWII ended under the Soviet occupation it was turned into a secret nuclear bunker in case of a nuclear attack on Budapest.Must visit of anyone interested in History! Well worth the very reasonable entrance fee.

A Fascinating Glimpse into The Past.. What an interesting and informative tour. We found the stories of how patients were treated in this unique hospital ( built in passages beneath the rocks of Castle Hill) during World War 2 and the Hungarian Uprising quite fascinating. The guide was excellent and brought to life the horrors of this period as she led us through the hospital assessment areas, wards and operating theatre all now staffed by very realistic wax works. She made us appreciate the bravery and dedication of those who served with such courage in the most difficult of circumstances. It was also interesting to see how preparations had been made for nuclear attack. I highly recommend this visit.

Interesting.... Interesting look at a hospital that functioned in tunnels underneath Castle Hill during World War II and during the 1950s (and which was later converted into a fallout shelter). Actual equipment used by the hospital still in many of the rooms. Wax figures give an idea of how the space was used (but aren’t always entirely lifelike). 3600 HUF per person ($16 / 12 Euro), for a 1-hour tour (with discounts available with tickets from Matthias Church or from some tour bus operators in the city).

Great Place. Fantastic little place, huge under ground hospital actually used during WW2 and the revolution. Very interesting and knowledgeable guide on the tour. This is well worth the money. Can be reached by using bus 16/16a from Széll Kálmán tér or Deák Ferenc tér getting off at café viro mar at Szentháromság tér. Its a short walk from there
We'll worth a visit.. It was a very interesting place. Our guide had very good English and was very interesting. The figures were very lifelike. Would recommend it.

such a special place. I recommend to visit this place for everybody. The guided tour was so interesting, I just wished it would have lasted at least a bit longer than one hour because I would like to have a bit more time to watch everything and feel the atmosphere which is really special.

Interesting tour. The English tours go on the hour, every hour. If you have a Budapest card you get 30% off entry. Some of the wax figures are a bit macabre but our guide spoke excellent English and was very informative.

Most interesting. Amazing what could be done by rebuilding natural caves. It clearly shows the evolution from ancient history through World War 1 and 2, via the Communist period into present times (end of the 80ties
Little scary. I'm glad I did not have to stay there during the war. Under the ground, no windows, no fresh air... It is scary!
intersting and informative. Unique experience not to be missed if in Budapest. Gives a good insight into World war II and Soviet Hungary.

All nurses should see this. You will never moan about your working conditions again once you have seen this hospital! It was so interesting I could have spent longer wandering around just taking everything in. Our guide was very well informed and gave us a good overview of the history and workings of the hospital. It was worth buying the small booklet which helps to fill in any details of the story. The tours in English are on the hour and they are keen to give you a discounted entry fee for just about any reason so bring ID with you if you are any kind of professional.

Interesting. This was a cool place to visit - worth it just to hike up to the Castle District and see the beautiful area! I got a student discount and enjoyed the tour. The only way to see the inside of the museum is by taking a guided tour. Definitely recommend it for anyone interested in WWII, Budapest's more recent history, or quirky history.

Excellent little trip. Being a Doctor obviously I went to the hospital in the rock! It was great, really enjoyed it.English tour guide, takes you around the hospital and there are lots of things to look at. Lots of interesting facts about the hospital and the war which it operated during. There are lots of original artifacts to see, medical equiptment, drug bottles, even a full operating theatre!There is even discounted tickets for Doctors, Nurses, Red cross workers etc!! Lovely surprise, so bring your ID badge with you =)Would recommend to anyone who is interested in war time/ medicine. Fascinating place!

Great attraction. At my partners insistence we visited Hospital in the Rock during our day in the Castle district. I’m glad I gave in to her on this occasion because it’s a site definitely worth visiting. The tour guide spoke very good English and explained the exhibits and their significance well. Recommended if you are interested in city history and/or WW2 history.
Really interesting. Thought this might not be worth the money but it was really interesting, deep under the ground so quite cool, but fascinating bit of history

Definitely worth the visit!!. This place is definitely worth a visit. The staff at the desk were great and seemed to try their hardest to find a way to give us discounted tickets which we were able to have with our Budapest cards. The tour itself lasts about an hour and you see the operating rooms, the wards and the nuclear bunker. The guide was good and explained the history and purpose very well, however, there were a lot of pictures and information on the walls but we were moved along too quickly to view them properly. Our group size was a bit too large as well but the guide did her best to keep everyone together.It is a lot more informative than you would expect and although the wax work models are really outdated they do help you to imagine what it was really like during the time it was used.
Quality.. Thanks!Very interesting and really nice people telling history. Nice experience.Well recommended!Manu

Not to be missed!. We arrived there around 30 min before the scheduled tour in English and I was happily surprised to find out that I could get in for free with my International Teacher's Identity Card (ITIC)!! The tour starts with a documentary that gives you an idea of the history of the place. What you see is the hospital inside the rocks with all the tools that were used back then, plus a few scenes made with wax statues. The tour guide was very informative and explained also all about air system. Too bad we couldn't take photos but they take one of the touring group and post in their website so you can download it later. I loved it and would go back again if I went to Budapest again :)

Amazing. My girlfriend and I had an amazing time here, such a great exhibition! It was so much more interesting than we expected. Also, the staff was really nice and seemed to enjoy their job. I would definitely recommend visiting.

Interesting but only on a tour. I really like the sound of this attraction as something a little different. But was surprised to find you could only go on scheduled tours (none of that information is on any of the literature).The tour is interesting but you really don't get a chance to really see anything or read any of the literature on the walls. Dependent on the size of the group you really might not get to see anything.It's a real shame because I'm 100% certain this would be easily achievable by headset audio like so many other attractions across the globe. I know it's underground tunnels but it's easily navigable. Expensive for the time you actually get to spend looking at rooms.
Great. Very interesting place, great guides and well worth the visit. They offer discounts for under 26s and students so its worth taking ID.
Glimpse of history. Very interesting topic and a glimpse of cold war history. Strange to learn that even a few years ago it was still a top secret location.

Very Informative. A very interesting tour about the history of the hospital. We were unfortunate to have a tour with a group of French school children who spent their time giggling and messing around. Other than that no complaints at all - cheap, enlightening and you can even buy a gas mask afterwards!
Excelant. A place you must visit when in Budapest ,you will be sorry you missed it as we went back because we missed it first time there,a well worth while trip for all.

Great find!. This is a really interesting tourist attraction and of great historical importance. The most amazing thing about it is that it isn't huge and yet it is astounding to think that surgery, treatment, xrays etc were all carried out here. The actual equipment is all original and there's even an anaesthetic machine that had a starring role in 'Evita' alongside Madonna. If you work in a hospital , take some proof with you and you will qualify for a discount. You can't take photos inside but they will take your picture which you can print off from their website a couple of days later, totally free of charge Incredible value for money overall and the staff are lovely.
Sunday afternoon. Having lived in Budapest now for four years this has been on our 'to do' list. We were not disappointed! Very interesting exhibits and a guide that made it 'personal'.

Bygone history. If you visit the Buda Castle District the cavings are a good museum kind of experience. It is very interesting that how could be saved this institution for many years. You find a complete hospital under the hill, with all the original equipment which are all functional. During the II. War the wounded people got here, in to a realistic safety, and got the chance to survive. Of course this wasn’t an easy trip. You can see the lots of beds in a very narrow place, and you can see the operating room, and even the boiler house, and the whole system.It is a trip to the past, and you can feel the atmosphere of the war situationOf course this is an excellent experience if you do not have nothing to do with it, if your never had a real experience here, or any situations like that what this institution is presenting.

Hidden historical treasure. No guide was pointing this one out, but once again it was worth to go through list of attractions on TripAdvisor rather than sticking only to even great paper guides. Despite some signs pointing it out, it took some effort to find the place. After coming down (from Matthias Church and Fisherman's Bastion area) close to toilets, make sure you just keep going towards bars (barriers) and you will find it soon on the right.
