This place connects some dark history of Budapest from war times (hospital) and communist times (nuclear bunker) with quite entertaining content. The rooms are nicely packed with figures and equipment to give you the idea how things looked there once. The guide is informative and interesting, but somehow, like others mentioned in previous revies, seems a bit rushed like everything had to be packed in that one hour tour. I don't like too much talking either but extra 15 minutes or so wouldn't do much harm. The real shame and disappointment though is for not being able to make pictures. Why is it such a big deal? Anyway, strongly recommending this one to everyone. Surely not to be missed!

Great little find. This was a great tour around the Hospital. Our guide was very informative and explained everything really well. No photos are aloud to be taken in the rock however they do do a group photo at the end of the tour for you to download off their website.

Rushed. If you are a teacher or nurse then take your pass as you get a discount. We paid full price, which was rather dear and the tour felt rushed. The guide was good, very informative. A little to much focus on the heating systems and ventilation and not enough time to look at the fascinating displays.

Great Place To Visit!. I liked the link to the most recent history of Budapest, which was well explained during the guided tour. The hospital is very unique and is another must-see attraction in Budapest for anybody with an interest in anything that happened after 1939.

Caves. Worth a visit. Very well done and quite spooky at times. Would have liked a little more history on when it was used as a hospital and then a secret bunker but what was there was interesting especially the Dracula story

Very interesting. This place is a little gem, however the tour which lasts an hour is far, far, too speedy. You don't get time to breath let alone savour all it has to offer. The hospital areas are historically, very interesting and as a nurse I was particularly keen in seeing the hospital rooms and experiencing the atmosphere, but alas, no time to absorb or read the information that is provided. I was not that interested in the mechanics of how the hospital operated, i.e. Ventilation shafts etc. The guide was very knowledgeable and knew his stuff. The tour needs to be longer and less hurried. If you are a nurse or doctor you get reduced entry. So take your ID with you if you intend to visit this historical hospital museum.

Eerie trip back in time. You are given a speedy tour of the facility with English and Hungarian guides. I say speedy but it was probably an hour long - which is not enough time to read all the information on the walls.This underground cave network was transformed into a WWII hospital and then into a cold-war bunker. There are many waxwork models carefully placed to set the scene for you. The guide was very good and involved the small group in the discussion about what went on.I felt it well worth the time and money - but note that the tours leave on the hour so time your arrival carefully so you are not hanging around in the entrance.

Looked interesting, but you are rushed through and don't get chance to look at everything. My partner and I visited this museum and were told that tours are every hour on the hour. As it was 5 minutes to 4, we bought tickets for the 4pm tour which was in English. Once we had paid, we were told that the tour started with a 10 minute video, but the room was full so we would have to wait and watch it at the end. We were told someone would get us when the tour started...After 10 minutes, a woman who I think was the manager came over and asked us whether we were booked on the tour; when we said yes she said "my colleague must have forgotten to get you"...it turned out they had started the tour without us. She rushed us down the corridor past the first 3 rooms with a very brief description (no time to look inside) and we were told to make sure we stayed with the group. We were at the end of the tour group, which meant we couldn't hear what the tour guide was saying because the Hungarian tour was taking place 2 paces behind us and we couldn't make out the English over the Hungarian. After about 10 minutes the 2 groups split so we could at least hear what was being said. This museum has a lot to show and there are information boards throughout the corridors and rooms. However, you are not given chance to look at everything on show because they are under time constraints to get everyone through the tour in an hour. The information I did get was very interesting, I just wish we had been given more time to look at everything!At the end, I explained to the tour guide that we had missed the video so she sat us in with the next group. The video room is relatively small with a number of chairs set out. The video is in Hungarian with English subtitles which are very low down so unless you are on the front row they are near-impossible to read. I was really disappointed with this museum as I had read such great reviews. I didn't think it was worth the money (and we even got a discount for being EU citizens under 26) - there are much better museums in Budapest.

Do it.. Firstly, don't be shy about asking for a discount on the ticket. If you are military medical police coastguard etc you will be offered a discount. If not. ..ask. I was more surprised with the history of the events of the hospital are really interesting. The tour is one hour long and in English. Worth a visit.

Must see. This was a difficult place to find but worth it. The tour guide was very informative and you got a sense of what people in Budapest went through during the German and then Russian occupations. Tours leave on the hour and last about an hour. This place was first a storage space, then an emergency hospital in WWII, then a German military base and finally a Soviet nuclear bunker. Fascinating history!

Incredible and thought provoking!. This hospital is based in the old town on castle hill and should definitely be included on every sightseer's list! There are organised tours which leave on the hour and are very well structured, it costs around 10 euro per person. The tours are incredibly relaxed and informative and it was great to learn about the history of the city and conflicts. The hospitals history is quite remarkable and is a true testament to the strength of the human spirit. You will leave with a better understanding of Budapest, as well as feeling uplifted and humbled.

excellent venue for history, culture, science, medicine. It was a little bit hard to find the entrance, so you may want to take a good look at a map, and keep an eye on the signs. The building is facinating.There is a small gift shop which sells items which were stocked in the hosptial/bunker years ago. These are very reasonably priced and somewhat unusual (eg bags, gas masks, canvas stretcher).The tour guides have a lively spirit about them, and spoke very enthusiastically.The guided tours are hourly, so if you find you have just missed a tour just walk up to the castle area and wonder around the streets or pop into one of the lovely coffee shops.It is a bit chilly in the building, so if you think you will be cold they will loan you a fleece. These all looked smart and clean - but I did not need one.I think some people might worry that it would be claustrophobic, but I did not feel this way at all. The rooms are well lit, and well ventilated, and of reasonable size. I guess you could look at some photos to guage your own personal view.
An absolut must when visting Budapest!. Despite the expensive ticket you must visit the hospital! It is something you cannot miss during your visit there since it has a lot of history in it.

Fascinating. Absolutely fascinating, a great guided tour and very very interesting to see inside and imagine what was happening in the times it was actually in use as a hospital.Tours leave on the hour, so you're in for a wait if you arrive here at 10 past! Try and time your arrival about quarter to the hour.You can really imagine what would have been going on with the wax models and guide taking you round and telling stories, you come out just chatting and imagining what it would have been like having to be there in a different life.I'm not much a museum fan, but this definitely isn't just a museum.At times (especially when you go to the machinery rooms and see all the air filters, pumps, etc) it can get a little claustrophobic. But it only lasts around 10 minutes in this deepest part of the exhibition.

This is one attraction you must visit. The Hospital in the rock is one of the most interesting museums I have been in and the staff are exceptionally helpful. We all had a book of vouchers from the sightseeing tour of the city and staff at the Hospital went out of their way to ask if we had them so we received 30% discount on our entrance fee.Annie the guide is very friendly, helpful and down to earth. Even though she tours the Hospital several times a day she makes each tour special and it really is an amazing story of how people lived in WW2. The hospital is very unusual as all the equipment and medicine is original from WW2 and later the Cold War of the 50's when it became a Nuclear bunker. We all felt that this museum really made our visit special and thoroughly recommend it.
Spooky wax-figures. The Hospital in the Rock was very interesting and exciting. The only thing which creeped me out were the wax figures which are already quite old and look spooky. :)

OK tour - quite expansive.... We had a tour at the Hospital in the Rock.The guide was ok. Nothing special. The story is interesting but somehow I didn't "feel" it.The entrance fee is quite high, although it seems that the maintenance is quite expensive.
interesting place. I liked it! Feeling the atmosphere of the cold war, real old medical equipment, good guide, enjoyable stories. It is almost a must. Just get warm clothing, it is cold down there.

Great tour guide! . A fascinating museum which still looks the same as when it was in use. Provides an insight into the siege of budapest which was interesting. Our tour guide was superb - very funny and his sheer enthusiasm for what he was describing was impressive!

was okay.... good for a little history lesson... weird mannequins and some hospital beds. basically a story of how people were stuck in the hospital while budapest was being attacked, but how it also saved a ton of lives. entrance was a little hard for us to find... just a weird place overall.

Really fascinating place - would definately recommend it. It was very informative and the guide was excellent.He gave us lots of information about the life of ordinary people both during WW2 and the Cold War.Wish it had been longer than the 1 hour.The staff very very good and we even got discount on our entrance tickets due to concessions that we weren't aware of.Would definately recommend it

Very Interesting. Everything there is original and in the same position as it was when first made so it felt like entering into a time capsule!
Entry price was fair, we got a little discount as one of our party is a nurse!

well worth a visit if in Budapest. We came across this place by accident seeing it advertised near our hotel and decided to go on the tour. It takes about an hour but it was really facinating and informative. The one slight downside was that photography was not permitted. Definately worth seeing though!

Really interesting and enjoyable. Perhaps a slightly biased review working for the NHS and being a bit of geek of cold war stuff but really interesting and enjoyable attraction. Fascinating to see what happened through WW2 and also the cold war

Very interesting. We arrived some time before the tour, and were offered a place to sit and a hot drink. The tour itself interesting, but it felt like we were jumping from one place to another quickly. The end of the tour also takes you to scenes not related to the hospital, and it's not clear why they're there...The best part is actually the museum shop, where actual antiques from the hospital can be purchased for a very low price.

Amazing guide. Our guide Ester was amazing!! She speak slowly and clear so you can understand everything!! After the tour she recomended some hungarian restaurants and she draw a map for us!!well done ester!

Interesting but felt a little rushed.. The only way to look around this museum is by guided tour, tours begin at the top of the hour. We arrived at 5 to the hour, which was lucky. Would've been annoyed to arrive 10 mins later and need to wait 55mins! Can see why the tour is guided though, there would be too much to take in self-guided. We were lucky that there were only 3 of us on the english-speaking tour so it felt very personal. Guide friendly, good English, and knowledgeable.

different and interesting. you cant go walk around alone, it has to be a guided tour but it is interesting. The tour takes 1 hour. A great insight into times gone by and a stark reminder of what 'could have been'. Definitely worth a visit and only 5 minutes walk from the castle district main area.

Informative place to visit. For obvious reasons you can't just wander around and have to go with a guide. The experience is probably better for the guide because they explain the uses of the hospital over time. It is incredible to think about the scale of the underground caves. A bit disappointing you can't take pictures.

Well-organised. Their website is in English and gives clear and easy to follow instructions. Straightforward, no-fuss, you get in there just before the hour (tours run every hour on the hour). Our guide for the day 08JAN2014 was Eszter and she spoke perfect English and was most enthusiastic in her narratives. The tour started with a short film that gives a brief history of the bunker and continues with a guided walk through the maze of the bunker. This tour gives one a sense of the hardship and adversity that Hungarians experienced during World War II and the Revolution of '56. Excellent work in keeping the bunker in good condition; worth the entrance fee. Highly recommended!

Just what the doctor ordered! . Having been begrudgingly brought here by my historian girlfriend, I was pleasantly surprised to discover a truly fascinating and engaging museum. The staff were friendly and enthusiastic and the generous discounts were a definite bonus. The signage could do with some improvement (the museum is down some steps just below the Castle Hill walls), and tours run once an hour on the hour which is worth remembering as there's more than enough to take up your time within Castle Hill. The guided tour through the cave hospital complex is very informative; combining medical and military history to provide an unusual insight into Budapest's past. The exhibit content ranges from the 1930s to the Cold War and is well explained by the friendly guides. The atmosphere and conditions of the hospital throughout its history is brought to life not only through the colourful descriptions of the tour guide but the abundance of original material and the quirky wax figures used to occasionally unsettling effect to recreate scenes of hospital life. Following the tour the gift shop had a remarkable range of original military artefacts. I was delighted to pick up an authentic 1960s gas mask for only 1000FT - far superior to the usual pen or key ring offered in most museum gift shops! I would thoroughly recommend this museum to any visitors to the Castle Hill District.
The Hospital in the Rock. Young boys and girls that show you a real hospital under the Castle hill, used during second world war.

A must do tour. The Hospital in the Rock together wih the Cold War nuclear bunker made for a fascinating visit.
Our guide was firstly, interesting to listen to and secondly had a thorough knowledge of the history and the associated stories of the hospital and bunker. The other staff present clearly were equally as motivated. Thank you.

Touch Macabre - don't take little kids. A treat for history buffs - Eastern European history & WW2 & Cold War makes for a potentially really interesting exhibit but it falls short IMO when it comes to detail and social history. What you get here is a time capsule style preservation tour with wax work dolls of how the hospital has been used over the past 70 or so years, however, it does lack narrative and sometimes context for the hospitals place in the story of the city and its place in Budapest's history. I'd have liked more in-depth information on the rooms and exhibits on display, instead you are hurried by with little or no info about the exhibits and prohibited from taking photographs.There were quite a few young children on the tours (primary school) who were complaining of being frightened and clinging to their parents in the caves, the mashed up faces of the waxworks dolls would be enough to scare most kids forget the content, asking the children to wind up nuclear war sirens and let them blast out was also quite cringey. I wouldn't recommend taking your young children here.This real, once working exhibit could be awesome but the thin content and rushed tour let it down, it has the potential to be the best recent history tour in Budapest... but needs a rethink.

You'll get goosebumps in this place.. Well worth finding and visiting. Offers a peek into WWII. You really will feel like you are re-living history. This place is very well maintained, and a lot of great recreations. Our guide was extremely knowelagable, and spoke great English. I had goosebumps, just imagining what all was happening here during WWII. There is a short video in the begining, free bathroom, and souvenirs.

Great Cold War Nuclear Bunker Tour. Fascinating tour in the underground of Budapest in this WWII hospital bunker. The tour staff was great and did a really good job ....definitely a must see while in Budapest
Worthwhile. When visiting Budapest you must visit the hospital in the rock. The guide spoke perfect english and gave a good explanation on life in the hospital during the war.

A surprisingly interesting visit. A surprisingly interesting visit. The entire facility has been restored to its original condition with exhibitions of the conditions in the hospital during the Second World War and the Hungarian Uprise. All is illustrated with several life like wax figures to make it more real, but they can be a bit bloody for the faint hearted. A minor point is that the size of the group was rather big. The guide did her utmost to be audible for the entire group. Still the visit was really nice and it was definitely worth it.

Very informative - had a great time. This came up in my husband and my top 3 things to do in Budapest after our week long stay (we are early 30's)The hospital on the rock operates on a guided tour basis only. At our time slot they ran two tours - one in hungarian and one in English. Tour goes for an hour and costs 3600huf for an adult. One of the more expensive entrance fees but well worth it. Our tour guide was great, very informative, a bit humorous and spoke on some of the less commonly discussed facts from Hungarys history. His English was good - there were alot of medical and nuclear instruments in the bunker and he took the time to learn the English names for them which we thought was stellarUnderneath the rock itself is a bit of a time warp, the life size dolls are realistically depicting what it was like down there whilst the hospital was in use, there's stacks of old equipment to look at - medical, nuclear and historical war time.. plus I just find the whole building structure and the way it was designed very interesting :) plus, there's the opportunity to wind up one of cthe old bomb sirens at the end - as you can imagine loud but couldn't resist! very well worth it and highly recommended.

very authentic history of Budapest at war. not for faint nerves - displays are very authentic with beds, patients/puppets with colored/bloody dressings, old medical instruments. It must have been horrible then. The guides are great and show you everything. We had a Hungarian guide but the stuff is self-expanatory. You will be happy to live in good health.

Once you find it, it was surprisingly fun. The signage to get to the entrance needs some work. Once inside, you can see the dedication and energy of all of the staff. There are multiple levels of discounts (senior, military, teaching, health professional) that make the 1 hour tour very affordable. I don't think there was another tour, except for that of the Jewish sector, that gives you a true feeling about what WWII in Hungary was all about. Like the Holocaust Memorial, I am glad they are keeping this reminder alive in history.The tour itself is fascinating. As a health care provider, I saw first hand great work having been done in less than optimal conditions. They have every right to be proud of this facility and the work that was done there

Well worth a visit.. We had a guided tour of the hospital that lasted an hour and we didn't see the hour passing. The tour guided you through the facility and history of Budapest. The wax figures were very cleverly arranged to help you to understand what it was like during the winter of '45.Some of our party were retired health care professionals and they could vouch for some of the medical exhibits as they were fading from use when they were carrying out their training all them years ago.

Nice Surprise. I wasn't expecting much, and was very well pleased. The tour is a little bit long, but they work with guided tours, which really helps to understand the place and all of its history. You get to go inside this hospital/bunker and I even got to manage a manual air raid sirene. Suggest taking a whole day to wonder the castle hill area and find some time to go here. Find out the time of the guided tours so you wont waste your time.
Worth seeing. This tour provides a look back in time to conditions during WWII and the Cold War. More appropriate for older teens and adults.
Interesting visit. This was a fun and interesting tour to do while visiting the castle area of Budapest. It only takes a little more than an hour and is educational.

A reminder of the long difficult past of Budapest. Located in an extended underground area beneath the Castle District in Budapest, Hospital in the Rock is the site of a large medical facility that was used by a number of different groups during the more recent past in Budapest's often difficult history. The exhibits are well done, and the area is that which was actually utilized. Guides take the visitors through the corridors and one gets a feeling as to what is was like to be a patient or a medical worker during the war or a civil servant preparing for a possible nuclear attack and ready to test radiation levels on the surface above. This relatively small attraction is not to be missed.

Could be made more engaging. Tours are required and the groups can be large enough that it's difficult to hear the guide and we were rushed through the displays to the point that I lost interest. Hubby loved it. Fascinating place made less interesting by the touring format.

Very Cool!. Very interesting tour through the cave complex and lot's of information from the guide. We were running late for the English Language tour but they accommodated by letting us join the tour right after the introductory film and let us see it on the way out. A unique place that warrants a visit if you have the time. Not sure I'd put this at the top of the list though as places like the Parliament House, the Opera, St. Istvan's and St. Michaels Church probably are more in the must-see category.

Well worth a visit. An immersive step back in time, the Hospital in the Rock covers the lifetime of the institution, from the 1940s to the Cold War and beyond. It does its best to give a representative view of the time, and successfully conveys the good intentions of the designers and the horrifying conditions during the war in equal measure. The only, slight disappointment was that access is only by guided tour and that no photos are allowed, but this doesn't diminish the fact that this is worth a look for anyone in the castle district.

Hospital In The Rock - Budapest, Hungary. This museum provides a glimpse of a snapshot in time. Back to the 1950's. The tour includes quite an old video (not the best) with an overview of what was happening at that time. The guide was very good. I don't like caves but I didn't have a problemm inside as it was open enough for me....quite amazing how the hospital operated at the time....lots of medical instruments and other items....the wax figures help tell the story....a little depressing but it is history and "is what it is" or was. Tours take place on the hour. This museum is for people who appreciate history...not a beauty pageant in there.

Really interesting; a step back in time. A short video gives an overview of the history of Budapest and the Hospital in the Rock. The way the museum has been created is a good way to understand how everything worked back in the older times, but it's a bit surreal with the models but it being so quiet. The tour guide gave a good history of the hospital too. Worth a visit.

Underground tour. I had heard of this hospital and was thrilled to get to visit it. It is all underground and it was a little musty. It was neat to see the recreated scenes from WWII when the area was a functioning hospital. The wax dummies are a little off putting, not quite up to par. The information presented by the guide was great and she was able to answer any questions. You can even buy leftover soviet supplies in the gift shop.

Worth a visit!. My boyfriend and I really enjoyed this museum and found it very interesting. It was so unique and we enjoyed being in a place with so much history. The guide Gerda was excellent and gave time to ask questions and was very knowledgable. Really glad we went. Tours are once every hour, discounts for under 26 and over 62(i think) so take Id.

Hospital in the Rock. a first-hand view of a functioning hospital during WWII and the 1957 Uprising -- built into a cave - in the hills of Buda. Very informed and informative guide. Definitely worth seeing.
Good experience. Well worth a visit. The staff made it come alive and it was great to see the old operating instruments etc. Probably the memorial I enjoyed the most from all are visits

Interesting museum. The Hospital in the Rock is worth a visit. The site in its natural form is interesting to learn about. Information about the hospital & bunker just adds to an already intriguing experience. Pity we weren't allowed to take photos :(

Good museum with a great guided tour. I am not usually someone who is fond of museums and history and the like, but my boyfriend and I visited the Hospital in the Rock and I was very surprised at how interesting even I found it! Our guide was very knowledgeable about the Hospital and gave us a great tour around the site whilst answering all of our questions. Would definitely recommend a visit if you are in the Buda side of the city.

So interesting, but felt very rushed.. This museum provides a real insight, it is very atmospheric but we felt that due to the speed of our tour that we didn't really get the opportunity to fully experience this excellent museum. Including the introductory film at the start, the whole tour was completed in 50 minutes. We were told that the tour took 1 hour 20 minutes, so we were quite disappointed that it ended so quickly as we were really enjoying it.

Interesting history spot. I'm so glad we made time for this history gem. We were on time for the English language tour. It was fascinating to learn about this time in Budapest's recent past. I felt like I was walking through a 1940s hospital and would suddenly realize, "I haven't seen a window," then remembering all this was safely tucked underground. It's also interesting to learn about the atomic bomb age from a European perspective. The tour is very thorough and takes awhile and you should be aware there's no place to sit after the orientation film.

Why is war a bad thing?. I think this museum convinced me better than anything else why it is totally stupid to make war (and not love haha). All the horrors of the 2nd world war, the tears of the revolution of 56, the threat of the cold war - they are all here, in these walls. AND this place was not known by the public until 2002! (Pay attention to how they filled the 800 litres oil tanks in secret - if they forget to explain, ask! That will explain you the mechanism of the socialism!)(OK, I am Hungarian, so for me it is slightly different, but try to feel it!)

Very good and interesting tour. Tour starts with a short video about the history of the hospital and nuclear bunker, this is Hungarian with English subtitles. You are then taken on a guided tour with wax work models of the people that worked within the tunnels: doctors nurses, Nazi officers and also current Hungarian soldiers in Afghanistan. The tour guide is very knowledgable and discusses the various uses of the bunker over the years and also the challenges the hospital faced especially during the siege of Budapest.You get a discount with the Budapest Card here. You are not allowed to take photographs of the exhibition but a group photo is taken by the tour guide at the end. Very good and interesting tour.

Brilliant exhibition. The hospital in the caves is a must. You are taken round by enthusiastic guides, this hospital, laid out as it had been with wonderful manikins, original medical equipment, shows the extreme traumatic times the Hungarian people have been through. If you work in health services the entrance is free, go it's amazing!
A must visit!. Really interesting place to visit. The staff were very helpful and the tour guide spoke extremely good English. The displays and information provided by the guide were fascinating.

Hokey but unique. Be sure to ask about the couple who supervised this cold war secret hospital, which was never used after WW2. The Nazis used it, and it is set up with wax figures and props to be a unique visit for families with kids. Watch your head, the tunnel ceilings are low.

AN EXPENSIVE AND RUSHED TOUR. This attraction gives an account of 20th century Hungarian history from a different perspective: firstly, showing a secret hospital created in the cave tunnels in preparation for the Second World War and subsequently used during the Soviet occupation - being converted to a nuclear bunker.However, the visit comes with a very hefty pricetag (3600 HUF) and involves a one-hour guided tour (which is compulsory). This was too rushed and allowed no time to study the wall displays

Enthusiastic guide + great educational experience. One of our more educational activities during our time in Budapest. Our guide showed us around an underground cave network that was used as a hospital during the Soviet and Nazi occupation period. She also talked about the history of the city which was very interesting and at times emotional. Definitely worth a visit! The entrance fee is halved if you are under 26.

Such History. Great little tour of the cave system under castle hill, used for a hospital, and nuclear bunker etc. Now an attraction.The guide we had was slightly pushy but took us round and was very knowledgeable and spoke great english.Very interesting History. If you like your war history, this is a place to take a look!

Cool, hospital and nuclear bunker all-in-one. This was a cool place to visit, during the war it served as a hospital and during the war they added a nuclear bunker. You have to get a guided tour trough this place as a requirement, then again its great to hear about how all the rooms were used and the harsh conditions the hospital had to endure during war time. A great extra is to see how they implemented the nuclear bunker and how it should have been used. Fun tour, although sometimes the guide was a bit hastily and cheap if ur under 26.

Interesting version of a historic hospital. Hospital in the rock was again a gem we heard of through tripadvisor so thanks again. HITR is down the hill not far from the royal palace [take some steep steps down, signage indicates it if you search for a bit]. Tours run on the hour during business hours & it was really interesting, starting from the entrance which used to be a route for ambulances, they show a short video on it’s uses since early 20th century & can even reveal trivia on how secret entrances were used & how the main hospital of the time would act as a ‘feeder’ providing supplies, staff etc. Apparently fuel was supplied near the palace flower beds with what looked like a water truck every week, which nobody noticed all that time. A very knowledgable guide will lead you throughout the tunnels & show you mannequins which are set up to re-enact the challenging times which patients & staff faced. Good if you are interested in this history or a details person. Hubby enjoyed it more, but I did find it very interesting

Really cool to visit. I was particularly excited as an Emergency Health Care worker to visit this site. I have visited the Canadian Cold War bunker (Diefenbunker), and Churchill's bunker in the UK. This was just as good and included a guided tour. However, it is quite a hike uphill from the nearby train station. Take a cab up - they're cheap. The walk down is fin. It was great to walk through the structure as though entering as a patient. The tour was very organized, and the wax figures made the operating rooms and other displays more realistic. Our guide was well informed and spoke excellent English. Unfortunately, no photos were allowed during the tour, and the small guide book at the gift shop did not show the interior of the hospital/nuke shelter sufficiently. I did manage to grab a couple of pics at the end of the tour of the Communist era ambulance.The gift shop has some really neat stuff for collectors. I got an original old glass syringe, but there were also Hungarian Army map cases and metal first aid kits available for very reasonable prices.

Really worth the 3600 HUF. It was a very enjoyable one hour tour. Our guide spoke very well in English and was quite knowledgeable about the history of the place. The wax figurines add life to the place and the original instruments are fascinating to look at. I recommend this tour if you are visiting the Buda Castle on the hill.
Very Interesting. Tour lasts one hour, guide was very good + her English was excellent. Very interesting. Would recommend it.

Interesting. I had no idea what to expect from this attraction but I loved the hours tour. A hospital located in a labyrinth of caves. If you are interested in WW2 this will appeal to you, and even if not there are other fascinating parts of tour. The only issue is the plastic statues used to show how the hospital worked look like acid victims, but the tour guide makes the tour feel short and is informative Make sure and try the air raid siren at the end of tour and get a gas mask for £3.00. Brilliant.

Surprisingly interesting. Visited here on a whim as I had an afternoon free and wanted to see something a bit different. I was very pleased with the Hospital in the Rock and learned a lot about Budapest's history that I most likely wouldn't have otherwise. You can only go through with a tour guide but ours was fantastic and very friendly. My only complaint is that I would have liked to have been able to take some photos. It's not particularly quick/easy to get to from the city centre but it's definitely worth it!

Interesting Place, Good Tour. The guided tour of the hospital went for approximately 1 hour. The hospital and history was very interesting, tour guide was great - very knowledgeable and spoke well.A unique spot that is worth a look and where you can gain more of an understanding of the (relatively recent) history of the city.There are a bunch of wax figures in the hospital which I honestly could have done without - they were distracting and sometimes a bit creepy. Other people on the tour thought that they brought the place "to life" - each to their own!Note that the tour is completely guided, you can not take photos and it's a bit chilly once you get inside.
Best Spot in Budapest. I really appreciated this unconventional 1 hour guided tour.It gives you a real idea of what it was like during the war in Budapest. I strongly recommend it to everyone!

Very interesting. Though a bit pricy for Budapest, this museum is well worth the money. You walk through the former hospital in the caves under the castle for about an hour. The tour is guided which has its pros and cons - you learn a lot, but I felt a bit rushed in the beginning and would have probably taken more time if I had been on my own. Still, one of the most interesting and impressive parts of my trip to Budapest.
Great experience!. We had an excellent guide who offered a great deal of historical information. This tour really opened our eyes to what Hungary was like during WWII and the Cold War era.

Worth a look. This is a good exhibit. Lots of history and quite interesting. You get a tour guide who can speak excellent English and they do not rush you around. One thing you need to know is that don't allow photo's. But they do take a photo of you that you can buy after.
interesting. It's not an interacting, high tech museum, but a very interesting one. How people could survive under the ground during the war. It shocking to imagine, that it really happened.
A cool museum for MD and RN.. If you are in the health profession and you have an hour. This is a must visit place on the Buda side. Btw, they gives discount to MDs and RNs.
Going back in time. This was a wonderful way to learn more about Hungarian history. We were a family with three generations, and all of us enjoyed the tour and the fantastic guide!

Very interesting visit.. One hour tour. Small groups, so book ahead. A genuinely interesting insight into the hospital's history, using mannequins for illustration. Loved the chance to sound the air-raid siren at the end.

Enjoyed my visit here. I had heard about this Hospital some time ago and have always wanted to visit it The Guide was young and pretty and the tour was conducted in English She was very knowledgeable about the equipment used and the history of the Tunnels how they where constructed and the reasons why From 1940 Air raid shelters to War time Hospitals cold war shelters The Staff there had a genuine enthusiasm about the place

Surprising tour - hidden underground hospital. This seemed like an Okay tour from the information book. It was a secret underground hospital with surgery taking place. Many mannequins are used to demonstrate the activities and conditions in the hospital during war times. It is well worth the visit.

Very Interesting Historical Place. This is a must-see attraction on the far side of Castle Hill. It's very easy to find from the square in front of St. Matthias Church. It can only be visited with one-hour guided tour, many in English. An expanded cave system served as a sometimes secret hospital during WWII as well as during the cold war years. Fascinating, well worth the time.

Absolutely fascinating!. This is a wonderful place to visit if you have a medical background! To think of a fully functioning hospital in caves hidden under a castle with it's own power, air and water supply still kept in readiness to this day is amazing. The wax models bring it all to life and a very good English speaking guide gave us an excellent tour.Well worth a visit.

unique. A guided tour (pricey) take hospital id as you get a discount. Very interesting insight into the horrors that have happened in Buda Castle area. Clear knowledgeable English speaking guide. I would have liked to spend more time examining all the old medical equipment eg a Morpheus anaesthetic machine in superb condition but we were hurried along. a unique facility in excellent unchanged condition. Makes you wonder what else is down there.Well worth a visit.

Nice tour through hungarian history. The hospital now is a museum where you can learn a little bit about hungarian history. You have to pay the visit but the tour is guided (in my case by a woman that speaks english very clearly). The tour starts with a short movie and then we walk inside the caves that form the hospital with the guide explaining everything about the second world war and hungarian revolution.

So interesting!. Definitely worth persevering to find this place. Not the best sign-posting but just ask someone. Get discount if you are a doctor or nurse, teacher, under 25 so bring some ID. Really interesting place, fascinating for medics but also for non-medics. Full of history. Dont miss it!
Compulsory 90 minute tour. Looked interesting but when we visited the tour only left on the hour, was compulsory and takes 80 - 90 minutes. We didn't want to take that long so chose not to go in.
WOW! FANTASTIC hour .... A very good guided tour about wartime Budapest and the aftermath of the '56 revolution... very authentic and sobering.

Excellent museum and exhibition. We did not know about this fascinating piece of Hungarian history, but a recommendation on arrival in Budapest ensured we visited this hugely interesting historical site with the entrance hidden in the side of the hill. Hospital and later a nuclear war bunker ... wow what a find! Highly recommend a visit.

Unusual and interesting tour. This is one of the more unusual tours that we took. There is a actually a hospital and nuclear bomb shelter underneath Buda and the tour not only shows you what it was set up to do but they include "people" in the tableau so you get a real sense of how this facility was used. It was mostly used during WWII for a relatively short period of time but the history is very interesting and then to see the bomb shelter and hear the story of how this was intended to be used (!) was eye opening. If you are looking for another slice of life in Budapest I would recommend this tour.

Don't miss it. This was probably the most interesting thing we did whilst in Budapest. The guided tour of this underground hospital was really fascinating. You are shown a video about the history of the hospital before being taken around the underground tunnels and rooms, which are set up with wax models to show how they would have looked during the war. There was even medical equipment and supplies from the war displayed. Go if you have the chance!

fascinating museum. an underground world war 2 hospital and soviet nuclear bunker which is well presented with excellent dioramas illustrating the conditions that patients were treated in. As a surgeon and a theatre nurse visiting we found it fascinating and highly worthwhile to visit.
Glad I found this.. While visiting Castle Hill do not leave without visiting this.1 and 1/4 hour guided tour. Fascinating, guide was excellent.

Great history lesson. The price made me question this stop, but I'm glad I went. Our guide was fantastic and very knowledgable, and though parts are a little cheesy, you get to see a lot of the hospital and get a sense of what it must have been like working down there.

Very interesting museum.. this museum provides a fascinating insight into providing medical care during the seige of Budapest during WWII and then later on through cold war events.Touring this museum is on a guided tour and English guides are available. Tours are an hour long and leave on the hour. Discounts on admission are available to Medical professionals, Red Cross members and military members upon showing relevant ID. They displays are well done and give a sense of the terrible times when this hospital was used.Recommend this attraction.

Unbelievable!. The only place of it's kind: almost living history. From the awful winter of '44-'45 when the Russians were besieging Budapest. Any interest in medical care or WWII would make this an interesting experience. When I went, I was the only English speaker in the group of about 30--and I was given everything in English. However, not for the claustrophobic or faint of heart. The history of this hospital is not happy.

Interesting and not your average tour. This was a very unique tour and the displays were pretty "old school" however the story about this hospital is very cool. It was definitely the first time I have ever wound up an air raid siren! I recommend the tour although you will be ushered through.

A really interesting way to spend an hour. It's a hospital that was built into Budapest's natural cave system and was used during WWII and the siege of budapest in the 1950's. It really is fascinating and a great way to spend an hour with tours going on the hour every hour.

Visits on the hour. I would not call this a must-see but if history and medicine are your things: go for it.
Visits are on the hour and the guides speak different languages. Be sure to take a sweater because it is cold inside.

Interesting, but not gripping. This tour is worth taking if you have a special interest in unusual hospitals, war-time medical care, or Soviet history. The interesting aspect of this tour is that -- with the exception of the wax figures used to bring the story to life -- everything in the space was actually there during the time the hospital was in use, so it is not re-created. However, despite the initial interest, for most people, I suspect the tour doesn't provide enough to fill the time allotted.
Different and historic. Is not cheap but is a real historic site. Try to get with teacher, nurses, doctors, etc.. discounts. And don't forget, the history was yesterday.....

Well Worth a Visit. I was expecting something like the Underground Hospitals in the Channel Islands but this is a fully equipped hospital which looks like it could still be used! After the tour try to find the exhaust pipe for the generator up in the main cast le area.

Really excellent tour unique gifts in the shop. Great tour this. Its all about how the natural caves under the castle were kitted out during the war as a hospital then nuclear bomb shelter. The guide was excellent and spoke great English. Best of all I got a unique souvenier for my boy back home- a genuine gas mask for only about £5.00. Other cool momentoes for sale in the shop. Only negative comment I would give was its location wasn't well signposted, which was a common theme for some of tourist attractions in Budapest.
Very interesting place. Enjoyed the guided tour. You got a lot of information on the history of Budapest. A unique and moving place.

Hospital in the Rock. A great tour, even if you are not in the health care field. As a nurse I found it very interesting, but so did my husband. Knowledgeable guide, who spoke excellent English. You must be able to walk on uneven surfaces, but we felt safe throughout our tour. So much history about the cold war to discover!! Would highly recommend!!!

One of the most interesting attractions in budapest. I found out about this attraction by reading a time out magazine and im so grateful i found it! It's very fascinating, absolutely different from anything you have ever seen, it's a bit hard too find but it's well worth it. The tour is far from being a dull visit to a historical attractiont hanks to the young tour guides that engage the visitors. Don't miss it

A Budapest Highlight. Only about 150 yds from Matthias church near the castle this is well worth visiting. We had a friendly reception snd excellent guide. The tour gives you an idea of not only the history of Budapest in wartime and postwar, but also what the siege of Budapest was like. This was a highlight of our Budaoest visit.

Interesting and unusual. This hospital is just as the previous reviewers have stated, interesting particularly for hospital personnel and history buffs, but worth the time of anyone. There are wax figures that show how things were. It is not such a polished tourist attraction; you don't feel like it is there just to take your money. My only complaint is the tour guide hurried along and I would have liked more time to look at things.

An unusual but very interesting place. I work in a hospital, so maybe this appealed to me a little more than most people, but for a look at a different part of Budapest's history Hospital in the Rock is well worth a visit.Tours were every hour on the hour, so you should try to fit this into your itinerary to arrive in time for the next tour, so you're not left standing round for nearly an hour.You can't take photos on the tour, but I suppose that means to get an appreciation for the hospital other people then need to go themselves. It also means the hour-long tours can run quickly and efficiently, without being held up by photographers.If you're interested in healthcare, and how things have changed in what is really a relatively short period of time, make sure you check out Hospital in the Rock.
Don't miss it. This is a facinating place, easy to find and not too expensive. The guide was a little to fast for us (spoke & walked quickly) but this is a must visit, very interesting.
Good reason to cross the river. Great piece of history from my lifetime. Not to polished which I really like. Not like any museum or restoration I have visited; distinct part of Hungary's recent past

A hidden gem. This is a must see in Budapest! A world war two hospital built into caves and tunnels under the castle! Later converted into a nuclear shelter during the cold war. Due to the adaption of existing tunnels it's twisty turny and higgledypiggledy inside which adds to the quirkiness! Only downside was due to being shown round by a guide, there wasn't enough time to look at all the exhibits, felt a bit rushed at times. If you're interested in bunkers and cold war stuff, or general history, you should go see this. Admission is quite reasonable, and tours are on the hour throughout the day, up to 10pm.

Hidden Gem. Came across this gem whilst walking around after visiting the fisherman's bastion. Our guide, who spoke excellent English, gave us an insight into the workings of this fascinating hospital and nuclear bunker!
off the track. Visited the Hospital in the rock, amazing to see a hidden treasure of Budapest that not many guides inform you of. Very interesting

Interesting tour of a "secret war-time" hospital. An interesting tour of this secret hospital embedded in the rock, built initially to provide care for civilians during the war and subsequently, for resistance fighters. Amazing to see a fully operational hospital is such a confined space; was operational until the 1960's. Also served as a bomb shelter--so lots of gas attack gear on display. Unfortunately, cannot take photos during the tour, but well worth the tour, especially for medical professionals and other wartime history buffs.

Cannot miss in Budapest. Do not miss this tour, it was one of our highlights in Budapest. Fascinating guided tour that takes about an hour with introductory film. It is similar to the Churchhill War Rooms in London, just as interesting but more casual and loose. The staff is younger, knowledgeable and multilingual. This is a newer attraction and may not show up on some of the guides. Great location, but a little hard to find. Head to west or Buda Hills side of Castle Hill. You go down a flight of stairs to a ring road which you follow left around the hill. I guess a hospital/command and control bunker built in the side of mountain is difficult to find by design. They offer military discounts if you have your identification card. The gift shop sells basic Soviet/Eastern Bloc military gear that was stored in the complex. Only negative was that we were the last tour of the day and we had twice the number of people in our group than was ideal.

Different sort of tour. This hospital in the caves was very worth the time to see if you are into the hospital setting of the forties during war time. Gives you a perspective of the harsh realities of the time. A bit hard to find since it is down a flight of stairs from the main area of the town. Great English speaking guides. Discounts for seniors, educators and medical visitors.

Don't miss this attraction!. Taking a tour of the Hospital is a must! The museum is very well equipped, with life like wax figures depicting how life may have been like for patients and staff. The English speaking guides are very knowledgeable about the museum, imparting a lot of information during the 50minute tour. Walking through the underground tunnels is very sobering, the history of the Hospital leaves you feeling very contemplative of the war and the revolution. If you're in the medical profession you'll be interested in the instruments and equipment on display as well as gaining a sense of how your working day would look. The tour seems to fly by, theres so much to see..it would have been nice to have had more time to look at tge displays. Thoroughly enjoyed our trip back in time.

Interesting and historical. They do a great job of explaining the fascinating history behind the hospital and some other events in Budapest history, which spans many years including World War II, the Cold War, and the attempted revolution. Brings the realities of war to life.
Really worth doing. We really enjoyed this. It was a different type of attraction. The story behind the hospital in the rock is interesting and it was amazing to see the items that were kept.
Hidden hospital. Very interesting to take the tour through the hospital. Amazing how the medical personnel were able to care for the injured in such a place.

Hidden gem. Please do not miss this museum!!!This is a hidden gem amongst the many museums Budapest has to offer. The entrance is quite small and hidden, behind the Buda castle. Nevertheless, once you find it, you will be immersed in history and stories about the interbelic and cold-war periods. The guide was really really funny and he knew tons of facts about the location. He also presented them in a totally exciting way. We took a one-hour long tour of the hospital-museum and we visited all the rooms. The staff did a great job with the reenactment of all the scenes within the museum. I really enjoyed that the guide actually let us try and use some of the exhibits (for example, we could ring the alarm horns that were used to announce the locals about a possible air-strike. That was soo cool). I totally recommend this place, but bring some warmer clothing as inside the museum it might get a little bit chilly.

A must see. This tour was the best we had in Budapest. I was amazed at the history and significance this underground secret hospital held. The tour was insightful, powerful and the guides were very funny. This is an hour tour but you can't miss it. Felt I learned more history about Budapest than I did at any other site!
must visit!. This is the unique ,historical, interesting place. guides are very professional and speaks clear English. they should sell brochure with color photos.
Must visit. Do visit this lovely place - you will be intrique by the place and surrounding. Eat at Hardiq - one of the best restaurants in Castle District though a bit pricey.
difficult to find. Really wanted to see this, not sure what we done, followed the signs, but couldn't find it, I believe its well worth a visit. but as short on time we didn't get a chance
Very interesting. A little hard to find but once there a great insight into an incredible history. 1 hour tour around the hospital helped in getting the information across.

Quirky and insightful. This is a quirky place to visit with compulsory tours in English on each hour. The dummys add a bit of macabre to what is a very sad history connected with this place. For a UK'er it gave some insight from the other side of the WW2 conflict.

A good tour. This was a good museum tour and the tour guide was excellent. The museum and exhibits were good however, a tip for EU tourists - take a passport and you will get a discount, unfortunately we didn't have ours with us so we had to pay the full price.It was worth a visit if you like exhibits (wax people etc...) and a tour guide as opposed to a self guided visit.
very unusual. You don't see a site like this in all cities you visit! The history is well explained. It is a little difficult to find but ask and locals will instruct you how to find it.

History on the quick.. The guide was very good. You get a pretty good history lesson of what happened during WWII and after when the hospital was turned into a nuclear bunker. Probably more interesting for medical types but history buffs would like too.
Amazing. Just amazing...the location and also by what the Hungarians were able to do in such small spaces. Lots of history! Loved it and not just because am a nurse :-)

Interesting museum. The Hospital in the Rock is an interesting museum. It shows the development of the hospital from inception, functioning during WW2 and the 1956 uprising, to its role as a nuclear bunker in the 1960's. There are hourly tours (departing in the hour) and these last around 60 mins. Annie, our guide, had excellent English and gave us and informative tour, highlighting the different roles played by this fascinating building. I was amazed at how much equipment had survived intact since WW2. If you like history to be tangible, then this is a great place to visit

Dark and interesting history. I throughly enjoyed this attraction and cannot understand the negative reviews.The tours take place every hour, on the hour so make sure you arrive at the right time.The tour began with a nine minute video, which was in Hungarian, and subtitled in English. We were then split into two groups, one for a Hungarian tour and one for an English speaking tour.Our guide lead us through the caves and told us some very interesting facts and fascinating stories about the hospital and the secret nuclear bunker. There were wax works of hospital staff and patients, some with amusing expressions, and original equipment and machinery from the hospital on display.The tour lasted an hour and ten minutes. The tour was a little on the expensive side, but worth it. There is also a gift shop selling soft drinks, chocolate bars and a small selection of items including gas masks and medical tins, all of which are reasonably priced.
Fascinating Experience. Trips on the hour every hour, so don't be late or you 'll have to wait. Very informative if sobering visit. Quite unbelievable what people had to endure in WW2
Great. There are quite a few steps to get to the entrance, but well worth the effort. Good guides and a very through and interesting tour.

Well preserved, old medicine, secrets, history. I am a doctor so this hospital was a "must see" in Budapest and it was really worth visiting it. The tours are guided in English and start hourly and last one hour. You see the wards, communication chambers, operating rooms and what I really liked were the instruments, apparatus, materials used during the WW II, and all of them are very well preserved. You also see the anti-nuclear bunker and impressive ventilation system and generators supplied by 2 big tanks of fuel.You should take a coat with you because it is cold 15-16 Celsius degrees, or you can choose one of the coats from the entrance. Pictures are not allowed but the guide will take a group picture at the end of the tour.The entrance is a little expensive, 3600 ft for adults, but I think that in the 28-th of each month, the last tour from 19 o'clock costs 1800 ft. I visited the hospital on the 28th of August, at 19 o'clock and I paid half the price and I also got a discount ticket for the Spy Museum.

Great tour (esp. for hospital staffers!). My husband is a radiation specialist who works in a hospital and thought this was the coolest thing he's seen in a while. It's awesome for docs, nurses, hospital staff, or physics/radation specialties. It gets a little chilly (about 55-60*F) and you're down there for an hour long tour, so I would bring a light sweater if you get chilled easily. The guides were informative and the tour offers discounts for all the people mentioned above or ANY military- quite nice of them!

A must-visit. A museum full with facts about Budapest's history. The guides know what they are talking about and their joy is contagious. We believe this well hidden spot is a must-visit on your trip to Budapest.

Hidden history. We took a private tour guide in a group of 5. There is a lot to consider when you are walking through the tunnels. You have to listen carefully as the dialogue could get lost in a larger group. It is a wax museum but there is a lot to see apart from the hospital figures themselves. Imagine is a must, there are all the mechanics of the tunnels, air purification, lighting, safety features, fuel storage . Just imagine yourself having to endure a stay in there, under occupation, surrounded by smokers and sick people. I would definitely recommend a visit here.

Unique museum. I liked this museum very much. The cashier was very friendly and she informed me about the different kinds of discounts (even if there was a chart just next to her). Make sure you bring your national professional ID if you're an EU teacher or you work in health care as there are discounts (free for teachers!).I was the only Hungarian in the group, and the guides asked me three times if I was sure about not wanting a Hungarian guide. I found this very professional, as they could have just ignored me (especially because - being a teacher- I did not pay a single forint .)First, we saw a short (6-7 mins) film about the history of the hospital. Then we were led to the cave system underground. They provide you with coats as the caves are a bit cold. (I liked the idea that they used special coats still worn by nurses and doctors in some hospitals in cold weather.)The guide, Gerda was very informative and told us lots of interesting little stories. I was very well informed on the tour, but it still was't too much, just the right amount of information. The hospital was a very unique experience with its 1 km underground system. I saw different treatment rooms, an operation theatre, kitchen, wards and the machinery rooms. As the hospital used to be a top secret location, the stories about disguising functions of the hospital are fascinating.Yes, some visitors did sound the siren, but we were asked before if there was anybody who did not want to hear it. The tour guide took a photo of the visitors which can be seen on their website.The only downside was that the tour was a bit rushed, I wanted to read the posters, but there was no time.

unusual sights. This is a long tour with a number of strange wax figures in different spots. The tour is in English, but the tour guide moved fast and we had a large group and given the tunnels, you can lose the commentary being given up front. The most interesting part is simply the tunnels themselves and the rooms carved out of the rock. It's worth doing but not one the top sights in budapest.

One bizarre attraction. A concealed venue used as a hospital during World War II and the Hungarian revolution, and as a nuclear bunker until the end of the 1990s. Tours in many languages detail the uses of the place, displaying the machinery required to run it, the medical equipment used, and how it operated. Friendly staff, a well-stocked gift shop, and a welcome cool temperature during the Budapest summer. This didn't seem expensive to me.

Very interesting but make sure to go early or late in the day - we were stuck in a very large group.. I was really excited to learn about the history of the secret WW2 hospital and the tour did not disappoint. You also got to see a wide range of medical equipment and the tour guide is very informative. The only issue was that our tour group was huge as there is only one tour every hour. This meant that we couldn't take our time whilst looking at the rooms and sometimes we couldn't always hear. Despite this the museum was still worth going to and it may be better earlier or later in the day.

Very interesting, great for people who like history.. Some people mentioned this is expensive but if you are under 26 it is only about $8 Canadian. You have to see the hospital on a guided tour, you can't just wander around yourself and there are no pictures allowed inside. Our guide was knowledgeable and she was quick to answer any questions, I really enjoyed the tour.
Best Museum to visit. This was the most fascinating museum with guided tour ( no pictures were allowed) this is especially interesting if you are in the medical profession.

Unique museum experience. i had a great time in the museum. Before the tour starts, the visitor can see the movie about the hospital. The tour guide is very informative. The tour type is walking around museum and there are wax figures to represent what happened in the rooms. The tour is divided into 2 parts. The 1st is about the hospital it self, the second is about the machineries of the hospital. You can choose to leave in the second session or continue the tour. But the price is same. You cannot take photos in this place. The down side about this place is in some rooms are stink, i don't now if others notice it or not. Because I'm very sensitive about smell.There are many touching stories and surprises about this place. You should here if you want to have different museum experiences.

Think twice about going to Hospital in the Rock. The Hospital in the Rock is fascinating from a historical and medical viewpoint. It is unfortunate that the tour is somewhat imbalanced and manipulative. From the get go, our tour guide brushed aside Hungary's alliance with Hitler, by saying something like, "you all know the history, we went with Germany in the war" as if they were on a date! You see neat medical stuff. But also be prepared to see Nazi collaborators who used the underground space for strategic purposes. For some reason, the tour included a representation of Hungary's military assisting the US in Afghanistan in 2011. Presumably this was included in the tour to assuage any hard feelings still lingering by American tourists. The hospital is cool. But the guide stays on script and is fairly repetitive. I give it two thumbs way down.

Informative and great for children. We're both nurses and was fascinated but history about the hospital inside the cave.We brought our 8-year old son with us on our visit to Budapest and we're surprised how our son absorbed and remembered all the details of the tour inside the cave. Even the part where they have to use bandages taken from dead bodies - he found it fascinating and carried on looking up for more information from the internet when we get home.There's a lot of interesting old instruments, medical equipment and antiquated but working machines inside the cave, but the dummies and mannequins are disappointingly hilarious. They looked like they're from 80s horror B-movies special effects department. Don't this put you off from visiting this place because it was such full-on assault from what old medical and nursing practises in the past and how we've moved on in both fields. It's astonishing to learn that some practises are still the same as today and some are really medieval you won't think it'll have a place in today's clinical practices.Highly recommended for everyone. Don't miss it when you're in Budapest.
hospital in the rock. Very different museum with an interesting history.Good guided tours.Only neg no photos allowed.Good spot to visit on hot summerdays.

disappointing experience. i went to the hospital in the rock after reading up on it, and had great expectations. needless to say i was greatly disappointed. first off - the price is way too high, especially in comparrison with other sites (And no student discount). the tours are bilingual, and so what could've been an interesting half hour tour becomes a stretched out one hour tour, in which you get to hear a long explanation in hungarian and then a short explanation in english. the tour guide took her time and so the tour got stretched out and it turned the experience into an extremely unenjoyable one.and the grand finale of the tour- you get to sound a siren. the tour guide should have had the decency to ask if anyone is from a country where they might experience sirens (as such a person, i can tell you there was absolutely nothing fun or exciting about hearing that siren be sounded again and again by everyone on the tour) nor did she say that that was the end (so anyone who didnt want to hear the sirens would know that they could leave). all in all, although the story behind the place is inetersting and enables you to learn about the history of budapest during WWII and the soviet occupation, the experience on the whole is just not worth it.

Very informative (though a bit tedious). The tour inside the hospital is very informative. You get to hear and see the interesting and extraordinary story of the caves under Buda. The guide was very nice and knowledgeable and we learned interesting facts about the city during WWII and the communist era.However, the tour is a bit long and a bit expensive too (about 4000HUF for an adult). You're not allowed to walk inside the museum by your own and this means that you can't leave when you had enough and that you have to pay full price.If you're a teacher/nurse/doctor, make sure you bring an id proving it for a substantial discount.

Excellent tour, worth going in. The hospital is actually pretty easy to find. From the St. Mathis church continue away from the river, past a general on a horse until you get to an overlook. Go down the stairs, turn right, and you are there. It's signposted along the way. The tour starts on the hour and they have jackets you can use if you want. The tour shows some great history, including the hospital and it's uses during the Cold War. Cool to see.

Excellent tour, definitely worth doing. As other people have mentioned, we had a bit of trouble finding the place to start with (it's on the lower road) but it's well worth persevering. There's a tour in English every hour, and when we went, it was free - I think because we're part of the EU perhaps. It's a shame in some way though, because they really do a fantastic job with the place, and it'd completely justify a fee of some sort. We ended up buying one of the metal medical cases at the end of the tour instead. The tour guide was a lovely girl who really knew her stuff, spoke excellent English, and was very enthusiastic. The displays are really well done, and it gives you a strange feeling to walk through the corridors and see them all, since I believe they're recreated the way they were when the place was in operation. At the start of the tour they tell you to take a coat from the rack if you're susceptible to the cold, and it DOES get cold, even though it was 34 degrees outside when we went. Informative, interesting, and captures the imagination spectacularly, this was one of my absolute favourite parts of my trip to Budapest, a definite recommendation.

Not for children. We visited Hospital in the Rock recently and enjoyed it very much. The displays are well set out complete with wax work figures. Every hour a tour is conducted in English by a very informative guide. But it is not for children.

Great fun and informative.. Very interesting indeed nice pace to it guides were very informative and there english was excellent nice plus was the nice and cool interior a very welcome break from the sun.Price was.3600 over 26 and 1800 for under

Amazing experience!!. It's definitely worth visiting this hidden museum. The guide was very informative , friendly and open to questions. It was intriguing to be inside such a place and be surrounded by so much history. Definitely worth going and experiencing it .

great tour. Very interesting and a must see for WWII buffs and doctors and nurses. We had a very knowledgeable tour guide. The history of this secret hospital is perfectly preserved and we were able to view rooms filled with the original hospital equipment and medical supplies.
Very interesting thing to see. We enjoyed the visit here very much. Great tour guide. Was very different to hear about things that are only in the recent past.

Oh yes, oh yes!. The Hospital in the Rock, once we found it, was absolutely worth the visit. A guided tour leaves on each hour - our large group was split into Hungarian and English speaking sections, but our group was still a little too large to comfortably follow our guide. That said, this is an excellent journey through an old hospital hidden away in the caves under Castle Hill. Wax figures (some disturbingly green) recreate the scene and there are plenty of authentic looking items in place to allow you to see how things were sixty plus years ago. Our tour guide, Milan, was very entertaining as he whisked us through the complex fairly rapidly, and was clearly passionate about the history he was explaining. Oh yes! As much as we scoffed before heading in, it did get genuinely chilly inside so take one of the proferred coats if you're sensitive to the cold. Otherwise, it's an excellent escape from the heat of the day.Highly recommended - the best thing we've done in Budapest.

Excellent eperience. Although it was a bit hard to find, the museum of the hospital in the rock was a very good exprience. There is a guide who guides you in the museum and explains you all the history of the hospital in english. The guide is very good and ready to answer all of your questions with humor. The whole tour lasts about an hour. It's not boring and you can learn a lot of things. Hospital in the rock is worth visiting.

Very interesting complex, worth a visit!. Very helpful staff, English tours leave every hour lasting about an hour. It seemed a bit rushed in parts, could have done with a bit more time to look at the hilarious waxwork figures in each scene. Its a massive underground system and strange to think it was still in use not too long ago! Shame only a small amount of the complex is accessible, but when you see the scale of the hospital on the map compared to the rest of it, you will understand why it all cant be public. The newer part with air filtration system is still used too!Our tour guide was so great and you could see she was passionate about the hospital. Great for all ages, reasonably priced (we got a half price discount being under 26) and well worth a visit if you've got an hour to spare!

Well worth a visit. Hospital in the rock is an incredible place; it spans two eras, the first as a hospital in WW2 and secondly as a nuclear bunker during the Cold War. The tour starts on the hour and lasts an hour. It kicks off with an informative video and then proceeds through the facility. The guide, who spoke perfect English, was engaging, informative and enthusiastic. She really brought to life what would otherwise be a slightly odd collection of wax dummies and memorabilia. I would thoroughly recommend and its good value for money. The staff were very helpful, even telling us about a discount we didn't know we were entitled to!
Interesting glimpse into near history. One of the best historic tours we have had. The fact it was operational only 40 years ago made it even more real.

Bizarre time-warp attraction in Budapest. This attraction used to be a working Red Cross hospital and nuclear bunker before the second world war and during the Cold War. A lot of the original inventory is still there to be seen brought to life by some hilarious wax-work models (check out the one on the toilet if you go). The tour is guided and takes about 45 minutes and you do take in some history on what life was like in Budapest during that period. However it was a shame that the pace of the tour meant that at times you couldn't read the posters and information on the walls that someone had obviously taken the time to prepare, for fear of being left behind the group. The tour ends with an air siren demonstration so be prepared to be deafened as well!

History Speaks.... As you enter you immediately feel that you went back a couple of decades in time. This was a shelter during WW2 and hundreds of wounded soldiers had been treated here. It served the same purpose during Hungary's revolution against communism and the Russians in 1956. Before and after it also served as a secret shelter of top political leaders in case of a nuclear war. (possible efficiency still doubted though...) Very nice presentation of medical equipment used in the 1940's and 50's. Excellent guided tour in English for about one hour.

Mixed Experience. The history of the place and the museum pieces make this well worth a visit, if you are interested in either the modern history of Eastern Europe or science ( I loved the old X-ray instrument and other old medical equipment). It is not often you get to visit any cold war nuclear fall-out shelter or WWII hospital. A highlight to me was the availability of original cold war bandages as souvenirs – OK they are past there use-by-date. The wax models in the display are well done if a little cheesy. The down side was the group for the tour was large and the guide didn’t always wait for everyone to catch-up. Not a must for everbody but I really enjoyed it.

Warm welcome. Totally impressed by this place.
When the nice cashier girl found out that I'm italian, she continued talking to me in italian, what a gesture, loved her! After that I had the best guided tour during my trip in Budapest, a perfect time travel (in english, for an hour). If you want to feel the history, this is your place!

Not to be missed!. This was a fav of our trip. It's an interesting insight to how things worked in the early 1900's and the mentality. You can gain a better understanding of WWII when you visit this hospital. Bring a jacket as it can get cold underground.

Very interesting. Great staff and guide.. This was the highlight of my trip to castle hill. It started off great with the cashier taking the time to find us the best rate. The Budapest card also gives you a discount here. We made it just in time for the English language tour and our guide was great as was her English. The hospital tour was very interesting and gives a stark picture of what Budapest was like during the siege during WWII as well as during the failed revolution. The guide also let my son crank the air raid siren which made his day. I highly recommend a visit.

Very Interesting. Good little history lesson in Budapest through the past 100 years or so told as you move through the hospital. WW2 and the Cuban missile standoff especially interesting. It's also a good idea to beat the summer heat in the middle of the day. They offers coats which we took and carried round with us but we did not need them.

Interesting for all ages. Very interesting! Brought to life by the wax dolls that are in place, it almost feels like its still there. This really gives you a feel for what it was like. Great staff and our tour guide was so great and you could see she was passionate about the hospital. Great for all ages, and relatively cheap (although we got half price as we're under 26) - worth it!!!

Worth a visit. Very pleasant staff. Shows how Red Cross ensured this hospital was kept safe whilst the others were destroyed. Interesting to see all the kit used in those days and the methods of keeping ventilation underground

Awesome experience, but very slow tour.
