It was a fascinating walk through a cold war era nuclear bunker slash hospital and quite worthwhile, but there were two things that bothered me: 1) the tour groups are so large that a guide might be talking for five minutes about an exhibit and you don't actually get to see it until people move onto the next exhibit and there's room for you to view it; and, 2) the tour guide was knowledgeable and professional, but she conducted the tour in both English and Hungarian, which meant that everything was said in both languages, doubling our tour time. These are two points I think this museum could quite easily improve on, but even so I definitely recommend seeing it!

Unique learning experience. We had an excellent time in the 75minutes walk through of the Hospital in the Rock Museum and Nuclear bunker. We not only learnt a lot about the history of that time, how they functioned, also we did that in a very fun way.Exhibits are arranged in forms of wax work statues, instruments, pictures, etc. Photography is not allowed inside, though the tour guide will take a picture of the group, which one can download from their FB website.It is very cool inside and there is a discount for Army veterans (of any country), medical staff and people under 26 & over 60 as well ! Just carry the required identification.To reach it, walk from Matthias Church, with your back towards it and on the end of that street is stairs going down. Come down and you see in 50m ahead.

Unique WWII and Cold War Relic. A very interesting walk though history. The stories of how the people were scared of nuclear weapons from the West was also revealing. It's also a good idea to beat the summer heat or rain. They offers coats but we did not need them.

History and mistery breath. It was a great experience to be there. The place was released for public in 2007 and before it was top secret. I almost felt like I got back in the time. Nice addition was the discount for medical staff.

Informative, fascinating, fun.. The tour with hospital in the rock is affordable and interesting. Our guide, Diana was a real class act, speaking as quickly and wittily in English as in Hungarian. She made learning the history of this interesting place feel effortless, and I found myself much more engaged than I expected to be. A must-see when in Budapest!

Absolutely Fascinating. Historically this was extremely interesting. The tour was very informative with the waxworks adding to the atmosphere created by the guide. Caves aside the cuddly toy viruses in the gift shop were a quirky and amusing souvenir. Well worth a visit and coats are provided if required as the temperature is about 15C.

Well Worth the time. We enjoyed the underground tour and history lesson which lasted about 70 minutes. Our guise was excellent and enthusiastic. A geat spot to cool off on a hot day, as the temp underground is about 4o degrees less than above.

A BIT DIFFERENT!. We visited Hospital in the Rock recently and enjoyed the visit very much. The displays are well set out complete with wax work figures. Every hour a tour is conducted in English by a very informative guide. A film is shown at the start of the tour giving the background and also showing news bulletins of the era.Our only criticism is that because it is the busy holiday season the size of the group was quite large (25) and so was hard at times to see the displays.Well worth the visit!

Very interesting. This a a museum which is well worth a visit. Located under the castle, it is a secret hospital which was used during WW2 and then later used as a supposedly nuclear proof bunker during the cold war. The tour takes you through various rooms and is fascinating for people interested in this period of history.
A unique experience. A very interesting tour which gave an excellent insight into the recent history of Budapest. The guide was very knowledgeable and spoke perfect English.

Amazing (especially on hot days). This seems to be one of the hidden gems, since it was quite empty on the day I visited. You are guided through a maze of caves that was turned into a hospital at the time of WW2, and which continued to be used as such until very recently. You see real beds, instruments, and places, and another part of it was a bunker during the Cold War, so you can see the communications, tracking and purification devices in case of a nuclear attack.They offer you coats as you go in, since it's quite cool inside, but if you go in the summer you'll be thankful for the coolness, don't bother with the coats :)

Cool and cool. Hospital in the Rock has a lot of history to tell. The guides are excellent storytellers, friendly and speak good English. The visit to the museum has two parts: the hospital itself and the (smaller) nuclear bunker. It gives a good impression on how life was during WWII and the Cold War in the bunker and it's surroundings. It's a good idea to do if it's 30 degrees Celsius outside, since inside it's pretty cool. You can take a warm coat if you're feeling cold.

Nothing special... I wouldn't bother going!. Pipes/wires a tunnel and nothing much else.. They only do guided tours - it's a combined English/hungarian group takes ages to translate.. I would spend the afternoon elsewhere!

Excellent tour - worth the visit. I took this tour today and found it to be quite interesting and well worth the money. Having worked in hospitals in the US over the past 20 years it was interesting to see how they were able to function in such confined spaces with limited resources. If you are interested in seeing a piece of history that really was not so long ago, I would highly recommend taking the time to take this tour.

A nice visit, but nothing special. To start with the conclusion: a visit to the hospital is nice, but don't expect anything special.The tour guide rushes the group through the cavesystem, quickly switching between Hungarian and English to get the story across. It is definitely an interesting story, but the main problem is that the tour is filled with trivial information which don't add to the experience.

A piece of the past. I was reading some of the other negative reviews and I don't know what people were expecting but I honestly really enjoyed this place. The tour is in English and you get to see a hospital bunker originally built during the 2nd world war but now full of 1960's cold war era medical and civil defense equipment. The guide was knowledgeable, informative and I was never bored. If you want something slightly unusual in Budapest and or are interested in the cold war, this place should not be missed. Plus how many times in your life will you get to sound a manual air raid siren?

fantastic faces. Great and interesting tour that gave you an overview of Budapest recent history. Amazing wax work creations and a tour guide that spoke fantastic English. Worth a visit when you are there.
Only for local people. I don't was impressed by this place.- Perhaps I was expecting another thing so my review I think that is not reliable.-

Cheesy and disappointing. I'll give this a miss unless you're really running out of things to do. Tour was overly long and too detailed. Lots of wax figures I guess to try a dramatize it but came off as rather cheesy to me. The nuclear part was really a waste of time.

I was there in 1956. This was a secret hospital in the Gellert Hill connected by tunnelfew kilometers long to escape highway.It was open during Hungarian Revolution in 1956.I visited it with Polish Radio journalist.There were wounded Soviet soldiers and Hungarian fighters in the same room.Weapons were left outside,no weapons were permtted in the hospital.I was happy to see that hosptal is now tourist attraction.Worth to se for few mnutes!

Interesting place. Located "below" Castle Hill(other side than Danube). Little hard to get if you are living for example Pest side. It was REALLY hot day, so this was literally cool place. Friendly English spoken guide.

Great place to cool off. We were in Budapest during a 100 degree heat wave and this was a great way to survive the hot afternoon. We were not allowed to take photographs, but our guide was friendly and fluent in English. Not the most exciting museum, but it is still a work in progress.

Fun, easy tour. My favorite tour in Budapest. The hospital is well maintained, the tour guides are very knowledgeable, and the tour is well timed. The military exhibit at the end is quirky (why is it there when there is no relation to the hospital in the rock), but overall this is a great visit to learn more about Budapest during WW2.

Late October in the stomach of the hill. Warmly recommended to people who are interested in history and army however it takes anybody away to the previous ages. There is Hungarian and English guide and many wax figures who are located in the original furniture of the cave. Warm clothes are welcome because the tour takes around 1,5 hours. At the beginning a short movie tells the story of the cave with original news theatre parts. During the walk you can really imagine how they worked in the hospital.

Awesome. We visited here on a very hot June day 2013. After hunting for a while we finaly found it. We asked the staff why it wasnt better sign posted they said they werent allowed to. Never mind it was well worth the hunt. This place provides an amazing glimpse of what it was like to work or be a patient here during WW2 and the Hungarian revelution of 1956.It is all underground. A military hospital with wards operating theatres and kitchens.Also the governments nuclear bunker is here. This bunker was kept in constant operation and is a relic of the cold war. our guide had great english and was very knowledgable and realy brought it to life for us. Well worth a visit

Best kept secret in Budapest. Great window into WWII and the Cold War. History always looks larger than life in the movies and on TV. You need to see something like this to get a sense if reality. Fascinating tour of a functioning cave hospital and actual nuclear bunker. Tour guides are well versed in history and speak great English. This is actually easy to find by descending the steps off the back (away from Pest) of the mountain directly from the square with St. Matthias Church. Turn right and in a short walk the entrance is on the right.

Enlightening history. This museum is well worth looking at but not too well signposted. Some walking is involved , about 1km, through the tunnels so being reasonably mobile is advised.The tour guide was excellent in both knowledge and English and gave a very insightful history of the caves, the hospital and the nuclear bunker.The caves are cool, about 15 degrees, so take advantage of the coats supplied. This came as a welcome relief though with outside temperatures being in the 30s!

Don't miss this!. So glad we found this out of the way museum. Our tour guide Sophia brought the hospital and communist Hungary back to life during the 45 minute walk through the underground. If you liked the Churchill Museum in London or enjoy hands on history, you will appreciate the Hospital in the Roclk.

awesome. Well worth a trip. We climbed up here after a trip to the Gellert hot springs spa next door. The story is related in several ways and is very interesting. The chapel itself inside the rock is also amazing to see.....very peaceful for worship
good stuff. I encourage everybody to go. I heard most of hungarians havent heard of this place. It's a must go. If you go to one museum this should be it.
Very hard to find.. We thought this was well worth a visit. A lot went on here unbeknowns to outside world.Needs more signage in Budapest generally.

interesting. Our family is not a war or history buff, but we make the point of visiting places where our kids can learned more about history and the suffering that people experienced due to wartime, but how some people worked together to help others. we found this museum to be interesting. It is neat to think that a cave could be turned into a hospital with running water, electricity, and even air circulation system. It is also interesting to hear how it was kept a secret. By the time the 1.5 hr tour ended we were cold having just summer clothing on so bring a light jacket or be sure to borrow the coats the museum provided free of charge at the beginning ofthe tour.

Extremely interesting. We were waiting for sun set to see the lights on the Danube one last time and so went exploring and we came across this gem. It's not very well sign posted or advertised , but its so worth the hunt for it. When we eventually found it, it was closed, but we went back on our last morning, and we are so glad we did. What an interesting place! We were amazed, and our tour guide spoke excellent English. We were in a small group (us two young English people, and two elderly American women) which was good as we had the chance to ask questions. The guided tour is good, as if left to wander we probably wouldve become very lost! It's a wonderful place and was one of the highlights of our trip. It's a shame you can't take photos because we would have liked to show others what it was like, but we have the memories :) PS we are young (20 + 24)
the secret hospital. visit this secret place that was build over the years to become a hospital during ww2 and afterwards a nuclear bomb shelter and hospital.

Sugar!. I liked all the signs everywhere saying Sugar! That turns out to mean Radiation! in Hungarian. We popped in here because a friend recommended it. Otherwise, I would have missed it. We got reduced entry because I am a nurse and partner is a doctor. It takes over an hour for the (obligatory) guided tour and my old feet were tiring by the time we finished but it was all very atmospheric and the guide, Tomás, was very knowledgable and charming, managing to talk for over an hour in two languages with great aplomb. It was a wartime field hospital and then a nuclear bunker and it's all built into some limestone caves deep under the castle area. Much more fun than the Disneyfied Fisherman's Bastion.

IMPRESSIVE!. This has to be one of the most interesting visits I´ve made during my trip across Europe. It might be a bit pricey, but it´s not like you´re gonna find a place like this on every corner. The hospital was built out of a series of chambers that date back to the ice age. These chambers were linked together and then formed a labyrinth, which was used among other things as a hospital and later on as a bunker during the cold war. If you´re a history buff, please do visit the hospital in the rocks!

Not worth the 90 mins tour.. I was really looking forward to this tour which departs hourly. However, it was a let down. It went through the history of this cave hospital and went on to talk about the Hungary in WW1 and WW2 which I found a tad bring as I wanted to know more about the cave hospital. I guess there wasn't much to talk about it. The tour pace was a little slow and the display are all wax human display. Could b more interesting or t least shortened the duration.The tour guide also alternate speaking in English and Hungarian which adds to the length of the tour.Won't recommend it.

Weirdly interesting and remarkable.. Visit the hospital, even if you arent too in to history you cant help but be fascinated. its a little bit long winded as the tour is in both Hungarian and English but run with it its worth it. The only bit that comes over a little odd is they have cramed a full size helicopter down there and recreted some vingettes from Afganistan.

If you have the time do it. Interesting look into the WWII cold war era hospital the tour is informative and worth doing if you have time while in Budapest. Great idea on a rainy day if you are looking for something to do .The entire cave system is much bigger than one expects from the outside and left me wondering how much effort went into digging the place out Oh one other thing to mention about it is if you are a medical professional; with accredited identification your entrance is practically free.

Would like to see more. We took the tour, it was okay but not exceptional. I would have liked to be able to take some photos or buy a set of photos but none were available. Therefore I have nothing to share with others when I get home. The cave system is much larger than what is seen on the tour. More would be better.

The ingenuity and strength of people never ceases to amaze me.. If you go to Budapest I recommend a visit here. Very informative and friendly. The only shame was not being able to take photos while inside but hey memories are worth a thousand pictures
great. extremely interesting! It's absolutely worth visiting! A piece of history in the heart of the caste district!

Well worth a visit. The hospital in the rock is well worth a visit if you like wartime history.A very interesting hour and half tour given by an excellent tour guide the only down side is that we got into a large group so going round some of the rooms you miss what the guide is saying as some of the rooms are small and the tour guide also tells the history of the hospital in Hungarian so you are waiting for her to finish before you can move on which sometimes makes it a little bit boring but a very interesting tour overall.There is a gift shop where you can purchase many wartime items my friend bought the authentic gas mask at great price of just £3.

Visit if you get chance. If you like visiting places of interest you will love this. Guided tour which in English was also given in Hungarian by the guide which did slow the visit down but let you look around whilst the other language is given. The only down point for our two couples was the size of the group we were in. Sometimes in some of the smaller rooms not everyone could get in and listen to the guide. However don't let that put you off, if you are over 62, or in the medical,military,teaching profession bring some I.D and get in for a good discounted price. We didn't but it was still good value. Even the original new gas mask and canister for £3 from the waiting area was a nice little present for the kids !!

A Fascinating Visit. This is one attraction I would certainly recommend to visitors. A very worthwhile hour and a bit was spent on this tour. It was very good and went through the whole history of the hospital. The guide was excellent and gave very good explanations at every stage of the tour. the way the rooms and exhibits were laid out gave you a real insight into what life was like in the hospital both during the siege of Budapest and then under communist rule.

very interesting. I never imagined that such an hospital could exist with all the necessary equipment. The guide tour was excellently done. Better check the tour schedule before showing up as these are only a few a day.With the tour guide we also learned some of the hisrtorical facts about the second wolrd war and of Hungary in general

Amazing living museum!. This hospital is exactly as it has been for over 50 years, waiting ready in case of a nuclear strike. The facility was managed by the same couple for 40 years and is in the same state of readiness that it was during the cold war era(just without the staff). We took part in an informative tour which was discounted for myself being a teacher and my partner being a university lecturer. Excellent tour.
Surprise Hospital. Not hugely publicised but a must to visit. Tour takes over an hour , gives a good incite into life in Budapest during the war and oppressed years under communism.

Fantastic to visit. As Australians we have been very sheltered from war and taking my 14 year old son to this incredible 'attraction' has made the European wars come alive for him. My parents were also very impressed with the whole exhibition. My mother is Hungarian born and was amazed to see the place where the alarms A must if you are in Budapest as it is a quick walk from the Castle district. The items for sale are genuine articles from the cold war. My son bought gas masks for his friends for $4.50AU each. We will definetely return

Interesting visit!. We sought out this museum because we thought it looked really interesting and we weren't wrong! You have to take a guided tour but it is really worth it. They go on the hour but it's close to other attractions so you can always buy your ticket and then look around some more before going back to the museum. The tour is led in Hungarian and English. The tour didn't drag and it was really informative. The tour guide was excellent and had lots of stories to tell and very detailed information to share.

Worth a look. Underneath Castle Hill, this is a good attraction to visit in the hottest part of the day as it's cool. Tours are guided only, and depart on the hour. The guides are knowledgeable and presentation was interesting and entertaining. The tour takes around an hour to complete, and the tickets will also give you a discount from entry to the spy museum not far away.

Worth visiting. If you have medical connections this is well worth a visit and is cheaper if you can prove your profession. It's amazing to see how patients managed to be treated in crowded conditions.

Interesting and worth a look. We found this hard to find – both the tourist maps we were given directed us to the opposite side of the Castle walls. The best way to find this is to follow the sign posts in the Castle area. Once found it was well worth it though!It cost about £10 per ticket which we found expensive however if you are military, a teacher or a DR bring ID and you get a big discount. The only way to view the hospital/bunker is by tour which runs every hour however if you arrive and one has started you can buy a ticket and come back later for the next.Our tour guide spoke excellent English and was able to answer all questions. There was a moderate about of walking but nothing strenuous. The hospital is cold so bring a jumper or you can borrow a coat from the museum. If you have an interest in communism or WWII history then this helps paint a picture of Hungary’s association with both.This was an interesting tour of both hospital and nuclear bunker which made for an interesting alternative to other Budapest attractions. The gift shop is also worth a look for cheap memorabilia of real items found on the hospital.

I wasn't too impressed. My husband has suggested this museum to me. He had found it very interesting and thought that it was fascinating. I however did not. It was amazingly cool in the mountain, which was appreciated being that it was really hot. I was disappointed when I found out that we could only go in if we signed up for a tour. I was under the impression that we were going on an English tour. However when we caught up with the group (we came into the tour 5 min after it started) the tour guide was speaking hungarian. I believe the tour took twice as long because he had to do his guide in two languages. I became very annoyed at this point. The tour guide himself was very nice and polite. It just wasn't my kind of tour. I will say though that the wax figures they had to represent the doctors and soldiers were very disturbing. If you are interested in Nuclear Bomb shelters this tour is for you! :D

Hidden in the rock. make sure you arrive in time as museum can only be visited on guided tours which are every hour and last 60-70mins. Tour excellent with very good guide who spoke excellent English. it was hot the day we visited so the coolness of the underground hospital was very welcome however for guests that find it too cool there are warm overcoats available at no cost to wear for comfort. As a nurse I got discount on entry admission. As a nurse working in modern day it really gives me great admiration for the work of the medical staff during WWII and the Hungarian Revolution of 1956. well worth a visit.

Under the hill. This is a fascinating museum . The caves under the castle hill were converted into a hospital in the 1930's used in the second world war and the 1956 uprising,then converted to nuclear bunker.It is much more fun than it sounds and you can buy original gas masks for only £2.00.

Hidden in the Rocks.... This is an interesting place to visit if you're in the medical field. It gives you a different perspective on those helping patients during WWII and the Hungarian Revolution of 1956. I can't imagine working in those conditions back then, so kudos to those who did. This is a place where you need a tour guide to fully understand what was done and how the hospital was run. The one thing I don't think the tour needed though was a visit to the mechanical room. I got nothing out of that part.

Amazing. Hard to find, you have to go down the ramparts of the castle Hill, but an interesting place to visit: it tells the history of the hospital in the second world war and in the revolution of '56. It was kept operational untill the late 80 's. As a Red-Cross nurse a got a discount!They even used the same Red-Cross stamps on their formulars as we do now.I wonder how many more of these hidden placets excist we don't know anything about.

Fantastic. As a nurse this is a must ,too think this was kept operational throughout the cold war with its own nucleur bunker and water supply and too see the old equiptment it makes you think .You can even turn on the air raid siren and deafen every one.

Excellent place to visit on a hot day!. We very much enjoyed our visit to the Hospital in the Rock, it was a warm day outside but inside the rock was quite cool. There was only 6 of us on the tour and the tour guide was excellent, very informative and spoke excellent English. She was quite passionate about her job and was happy to explain any questions that were raised. We got reduced price tickets by using our Budapest card, but would have been more than happy to pay the full price as it was well worth the visit.
Very interesting!!. My friend and i learned so much history here about the Hospital on the Rock. There is an excellent tour guide who showed us around and spoke very good english,Well worth a visit!!
Very informative. We found this fascinating as we are history buffs. the guide was very informative and was happy to answer questions. It is extremely well presented and worth the price ticket.

A hidden gem in more ways than one. Brilliant place to visit. The secrets that are held in this hospital are amazing. The janitor who ran it kept it a secret for more than 40 years. The generator was run by oil and the tanks were secretly filled up whilst watering the flowers outside. The tour guide was very good, explaining everything clearly ad the exhibits were truly magnificent... Well worth a visit...

Great Place to Cool-Off On a Hot Day. This is a very interesting place to visit on a hot day. Inside the caves under Buda Castle it shows a history of how the people of Budapest used this place throughout its history including a hospital and nuclear bunker.

very interesting. definitely worth a look if you are into war museums and nuclear bunkers! Dragged my girlfriend there - at first she really wasn't impressed with going to see a nuclear bunker as we were meant to be on a romantic break but she did enjoy it once the tour got going!

Museum tour with a difference. Didnt really know what to expect but the hospital and nuclear bunker were definately different to the normal museum tour. The fact that if you wanted to you could buy authentic items from the hospital in the small shop was interesting too. The guide was excellent switching from Hungarian to English throughout the tour as well
A real blast from the past.. A really unique and facinating experience. Tour in english lasts 75 min. Show your Budapest Card for a discount, and don't forget to buy your souvenier gas mask! Enjoy.
A nice cool way to kill an hour. It was okay. No photos allowed, i suspect that its because the displays are a little cheezy, with the wax maniquins.
great tour guide. This tour really gave us a feel for what the Hungarian people had to endure. English speaking tours start on the hour and last about an hour.

Hospital & Nuclear War Bunker. Really interesting museum which we just happened to be walking past, so called in. The staff are great, very knowledgable and helpful. Students get quite a large discount so it's worth taking your cards as proof. Would definitely recommend to anyone visiting Buda.

Definitely give this a visit. We visited this on our last day in Budapest, but both my boyfriend and I agreed that we should've gone on the first day. This is because the guided tour of the hospital gives you such a good history of Budapest in World War 2 and the Cold War that you appreciate the city's history so much more after you leave. We didn't know much to start with, and we felt a lot more knowledgeable after we left. The tour is just over an hour long, but the time goes by very quickly! The hospital has a lot of original objects in it, which makes it even more interesting. You really get a feel for the history of the place and the tour guide was brilliant. Definitely go! So worth the money! If you're between 16-26 you can get a 50% discount if you show your EU passport or driving license!

A revealing walk back in history. They have tried to make is as it was during the war. They have made life size people, soldiers, patients, doctors nurses. They have tried to make the rooms look authentic with bunk beds, x ray equiptment. The bunker where they used to test nuclear equiptment makes you feel a bit uncomfortable. We had a very good tour guide.

Moving. A worthwhile trip to give an insight to Budapest during the Second World War and the Cold War. The guide was very knowledgable and was pleased to answer all questions. Did give me goosebumps at times!

Fascinating take a look!. We stumbled upon this place but what a little find. It's a fascinating place give it a go. A top secret hospital for many years, it had to be maintained by a couple singled handed for decades.It is now open for tours.
Never found it. Guess it really is a secret hospital, as we walked and walked, thinking we were following the maps, but never found it. It does charge a fee to go inside.
Amazing. This was a fascinating, but rather oppressive place, which highlighted Budapest's turbulent, and quite recent history. Well worth a visit.

Nuclear Holocaust ready !. This was a fascinating tour and well worth it. The hospital in the rock is built in the caves and tunnels that run under Castle Hill. It was an operational hospital during the second world war and in the 50s and 60s it was converted into a secret hospital to be used in the event of a nuclear holocaust. It was kept in readiness at all times and completely secret. It was also a hospital during the 1968 uprising. I should add for full disclosure that some of the mannequins used in the display are a little hokey...but still fascinating.

You get a discount if you're a doctor :). A very interesting place, reflecting the history of both WWII and the Cold War in Budapest. We were lucky to get into a foreigners-only group, so a guide only spoke in English. The museum is a system of interconnected underground caves which were utilized to host a wartime hospital that was fully operational during bombings and siege of Budapest. Later, in the communist era, it was transformed into a nuclear-proof shelter. I would say it is very atmospheric, making you think of atrocities of the war and bravery of doctors who managed to save lives under appalling conditions.The entrance ticket is not cheap, but you can get a discount if you are a doctor/nurse, and have a document certifying this.
Interesting. Very interesting tour with knowledgeable guides. Takes over an hour but the time goes quick. Good discounts available especially if you are from the EU and under 26

Fascinating piece of history. I visited alone at 1000 opening and it looked like I would get solo tour. I asked if this meant it would be shorter but guide said that she could tell me more. Joined at last minute by two locals so tour in two languages. I felt that the guide did an excellent job of explaining in both languages. To thos ethat say they wanted more time, the bilingual tour actually gives you more time when not actively listening

A must visit. I found Hospital in the Rock on Tripadvisor - it's not in any travel or guide books. I was really keen to visit this site, it sounded interesting. And I wasn't let down. In fact, this place exceeded my expectations!To get there: I took the Funicular up to the Castle (or you can walk), walk straight over to the back, and then to the right hand side where the road goes underneath a bridge connecting to the Castle. Stay on the bridge over the road, don't take the steps immediately heading down on the left hand side after the bridge. Walk along this road (Uri Utca) which has lovely high rise views over Buda. You come to a covered staircase down to Lovas ut. At the bottom of the stairs, turn right and the entrance is right there.It's 3600 HUF to get in. About £10. They said the tour would take 75 minutes. (tours depart on the hour every hour, last tour at 7pm). Can only visit by tour guide. My 6pm group was about 35-40 people large. Quite big. My tour took about 95 mins.They start the tour by showing a brief video about the history. Then you have a tour of the whole complex. They have opened the museum with genuine artifacts from the 1950s and wax works which makes it very realistic to appreciate the conditions they worked in during the war. They show you the engine room, as well as operating theatres, wards, kitchen. No photos allowed inside.Honestly, it is a must see!
Interesting. Interesting but it takes a bit long time as the guide first speaks English followed by Hungarian but it is worth seeing.

Fascinating. Ok, I am a nurse, so I was intrigued by Hospital in the Rock. It was built starting in 1939 to afford more hospital access and when WWII came to Budapest, it treated/housed up to 600 occupants. After the war, the Cold War saw it become a Nuclear Fall out Bunker. Lost of original equipment, set up to look as it did in those days. Well worth the visit. My husband is non medical and he enjoyed it immensely. Our guide was very knowledgeable and gave a wonderful tour
Hidden gem. Very interesting. The guide was very informative. Electrical equipment is still in full working order.

Informative and interesting. We only visited a couple of museums during our trip to Budapest and was glad we chose to come here, although it was more one of the more expensive places to visit. The hour long guided tour (in English) sometimes felt a bit rushed as there was lots to get through but was really informative with useful stories from the history of the hospital. Lots of the rooms are set up with beds, medical equipment etc. as they would have been at the time.

Another secret in the Castle District. Other reviewers have already mentioned that this 40+ yo facility was built for use as a secret hospital during WWII. It was also used by the Germans and Russians. Of all the bunkers I've seen recently in Central Europe, this one was easily the most impressive. The air filtration, water storage and filtration and power generation systems were before their time.We arrived 10 minutes after a tour had already started so an attendant gave us a quick yet efficient briefing, enabling us to join the previous tour. The guide delivered his presentation in Hungarian and perfect English. We didn't feel that it was rushed; there was plenty of time to look at the exhibits.It makes perfect sense that visitors can ONLY see the bunker with a guide. There is so much original equipment, medical supplies and historic items. The rooms are a bit of a maze. It could be dangerous or confusing for people to wander about on their own. The air filtration system is still operational and the management of the bunker would not like anyone tinkering with the machines!From Matthias Church, walk away from the Fisherman's Bastion along Szentháromság Street (past Cafe Ruszwurm). Veer left onto Gránit lépcső and take the stairs down to Lovas Street. Turn right. You'll see the entrance to the museum.
brillant. Really enjoyable tour. Do not miss if you are going to Budapest. Expensive compared to other attractions but worth the money.

Well worth a visit - friendly and helpful staff!. The hospital in the rock was a really interesting place to visit and shows a different side to Budapest. The tour is provided in English and is very informative, showing the use of the hospital during the War and then its conversion later on to a secret nuclear bunker!The staff were also very helpful, we arrived 20 mins after a scheduled tour and would not have had time to wait for the next one as we had a flight to catch! One member of staff took us personally down the tunnel, explaining different sections along the way until we caught up with the group on the tour. Great service and a great experience! Thanks guys!

Overpriced and tour way too long. The hospital is a historical gem and the wax characters are an attempt to bring the hospital to life for the viewer, for this I rate it highly but unfortunately the ability of people to exploit an attraction in order to swindle tourists stricts again.The tour is way overpriced, i mean extortion at 3600ft (12e +) for people over 26 and 1800 for under 26 but certain concessions apply to particular groups.The tour guide I had was boring and not polite and she made the 90 minute tour feel like an eternity. The hospital would be a far better experience if people were allowed to walk around by themselves and read placards (if they were provided) because the historical notoriety of this attraction speaks for itself having aided victims during nazi occupation and communist rule and being hidden away to provide safety from the shelling, however having to be confined in a group with a guide with broken English took from the experience as did the inability to take pictures, should be allowed to take pictures if you pay to get into something.

A different insight into Budapest. The Hospital in the Rock is well worth a visit, particularly if you want to escape the cold for a few hours. As many other reviewers mentioned, the tour does feel a little rushed. Our group was quite big & i would have loved to have pottered over the memorabilia for a bit longer. Our guide was very knowledgeable & passionate about the role of the of the hospital during WWII and the Hungarian Uprising. Well worth a visit

Well worth the time and vist. Well worth the time and visit if a little pricey. Good interesting tour and excellent tour guide, takes about an hour for the tour and explains its use as a hospital German command centre and conversion to necular Bunker.
Hidden gem. A really interesting place to visit, packed with history even if a little difficult to find! Good value, and great for a rainy or cold day

Cool gift shop!. It's hard to find, but worth it. Your forced to go on a tour (I suspect they still keep some dodgy stuff down there!) but it is quite good. You're not supposed to take photos, but its still possible. The gift shop is cool, has loads of old military gear, with gas masks etc for £3!

Interesting guided tour but a little rushed. The good:- Guided tour - Short video at the start of the tour to give a summary- Interesting peek into the underground hospital- Wax figures can be quite helpful in giving an idea of the activities in the hospital then, especially if you are going with children.The bad:- Tour was a bit rushed. Will be nice to give us another 15 mins so we can have a little more time at each section/ room.- No photos allowedAll in, recommended interesting attraction. Can be done after the walking tour (check my review for walking tour) as it ends around Fisherman Bastion and you can walk down to hospital in the rock. Worth a visit.

Worth to visit. Definitely worth to come and visit, the tour guide isdetailed but sometimes need less extra information. The price is also fair but in the souvenir shop a bit overpriced:) If somebody interested in the Cold War history, go and check it:)
A hidden little gem. Came across this by accident but it was well worth the visit. Guided tours only on the hour in English & Hungarian. You also get to see the Nuclear shelter

Interesting place to see.. Worth a look around, entry was a little high for Budapest but reasonable.
The other reviewers mentioned the guide bringing the tour to life, unfortunately our guide was not quite as immersive, but she was ok all the same, the tour felt a little rushed and did not quite go into enough detail at times.

Cool museum worth a visit. This is a museum located in the very old tunnels under the castle district in which a secret hospital was built during WW2 and later also a nuclear bomb shelter. It's very authentic with a lot of the original equipment still there and life size dolls showing how it was used. Only guided tours (about 1h). No photography allowed, but you get to sound the alarm bell! They sell cheap WW2 gasmasks (4?) and stuff in the souvenir shop.

Really interesting if a little rushed. Fascinating museum set into the rock and the tour starts with a short film in Hungarian with English subtitles followed by a tour of the labyrinthine tunnels and wards of the former hospital. Several times the guide chided anyone not keeping up and there were lots of photos and information boards but not really enough time to take it all in as we were rushed onto the next part. The most moving part was the large ward with models lying in bed - a hush descended over the group as we all reflected on the horror that must been experienced but almost on cue we were summoned to the next room and the moment was lost.There was a lot of information to take in and my regret was not having time to read all the information boards - those I did manage were excellent. Before the hour was up we were in the shop and the guide was spiriting away another group.This has the potential to be a five star attraction if only they would invest in another giude and make the tours 10-15 minutes longer. The tunnels are large enough to take 2 groups at different stages of their tours.Still worth doing this but they are missing a trick marching folk around so quickly and then berating them if they hold back to read the information!

Favorite tour in Budapest. The Hospital in the Rock is a bit of a walk from the castle complex, but well work the effort to get there and time you invest in the tour.The tour is 80 minutes long and starts about every hour. The facilities have been wonderfully restored/maintained. The tour starts with a quick video intro to the hospital and then continues with a guided tour of the hospital (typically in Hungarian and English). Most of the rooms include mannequins that show scenes from the hospital's past from WWII through 2002.The gift shop offers some very unique souvenirs including gas masks, stretchers, and first aid boxes as well as traditional ones like t-shirts.
hospital. amazing (just one word) its a maze of tunnels with an english speaking guide very interesting place to visit

So Secret!"!. Not easy to find! Locals did not seem to know it and offered many locations. Eventually found it on a sign post near St Mathias Church. Intriguing place and well set out to represent recent history. The guided tour was dual language and a little hurried as she had to repeat everything in each language and had a deadline to meet. There are concessionary admittance fees, which we did not find in other attractions. My friend and I are nurses so found it very interesting.

Very informative. Visited here after reviews on Trip Advisor Found the tour to be very informative but thought the price a bit high about £ 11 each discounts for over 62s Armedforces ,Teachers, Doctors and Nurses Must have proof.

Very interesting.. This is certainly worth a visit. Our tour guide was very knowledgeable and took us round in about an hour and a half. His English was fantastic and the small size of our group made the tour enjoyable, rather than having to strain to hear him. I would have liked to be allowed to take photos but this is a small point. There weren't any photos to purchase at the end either so the only photographic memory I have is one of the front of the building.

Interesting, but expensive for what it is. Hospital on the Rock tour was interesting, and the guides were good. However, there were two tours running at the same time, a Hungarian and an English language tour, so we had to wait for translation at each point of the tour. There were an number of interesting facts and stories about the hospital, but I found the tour of the nuclear bunker much more interesting. The highlight of the tour was the fact that we got to sound an air-raid alarm at the end of the tour. The tour of the hospital lasts about one hour, and the tour nuclear bunker lasts about 20 minutes. There are a number of discounts available but I was unable to avail of any of them, so I paid the full admission price of €20. I felt this was a little expensive for what it was.

Interesting Tour. Although this hospital was never needed for its intended purpose, it is a very interesting tour for all ages. You feel as if you are going back in time as you enter and walk through the old hospital. It is fun to see the tools and technology of the time. As I remember, it is cool inside so you might like to bring a light jacket even in summer.

A reminder of Hungary's recent history. Always love to visit places that were once used for their purpose instead of visiting a museum about an event. In historic terms this rather scary place was active until really recent times as the photos and story told by your excellent guide prove.Worth checking out if you are having a day on Castle Hill and fancy something a bit different.

Creepy fun. This makes for a very unique experience if you are in the Castle area. You tour through an underground hospital that was used at various times in Hungary's history - even as recently as the 50's. There are life-like manequins, some with bloody wounds, and various hospital equipment set up for a real-life feel. The guide does a good job of explaining the history without overwhelming visitors. Definitely good for kids age 8 and up, I would think. Our kids will never forget it!

Interesting. We visited this attraction recently and found it interesting. On the down side it was guided tour only every hour and the group size of 35 was way too many for the size of the rooms. No time was given to actually look at the exhibits and you had trouble listening to the commentary. The tour was 90 minutes but along with the wait time we were there over 2 hours. Also be aware that most museums are closed every Monday in Budapest.
Something different. Interesting but the guided tour could be much better. Could be bit complicated to find the location, but one just has to follow the signs.

Really interesting!!. This one is really worth a visit. The tours run every hour on the hour and last around 1 hour 20 minutes, do not be put off by this as the guide speaks in both english and hungarian. We found the tour really interesting and the hospital has been pretty much left as it was during the war!!

History of mankind... Worth to visit!. Since photos inside are not allowed, all Tripadvisor members take a photo from the entrance... So do I - The museum, located underground, 3 min from the Hilton, and displays the Hungarian Civil Defense Hospital used during the 2nd World War and the Hungarian Revolution - Law Enforcement discount ;)

Must see if you want something interesting and unusual. . We loved this, it was so interesting. Our guide Milan was really passionate and made the underground hospital come alive around us. The tour was just over an hour and in Hungarian and English it covered the history but also included some fascinating anecdotes about people who worked in the hospital. If you are a medical professional, student, pensioner or under 25 you get a 50% discount off the already very reasonable entry of 3200huf. The small gift shop has some very unusual souvenirs we bought a gas mask and a helmet!! Check it out, it's awesome!!!

OMG. I am glad a friend of mine told me about this place. It is a hospital built inside caves during WWII. It was not open to the public until 2002 and was a government secret. Really fantastic , take the english tour

Fascinating - once you've found it!. Very interesting insight into hospital life during the war and post war. Also being inside and learning about the nuclear bunker was fascinating.
Was a little difficult to find and tours only run on the hour every hour do don't be late.
Quite a unique experience.

unbelievable. This is something we never saw before. Operating theatres, their own air, electricity and water supply, X-ray chambre, wards for soldiers and civilians and all that hidden in a rock! You can even see a full sized helicopter ... imagine that!

I learnt so much!. A really interesting tour. I learnt so much that I didn't know about Hungary and Budapest over the last 70 years. Seeing inside the hospital was really interesting, loads of things to look at. Some of the wax works are a little odd and creepy, but on the whole a thoroughly worth while experience. Our tour guide was amazing too, he was so enthusiastic about what he was telling us that you couldn't help but to be entertained.
You may not miss this one. I thnk we all need to see this with our own eyes . But i dont understand why we may not make photo's because its realy expensive to visit it .

Fascinating place. Fascinating tour of the hospital in the rock. Our guide was very knowledgable. The only downside to the tour not a problem that could be solved) was there were some Hungarian visitors who talked incessantly through the guide's english & hungarian commentary.

Fascinating. A real find. Very interesting tour, with discounts for Doctors (me) and nurses, and free for my wife who teaches (don't understand that one!!). Very well organised, although larger groups might be a struggle (only 6 on our tour). Walk is 1km and 1hr thru the passages. Also good Cold War part, as the 'hospital' actually was a nuclear bunker in that era.

Well worth the finding. Its a bit out of the way but an excellent museum to visit, the guide is very passionate and informed about his tour and entry is only about £6. You go deep into the complex and unlike other tours i have been on they take you of the beaten track and show you the workings behind the complex such as the power generators and plant rooms for water and air filtration.The only downside if the fact you are not allowed to take pictures which would be a great momento of a very interesting museum
Great Museum. Really interesting and hidden out of the way but worth the trip! Although be aware tours are every half hour and have to go on one.

Very interesting. Would definitely recommend a visit here. The tour is an hour long with a guide...very interesting and informative. Only downside was that you can't take pictures. Little gem and handy that it opens until 8pm. Not the easiest place to find but worth the hunt!

Fascinating underground hospital. Follow your guide and wander through the slightly claustrophobic underground hospital. Although it was only used for a short period during wartime, it has a remarkable history. All rooms are intact and very well decorated to give you a clear view on how it was 50 years ago. The nuclear shelter and machine room are interesting too. We had an excellent English speaking guide.

Difficult to find but worth the search. Gives you an insight into the 19oos history of this city that was engulfed with wars.
Our tour guide was clear and gave us many interesting facts.
Tickets were a little on the expensive side compare to other attractions.

Brilliant way to spend an hour. Brilliant attraction. Adds to your knowledge of modern day budapest during the second world war and beyond. Could have spent a whole deal longer in there but this is a tour and a quick one at that, found myself wanting to call out to the guide to slow down. Reason for it being a tour is the way the attraction is structured. To make it more authentic they have left as much of it as it would have been during its operation which means it really comes to life, however it also means there is lots of things that can be touched, pressed etc so a guide is essential to ensure the continued authenticity.

Interesting, but could have been better!. We went to the Hospital in the rock, which was good, but not quite as good as I had hoped. It is a really fascinating place, having been a hospital in WW2 and in 1956 during the revolution. There is also a nuclear bunker, which until 2002 was a secret, only known by a select few. The tour takes an hour, with a guide included in the price. You are shown wards, operating theatres and other related hospital exhibits. There is then various German military displays, with a helicopter rebuilt in one if the old wards.It is an amazing place when you consider it is cut out of the rock, but I wasn't too keen on the wax works models recreating how it would have been. I'm sure it is the only way they can really show how cramped and unhygienic it would have been, but wax models don't do it for me (I never liked Madame Tussaud's either).I thought at 3600 huf (£11 ish) it was a bit expensive for one hour, but the equivalent in the UK would be more I suppose. The tours are on the hour and if you are in the Armed Services, medical, police or teacher then take your ID as you will get a decent discount.Not bad, but not great value for money!

Really interesting.. The tour is walking tour around the hospital which was based in the caves under Castle hill. A tour guide walks you around and explains in English how the hospital was used during WW2 and the seige. It takes about 75 mins. It is quite fast paced and you receive a lot of information in a short amount of time but it is really interesting and worth a visit. If you are disabled, a member of armed forces/police/hospital staff or a student you may be eligable for a discount so take proof with you.

A fascinating history lesson. The tour of the underground hospital and nuclear bunker was fascinating as well as offering an insight into Hungary during the second world war and the Cold War. The guide spoke excellent English. (Unfortunately the group was a little large with some ill-mannered individuals who chatted amongst themselves but the guide could be heard almost all of the time.)

Well worth the time!. I loved the Hospital in the Rock museum. It was absolutely a fascinating view of Hungarian history.The hours are great - it seemed to be opened later than other attractions (we went off season- so it was getting dark before 5)The tour guides English was perfect although she spoke extremely quickly.I agree with other reviews that it was somewhat difficult to find. I would definitely bring a coat for the tour as it was very chilly after being underground for a bit. My only other complaint is that the tour seemed to fall apart a little bit at the end. They were introducing some broader topics about special forces that didn't seem to fit in the presentation.I would recommend this tour to anyone visiting Budapest...very unique.

Amazing tour and information. The Hospital in the cave is not heavily advertised but is definitely one of the most informative and interesting tourist attraction Budapest has to offer.We had a great tour guide who spoke in english and hungarian.The tour lasted over an hour and had some freat stories and tales from both wars.Woukd thouroughly recommend doing this tour!

Good, but avoid if you're looking for academic explanations. The place in itself is fantastic. The sheer volume of work that must have gone into making these undergound galleries is breathtaking. You would be excused for missing it though, as the signage is not the best; the easiest is to take a straight line from the main entrance of St Matthias church, towards the city walls. Then take the stairs, at the end turn right, and fifty meters later, you're there, below the Castle's wall.The entrance is unassuming, but the staff welcome makes up for it. You're not allowed to take pictures or film during the visit, which starts with a nine minute movie, essentialy a patchwork of disparate facts and does not give one a clear timeline of how the hospital came about.Still, the guide then takes over and...the visit comes alive. Ease in English, good explanations of the museum which in itself is a valiant effort to show a side of Hungarian history which is lesser known to foreigners. The special forces exhibit is pointless and only reinforces the notion of patchwork, yet the guide found the right words in making a slight link with the work of the hospital.All in all, not bad, if not slightly expensive (3,600 ft per adult - 13 euro).
Interesting insight into Budapest/Hungary. Our tour guide was superb - spoke wonderful English, very articulate and passionate. Very interesting window into a certain period of history.

Hospital In The Rock. We included the visit to Hospital In The Rock with our visit to the Matthias church. The place is well sign posted, which we were pleased to see as we may not have found it otherwise. The tours run every hour and is cheaper entry for people under the age of 26 (take ID with you, if you are). We found it an interesting experience with instruments, original features and wax figure models to replicate what the hospital would have been like. I would say that it is still under construction in regards to the displays but I do think it is worth a visit.

Very interesting museum. We nearly didn't find it but when we did we were very glad. The museum particularly interested me when we were told of the magnitude of the people treat there and the size of the cave system. Definitely worth the trip.

An exciting history lesson. We didn't expect to be getting a history lesson during a weekend in Budapest, but this turned out to be an interesting one!Hospital in the Rock is, well, what the name suggests: a former hospital which was used for a short time during war.All the original equipment is still in place and were were taken from WW2 to 1956 to the Cold War by our guide who took the tours in English and Hungarian. The very authentic set up gave us an inkling of what it was like to work and be treated in a horrifyingly over-run hospital. Parts were also used for a bunker. Very hard to describe so it is best to take a visit. It takes about 90 minutes and worth a stop by if you have time.

Interesting history. Would recommend this place - such an interesting part of Hungary's and Europe's history. The tour is well priced and lasts for approx 90mins, great value. We thoroughly enjoyed our time learning about the history of Hospital in the Rock!

Found IT. Certainly a secret of the past and I finally found it LOL The tour guide was excellent and it was definitely worth a visit ( it does get quite cold in the cave system so I advise you take a jacket)
Worth a visit. Great tour of this fascinating place... Definitely worth a visit. Takes approximately one hour but a worthwhile place to see from an historical perspective.

Very interesting tour of the hospital. Think it was about £9 for each adult, discounts given for armed forces, Police and Medical staff. The chap that walked us around was very entertaining and gave a brilliant detailed talk on the history of the hospital and other historical events in Budapest. I was fascinated by the information and amused by the wax works. The tour last for about an hour.

Imformative. Great tour, a bit rushed and cramped in the rooms but very interesting with the wax models and the real medical tools. Tours start every hour on the hour and we didn't know this so we had to wait 50 minutes as we just missed one. Overall, quite an interesting place to go.

interesting history. On budda side with good views and interesting history, old and contemporary. Good example of destruction by Allied forces during WWII. Site is in a location that is good for strolling to St. Stephen's church next.

Very interesting. I had read about this place and totally forgotten again..I just happened to spot the sign as I was walking around the castle area. We payed for the tour and waited for the start I was surprised there were do many people on the tour. As part of the price you pay for the guide as well so you don't get lost in the cave system! Our guide spoke perfect English all her info was very interesting. I loved the tour we wer transported from WWII to 1956 to the Cold War and back again. It was great seeing all the old hospital equipment and kitchens and how the ran through such adversity personally it was interesting for me as I work in a hospital! The nuclear bunker aspect if the tour was interesting too it was fun to see how it was kept operational with all the tricks above ground. The only downside was that there were so many people by the time we got to look at something the guide was giving info on the next part. Other than that it was great.

A great eye opener!. We saw this museum on Tripadvisor and thought we would take a look as we were stayibg in the Castle District. The tour was extremely informative and interesting. The guide spoke perfect English and was very knowledgeable. A highly recommended tour if you have a spare couple of hours!

A must see in the Castle District. a 1 hour guided tour is fascinating and I was very surprised to see so many exhibits, hospital wards, operating theatre, many medical tools, together with the history of the facility and its many uses over the years.
Don't miss this !. Interesting. Good guide who spoke perfect English, was able to answer all questions asked and who was funny too. Nice and cool underground on a hot summer day.

A really cool place to visit in Budapest!. While I was in the Budapest Castle, I encountered this place. This hospital in the rock is basically a set of natural caves that were expanded by man. It was used during World War II and continuously (in secrecy) up until the 60s.Interestingly, this particular tourist attraction is quite different and unique than any other in the world. Not only was it a hospital hidden underneath Buda Castle but it was also a nuclear bunker and "top-secret" until the end of the Cold War.One story I found interesting is that the keepers of the facility needed tons of diesel fuel to keep the place running in case of a nuclear attack. What they did was install a pipe outside above this hospital that ran along a bed of flowers. For 40 years, a "flowering truck" would come around and water the flowers and provide diesel fuel into the pipes. It is my understanding that nobody found out about this.This place is certainly quite unique and worth a visit if you have the time. The tour is about 1 1/2 hours and you must follow a tour guide. It is quite comprehensive and leads you through a series of tunnels which displays several areas of the "hospital" and nuclear bunker. The tour guide explains how the work day and how it still operates with a unique air filtration system.All in all, I was extremely impressed with this attraction and would recommend it to anyone who is in the medical field or interested in a very cool piece of history. If you work as a medical doctor, paramedic, police officer or in the medical field ask for a discount which is pretty substantial.

so informative. definitely worth a visit, so much information about the recent history of budapest and the wax works give you a real feel for what it would have been like. tour was in hungarian and english though so felt slightly rushed. also you cannot take photos which was a shame

WOW FABULOUS PLACE. We stumbled across this place whilst in the castle area of Budapest. We saw the signs and thought we would check it out. It was a bit hard to find, it is opposite the front of the cathedral where the statue is. Go down some steps and turn left into the rock.Admission was cheap about £7 with various discounts availabe. The staff spoke great Enlgish and were very enthusiastic to help you. The tour lasted at least one and a half hours and the guide was great with excellent English. Very informative and an eye opening and unforgettable experience.A good souvenir shop priced very cheaply, and they sold snacks and driks while you waited for your tour.We are not great historians but we were totally wrapped up in the tour,and we will never forget this experience.This is run by a charity and well worth a visit for all kinds of people although young children may not appreciate it.

Tour in 2 languages not adviceable. The hospital is well worth a visit, but be ware: you can only visit with a guide. We were the last tour of the day and our group was too large for the narrow corridors and small rooms. There were 2 Hungarians (in a group of about 20) so the guide did the tour in both English and Hungarian. The stories she told were very interested, but because she had to repeat everything in Hungarian, the tour took a very long time and it was quiet boring to wait for her to tell the whole story again in another language.
Fabulous. Very informative and interesting, the tour provided lots of information and the displays really bring the hospital to life

Wow! Interesting for all and must see for medical staff.. Very educational and interesting. Amazing to walk through and imagine what it was like when in use. Wax mannequins and actual equipment as you traverse the cave leave a real impression. And they give military discount with an ID.

Worth seeing... once. There are many positives, starting with the staff, who are friendly, knowledgeable, and helpful. They were kind enough to admit our family at the family price even though our children are above the age of 18 -- but more on that in a minute. The sheer spectacle of the caves and equipment within is definitely memorable and worth seeing. It looks like they are setting up for additional video presentations within the cave, which would be very useful, as the introductory video shown is interesting.But... there's the cost. At 3600 Ft (~US$16) per adult (7200 Ft for a family of 4), that's just a lot of money when compared to many other attractions in Budapest. Our tour had roughly 40 people on it, which is a bit unwieldy as well. Perhaps the video monitors will enable this to be a bit more self-service.Glad to have seen it, but while we have repeated visits with guests to many other attractions, the cost and our "just OK" reaction to this one means we'll not repeat it ourselves, and it would be one of the first things I'd jettison from an overcrowded itinerary.

Excellent exhibition. Very well presented and interesting exhibition. a MUST, if you are visiting Budapest. It gives you a very good overview of the Hungarian history too. It was a bit pricey, but it was definitely worth it.

Fascinating. A tad overpriced and too full to take it all in this has so much potential and if you are a nurse or a doctor or an engineer or even a history buff then this place has it all. The links with nazi germany and communism were such an eye opener and sas in so many ways but its an important piece of history which as a tourist attraction could be improved upon

Must be Present on Every Itineary. Very well presented Museum which due to its authentic location is an absolute treat to those who maintain even a minor interest in European history. The tour guide spoke very good English and kept it interesting at all times while other staff at the establishment were enthusiastic and friendly. The exhibition itself is flawlessly presented and is akin to the "secret wartime tunnels" at Dover Castle. Overall, this is a truly great way to spend an hour or two while one is in the castle district.

MILITARY HOSPITAL HIDDEN UNDER THE CASTLE. Even a seasoned traveler has to be persuaded to visit this site. Only recently advertised in Hungary on billboards in the Tube, and hard to locate. Once you know you way, it is an unforgettable place showing the fate of Hungary. It is also interesting from a medical point of view.

Extremely nice /a place where is good to be italian. The tour is an amazing experience and the staff is very helpful. At the cash desk we were served by a kind girl who speaks brilliant italian, we were amazed... STRONGLY RECOMMENDED!

Well worth a visit. We visited the "Hospital In The Rock" during our recent trip to Budapest. It's quite easy to find, with the entrance just behind Castle Hill. You can only look around as part of a guided tour, but we only had to wait a couple of minutes before the next tour left (in English and Hungarian). Our guide was really excellent, and seemed genuinely interested and enthusiastic about the displays and information she was telling us, even although she must have given the same talk many times before. They have a lot of waxwork displays that are quite realistic, and there's a display at the end of the tour about modern day Hungarian soldiers. I thought this was well worth a visit if you're in Budapest. Discounts for healthcare workers, students and pensioners.

A fun 2 hours on Castle Hill. My wife's a nurse and so we couldn't miss this one. Built into the naturally and artificially created cave networks, the hospital/nuclear bunker stretches over a kilometer into the hill. The tour is informative and the exhibits recreate the atmosphere of the hospital during WWII. Buy a gasmask in the gift shop!
Must see. A fabulous experience, really well presented and hugely interesting. The english speaking guide was terrific. Highly recommended

excellent. This is a great tour. The tours start on the hour and last about 70 minutes. The tour guide speaks Hungarian and English and is very informative. There is a reduction for people under 26 and over 62 but remember to bring proof eg passport etc.

A Hidden Gem. This was a secret hospital operated by the Red Cross in Budapest during the war and afterwards. It is now a museum with most of the original equipment in place and lifelike wax models of doctors and patients.The english speaking guide was excellent and provided comprehensive information about all aspects of the hospital, including some relevant historical information about Budapest. Well worth a look!

A must see. This was an amazing insight into the tenacity and ingenuity of the Hungarians and the fight they put up against 20th century invaders. Hard to believe that it was a fully working medical facility buried in the rock where lives were saved (and not) while shells were falling all around and vicious fighting was taking place.
Incredible. This hospital, carved into the side of the rock under the Buda Castle is a must see for any health care worker. We are nurses, and were awed by what took place there.

Top secret!. This place was top secret until recently and has a very interesting history. Used as a hospital during the war and during the Cold War also. Lots of interesting stuff inside, brought alive by use of waxworks. My only criticism is that you don't get much time to linger inside to read the materials on the walls, however overall a must see. 3600huf adult entry, 1800 for concessions.

Very interesting and informative. I visited the attraction while on a weekend away with friends. It was very interesting a great way to spend a an hour or so. A tour guide takes you around the underground hospital and nuclear bunker complete with original medical equipment and some creepy wax works. Really thought provoking and informative giving a real insight into how things were in Budapest during world war 2. Tours leave on the hour- we weren't aware of this but luckily arrived just in time!

An interesting tour. I hadn't heard of this place until arriving in Budapest and I found it really interesting. It dates back to 1940, lasts for an hour and doesn't cost that much either, worth a visit to, however sadly no photo's

Memorable visit to the history of Budapest. We were so lucky that we met tourists that recommended this museum to us. It wasn't advertised that much in the travel books. The museum was opened quite recently in 2008 and it's absolutely a must visit to those who are interested in the history of Budapest in 1940's and 1950's. This place is full of tragic incidents and it's a remarkable example of humanitarian work during the most difficult times (the second world war and 1956 uprising).The guide introduced the place well during 45 minutes tour. You can visit the museum only by taking part to this guides tour. But I must say it's definitely worth it; the guide gives so much more insight to the visit.The authentic medical instruments, machines and furniture along with the wax figures give you a good picture of the real environment at that time.After the tour we spend a while in a different kind of museum shop where we found some very interesting items to buy (eg. medicine box and gas mask).Köszönöm & vislat,Sari

Well worth a visit. We found out about this while over in Budapest and paid it a visit. Its basically an hours tour of a secret underground hospital which was used during WW2, plus an atomic bunker for use in the event of a chemical attack. Theres also a decent gift shop at the end which sells some pretty unusual items!The tour guide was very friendly and there are tours which are carried out in English. Would definitely recommend if you are looking for something to do for an hour or so in the Castle District.

Fascinating and very cool. This was another slide of history in Hungary's varied past. Learned how it was used as a hospital for a short time in WWII and again for the 1956 uprising and the inhuman conditions they survived. How it was built using the natural cave system and how it was concealed is really interesting. One of my favorite places visited on our weekend trip.

What an amazing place. Everyone travelling to Budapest should visit this attraction as my husband and I found the hospital and the history of it amazing. The staff are very knowledgable the tour itself is fascinating. Our guide was a fluent English speaker and seemed to be very passionate about her work and very proud of what the hospital had achieved in its history. A must see attraction

Unique and very interesting. After many trips to Budapest finally we had a chance to go to the Hospital in the rock and it was a fantastic experience.The tour guide Orsi was fun, knowledgable, friendly and spoke great English. The tour of the rooms was really fascinating, the exhibitions were well presented. It was a really unique experience and I would definitely recomend it if you fancy doing something fun and learn about history at the same time.Some people mention on tripadvisor that the entrance fee is too expensive. I think it might be very expensive for Hungarians but at £10 a head. Seemed very good value to me given that the tour lasts for nearly 1.5 hours.

Secret attraction. A very interesting musuem based underneath the castle. The hospital is one of a few based in Budapest but the secret bunker is the only one that we were aware of. Lots of history and the guide was very fluent and looked interested in what she was telling us. The group was quite large so it was split into english and hungarian which seemed like a good idea. the tour takes about 80 minutes. Some parts were quite sad but it does give you a very good insight into what it was like to be taken into care during the war.

Overpriced. The good: It was very interesting to hear about the history of the hospital through world wars and invasions. The guide was personable, and spoke English fairly well. The info she shared was mostly interesting and relevant.The bad: The tour was entirely too long at an hour and a half, the group was so large that not everyone could fit in the rooms at once, which means that you missed out on a bunch of info if you were at the back of the group. While I understand that they wanted to illustrate for you what some of the spaces were used for, the mannequins and medical equipment displays were somewhat laughable after a few rooms. The air was stale and it was hard to breathe. The overall environment was oppressive.The ugly: Visitors gleefully tried out air raid sirens. In a tiny room. Full of people. It was ghastly loud and grossly uncomfortable.While I'm glad to have learned more about the history of the area, the tour was completely over-priced. Had I the chance to go again, I'd skip it.

Amazing. Wow! I hadn't heard of this until we arrived in Budapest. Is on Buda side & we reached by Hop on Off Bus. Difficult to find entrance. Guide on Bus didn't know what we were talking about neither did many other people we asked. Wonder why as definately set up for tourists. Eventually, after much walking, climbing steps was advised by book shop keeper of correct directions & we found that was just down road from where we got off bus. So my directions. Get offf bus, walk down hill, past entrance to Labyrinth which comes up first & is not well sign posted. Then a little further on, easy walk is entrance to Hospital In The Rock. Tours are on the hour & I recommend this to all. Amazing, incredible & more. They have a web site so google it & check it out. Discounts apply for Doctors, Nurses but you must be able to prove that you are one. They are still discovering more sections.

A visual history lesson. This is tricky to find as, certainly on my map, there was no indication it was down lots of steps. I suggest you have a look on their website (just google it and the site comes up) before you go as there is a good map on there. It is well worth the effort to find.I'm not really a fan of guided tours but we arrived just as an English tour was starting so we decided to join in. I'm really glad we did as our English speaking guide was excellent and very informative. For me it was learning more about the history of Budapest/Hungary that made it so interesting and I'm not sure we would have gained the same insight just walking round on our own. They certainly won't win any awards for the best wax work dummies but this didn't detract from the story that they told. Despite the fact that the hospital was only used briefly in WWII and the 1956 uprising, the history that you learn on the way round is a much broader picture of Hungary’s past. So if you are interested in the history of Budapest/Hungary I would say this is a must.

Not easy to find but worth it. This is a little out of the way but not too hard to find. After visiting Matthias church and near the memorial, we went down the long road from the centre and found it down an arch at the bottom of the road. It cost us about 6400 forints for both of us and we could pay on the credit card which was good. The tour was done at intervals through the day so ours was 12pm. The girl that did the tour was very good and knowledgeable, she could answer any questions we had. Going underground was a little eerie and it really brought home how much they had to go through over the years. It was excellent. The was also a little gift shop after which had a few fun items.... Definitely recommend.

Really interesting. This is an attraction that we couldn't find in any of the guide books. It was only when we saw a poster in the castle area that we knew it was there. This is a fascinating trip round the underground hospital used during both WWII but also the Hungarian revolution in 1956. It is very well presented with lots of wax figures to give you an idea of the conditions. The guide was brilliant and really informative.
