This is something well worth visiting and really needs to be promoted more by the Budapest tourist industry.

Very nice experience. After a short movie, a pretty young lady gave us a nice tour of this strange and intriguing structure. The hospital and nuclear bomb shelter look very well preserved with all the original fittings. A good destination to spend one and a half hours.They sell very original souvenirs, like first aid tins and gas masks.

Hospital in the Rock, Buda, Budapest, Hungary. Underneath the hill upon which the Castle in Buda stands, is a hill made of limestone. From early times, people used the caves to store perishables. In 1930, an engineer made a map of the caves and passages, and from that, an entire hospital was built within the rock. The hospital was in use throughout WW2 and then again during the Hungarian uprising in 1956 (or 7.) The tour took about an hour and a half and was given by an entertaining tour guide who spoke both Hungarian and English. It was a fascinating glimpse into the history of that era, and the machines developed for air distribution and water storage were amazing. Because of the use of wax figures depicting doctors, nurses and patients, the visitor could well imagine what the hospital was like when it was functioning.

Half price under 25!. Very interesting and a little creepy. Knowledgeable tour guide, and it was half price if you are under 25!Very poorly signposted, so look it up in the book before. Would recommend even to those with the faintest interest in WW2, Hungarian revolution or the Cold War.

Fascinating and fun. We saw ads for the Hospital in the Rock, and it was also mentioned in one of the guidebooks that we brought with us. The entrance was a bit difficult to find, but we're definitely glad that we found it. The tour, while a bit expensive, was interesting for all of us (including our three children). The tour lasts for quite a while, and takes you through what seems like an interminable series of tunnels with hospital rooms on either side. You see the original equipment, along with dummies dressed up as doctors, nurses, and patients in a variety of poses and positions -- some of which are quite graphic.The history of the hospital, how it was used, and the mechanisms that they had in place to deal with a potential nuclear attack were all of great interest, and were explained clearly by a guide who spoke fluent English.One amusing point is that you're not allowed to take pictures, because the facility is still owned and run by the Hungarian military.

Interesting museum - Entrance fee too expensive!. The hospital and guided tour are very interesting but the entrance fee is far too expensive by Hungarian standards! It costs around 10 pounds sterling ... Twice as much as all other museums in Budapest. Many people outside the museum decided not to go in due to the extremely expensive ticket.

Well worth a visit. This was a spur of the moment trip, we saw a sign for it whilst walking around the Buda side of the city and so glad we wentWe didnt really have that much of an idea of the history of budapest the museum gave a little insight into this it's fascinating to think of the "secret" hospital hidden away underground. The rooms are exhibited to give an idea as to how they were onced usedThe guide who took us round (Anni) was lovely and spoke brilliant English it takes about an hour to go round it is a fully guided tour, really enjoyed it a brilliant museum

History appreciation?. Went on the last tour of the day with only 3 other people in English so didn't have the crowd complaints of others. While most of the individual items in here aren't overly impressive, as you walk through this hospital, you get a good appreciation for the history and though processes behind it. I personally wasn't overwhelmed but admittedly don't appreciate history like I should. However, I recognize it's something unique that you won't really see other places, so if you have the time and are a history buff at all, I would recommend this, especially if you are under 26, a student, teacher, or in the medical field (admission discount).

Better than expected. We almost didn't go to this museum, but I'm very glad we did. It is a former hospital established inside naturally occurring caves, converted into a nuclear bunker during the Cold War, and now a historic attraction. There are waxworks which bring the museum to life, and because the history is relatively recent, many of the artefacts are real rather than replicas. Our tour guide gave just the right amount of information - and it is interesting to hear the history from a different perspective, rather than it being purely a political history. Highly recommended.

Excellent. We visited this sight on the spur of the moment at the end of a long day in the Castle area, but were very glad we took the tour, which takes just over an hour and is very interesting. There is a discount for seniors.

unique. Visited this museum today. A fascinating experince. Great guide in Annie who chenged languages seamlesslly. Musuem itself well set up, with 'real life!' tableau. This a unique museum and well woth a visit.

A new experience in the life!. This attraction is rather unique since you visit a second world war hospital in a cave system and at the top of that, how it was prepared for an atomic attack during the cold war. Tour is very informative and takes around 90 minutes. Ticket is rather expensive but somehow worthy to pay! We recommend this attraction to all.The only thing that we did not enjoy much was the extension of the museum. We think that it does not fit the purpose and history of the museum much.

You can really feel the history of the city & the country. We visited the hospital in the rock & really found the whole experience mind blowing! The engineering involved to first provide a basic 'bomb-proof' hospital in time of conflict & extreme turmoil, & later a nuclear blast proof shelter, is well.....utterly astounding! The vast tunnels challenge engineering principles to provide fresh air & provisions. I won't say too much as it may spoil the overall experience for those wishing to visit but if you see any pictures of the old Budapest during the 2nd World War, with all the bridges bombed in & all the houses & building left standing as 'shells', it really gives a sense of perspective of why extreme measures were taken to provide a safe haven to administer first aid & hospitalization of injured citizens & troops.If you like historic tourism I would like to think you'd appreciate this.If you work in the medical profession they do offer discount at the attraction with proof of occupation.

Very interesting history. One of our interests and pleasures in travelling is engaging with the history of the places we visit. With this in mind we very much enjoyed a visit to this intriguing attraction. There was a delay in the tour starting but the wait was well worth it as the 1 hour tour in Hungarian & English was fascinating. It covered its history with its first role as a first-aid station, then a hospital during WWII and finally a nuclear bunker under the communists which was actually maintained in readiness till 2000, beyond the fall of communism. It was equipped with the most modern medical equipment of the time. The operating theatres contain x-ray and anaesthetic machines; the only use they ever got was on the sets of the1990s film ‘Evita’ ! The bunker was shrouded in complete secrecy, the populace being told the area had closed. This meant that e.g. water and oil had to be channelled from a local flowerbed and the generator & other exhausts being directed through guttering on a house on Uri ut. Housekeepers lived in the bunker till 2000 changing the bed sheets every fortnight. The latter endeavour I think is a good illustration of the kind of fallacy that can be inherent in these monumental political systems.

Great Attraction. This is a very interesting tour. I have been to nuclear bunkers before but I find each of them interesting and they have their own stories. To have a hospital linked was something different. Highly recommended. Only con was that the tour had too many people but don't let that spoil your visit - stay close to the guide and you will hear and see everything.

Underwhelming. I was in the Hospital in the rock last week (July 2012) as I was told it was one of the most exciting attractions in the city, but I was left disappointed. The only thing that it's worth visiting is the area where it is located where you can enjoy an amazing view of Budapest.But for the attraction itself it is nothing more than a series of war hospital rooms with medical instruments displayed in cases.The tour is overcrowded and so quick it doesn't give you the time to enjoy everything is displayed. The guide wasn't engaging and given the size of the rooms and the corridors it wasn't always easy to hear her as she was starting explaining while we were in the previous room.There's also a nuclear bunker in the building, but again nothing impressive.I would recommend it only if it was free, 3000 Ft (the sum I paid) is definitely too much.

a bit of a disappointment. I had really high expactations for this visit, especially given all the great things i've heard about this place.let's start with the pros:1) location = near the top of the main hill in Buda and frankly not hard to find at all .2) atmosphere = if you are into modern history this is really a must, but i think everyone can enjoy this experience as it is definitely something out of the ordinary.cons:1) price: 3000 FT (around 10 euro) it's not cheap, especially considering avg prices in Budapest and the quality (very poor) of the tour you get for the money.2)tour: this was really, really disappointing --> the tour consisted of a group of around 30 people and a guide. It was a mixed bag of hungarians and europeans so the guide had to translate everything in hungarian and english, making the whole experience a bit tedious and too long. Moreover since you have to walk in narrow corridors it is really hard to fit 30 people and by the time the guide starts explaining something you might still be in the previous room and end up missing half of the informations. Also i have to say that the guide wasn't engaging at all, she sounded bored, like she didn't really want to be there at all.All in all i really liked the place, even though the horrible tour spoiled the experience considerably.

Interesting place. My teenage daughter and I visited in June 2012. We had previously visited Diefenbunker in Canada so were curious to see how it compared. Surprisingly the hospital has been used as late as the 1980's and I believe until recently the still had monthly drills for hospital staff to get there. There are no photographs allowed inside. There was a huge group of people waiting to tour (not incl a school group) and they didn't separate us so we had only 1 guide. She didn't have a microphone or a loud voice so at times it was impossible to hear. Especially because the rooms & hallways are small, the whole group couldn't fit in. She tried to separate us into Hungarian and English speakers, but it didn't work very well. Was still cool to see the rooms and displays.Would recommend a visit, especially if you could get in a smaller group.

So interesting. We were the only ones on an english tour at 4pm. So we had the guide to ourselves. Very interesting history and exhibits. Cool cave.The special forces exhibit seems a bit "forced" and out of sinc with the hospital.

Fascinating look at a humanitarian marvel. This structure has been used for multiple purposes over the years. The exhibit and tour reveal a lot about the Hungarian spirit, as well as insight into cold war attitudes. They have recently constructed a helicopter inside the facility as part of their special forces exhibit--amazing!

Colorful, interesting tour. This was an excellent tour that traces the history of the hospital. The complex is furnished with original equipment and wax human figures which adds realism to the displays. I took the English tour. The guide spoke well and was very knowledgable and friendly.

Wonderful tour!. Hospital in the rock is not what we expected. The cave system in Budapest is really unbelievable and the caves/caverns that were connected for the Hospital are doubly unbelievable. The tour is about an hour long - about $10 USD for all 3 of us to tour. We watched a short video and then had an English tour throughout the hospital and then the Nuclear Bunker that was built by the Soviets. It is very interesting and fascinating to see how they were preparing in case of a nuclear attack from us. Man - those poor people in Budapest - Occupied by the Nazis and "freed' by the Soviets. What they were able to accomplish in building this hospital is amazing. We all enjoyed the tour very much! Definitely a must-do in Budapest.

Excellent tour guide. This was quite hard to find and looked quite unassuming from the outside. The shop inside sold fake gas masks and the like and seemed a bit peculiar. However, as soon as our guide began our tour things picked up. He was fantastic and conducted the tour enthusiastically in English and Hungarian. The history of this place is mindblowing and brought to life by our great guide.

Chills, and not just from the low temperature. This was one of those “gut check” tours that brought back memories of being a cold war child in the 50s & 60s when Russia was the lumbering bear preparing to devour us with atomic bombs. This hospital treated victims during WWII and also served as air raid shelter.. During the 1956 up-rising, it was overfilled with wounded and dying Hungarians. Then it became a secret bomb shelter to survive nuclear winter. Today it has scores of injured wax figures bringing home its message and piles of rations to endure radiation. It was simply a haunting experience for me and I would caution about taking younger children into its corridors.

Surprisingly interesting. Thi swas super secret and it is a bit hard to find so expect to look for it for a while if you are not with a guide.we had a late afternoon tour. There were three of us and guide who did htetour in both English and Hungarian.She was well informed and gave a good tour.We also bought the joke Soviet Passport at the Museum shop. I did not mean to but I spent so much time looking at it if decided buying it was only decent thing to do.They provide coats which are useful because it is cold there even when its hot outside.It is quite a story

Humbling, A hospital with a difference. Rather than seeing the tunnels under Buda, go to the Hospital in the Rock. Informative guides in English x3 per day take 45 minutes to guide you trhough tunnels that were used as hospitals in 1944-45 and 1956. An Amazing and somewhat humbling experience, the pain and exerience these people went through to survive reminds me how lucky we are. Situated just below the main road running away from the river and St Mathias Church, you wont be disappointed.

Cool Hospital/Nuclear Bunker. 10km of naturally occurring caves were changed into a hospital in 1944 and renovated further to create a nuclear bunker. The exhibit is based on the 1956 failed Hungarian revolution where 700 patients overwhelmed this unique hospital. The 200 wax figures are a bit much, but they do help to set the stage. On a hot day (>30 degrees), the tunnels were cool at 14C (bring a sweater or borrow one of their old coats). Good tour guide. Tour leaves every hour on the hour and is in English. Discounts to teachers, people under 27 years of age, professors in the EU, etc. Bit of a pricy exhibit but very neat to see.

Very neat - makes a good rainy day visit. I visited this sight with my 3 daughters (5, 7, and 9). The tour was an hour long and we all enjoyed it.The displays were well done, and both myself and my daughters thought the tour was very well done.You watch a 5 -7 minute movie at the beginning, which sets the scene, and then begin your tour of the facility. It is amazing that they had a world class hospital located in some caves underneath the castle.I would recommend this tour if you are looking to escape the rain or want something a little off beat. EU citizens can see this museum very reasonably.

Just ok.... Went here with my husband in January 2012. The story of the place is interesting, but the guide kind of ruined it, she seemed like she was on autopilot during our tour. She was perfectly nice, but not engaging, not exciting, her responses seemed canned. The smell of the paint also gave me a headache. It is worth it if you are into Cold War history, but I wouldn't call it a must-see.

A Must Tour. While seeing the castle, we came across the Hospital in the Rock and took the 1 hour tour. This was so interesting. We learned so much about the history of the facility and of Budapest. Our tour guide did the tour in both Hungarian and English. His English was perfect and his excitement for the facility made this one of our most memorable tours.

Well worth a visit. Really interesting tour with a very knowledgable guide took just over an hour. Good insight into conditions in WW2 and a rather frightening realisation of the extent of cold war preparations - stacks of gas masks made as recently as 1984.Recommended.

Incredible Piece of Modern History. Adults and older children can appreciate this most. A true taste of history and resourcefulness. I will tell no more so you can find out for yourselves. Located in Old Buda opposite church (No 16 Bus not 16A) stand between church and statue take road in front at end of road takesteps down and turn right you will come to the entrance ((you need to be at the foot of wall opposite (not adjacent) side to river)). Take a look round at the other attractions on offer whilst in the Old Buda make a day of it.Open: Tuesday to Sunday 10:00-20:00. Last entry 19:00. Tour every hour on the hour.

It is worth a visit. Not really easy to find if you go by yourself, but once there, everithing is fine.A very knowledgeable tour guide took us down in he mountain, where the hospital rooms are recreated in very reallistic way.Impressive views of the rooms, make you think about the the life there had been.A must see in Budapest.

Unusual attraction to see. I saw this attraction in the Free Budapest visitors guide magazine and the name and picture looks interesting so we set off to see this.the next day, with my 7 years old son. It is hard to find and after walking for over half an hour up and down the Buda Hill and found it under the cave. It is an hourly tour that must be guided around the hospital and NO camera are allow to be taken inside. It is very cold and they offer the war time jacket for us to wear and I would say it is an amazing things to see and learn alot from this. A top secret Military hospital during the II world war and later to be use again in 1956 under the cave. It would really be spoilt if I tell you more but if you are in Budapest please go there and surely you will agree with me. My little boy loved it and want to go back again but for me I find it abit scary. They use Human figure to make it looks real. A must see.

Medicine in Hard Times. As a doctor nearing the end of her career I was delighted not only at the free entry fee(Bring some evidence of your trade for this!) but also to have a look at the type of conditions some colleagues had to work in in the not too distant past-the life-size realistic mock ups of the underground house of safety/healing were humbling as were the stories the guide told us about what went on under the ground-an excellent insight and well worth the trip-They did their best for the city as a whole under very trying circumstances.

A different type of history lesson. Although I am not a history buff this was a fascinating museum in the caves. It is an underground military hospital from the 1940's that later became a nuclear bunker.  The tour started with an informative 10 minute movie. We then we led into many of the different rooms (operating room, offices, recovery room, patient rooms, nuclear bunker, machine rooms, etc.). It was eye-opening being able to view the original equipment such as electrocardiograms, surgical instruments, bandages, geiger counters, masks etc. used during WWII. The wax figures were a bit creepy as well as the blood on many of the bandages but made it very memorable.

Worth a look, but the tour is a bit long.. It was very musky and a bit strange. The location was hard to find. We walked around the Palace and St. Matyas church a couple of times before we could find it.

Fun and Interesting. After getting caught in the tram door when trying to get off and nearly having a stroke climbing up the 'omen' steps to get to the Hospital, I was praying it was worth it and it really was. We decided to do the 7pm torch tour and were expecting to be scared but it wasn't scary at all and was a very interesting and fun tour. There were 7 in the tour group and we all were joking as we went along which made it a bit more relaxed.Our tour guide had great English, knew everything about the Hospital and had a sense of humour too. The wax works are quite creepy in the dark but they help to create the feeling of desperation and coldness that the staff must have had to put up with in their time there. Oh and sounding the air raid siren was a bit too much fun for me.This tour is a great one to experience and I recommend it for anyone looking for something unusual to do in their time in Budapest.

Interesting Historical Oddity. This one hour tour is worth the trip. It can be hard to find but signs are available. The wax figures are a bit odd, but do help you envision the hospital in action. The soviet artifacts are interesting and it is amazing how many items have been left untouched.

Took us an hour to find it!. I know that this was a secret bunker, but when you turn it into a tourist attraction it would be a good idea to let us mere mortals know where it is! sign posts were few and far between and even the directions in our guide book were sketchy. Basically, if you start at the castle and follow the road BENEATH the Walls in an clockwise direction, you should eventually stumble across it.The girl at the ticket office refused to interrupt her private phone call to serve us, so after 5 minutes we walked away and came back later. Not surprisingly, there were not many on our tour!Once we were in, things improved enormously. The guided tour was informative and interesting and although the entrance fee was a little steep, we enjoyed it.

Fascinating Tour. Kept secret for decades this hospital is absolutely fascinating. After a brief film in Hungarian with English subtitles a guide led us through the hospital speaking in both Hungarian and English. Very educational. Young children might find the "wounded" wax figures very scary, so know your child before deciding to go. Probably best for ages 12 and up as the horrors of war are addressed. Take the only staircase down from the wall and go to the right. (This is NOT a boat tour.)

Interesting insight. A very interesting and informative tour. As it was a mixed group of English and Hungarian, the tour was done in both languages. The tour guide was excellent and it was definitely worth a visit! Note - it does get quite cold in the cave system so I advise you take a jacket, also the tours depart every hour so check the times of the tours before you go!

Very interesting place. During centuries many corridors were digger into Pest side of the Hungarian capital. Here you can visit around 1 km out of the 5 km of the existing corridors which has been used as a hospital in 1940 and as a atomic shelter in the communist times. Very useful guided tours every hour both in Hungarian and English languages. Be careful to have a coat or sweater as there is no heating. Also a local lesson of history. Not for kids as wax statues of wounded people are spreader around the place.
